HEADLINE: The World;
O.K., the Ruble's Junk. Not to Worry. Russians Get By.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
IT'S already autumn in Russia, and as a pleasure drive along any country road outside the capital will reveal, the countryside is a riot of beautiful flowers. It is also a riot of Mickey Mouse beach towels, fresh and not-so-fresh fruit, various grades of motor oil, stuffed toys, bricks, pillows, used furniture, just-picked mushrooms and, in at least one instance, gravestones, available with your choice of inscription.
From the daisies to the markers, they are all for sale, by householders and their children who sit patiently by the roadside in straight-backed chairs dragged from their homes, eking out a few extra rubles in the after hours. 
 Such riots are one reason there have not yet been riots in the face of Russia's deepening economic gloom.
Life in Russia is hard -- harder still, because so many expected better this time. But this is the nation that coped with the Golden Horde, Ivan the Terrible, the siege of Leningrad and Communism, and outlived them all. Coping is in the national genetic code, a source of humor and pride and even song: "Anything but the war," goes a refrain from a popular Soviet-era tune.
In a nation where workers go months without pay, basic services are spotty and the currency is losing its worth, Russians' ability to cope may be Boris N. Yeltsin's salvation, too. Americans lose their cool when that lever on the ice-cube maker gets stuck and the bin in the freezer isn't replenished. Russians live in a freezer with not much more ill humor, and considerably more ingenuity.
 
Rats Get a Break
In Vladivostok, on the Sea of Japan, a prolonged drought this summer rendered water supplies non-potable and limited working faucets to but a few hours a day. Strikes and bankruptcies in the coal industry made electricity a sometime thing at best. The city is broke and many toilets don't work. By the way, the Mayor also suspended rat extermination last spring.
Some 635,000 people live in Vladivostok, most of whom could not take regular baths this summer because of the drought. For entertainment, they turned to hand-cranked generators to power radios and televisions. To eat, they cooked on Bunsen burners. To bathe, one woman slept with her faucet turned on, so that a sudden decision by the water works to begin pumping -- usually in the dead of night -- would produce a sudden blast of water and awaken her.
This is the sort of things Russians do in place of just complaining. The woman with the ever-ready bathtub has a friend, an American who edits The Vladivostok News, who wrote in The Moscow Times that he left his faucet on, too -- and flooded his apartment.
In Russia, coping literally starts at childbirth. The average Russian family consists of a couple and one child, and few have more than two. In Soviet times, the reason was simple: children were too expensive. Moreover, housing was so cramped -- with husband, wife and in-laws sometimes stuffed into two rooms that shared a kitchen with three or four other apartments -- that more children were not only too much to bear but too difficult to create amid paper-thin walls.
Under capitalism, the apartments are being combined to create middle-class residences. Unfortunately, all else remains the same for Russians beneath the middle class, except that their pay is less than it was and they frequently have been evicted by landlords seeking better-paying tenants. In such cases, they and their lower-class country cousins resort to time-honored Russian coping tactics, honed under years of Communism.
The principal ploy, called "blat," is a way of getting something -- a new carburetor or theater tickets or an introduction to an employer -- by leaning on someone to whom you have granted a favor. One might call it string-pulling, but it is really a social convention, a form of barter that fills a real need that the Soviet system would not satisfy, and that capitalism so far cannot.
Where blat does not suffice, Russians turn to relatives. Parents work past retirement to feed their jobless or employed-but-not-paid children. Rural families get packages from their city relatives; city folk get food from backyard gardens that have become absolutely essential to winter survival in the boondocks.
And not only the boondocks. It is seriously believed by some that Russians have been so compliant in the face of adversity this autumn because they are so busy tending their gardens and hoarding for winter; this leaves no opportunity for full-time protest. Some units of the ill-fed Russian Army were granted leave this summer to pick mushrooms, a national passion that for some has become a necessity as well.
 
Free Lunch
In some of Russia's most remote reaches, coal miners have been on strike for months, raising families without drawing pay. They survive in part on the vegetables and chickens in their yards, in part on the money their wives earn at jobs or by selling handmade goods, and in part on a Communist-era holdover -- the factory lunch, which they still get and take home.
There is charity: American-style philanthropy, through Rotary clubs and similar organizations, is taking root. Submarine-builders in the Far East who have not been paid for 16 months survive in part on free bread, doled out through passes from a local baker.
And there is subversion of the system, sometimes called theft. True to the old Communist notion that the people own the nation's means of production, workers have been known to quietly claim their share of coal, autos and other necessities of life.
Sometimes they cut out the middleman and make the products themselves. Although Russia's production of raw ethyl alcohol is dramatically increasing -- up 12 percent in the first half of 1998 from a year before -- the vodka production of Government-sanctioned companies is plummeting. Indeed, legitimate producers of vodka make up a mere 29 percent of the market, the Government said recently. The rest appears to be controlled by a thriving industry of bootleggers.
Which suggests that however difficult it is for average Russians to cope with the collapse of their economy, capitalism has some life left in it yet.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 13, 1998, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A chart on Sept. 6 comparing the economies of the former Soviet Union and Russia misstated the per capita gross domestic product. According to the World Bank, the G.D.P., in 1998 dollars, was $6,190 in 1988 and $4,269 in 1996.

HEADLINE: Generation Wallpaper;
A tribe of newly affluent global nomads has a magazine to tell them who they are.

BYLINE: By JULIA CHAPLIN 

 BODY:
IF a tabloid television talk show decided to visit downtown Manhattan, Kelly Galligan and Ed Briggs -- proudly seated on a recently bought 1950's square-cornered sofa in their apartment -- would make ideal guests for an episode called "We Traded the Grunge Life for an Eames Chair."
The couple admit, sheepishly, that they were once slackers who blasted Nirvana and made a pact to stay unemployed during the Gulf War so they could watch CNN. Today, Ms. Galligan is gainfully working at a new media production company in Silicon Alley and Mr. Briggs works in the art department of the television show "Law and Order." And like a large number of their fellow downtowners, they've chosen mid-century modernism -- the industrial, futuristic design style of the 1950's and 60's -- to mark their transition to affluence. 
 Wearing a Calvin Klein tank top, slim jeans and black rubber Adidas sandals, Ms. Galligan, 31, described how one day they put their funky votive candles and wrought-iron bed into storage and painted their natural-wood floors a lacquered black. They filled their Chelsea apartment with such modernica as a fiberglass 50's Tulip chair by Eero Saarinen, a shag rug, an amoeba-shaped coffee table and two space age chrome lamps they found on the Internet.
"We call it the Change," Mr. Briggs, 46, said. "A lot of our friends have gone through it, too. They show up for work one day wearing yellow-tinted prescription glasses, the next it's Gucci loafers and finally the long hair gets chopped off."
A wave of downtowners who once embodied the "Rent" life style, partial to thrift-store fashions and long hours at coffee houses, has been transformed into an upwardly mobile, entrepreneurial crowd. They can be described as the Wallpaper Generation, after the two-year-old design and life-style magazine that has given an ultra-hip spin to the retro-future look of the postwar decades.
It is a generation that breathes technology, fast travel and designer labels. Above all, it wants to be stylishly poised for the millennium -- in 70's-inspired Gucci clothes, conducting international business on a tiny Motorola cell phone, while lounging on a Florence Knoll sofa, circa 1954, like the one in Tom Ford's Paris apartment.
"I call them global nomads," said Tyler Brule, 29, the editor in chief of Wallpaper. "Whether they're a West Coast snowboarder, a copy writer for a hot advertising firm in Stockholm or a grunge kid working in an indie record shop that suddenly got a film deal, there's a degree of affluence all of a sudden. They're a young international group that grew up moving around without any possessions, and now they need advice on how to live a sophisticated life style."
Like Details magazine in the late 80's and Wired in the early 90's, Wallpaper, which is based in London, has momentarily captured the mind-set of Generation X. It has a small circulation -- 85,000, including 30,000 in the United States -- but its influence far outweighs the numbers. In many a downtown apartment, it is the only magazine on the (boomerang shaped) coffee table. It's a name to drop at rooftop parties and in other magazines' editorial meetings.
Almost from its first issue in September 1996, it attracted the covetous attentions of publishing giants like Conde Nast and Time Warner, and Time ultimately bought it, increasing its sporadic publication to eight times a year. The latest issue, at 334 pages the fattest ever, drips with ads for Prada clothes, Bulgari watches and Smirnoff Black vodka.
"When Wallpaper first came out, it was like, 'Why didn't I think of that before?' " said Sean MacPherson, who owns stylish Los Angeles night spots like Bar Marmont and El Carmen's and is also an avid collector of modernist furniture. "It's such an obvious idea. If you take the idea of a tribe, where I can fly to New York City and have more in common with someone I meet at a restaurant than my next door neighbor, there's definitely a Wallpaper tribe."
The magazine goes beyond traditional shelter publications by photographing fictitious living rooms inhabited by terminally hip models, wearing the latest fashions and dining on stylish but birdlike meals. For the magazine's newly arrived readers, every item, down to the wine in the glasses and the ambient-style music on the DVD player, is listed, with prices and store information.
But Mr. Brule maintains that the Wallpaper Generation is not just the latest wave of yuppies. "Our readers are not corporate -- they're entrepreneurs," he said. "They would never spend all day hung over behind a computer like in 'Bright Lights, Big City,' because most of them are self-employed or working at small companies." The prototypical Wallpaper interior seems to be the first-class lounge of an international airport.
The magazine did not create the revival of mid-century modernist design, which includes Scandinavian modern masters like Arne Jacobsen and Alvar Aalto and Americans like Eero Saarinen, Florence Knoll and Charles and Ray Eames. These visionaries used wartime technology -- materials like fiberglass and foam rubber, and techniques for bending plywood and molding plastics -- to make furniture that was streamlined and easy to mass produce.
There was a naive optimism about the future in the aluminum lamps and stacking plastic chairs, and the look was echoed in the Jetsonesque imagery of pop culture.
Its rediscovery by furniture dealers and collectors -- embraced with a hipster's wink -- has been gaining momentum for several years, and lately it has shown up everywhere from music videos to downtown clubs. Seeking evidence? In Hollywood, Tom Ford of Gucci, the actor Vincent Gallo, the actress Kelly Lynch and Eli Bonerz, who owns X-Large Clothing with Mike D of the Beastie Boys, have all bought glass-walled houses by mid-century modern architects like John Lautner and Richard Neutra. In the film "Men in Black," the headquarters building was based in part on Saarinen's gull-winged T.W.A. jetport at Kennedy airport, and the set was decorated with Jacobsen's sensuously futuristic Egg chairs from 1957.
In the Queen Latifah current video, "Bananas," there is a Peter Ghyczy 60's Egg Garden chair, and in Missy Elliot's video for "Beep Me 911," there is a fiberglass Gyro chair by Eero Aarnio. The pieces are an "easy read for a futuristic moment," said Paul Hunter, the director of Queen Latifah's video.
Wallpaper, if it didn't create the trend, had peerless timing. "It's sort of a chicken-before-the-egg question," said Matt Hanna, 31, an editor at VH1, sitting on an egg-shaped cushion at Cafeteria, a new modernist-inspired restaurant and lounge in Chelsea. "I've always been a Wallpaper kind of guy. I just didn't know it till the magazine came out."
Scarcely a year ago, cool SoHo lounges like Spy and Wax were furnished with Victorian velvet couches and dripping candles. Today, clubs of the moment, including Veruka, Lot 61, Bond Street and Moomba, have all embraced mid-century modernism. Lot 61's blocklike rubber seating was made in the 50's for a mental hospital. The new restaurant Bottino in the west Chelsea art district has 100 vintage Eames chairs. And Cafeteria, co-owned by the clothing designer Victor Alfaro, has 50's-inspired patio chairs. Even Stone Gossard, a guitarist for Pearl Jam, one of the last surviving grunge acts, is a co-owner of a new modernist-inspired club, ARO.space, in Seattle.
"We definitely wanted to move away from that found-in-a-thrift-shop look," said David Schefer, who designed Moomba and Veruka.
Allen Look, 32, an architect who was sipping an oversize cosmopolitan at Standard in the East Village, another hot spot that has adopted the style, explained it this way: "Try to imagine that downtown was a big college town. Now, it's grown up and wants to be more responsible and clean."
At Bond Street, which looks like a Zen version of a Gucci ad, with spare dark tables and muted olive banquettes, a stylist in a black Daryl K T-shirt who goes by the single name Sabrina rested her chopsticks next to the tiny sushi roll she was sharing with a friend. "It's very Wallpaper, isn't it?" she said.
Downtown, furniture and interior design have acquired a hipness once reserved for fashion designers and alternative music. At Form and Function, a new store at 95 Vandam Street that sells rare Eames pieces and vintage electronics like the first-ever Walkman-style headset from 1970, Fred Schneider of the B-52's rock band is an owner; shoppers include musicians like Moby and Mike D. In a recent Rolling Stone interview, Mike D said Wallpaper is one of the only magazines he subscribes to, and he mused about starting a line of home accessories.
The most unlikely crowd is gravitating to the Wallpaper look. On television monitors facing Lafayette Street from Supreme, a skateboard shop, educational films by the Eameses are shown. "The cool furniture just sticks out," said James Jebbia, the owner of Supreme, as well as of Stussy, a major skateboard and hip-hop clothing line.
"Many skate graphics and logos are influenced by the simplicity and humor of Eames or Nelson," Mr. Jebbia, a collector of modernist furniture, maintained. "When my friends come in from Japan or London, the first thing they want to do is check out the fresh modern furniture stores downtown."
Certainly many admiring the Eameses through the window of Supreme have no clue to the historical place of their work. And that seems true of many members of the Wallpaper Generation. Jim Walrod, 33, a co-owner of Form and Function, said the appeal of mid-century modernism to Generation X, even those without knowledge of its origins, is natural because of "an invisible reference point" young people acquired after years of exposure to the art direction of old movies and television shows, not to mention the teak and stainless-steel contents of their parents' living rooms.
"Kids with no design training will walk over to a Swan chair or an old radio and just start smiling," Mr. Walrod, a skateboarder, said. "They don't know why they're interested, but it's probably because they saw it on 'Logan's Run' or at their aunt's house."
Ronnie Morales, 28, who recently quit his job at Stussy to become a full-time modernist furniture dealer, echoed the point. "It's like the furniture belongs to our generation even though it was made 40 or 50 years ago," he said.
And Frankie Inglese, a downtown deejay who has stocked his space age bachelor pad with vintage electronics, traces his love of space age design to mid-60's album covers. "It's nearly the year 2000," he said. "We have great technology, like cell phones, the Internet and digital cameras. But we're still sitting on eyesores by Ikea. This is not what the future was supposed to look like."
In the last year and a half, older downtown stores specializing in industrial modernist design like Moss and Troy have been joined by a slew of newcomers, including Ace (295 Elizabeth Street), Re-Generation (38 Renwick Street), Antik (104 Franklin Street), Twenty (20 Prince Street), and R 20th Century Design, which is at 326 Wythe Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
Evan Snyderman, 28, and Zesty Meyers, 29, opened R 20th Century Design in a lonely industrial neighborhood eight months ago and were featured in Wallpaper almost immediately. On a recent Saturday afternoon, the store was packed with tattooed artists and other young people marveling at an aqua George Nelson daybed priced at $3,750. Mr. Snyderman said he couldn't get over how well the store is doing, considering the typical resident of the area is supposed to be a starving artist.
"At first there was some neighborhood resentment because our store was sort of slick looking and expensive," Mr. Snyderman, who set up a layaway plan, said. "But now people just want to know what the stuff is."
As modernist design becomes trendier, some of its longtime champions are skeptical of the newly converted. "It's like New Balance sneakers," said Serge Becker, a co-owner of Bowery Bar, who plans to open a new nightclub at the Joseph Papp Public Theater this fall, which he has designed in 1930's Italian-modern style. (Think cork walls and Perelli rubber floors.) "Soon, people will get sick of it and the people that liked it all along will be left," he predicted.
The London press has recently proclaimed the end of the buzz about Wallpaper. The magazine is an easy target for critics of its achingly hip fashion models either posing amid lavishly priced interiors or racing to catch the Concorde. "It's as if you can't be cool unless you can afford to fly first class on your own private jet with the perfect modernist interior," said Mike Mills, a graphic designer for hipster bands like the Beastie Boys, Cibo Mato and Air, who has lectured on the Eameses to college students. "A better magazine would have furniture that cost under $20 and where jet-set meant Tower Air. It's very un-Eames-like."
Bill Doige, a set designer who works for Calvin Klein, said he wouldn't dream of using modernist furniture again because "everyone and their grandmother is using it."
"When you see a Citibank commercial that has all modernist furniture, then you know it's time to try something else," he said. "Next season, I'm going to try the Dada look: lots of shapes but no recognizable props."
Still, at Form and Function, Mr. Walrod predicted that the look and the life style have plenty of mileage left in them.
Recalling a television commercial for L'Oreal Preference with Heather Locklear tossing her blond mane while seated in a luscious purple 50's Egg chair, he said, "If I was a kid and saw that, I'd be so happy I'd start investigating modernism immediately."

An article in some editions on Sunday about a magazine called Wallpaper and the people who buy the modernist furniture it promotes misstated the address of Ace Furniture in Manhattan. It is 269 Elizabeth Street, not 295.

It opened in 1993, not in the last year and a half.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 4; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: The Wasteland

BYLINE: By Thurston Clarke; Thurston Clarke is the author of "Equator" and "California Fault." He is currently writing "Searching for Crusoe," a book about islands.

 BODY:

AN EMPIRE WILDERNESS
 Travels Into America's Future.
 By Robert D. Kaplan.
 393 pp. New York:
 Random House. $27.50. 
 Robert D. Kaplan has traveled to Omaha and seen the future. Here it is: "Standardized corporate fortresses, privately guarded housing developments, Disneyfied tourist bubbles"; "isolated suburban pods and enclaves of races and classes unrelated to each other"; an automobile-oriented city where "you will be even less comfortable outside of your car in the future than you are now"; a business elite with its own foreign policy "dominated by the concerns of trade and Realpolitik rather than by human rights and spreading democracy"; a politically apathetic populace more interested in health clubs and the Internet than in community life; a society where the poor fend for themselves; and a "civilization influenced by the impersonal, bottom-line values of the corporations."
And Omaha, believe it or not, is where Kaplan discerns the outlines of a future he describes as "not so bleak," one that "might, in its own way, be as wondrous as our past." He also glimpses this wondrous future in California's Orange County, a "more refined and sophisticated" Omaha-style suburban pod city.
Thinking I had somehow missed the "wondrous future," I reread these chapters of "An Empire Wilderness." I found only the cold comfort that Omaha's and Orange County's high-security suburban laagers will boast a pleasing multicultural population because corporations find it more cost efficient to recruit the talented of the third world than to train low-skilled Americans, and the still colder comfort that because evolving city-states like Omaha are plugged into the world, their elites are increasingly skilled at the efficient exploitation of low-wage third world laborers. This has facilitated a relationship Kaplan describes as "oligarchal, like that between the citizens of ancient Athens or Rome and their slaves."
After following Kaplan through the rest of his travels in the West, where, like generations of writers before, he believes our future is most easily perceived, I finally got the point about Omaha and Orange County. After learning how global materialism and the communications revolution promise the slow and subtle withering away of the traditional nation-state, the death of the traditional middle class, a "wilderness" of region-states and suburban oases linked to a global marketplace and a new class of "rooted cosmopolitans" loyal only to their own region but intellectually and professionally inhabiting a larger world, I finally understood that Orange County and Omaha were simply the best of these fortified posturban oases.
Both are less bleak than, for example, St. Louis, which Kaplan describes as a corporate fortress circled by high-security suburbs of lonely and overworked people, and desperate slums of blacks who are irrelevant to the American economy. And better than Tucson, Ariz., with its miles of strip malls, subdivisions of cheaply framed Sheetrock houses and mobile home parks crammed with drifters and broken families who are forever drunk, dirty and in debt, with no connection to neighbors or relatives. Wages in Tucson are stagnant, urban planning nonexistent, political and community involvement negligible; local business leaders, who might feel some responsibility for the mess, are being swept away by national chain stores. The city boils with class resentment and violence, offers low-paying service jobs and is presided over by a millionaire elite that acquired its wealth by sitting on real estate. Just when you think the news could not get worse, Kaplan announces that by the middle of the next century 98 percent of Arizona's population will live in greater Phoenix or Tucson.
Kaplan believes the West's rural remnants will become irrelevant to its culture and economy. In Guymon, Okla., he finds a devastated landscape of cheap aluminum siding, increasing gang activity and desperate Mexican migrants slaughtering hogs in factory farms. Garden City, Kan., is the "sharp-contoured loneliness of one-story buildings without an architectural past, set against the moaning wind." Bozeman, Mont., has suburban sprawl, Disneyesque ranches and new class divisions threatening its natural beauty and social cohesion. He travels into this shattered countryside on a Greyhound bus he likens to a prison van transporting the underclass from one impoverished urban wreck to another, reporting that even in Eastern Europe and Africa he "had never traveled among a more rootless or unstable crowd whose members took such poor care of themselves."
Kaplan's journeys through Yugoslavia were the basis for his acclaimed "Balkan Ghosts," and his experiences in Africa resulted in "The Ends of the Earth," which forecast a grim future for impoverished nations. In both cases, his predictions have proved remarkably accurate, and I fear "An Empire Wilderness" may be similarly prescient, as long as you ignore the spurious optimism I suspect is a defense against the kind of unjustified criticism he received for his bleak vision of Africa.
As in his earlier books, Kaplan braids together his own observations with his meetings with leading businessmen, academics, journalists, politicians, social workers and government functionaries, and proves himself a journalist of impressive skill -- tireless, curious and smart. His theories are brave and provocative, and I cannot imagine anyone will concoct a more convincing scenario for the American future. But he can be a frustrating companion. His narrative lacks the humor and serendipity found in the best travel literature; it sometimes gives the impression of being an undigested, even unmasticated diary. When he concludes a major section with "So now I will pick up my journey from Omaha," you wonder: Would Kaplan's editors at The Atlantic Monthly, where he is a contributing editor, allow him to end an article this way?
After finishing "An Empire Wilderness," I felt like Scrooge asking the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come, "Why show me this, if I am past all hope?" Unlike Scrooge, we are not going to discover that this apparition was a nightmare, and unlike Dickens, Kaplan offers no remedies. At the end, he visits Vancouver, British Columbia, and Portland, Ore., lavishing praise on their environmental consciousness, dynamic urbanity, human scale and determination to control the automobile and suburban sprawl. He says Vancouver is a "rebuke" to the places he visited in the United States, including Orange County of the wondrous future, proof that high-density cities are desirable because they mean convenient, interesting places in which to live. But before we can grab this little life preserver he yanks it back by insisting that the Portland and Orange County models will compete for ascendancy and that the Orange County model will win, although he never explains why.
Kaplan's concluding chapter brings another small dose of curious optimism with the suggestion that places like Tucson, surely the most depressing city in a narrative with many contenders for that title, are somehow an "image of our dynamism." But if Tucson is all our dynamism can produce, I say let's spend more time in the hammock.
Like Churchill proclaiming that Britain's overseas colonies, dominions and allies would continue to fight if England fell to the Nazis, Kaplan imagines it will comfort us to know that as the culture of the European Enlightenment dissolves in the United States, and as wealthy Americans choose protected and isolated communities, the American ideal of a middle-class society will spread throughout Asia, Latin America and Eastern Europe. I take more comfort in recalling that famous photograph of the high-rise housing project in St. Louis being dynamited into rubble because its design encouraged isolation, crime and sociopathic behavior. It is easy to imagine the sprawling suburbs, big box stores and gated communities as permanent features, particularly because they are so enormous, pervasive and new. But if enough people become repelled at how they have disfigured our landscape and society, and insist on communities resembling Portland rather than Tucson, perhaps they too will some day be blown to smithereens.
"An Empire Wilderness" is not written as a call to arms, but its vision is so frightening and powerful it could have that effect. Maybe Kaplan's alarming predictions have brought closer the day when we finally tear down the gates, put the automobile in its place and walk out our front doors to rediscover our families and neighbors, revive our communities and save ourselves from his bleak future.

HEADLINE: Blue-Collar Greenwich

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Although your Aug. 31 news article on Greenwich, Conn., provides an accurate description of part of the city, it leaves readers believing that everyone here owns a Porsche, or at least a 1998 Ford. The reality is different. 
 Among the 58,000 residents of Greenwich are hundreds of people whose hourly wages provide little more than a subsistence living. Tradesman, small-business owners, teachers and health care workers may live in expensive homes, but their children hold jobs to buy the clothes they want, and expensive private college tuitions are not possible for them without scholarships.
There is greater diversity in Greenwich than in many American towns. Within the city's 50 square miles are families whose wealth comes from prudent management of their grandparents' success, as well as families from around the world who are the first in their generation to pursue the American dream. This variety of socioeconomic levels makes Greenwich a healthy town.
 
WILSON S. ALLING
Greeenwich, Conn., Sept. 2, 1998

HEADLINE: Looking to Doonesbury as an Economic Indicator

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
Has Doonesbury, the political comic strip by Garry Trudeau, become the latest sell signal?
The most recent story line, which began on Aug. 24, features Mike Doonesbury and his fledgling Internet company, Mikim Inc. Like most of its peers, it is losing money -- lots of it. But, as Mike explains to his daughter, Internet companies are supposed to lose money. That's why they go public. 
 As easy as Internet companies are to lampoon, the sight of them in the comics may be the clearest indication yet that their stocks have reached a top. Since peaking in July, when valuations were the most elevated, these stocks have dropped sharply. Yahoo is down 27 percent, for example, and Amazon.com has fallen 41 percent.
"When the mainstream press and humorists start to pick up on something, it does send something of a message," said Edward J. Mathias, managing director at the Carlyle Group in Washington, who has spent more than 15 years collecting various clippings, including editorial cartoons, on business and the stock market in the popular press.
Cartoonists and others "are very topical about what they do," Mr. Mathias said. While they may not be a leading indicator, they affirm that a particular topic has penetrated the public consciousness. And whenever something becomes that well known, an investor should assume that its popularity is reflected in the price of any assets, he said.
What makes many Internet companies easy targets, for Mr. Trudeau's satire or for worried investors wondering what to unload from their portfolios, is their lack of profits. While investors typically value public companies by some multiple of what they earn, many of Internet companies are measured by anything but.
"I'm interested in future profits," said Paul T. Cook, who manages the Munder Netnet Fund. He argues that Internet companies need to spend today to build market share tomorrow.
"A lot of these companies could be profitable today if they were satisfied with their current station," he said.
But some investors' willingness to ignore profits creates an atmosphere ripe for ridicule. As a result, Mike Doonesbury is proud of his company's burn rate, the amount of money he spends over whatever he takes in as revenues. His daughter scolds him for being "braggy" when she overhears him tell someone the company could lose $2 million this year -- easy. The same atmosphere was the subject of Michael Wolff's "Burn Rate," a tongue-in-cheek look at Mr. Wolff's own Internet company.
Many investors seem to have dispensed with even the pretense of profitability. How else do you explain the ability of Broadcast.com Inc., which went public in July, to report increasing quarterly losses and still see its stock jump by nearly 7 percent the same day?
This overreliance on growth in revenue and market share at the expense of profitability, a cornerstone of any successful business, makes other investors scornful.
"I think it's the silliest thing I've ever heard," Susan M. Byrne, the president of Westwood Management, said. While she is enthusiastic about the vast potential of the Internet, calling it "the rails of the new millennium," she remains convinced that a company must have a business plan if it is to profit from the Internet's popularity. Market share does no good if the business model does not make clear how a company can make money.
The problem, said Michael Murphy, a money manager and technology stock analyst who recommends selling short some of the Internet stocks, is "a good chunk of the Internet companies will never be profitable."
Alas, Mike Doonesbury may now be too late. With the overall market, and especially small stocks, down, the opportunity to win a favorable reception from investors is shrinking. "In markets like this, people get religion," said John E. Fitzgibbon Jr., the editor of The IPO Reporter, a weekly newsletter in New York.
By the end of last week, newspaper readers knew that Doonesbury's Mikim was faced with the abrupt withdrawal of its principal financial backer. But Mike himself still wanted to press ahead with a stock sale, in the hope that gullible investors would believe the appearance of success is the real thing.
"A luxury car might help," Mike ventured.

HEADLINE: In-House Competition From Web News Team

BYLINE: By MATT RICHTEL 

 BODY:
The next time Michael Jackson rumors start to swirl, word spreads of a Hollywood murder-suicide or Matt Damon changes his hair style, E! Entertainment will probably dispatch not one, but two teams of Hollywood news hounds.
One will come from the cable channel, the other from its sister Web site, E! Online, and company executives will not mind seeing the hounds race to get the exclusive. "They're trying to scoop each other all the time," said Lee Masters, president and chief executive of E! Entertainment. "It keeps everybody on their toes." 
 Mr. Masters said he did not intend the E! site (www.eonline.com) to compete with the network so much as to complement it, but he does intend for the on-line entity to have its own identity. Unlike some Internet sites that are linked to television programs or even entire networks, Mr. Masters wants E! Online to be something more.
Whereas E! Entertainment has sought to build its television programming on a shoestring budget, the company has spent more freely to build up the Web site, Mr. Masters said, though he declined to discuss specific figures. Companies that want to stake a claim on the Internet need to do so aggressively, and immediately, he said, and that costs money.
"You have to have mouth-watering content and you have to have an incredibly seductive environment," Mr. Masters said. "You have to stake out that territory now."
He is less effusive about E! Online's revenue, which he declined to disclose though he concedes that like most Internet companies, it is losing money.
E! went on the Web in August 1996 in a partnership with Cnet, a new-media company based in San Francisco. The partnership ended a year later, when E! paid a reported $10 million for Cnet's 50 percent of the venture. At the time, Cnet said it wanted to focus on its core businesses and E! decided it wanted to own its own brand on the Internet.
Today, 55 full-time E! employees work on the site, 40 of whom are producing the content -- a daily helping of Hollywood, including updated news, gossip, Webcasts of movie premieres, and features like "Stalkers," a three-part article on fans who stalk celebrities.
To be sure, not all the Hollywood scoops are exactly the stuff of the Lehrer Newshour. "We identified that Matt Damon was hot back in 1996," one staffer said, touting the site's accomplishments. "We broke the fact that Blues Traveler was leaving the Horde Festival."
The site appears to be getting heavy traffic, with roughly two million visitors a month, according to @plan, a Gallup Organization unit that tracks on-line traffic.
And a June 1998 survey by Relevant Knowledge Inc. ranked E! Online as the 23d most heavily trafficked news and entertainment site over all, placing it above ABC.com and MTV.com, and ahead of its direct competitors, which include Entertainment Weekly (www.pathfinder.com/ew), the News Corporation's TVgen.com site, and Entertainment Asylum (www.asylum.com).
E! Online is also one of the anchor entertainment tenants on America Online and offers entertainment programming for broadband Internet services that provide access and content over television cable lines, including At Home Network.
Mark Mooradian, a group director at the Internet research firm Jupiter Communications, said one of E! Online's strengths was its ability to complement the E! Entertainment cable channel.
E! Entertainment cites figures from @plan indicating that nearly two-thirds of the visitors to its Web site also watch its TV programs. That gives Mr. Masters confidence in his long-term plan to make E! a player in the industry's oft-predicted convergence of television and cyberspace. "We want to get our grubby little paws on every aspect of this business that we can," he said.

HEADLINE: Technology Start-Ups Suffer Market Jitters

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
After a month of hot and heavy flirting about a prospective merger, last Monday was going to be the day that CKS Group and USWeb finally got serious and set the price. Then the stock market started falling, dragging with it the already depressed shares of both companies.
"Things just froze," Mark Kvamme, the chief executive of CKS, an interactive advertising agency, said in describing how the $340 million deal with USWeb, an Internet programming and services company, came to a standstill. "We just stayed in our offices watching the market on our computers. We just hit return, return, return" to get up-to-the-second quotes on how far each company's stock had fallen. 
 At the end of the day, their screens showed that CKS stock was down 18 percent while USWeb had dropped 16 percent. That was close enough that the two companies were able to proceed with their deal, which was announced on Wednesday.
And that was the way things were playing out in the offices of start-ups throughout the high-flying technology industry, which had been watching a slide in market value for weeks before Monday's plunge. After that day of frozen panic, by the end of the week, much of the business was cautiously proceeding as before.
Sure the Nasdaq market, where most technology company stocks are traded, closed Friday down 22 percent from its high on July 20, but it is still essentially flat for the year.
Yet, for many technology executives, the jumpy movement of the market within a narrow range last week created the sort of nervous anticipation felt on a plateau in one of those darkness-enclosed roller coasters: you know the next move will be sudden and fast; you just do not know whether it will be up or down.
"There is no real effect on the mood here yet," said Garrett Gruener, a venture capitalist with Alta Partners in San Francisco. "But if the Nasdaq were to drop another 20 percent, that wouldn't be the case."
If the market fell further and looked as if it was not going to bounce back, the voluminous investments by venture capitalists and public stock investors in small technology companies would slow, bankers and investors say. And the existing companies would have to scramble for cash.
But for now, there is still a lot of money poised to be invested in promising new start-up companies involved in information technology and the Internet. Less certain, however, is how many of the two- and three-year-old companies now lined up to sell stock to the public will be able to do so in a suddenly skittish market.
"There is not pain or panic here in the Valley," said David Cowan, a venture capitalist with Bessemer Venture Partners in Palo Alto, Calif. "But there is concern. A stalled stock market will create billionaires at a lower frequency."
Indeed, more than a few longtime technology financiers see the fall in technology stocks from outer orbit to mid-stratosphere as a sign of some rationality in the universe.
"Personally, I lost a lot of money, but I think it's very healthy," said Richard M. Burnes Jr., a partner in Charles River Ventures, an old-line venture capital firm in Waltham, Mass. "Stock prices had taken on a life of their own, and that is very dangerous for everybody."
Mr. Burnes said he was worried about the billions of dollars that have poured into venture capital funds. Over the last few years, the soaring market for technology stocks has allowed many of these funds to post returns of 50 to 100 percent a year as they take the young companies in their portfolios public or sell them at equally high prices to bigger technology companies. Now, anyone who can tap out a business plan in Powerpoint has come to expect ready cash and lucrative terms.
"Entrepreneurs come into our office who don't have $1 million in revenue and they expect to value their companies at 30, 40, 50 million dollars," said Fred Wilson of Flatiron Partners, a New York venture capital fund. "That's absurd. You can't make money investing in companies like that."
Flatiron, he said, had stopped making investments and had encouraged the companies it owns to raise cash as a cushion in case of a downturn.
Other funds say they are still investing, only more cautiously. "I'm looking at things differently than I did two weeks ago," said Geoffrey Y. Yang, of Institutional Venture Partners in Menlo Park, Calif. "We will still invest, but the prices we pay could come down 20 to 25 percent."
And the mad rush may have slowed, he added.
"Deals that would have been done in a week are now taking six to eight week to get done," Mr. Yang said.
Yet other observers say all this talk of discipline will be quickly set aside as the venture capitalists realize they need to put to work the billions of dollars they have raised for their new funds.
"There is so much capital out there that the supply will drive up the prices of deals," Mr. Cowan said. "That means the return of the funds will ultimately go down."
Once the venture capitalists write their first checks to the budding entrepreneurs, their minds almost immediately turn to the "exit strategy." That is, how they can sell the company at a tenfold multiple, either to the public or to another company. In tougher times those multiples may not be possible.
For now, deals of all sorts have slowed until the state of the market becomes clearer.
"A record number of public offerings have been pulled in the last month or two," said Alex Lynch, the co-head of the public offerings practice at Brobeck Phleger & Harrison, a law firm that specializes in high-technology firms.
One of the best indicators of the strength of the market will be the fate of the public offerings planned for the next few months. These include E-Bay, a rapidly growing Web site that lets people run their own auctions, and the Globe, a New York-based chat service aimed at Generation-X users.
Even if these companies are not going to be able to proceed with their public offerings, they will still be able to raise money from venture capitalists and other private investors.
Many companies that had already gone public issued more stock over the summer, taking advantage of the surging market to build a cash reserve to ride out periods of tight money.
"We completed a secondary offering two months ago, adding $22 million to the $47 million we already had in the bank," said Jason Olim, the chief executive of CD Now, an on-line music store. "Our burn rate is probably $10 million a quarter," he said, referring to the deficit spending common at start-up companies. "So we have a stockpile of cash that will last us longer than a year."
Moreover, as stock prices fall, some midsized technology companies may find themselves in a position to buy other companies whose stocks have been hit even harder than their own.
Some entrepreneurs say that a perhaps less visible consequence of the careening market for technology stocks is the toll it takes on employees with the perhaps enviable problem of coping with the sudden appearance and disappearance of paper wealth.
"You get concerned about he morale of people in the company if everyone is looking at the stock price all day," said Christos M. Cotsakos, the chairman of the E-Trade Group, an on-line stock brokerage firm. "When your stock price rockets up like a meteor, it creates false expectations. Then when the price gets hammered, it drives people crazy."
Yet in recent years, every dip in the market has been followed shortly by another surge. And many longtime executives worry that too many newcomers to technology companies have never seen a truly down market.
"The thing that's scary to me is a lot of kids are coming here who think that their options are automatically going to go up by 40 percent a year," Mr. Kvamme of CKS said. "It's terrible when people start to believe they are invincible."
Yet to many young entrepreneurs, it seems perfectly clear that the Internet, is, in fact, changing everything, and that they can ride this wave to prosperity.
"I see only progress, only growth," said Mr. Olim, the 29-year-old founder of CD Now. "Value is being created at such a dramatic pace that it overwhelms any macro-economic phenomenon."
Mr. Kvamme, a 34-year-old alumnus of Apple Computer who has seen a few of Silicon Valley's earlier surges and dips, says that things are a lot more vulnerable now than they might seem.
"We're in a feel-good business," he said last week. "Any time there is uncertainty, it erodes confidence. Then decisions take longer; people stop spending. And once they stop spending, things only get worse."

SECTION: Section B; Page 2; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1138 words

HEADLINE: Metropolitan Diary

BYLINE: By Enid Nemy with Ron Alexander 

 BODY:

DEAR DIARY:
"You're having a Senior Moment," my friend told me when I said I sometimes look for something in another room and then forget what I came for.
When my cousin came for a visit and said she had forgotten her house keys, I told her she was having a Senior Moment. She laughed and when the occasion arose, and it did, kept repeating it throughout the day. 
 The second day we went shopping -- she for gifts, I just browsing. Suddenly I heard her say "Who am I buying this gift for? I guess I'm having . . . What am I having?" We cracked up. DIDA PORECKI
Bill and Rachel Schultz are still wondering if a seafood bar in Montauk on Long Island ever succeeded in filling the job with this description: "Wanted: piano player who knows how to open clams."
Emily Gioseffi and two friends were waiting in line in front of the Public Theater for tickets to "Cymbeline." The woman ahead of them was growing increasingly frustrated, glancing toward the front of the line every few minutes. Turning to the group, she asked if the line always took so long. One of the women informed her that tickets to the event were not distributed until 1 o'clock.
"Is everything in New York so inefficient?" the woman retorted, with an accent that indicated she was a foreigner. She then whipped out her Metrocard and added: "Besides, I shouldn't have to wait, I've already got my ticket."
The three realized that the woman had been waiting for an uptown bus to Madison Avenue and had mistakenly thought the theatergoers' line had something to do with the bus.
Attempting to help, Ms. Gioseffi went to check the bus schedule posted nearby, but the tourist frantically instructed her to get away from the bus stop, explaining "You're not allowed to stand there."
The conscientious visitor then read the sign aloud, slowly and deliberately, "No standing any time."
P.S. The three directed the woman to the subway.
Josephine Dalldorf overheard this exchange at an elevator in the World Trade Center:
First Woman: "What are you doing this weekend?"
Second Woman: "We're taking David out to North Shore Animal League to get a puppy."
First Woman: "Why are you going all the way out there? You have a wonderful shelter near you in Mount Vernon."
Second Woman: "I know, but they have a better class of animals at North Shore."
Another overheard exchange, this one by Florence K. Peate of two elegant elderly women chatting as they waited for an elevator at Bergdorf Goodman:
First Woman: "When I die, I've told everyone I want to be buried in a shroud with a closed coffin."
Second Woman, sounding puzzled: "Why?"
First Woman: "Because if I were laid out, you would look at me and say 'My God -- she's wearing last year's dress!' "
Scene: Columbus Avenue at 85th Street.
Time: Late Sunday afternoon brunch.
Players: A young man and woman, obviously a couple, sitting at separate small outdoor tables and deeply engaged in conversation.
Observer: Leslie J. Gersing who, on closer inspection, realizes that the couple are eating at different cafes. He's sipping coffee and smoking at the French-inspired Avenue. She's eating pizza at the adjacent Firehouse sports bar.
Who says love requires compromise?
Emanuel Kahn can't forget this conversation, and small wonder. He wanted a compact disk by Johann Sebastian Bach, so he telephoned a classical record music club and asked for the recording. After a short interval, the operator said that she couldn't find this artist. Mr. Kahn spelled the name and she replied that perhaps the artist was too new and wasn't listed yet.
J.S. Bach died a few hundred years ago, Mr. Kahn said, and he had previously bought recordings by "this artist." Please check again.
She came back on the line. "We don't have anything by this artist," she said. "He never signed a contract with us."
Honesty Is Not Always the Best Policy Department:
The sales clerk at the bakery counter of her local supermarket looked at Elaine Green and said "Yes, young lady, what can I do for you?" Ms. Green said, "First of all, thank you for calling me 'young lady,' and second, I'll have a plain rye bread."
The clerk replied: "Oh, I call all my elderly customers 'young lady' or 'young man.' "
Somehow the bread felt a little heavier to Ms. Green as she walked away.
The Scene: Vera Institute of Justice Ombudservice booth at New York State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. The Ombudservice listens to juror concerns and handles individual juror problems.
First Juror: "You gotta get me out of jury service. It's against my principles to judge my fellow man. It's against my religion."
Second Juror (interrupting): "Hey, buddy! How much do we get paid?"
Brian Maxey, the Ombudservice law intern: "$40."
First Juror: "A day?" Muses a moment. "Well, for $40, maybe I could judge my fellow man."
Public primping isn't unusual in New York but it's usually done on a subway or bus, and it isn't often as all-encompassing as that recently witnessed by Erika Boyd and her husband.
They were standing at a bus stop on 49th Street awaiting a Waterway Ferry bus when a young woman standing next to them began her elaborate toilette. She opened her oversize black bag and pulled out a mirrored compact, lipstick, eye liner, eye shadow and mascara, and carefully made up her face. She then dabbed complexion makeup to cover blemishes on her bare legs. The next stage was brushing out her complicated hairdo, twisting it into a knot and securing the new coiffure with two long black plastic hair sticks, placed to form an X. This was followed by the placement of long dangly earrings and a ring.
Finally she stepped in front of her full-length mirror -- in this case, a storefront window -- and inspected the length of her skirt and her overall appearance.
She appeared satisfied. The Boyds were, too. It was a Manhattan experience. She went on her way -- to a job interview? a date? a photo shoot? -- and they boarded the bus en route to the ferry and their home in New Jersey.
 
U.S. OPEN (AND SHUT) CASE
Heavens to Betsy, holy moley
When frankfurters are no longer lowly,
When they're served up on a sesame bun
And covered over with Grey Poupon,
When we find to our profound dismay
That all the foods are now Gourmet
When we care less who goes down in defeat
Than how we pay for what we eat,
Then it's time to admit the game of tennis
Has become an economical menace! MURIEL LILKER

HEADLINE: As Demand for Teachers Exceeds Supply, Schools Sweeten Their Offers

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
In Baltimore this summer, prospective special-education teachers were in such demand that they were offered more money than the union contract requires: those with just a year's experience got the starting salaries of four-year veterans -- the equivalent of a $2,000 raise before ever putting chalk to blackboard. And like applicants in all other subject areas, they were also entitled to reduced-rate mortgages and low-interest $1,500 loans for relocation.
In Massachusetts, teaching candidates will soon be able to compete for an even bigger windfall: Acting Gov. Argeo Paul Cellucci signed a law last month establishing $20,000 signing bonuses for nearly 200 of the most promising rookie teachers who apply to work in the commonwealth's schools next year. 
 And despite a new law curtailing bilingual education, California districts remain so desperate for teachers who speak languages like Spanish and Vietnamese that some are offering bonuses of up to $5,000.
Long accustomed to being supplicants in the labor force, candidates for public-school teaching jobs -- especially in special education, math and science -- are being put in the decidedly unfamiliar position of being wooed with financial sweeteners.
In making those overtures, recruiters from even the smallest districts have logged thousands of miles in the spring and summer, with those from teacher-needy states like Nevada and Alaska canvassing universities in upstate New York, Montana and Iowa, where there are far more rookie teachers than available jobs.
New York City recruiters, frustrated in their search for qualified math and science teachers, looked as far as Austria, where they hired 23 instructors eager to escape widespread teacher unemployment.
Even substitute teachers, the second-class citizens on so many faculties, have found themselves in demand: so depleted are the ranks of substitutes in Kentucky that the state has allowed some districts to hire those with only high school diplomas.
"In the past," said Marcia Brown, the director of personnel administration for the El Paso Independent School District in Texas, "what this school district has had to offer has been enough to attract teachers: the climate, good sound programs and a safe working environment."
"But now," she said, "because every district across this country is running short, especially in the high-need areas, the competition is tremendous."
Outbid countless times this past year by districts in Dallas and Fort Worth, which offered signing bonuses of $500 to $2,000 to hundreds of teaching candidates who committed virtually on the spot, El Paso has decided to join the fray. Beginning later this fall, new math teachers hired in El Paso will have their $25,012 starting salaries increased by $2,000 bonuses.
Buffeting the current market are rising enrollments -- the schools in Las Vegas, Nev., have had to hire 2,000 new teachers over each of the last two summers, largely to accommodate an influx of 20,000 new students -- as well as a drought of college graduates choosing teaching careers, especially in math and science.
The pressure on districts is building as total public and private school enrollment is expected to reach a record 52.7 million this fall, which the Department of Education says would exceed the record high last fall by 500,000.
And the competition promises only to get fiercer. The department expects new enrollment records to be set for at least the next eight years.
Public school rolls are expected to grow by 4 percent over the next decade, to 48.3 million from 46.4 million, as hundreds of thousands of teachers hired in the late 1960's and early 1970's to teach the Baby Boom generation retire.
While education experts say that signing bonuses and other perks signal a new respect for teachers in some quarters, they say they worry that such measures will amount to little more than a Band-Aid on a profession that is in danger of hemorrhaging.
But for now, as districts around the country seek to fill vacancies even after schools have opened for the year, they say the best they can offer are virtual carrots. Yet they say they have learned that even the most modest of gestures can cinch a candidate's decision.
Lasheaka Timmons, 23, who graduated last spring with a degree in secondary education and social studies from the University of Arizona, was offered a job teaching a continent away at West Baltimore Middle School, through Teach for America, which places rookie teachers in urban districts. But Ms. Timmons said she would have had to turn down the job, and work instead in Phoenix, without the $1,200 loan to cover moving expenses that school officials offered her through the municipal workers' credit union.
Ms. Timmons is to pay back the loan at a rate of 13 percent -- better than that offered by most credit card companies -- through weekly deductions from her paycheck over the next year.
"Just out of college, unless you come from a background where your parents can afford to help you, especially coming from Arizona, you wouldn't be able to relocate," she said. "It definitely makes you feel they want you."
Baltimore officials say that such perks, as well as mortgage loans that are discounted by an eighth to a quarter of a point, provided the teachers settle within the city limits, have been mentioned as critical enticements by several dozen of the more than 700 teachers hired over the summer.
But even as Baltimore schools opened last week, the district had been unable to fill nearly 100 vacancies, especially for special-education and elementary-school teachers, needed to reduce class size, and officials said they were still hiring. "If you could slant your story that way," Albrie Love Jr., personnel director for the Baltimore schools, told a reporter, "I would appreciate it."
In Massachusetts, where 59 percent of teaching applicants failed an entrance examination last spring, officials said they hoped to use the $20,000 bonuses, spread over the first four years of a teacher's career, to entice 175 of "the best and the brightest" into the profession each year. Under the program, up to 300 high-performing veteran teachers would receive bonuses of $50,000 divided over 10 years.
But Kathleen Kelley, the president of the Massachusetts Federation of Teachers, said it would take far more than bonuses to elevate the working conditions for teachers in the state.
"It affects so few people," Ms. Kelley said. "It's a drop in the bucket, and it doesn't take a systemic look at the problems."
Lupe Cruz, a bilingual education teacher in California with more than a decade's experience, said she ranked the reputation of the superintendent and his sense of teamwork as her top priorities in choosing this summer to move from a nearby district to the Alum Rock Union Elementary School district in East San Jose. Of no weight, she said, was the $1,000 signing bonus that she received for being a certified bilingual education teacher.
In fact, she says that she intends to spend the bonus money on her students.
"What's $1,000 when you look at it?" she said. "It's not going to pay for a major vacation."

HEADLINE: El Paso, Feeling Gouged At Pump, Fights Back

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: EL PASO, Sept. 4

 BODY:
A citizens movement to protest the high price of gasoline has become the hottest political issue in El Paso, drawing in Texas officials and entangling itself in a contentious proposal to open a pipeline from the Gulf Coast -- a kind of cavalry charging to the rescue.
A Dallas oil consortium that hopes to run gasoline through the dormant pipeline, which once carried West Texas crude oil to Houston, has fastened itself to the El Paso protest movement, hoping to override the objections of officials in Austin and central Texas who say they are worried about potential leaks into crucial waterways. 
 The squabble reveals not only the image that many El Paso residents have of themselves as beleaguered victims of a "continual and unrelenting fleecing at the hands of an out-of-control industry," as Ken Haverfield, head of the consumer group that is leading the movement, put it, but what has in recent years become an endless tug-of-war of economic, political and environmental interests in the nation's second largest state.
Mr. Haverfield first heard about the consumer group he heads, Make-a-Difference, or MAD, when he was turning the radio dial. The group had just been formed and was having one of its first gatherings.
"The prices in El Paso are higher than just about anyplace," said Mr. Haverfield, a substitute teacher. "Rent, milk, you name it, but especially gas. So I went to their meeting several months ago and kind of got caught up in it." Two meetings later, he was chairman. Not long after, he was president. And last Thursday, Mr. Haverfield found himself sitting before a microphone in the El Paso Civic Center, testifying to a pair of reassuring Congressmen.
Mr. Haverfield and his supporters say that until recently gasoline prices for most of the last 20 years have been 10 to 20 cents a gallon higher in El Paso than in Houston. They believe it is the result of a conspiracy by producers to artificially inflate prices.
The Federal Government is not so sure. John Cook, director of the oil and gas division of the Federal Energy Information Administration, said that while his agency did find a history of high gasoline prices in El Paso -- 10 to 15 cents a gallon higher than in Houston -- the differential is not unusual. There are many such regional differentials in the United States, he said, caused by variations in taxes, geography, competition and the laws of supply and demand.
The crux of El Paso's gasoline problem is geographic. The city is more than 700 miles from the Gulf of Mexico, where gasoline is cheaper to produce; residents often note they are about as close to Los Angeles, three states away, as they are to Houston. And while there are many refineries on the Gulf Coast, drawing crude oil from all over the world, there is only one in El Paso, a relatively small Chevron plant that draws its crude solely from the more expensive West Texas fields. The rest of El Paso's gasoline is from fields and refineries further west, where gasoline is more expensive to produce than it is on the Gulf Coast.
"Whether it's geography or not, I don't know, but we're like a lot of people wondering why it is that gas is so expensive in El Paso," said David Morales, spokesman for the Cab Association of El Paso, another proponent of lower gas prices.
Last year, the consortium, Longhorn Partners Pipeline, took over an 18-inch-wide, 430-mile-long Exxon pipeline that had been carrying crude from the West Texas fields into Houston and the Gulf Coast refineries. The plan was to clean out the pipe, test its structural integrity, build a 250-mile extension west into El Paso and ship gasoline, diesel and jet fuel through it.
"I started to go out to El Paso three or four years ago," said Carter Montgomery, president of Longhorn, which includes Amoco and Exxon among its investors. "The attitude out there has always been, bring on the pipeline."
But a lawsuit filed earlier this year on behalf of several ranchers charges that the pipeline project violates environmental restrictions. The suit is being underwritten by the Navajo Refining Company, a leading distributor of gasoline to El Paso, Mr. Montgomery said, and a potential competitor of the pipeline.
So last month, Longhorn filed suit against Navajo, charging it with violating anti-trust laws "in an attempt to maintain artificially high gas prices" in El Paso.
The suit against Longhorn, though, attracted the attention of politicians and water officials in central Texas. Both the City of Austin and the Lower Colorado River Authority joined in the suit, demanding that Longhorn conduct an environmental impact study before using the pipeline.
Last month, a United States district court judge in Austin agreed and ordered the study, which Mr. Montgomery said would delay the project up to two years. It is also unnecessary, Mr. Montgomery said, since the pipeline consortium has already conducted sufficient tests.
Mark Rose, general manager of the Lower Colorado River Authority, said his group's concern about the pipeline was one of safety.
"Our issue is that they are reconverting a 50-year-old pipeline that once carried West Texas crude to now carry gasoline, diesel and jet fuel," Mr. Rose said. "The goal to get gasoline to El Paso is a noble one. We just hope it doesn't turn out to be tragically bad for everyone in central Texas."
Mr. Montgomery said that Longhorn was continuing to build the pipeline and appealing the judge's order.
The high prices in El Paso, which has a per-capita income well below that of other major Texas cities, remain a staple of the talk-radio shows.
But Wayne Ederer, regional marketing director for Chevron, cannot see why. "I feel there is a lot of misunderstanding out there among the citizens," he said. "They see a refinery here and refineries in Houston and wonder why prices are higher here. They don't understand the cost situation that we have, using more expensive West Texas crude."
Mr. Haverfield said that the producers have no one to blame but themselves for the widespread distrust. "We've tried to get answers from them," he said. "If you can get them on the phone, all you end up with is scrambled eggs. You can't figure it out."
A dip in the price of gasoline here since March has further muddied the situation. Chevron and other distributors say it is a result of an increase in the local supply. Mr. Haverfield and others believe it has something to do with the pressure applied by his organization and by local politicians, including Mayor Carlos Ramirez and Representative Silvestre Reyes, Democrat of El Paso.
"I did notice that the price of gasoline here this morning was competitive with what it was when I left Houston," said Representative Gene Green, a Houston Democrat who joined Mr. Reyes at the public hearing in the civic center last week. "If it'll help keep the prices down, I'll be glad to come out here every couple of weeks for a public hearing."
Mr. Montgomery says it has become a pleasure for Longhorn officials to visit El Paso.
"There was a 5K road race a while back that we agreed to help sponsor," he said. "At the end, when they read the list of sponsors and they got to our name, everybody in the audience stood up and applauded. I mean, we had 2,500 people standing up, applauding us."
This, he said, does not happen every day in the pipeline business.

HEADLINE: Labor Unions Show New Aggressiveness

 BODY:
Major strikes this summer indicate a new aggressiveness by the nation's labor unions, which, after several disasters, had generally shunned large-scale walkouts.
Unions have grown bolder despite declining membership rolls and the slowing economy, experts say, because of the tight labor market, more combative union leadership and the teamsters' gains in last year's U.P.S. strike. But many business leaders disagree, asserting instead that recent strikes were coincidental with the expiration of agreements in industries where labor relations are volatile. And one expert suggested it was not workers but employers who were being more aggressive in their contined demands for concessions. 
 Still, with workers' wages finally climbing faster than inflation, labor leaders worry that a slowing economy and a retreating stock market will cause corporate America to clamp down on pay raises.

HEADLINE: Unions, Growing Bolder, No Longer Shun Strikes

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The recent strikes at Northwest Airlines, General Motors, Bell Atlantic and U S West represent the biggest surge in major walkouts in years and, industrial relations experts say, point to a new aggressiveness on the part of the nation's labor unions.
For years unions were so discouraged by several disastrous strikes, most notably the Caterpillar and the air controllers' strikes, that they had generally shunned large-scale walkouts. And even though union membership rolls are slipping and the slowing economy threatens workers, unions have grown bolder, labor experts say, because of the tight labor market, more combative union leadership and the teamsters' gains in last year's U.P.S. strike. 
 In 1996, the number of strikes nationwide had fallen to its lowest level in 50 years, 374, before rising to 394 last year. Even before the prominent strikes of this summer, the number of work stoppages increased this year, rising to 226 in the first six months from 214 the first six months of last year, according to the Bureau of National Affairs, a private research organization.
Even more significant for labor, striking unions have emerged more successful than in recent years, pressuring U S West, for example, to scale back mandatory overtime and Bell Atlantic to stop making most new jobs nonunion.
"All this represents a more confident and aggressive labor movement," said Harley Shaiken, a professor of industrial relations at the University of California at Berkeley. "In the 1980's, so many highly visible, pivotal strikes ended somewhere between disaster and debacle, but what we've seen this year is a number of important successes for unions. It might not be time to crack out the champagne bottles, but it's probably time for a couple of cold beers on Labor Day to celebrate what's taken place."
But many business leaders say the recent eruption of strikes stems not from an emboldened labor movement, but from coincidence: many collective bargaining agreements in industries with volatile labor relations have expired this summer.
"I don't see a trend," said Patrick Cleary, vice president for human resources policy at the National Association of Manufacturers. "I don't get a sense of any change in the national Zeitgeist."
But one cause for the surge in strikes is that many corporations continue to demand concessions. The 34,000 workers at U S West went on strike after the company insisted on replacing the across-the-board pay increases that unions favor with a pay-for-performance system, which would give management total discretion over each worker's raises: an idea abhorred by unions. The General Motors strike began after the company refused to make good on promises to invest $300 million in a metal-stamping plant in Flint, Mich.
"All of these strikes show unions' willingness to fight back more," said Richard Hurd, a professor of labor relations at Cornell University. "But it's not clear to me whether these strikes are caused by newfound aggressiveness on the part of unions or newfound aggressiveness on the part of employers."
John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., attributes the increase in strikes to both sides: greater labor confidence and to management hardheadedness. He said it was understandable that workers opt to strike when many corporations are making record profits and union members feel they are not getting their fair share of the expanding pie.
Mr. Sweeney called the current Northwest Airlines pilots' strike an example of this, asserting that the airline had made a stingy offer to its 6,200 pilots despite the company's booming profits and soaring executive pay. But the airline maintains that it cannot meet the pilots' demands, which it says would make them the nation's highest-paid pilots.
"What we're seeing is a complete lack of respect for workers, for the jobs they do," Mr. Sweeney said in a telephone interview with reporters. "We're seeing so many examples of how insensitive corporate America can be to their workers."
Labor leaders also note that workers' wages are finally climbing faster than inflation, after years of lagging behind. Despite recent wage gains, the average worker's inflation-adjusted wages remain 3 percent below 1989 levels.
But they fear that the slowing economy and reeling stock market will soon cause corporate America to clamp down on wage increases.
"If there is an economic slowdown or a recession, then wages won't fully recover to where they were in 1989," said Lawrence Mishel, research director of the Economic Policy Institute, a union-backed research center.
Despite the unions' new aggressiveness and their recent strike successes, labor is still faced with a declining membership.
There were victories in recruitment of new members, like organizing 19,000 passenger-service workers at United Airlines. So far, however, labor has fallen short of the goal Mr. Sweeney set upon becoming president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. nearly three years ago: to increase the labor federation's membership, now at 13 million, by 3 percent a year.
Nonetheless, Mr. Sweeney predicts that the labor movement will be adding, not losing, members over all within a year or two because unions are pumping more money and manpower into organizing.
Unions represent 14 percent of all workers, down from 35 percent in the 1950's, and Mr. Sweeney has repeatedly warned that unless labor recruits millions of workers, it risks fading into irrelevance and losing its bargaining clout. Under him, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has allocated $20 million a year for organizing, up from $2.5 million before he was elected.
The federation says that unions recruited nearly 400,000 new members last year, but nonetheless, union membership is down by more than 200,000 since early 1996, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The recruitment gains have been outweighed by losses caused by layoffs, plant closings and other factors.
Organizing faces other problems. The highly publicized campaign to unionize 20,000 strawberry workers in California has made little headway. And the teamsters' financial scandals and unions' tradition of holding lavish conventions in places like Hawaii have hardly helped labor burnish their image or woo new members.
"They're up against some pretty daunting challenges," said Mr. Cleary, of the manufacturers association. "You look at where the new jobs are -- data base administration, systems analysts -- and unions have not had much luck penetrating those occupations. And if you look where the job growth is geographically -- in the South and Southwest -- these are areas where labor hasn't had great success."
Nonetheless, Mr. Sweeney predicts that the labor movement will be adding members over all within a year or two largely because unions are pumping much more money into organizing. He boasted that 8 unions had membership growth of at least 3 percent last year, but that is a small fraction of the 70-plus unions in the federation. He also boasted that a handful of unions, like the Service Employees International, have met his goal of devoting 30 percent of their budget to organizing.
But many labor experts are unimpressed. "My assessment is that union organizing efforts have only been modestly successful," said Professor Hurd, of Cornell. "There's not a tremendously significant movement building for a wholehearted shift in commitment to organizing. You can't blame Sweeney. The bottom line is decisions have to be made by people in individual unions, and in most of those unions, hard decisions are not being made."
