HEADLINE: As Irked Creditors Wait, Officials Squabble in Syracuse Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
It is the sort of fight usually found on a playground, complete with glares, name-calling and a tussle over strawberry Twizzlers.
But this dispute is going on in a courtroom in upstate New York, where two men who are supposed to be unraveling an enormous financial mess are fighting each other instead. 
 Their battle is just the latest twist in the case of Bennett Funding Group, a Syracuse operation that the authorities call the biggest pyramid scheme in American history. When the concern, which financed equipment leases collapsed in 1996, about 10,000 people -- many of them retirees from New York, New Jersey and Florida -- lost as much as $600 million.
Richard C. Breeden, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is responsible for trying to get their money back. As trustee of the Bennett companies' bankruptcy, he has already had unusual success, recently mailing checks to investors totaling $50 million. While that amounts to only about 6 cents for every dollar lost, most victims of pyramid schemes are lucky to get even a penny back.
And Mr. Breeden promises more to come, including $125 million from an insurance settlement.
But in the course of his efforts, he has run afoul of Guy A. Van Baalen, a Justice Department official based in Utica whose job is to supervise bankruptcies in northern New York.
In court documents, Mr. Van Baalen accuses Mr. Breeden, whose pay as trustee amounts to $600,000 a year, of overbilling for his work (and for personal expenses like candy), and with creating conflicts of interest so serious that he should be removed from the case. Among other things, Mr. Van Baalen criticizes Mr. Breeden for serving as chairman of Equivest Finance Inc., a company invested in by the Bennett group, whose ownership stake has been taken over by the creditors.
Mr. Breeden contends that Mr. Van Baalen is a petty bureaucrat who has willfully misunderstood his efforts to help the investors. "I control the company because it's the creditors', and I want to be damn sure how their money is spent," Mr. Breeden said of his role at Equivest, which finances consumers' purchases of time-share resorts.
The dispute has delayed -- and may ultimately derail -- Mr. Breeden's efforts to sell stock in Equivest, which he describes as the only valuable asset Bennett has. But even if the sale occurs, Wall Street's sharp decline has cut into the value of the stock, which was trading for almost $175 million in late July but today is worth less than $100 million.
Mr. Van Baalen opposes the sale, saying Mr. Breeden has not given the court enough information about it. But he says he understands that it is the foundation of Mr. Breeden's efforts to recover money for the investors. "The trustee has put so much into this sale of stock as really crucial, that if it doesn't go . . . oh, my God," he said.
All of which has some people involved in the case rolling their eyes in exasperation. Indeed, a creditors' committee that represents almost all the individual investors in the case asked the bankruptcy judge in the case to put off any discussion on the conflict-of-interest allegations until after he rules on the Equivest sale, which he may do this week.
While the committee has criticized Mr. Breeden's fees -- and what it calls his high-handed ways -- it wants the stock sale to go through, said Daniel M. Stolz, a lawyer for the creditors.
How this dispute is resolved has enormous implications for the reputations of the men involved and for the thousands of investors who are awaiting more cash.
It may also affect the criminal trial of Patrick R. Bennett, who ran the Bennett companies and has been charged with 37 counts related to securities fraud. His trial is to begin in November in Federal District Court in Manhattan.
The dispute may ultimately have implications for Syracuse, the struggling upstate city of 164,000 where the whole mess began. Though the city's economy is starting to show signs of growth after years of stagnation, the pace is slow -- the city added just 200 new jobs in the year ended in June, according to the State Department of Labor, an increase of 0.1 percent (in New York City, by contrast, jobs increased by 2.3 percent in the same period).
So Syracuse is still a place where every job counts. At its peak, the Bennett group employed 250 people, the bulk of whom still work there but could become unemployed as the bankruptcy winds down. Mr. Breeden hopes Equivest will be able to hire some of them.
The Bennett companies were founded in 1977 by Edmund T. Bennett, known as Bud, and his wife, Kathleen. The bulk of their business came from financing leases on office equipment, like copiers and fax machines, which are often rented by state and local governments.
The company appeared to be extremely successful. From 1985 to 1987, it made Inc. magazine's list of the 500 fastest-growing private companies in America. The elder Bennetts, and their two sons, Patrick and Michael, became important figures and philanthropists in Syracuse.
"They were big, let me tell you, big things in the community," said William J. Moran, who runs the Hiawatha Council of Boy Scouts there. "They supported the nonprofit community to a great degree -- people would have gone to the end of the earth for them."
By 1990, according to court documents, the Bennetts began selling the leases, and pools of leases, to investors. Most of the sales were done through small brokerage firms, which described the leases to clients as very conservative investments.
Regulators were not so sure. In 1994, the Securities and Exchange Commission began looking into the Bennett empire.
In March 1996, the S.E.C. sued the company and Patrick Bennett, accusing him of selling $570 million of unregistered securities and of running a giant Ponzi scheme, in which early "investors" were paid off with the money put in by later "investors."
Some leases had been sold to more than one investor, and some were made up out of whole cloth, Mr. Breeden said. All the money that came in as lease payments, and all the money paid out to investors, came from a general fund that he calls "the honey pot." The Bennetts themselves used money from the pot to buy various things, but seemed to specialize in unprofitable gambling properties, including an unfinished riverboat, a defunct casino and a failing race track.
The day after the S.E.C. filed suit, the Bennett companies filed for bankruptcy protection. The following month, Mr. Breeden, with the support of his old agency, was appointed trustee by the Justice Department. It was a decision made over the head of Mr. Van Baalen's predecessor.
That may have been the start of Mr. Breeden's problems, although the life of a trustee is almost never a happy one. The trustee often becomes a focus for the anger of all the people affected by the bankruptcy, who resent the trustee for making money off their misery.
That is particularly true when, as in Mr. Breeden's case, he is making quite a lot of money. He stands to make millions of dollars, depending on how much he recovers for creditors, in addition to his annual $600,000 salary, which, he asserts, is not too much for someone who is running an enormous, complex operation.
But it sure looks like a lot in Syracuse, where the average worker makes less than $28,000 a year.
And Mr. Breeden has taken some very unpopular steps, including suing the defrauded investors to adjust the amounts of their claims.
Not surprisingly, emotions seem to run particularly high in the Bennett collapse. In Syracuse, "it was quite a shock at the time -- people didn't want to believe it," said Charley Hannagan, a reporter for the Syracuse newspapers who has written extensively about the case.
As for the investors, she recalled, "I would go to a meeting and people would stand up and cry."
Some investors continue to believe in the Bennetts, noting that the allegations of fraud have never been proved in court. The elder Bennetts have never been charged; according to court documents, Michael Bennett, who was charged with one court each of conspiracy and obstruction of justice, is expected to reach a plea agreement with prosecutors.
Patrick Bennett denies that there was any scheme to defraud investors. "In his opinion, there were enough assets there to pay the creditors, and if they were short, it was only 5 percent or 10 percent," said Richard Croak, an Albany lawyer who represents Mr. Bennett in the bankruptcy case.
"Pat is just an ordinary guy from Syracuse who got involved in this thing," Mr. Croak said. "He's not a criminal."
Patrick Bennett's parents go even further -- they appear to attribute all of the company's problems to Mr. Breeden, who they say developed a conspiracy against them dating to 1989 or 1990, during his tenure as S.E.C. chief.
Mr. Croak declined to comment on the elder Bennetts' allegations, but he has asked the court to allow him to depose Mr. Breeden about some of the potential conflicts raised by Mr. Van Baalen.
Stephen D. Gerling of Utica, chief bankruptcy judge of the Northern District of New York, denied the request last month, saying that allowing everyone involved in the case to depose Mr. Breeden would cause chaos.
"Mail arrives almost daily both applauding and criticizing the activities of the trustee," the judge said. "I dare say we would have examinations every day of every week for the next year and a half, if I were to order opening the proverbial Pandora's box."
If Mr. Breeden won that skirmish, he has also lost some. After an uproar over his purchase last year of about $17,000 of Equivest stock, he agreed to donate his shares to the University of Syracuse.
And last week, Judge Gerling ruled that Mr. Breeden must either resign as trustee or give up another of his jobs, as consultant to the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche. The problem, the judge said, is that Deloitte will not reveal all of its clients, some of whom may be involved in the bankruptcy.
But the judge's underlying complaint, and one of Mr. Van Baalen's as well, is that Mr. Breeden was slow to tell them about the consulting job, and provided little information when he did tell them. "The trustee appears to believe that the court and the parties should simply rely on him as a fiduciary to make an independent determination that he remains disinterested," Judge Gerling wrote disapprovingly.
That is exactly what Mr. Breeden says. Saying that he is doing what is best for the defrauded investors, he interprets Mr. Van Baalen's queries as attacks on his integrity.
"There has never been a trustee more honest or who has worked any harder than I have," Mr. Breeden said. "This is not a game -- it is a system that needs to insure the best results" for creditors.
And results, he added, "speak louder than words."

HEADLINE: Northwest Strike Mediator Sends the Negotiators Home

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
After shuttling between negotiators for Northwest Airlines and its striking pilots for two days, a Federal mediator sent the two sides home yesterday and asked them to redouble their efforts to bring an end to the nine-day strike, which has grounded Northwest's nearly 1,700 daily flights.
The National Mediation Board, which has been supervising negotiations between the airline and its 6,200 pilots since June, said that further meetings would be held in Minneapolis on Tuesday. 
 People briefed on the discussions said that little progress was made at the weekend session, which was called by the board last week at the behest of Transportation Secretary Rodney E. Slater to see if resuming negotiations would be productive. The meeting took place at a hotel near Chicago's O'Hare International Airport. The two sides met separately with the mediator.
The board's statement said the weekend meetings "involved the parameters of a settlement," but it did not elaborate. The statement pointed to the substantive differences between the two sides and asked them to reconsider their positions.
Northwest, the country's fourth-largest airline, dominates air service in the upper Midwest and middle South.
The governors of several states, including Minnesota, Michigan and North Dakota, have called on President Clinton to halt the strike. Last year, Mr. Clinton ordered pilots at American Airlines back to work minutes after they struck, saying that a strike would cause too much disruption to the economy. The White House, while following the situation closely, has resisted intervening in the Northwest strike, a move the company would welcome.
Pay and job security are the main issues in the strike, which is the longest in the industry since Eastern Airlines machinists walked out in 1989. Analysts say that the hard line taken by each side overshadows the narrow differences between the positions. The pilots say their demands would cost the company only $70 million a year; Northwest says the figure is closer to $170 million. The strike has already cost Northwest an estimated $300 million in expenses and lost revenue.
Pilots are angry that Northwest has resisted giving them a substantial raise after they and other unions made wage concessions in 1993 to save the airline from bankruptcy. Since then, Northwest has posted four years of record profits and its executives have cashed in stock options worth millions.
Northwest, which is also in negotiations with unions representing its flight attendants, customer service representatives and machinists, says that it cannot afford to give the pilots what they want.
It was unclear whether Tuesday's meeting would lead to a resumption of negotiations, which were last held on Aug. 28, hours before the pilots walked out.
A spokesman for the board declined to comment on the talks, as did representatives of Northwest and the Air Line Pilots Association. Another airline, Airtran, narrowly averted disruption over the weekend when it reached agreement on a new four-year contract with its flight attendants. The tentative agreement would give 500 flight attendants an immediate 10 percent raise plus 4 percent annual raises.
It was the first tentative contract for the Association of Flight Attendants at Airtran, which is based in Orlando, Fla., and was formerly called Valujet.

HEADLINE: In Senate Race, 3 City Candidates Accentuate Upstate Ties

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 4

 BODY:
Before a dinner of pizza and beer in a back room at Pete's, an Italian restaurant and bar here in the northernmost reaches of New York State, Mark Green offered what has become his trademark serenade to voters outside of New York City as he pursues the Democratic nomination for United States Senate.
"I was born in Brooklyn, raised in Nassau," Mr. Green said. "My wife grew up in Westchester." He added that he attended Cornell University in Tompkins County, and hastened to introduce his 19-year-old daughter, Jenya, who is a sophomore at the school in Ithaca and had accompanied her father to underscore the point. 
 Earlier in the day, Geraldine A. Ferraro, the former vice presidential candidate who is also seeking the nomination, made a point of reminding voters in Middletown, her first stop on a three-day upstate campaign swing, that she was born in Orange County and spent her earliest childhood years there.
And on his visits north, Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, the third major Democratic contender, sometimes tells people that his father was born in Utica. And for good measure, he tries to demonstrate his local affinity by traveling with Congressional colleagues or other area officials who support his candidacy.
In the upper corridors of New York State, these final days before the Sept. 15 primary are treating Democratic voters to the spectacle of three quintessential New York City politicians striving for votes by grasping for ties that stretch beyond the five boroughs and their suburbs.
Mr. Green, who is New York City's Public Advocate, lives on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, and dresses it. Mr. Schumer, the nine-term Congressman, lives in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and sounds it. And Ms. Ferraro, who is a former Representative from Queens, still has a home in Forest Hills Gardens.
So, running for statewide office presents a beguiling challenge: how to connect to the voters of western, central and northern New York, who are generally skeptical and often feel as shunted to the margins politically as they are geographically.
That obstacle can be even greater in a Democratic primary because rural voters, even registered Democrats, tend to be more conservative and because the conventional wisdom suggests that their votes matter little. Typically, more than 70 percent of primary ballots are cast in New York City and its suburbs.
"There's a feeling up here sometimes among Democrats that we're ignored," said Mike Schell, the former Democratic chairman of Jefferson County who now heads the Democratic Rural Conference, a coalition of party leaders from the state's 41 smallest counties.
But with Ms. Ferraro, Mr. Green and Mr. Schumer all extremely well known in New York City, the candidates and their aides say that votes north and west of Rockland County could prove crucial in the primary.
At her campaign stop in Middletown, Ms. Ferraro said that she expects that the major candidates "will split the city, a third each." She said that to lift her to victory this year, she is "banking on" the city's suburbs and upstate, where she scored well in her unsuccessful bid for the nomination in 1992.
Mr. Green, who was the Democratic nominee in 1986 but lost to Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Republican who still holds the seat, has also put higher stakes in his upstate campaign. He began courting the Democratic Rural Conference when it was first created two years ago and won the group's endorsement in March.
"I have a lot of room to grow upstate because I'm less well known there," said Mr. Green, whose campaign began airing two television advertisements in upstate media markets within the last week. "I gain more and more rapidly once they know I'm not just some downstate stranger."
Mr. Schumer has declined to characterize any region of the state as more or less important to his campaign strategy. But he has made a point of emphasizing particular local issues whenever he travels north and has enlisted many upstate elected officials to boost his candidacy.
"Any candidate from anywhere in the state can become well-known upstate if they do one of two things -- visit frequently or appear in the media frequently," said Robert Cook, the Monroe County Democratic chairman. "Schumer has been pretty generous with media buys. People know him."
Mr. Cook has not endorsed any of the candidates, but many county chairmen have. Of the state's 62 counties, Mr. Green claims 31 as his supporters, Ms. Ferraro says she has the backing of 13 and Mr. Schumer has 6 behind him.
Each of the candidates has taken a different approach to practical campaigning upstate. Mr. Green hascampaign offices in Buffalo and Rochester. Ms. Ferraro, who had a highly organized upstate effort in 1992, has more loosely organized support this year.
Mr. Schumer, who has raised far more money than either Mr. Green or Ms. Ferraro, has made quick trips upstate by airplane to hold news conferences or attend events.
"I've had Chuck on a cycle," said G. Steven Pigeon, the Erie County chairman, who is supporting Mr. Schumer. "He's campaigning like he's running for county executive, hitting all the public events," Mr. Pigeon said.
Mr. Schell, of Jefferson County and the Rural Democratic Conference, said Mr. Green's manner appealed to northern voters. "He is able to bridge whatever differences there are in personalities upstate and downstate," he said. "That probably comes from his being educated up here and growing up in the suburbs."
Mark Glavin, the Rensselaer chairman, who is supporting Ms. Ferraro, said, "You have got to have someone on the line who can generate the enthusiasm. She's the only one who can beat D'Amato. It's important to have someone who can appeal to the whole state, especially upstate."
New York's northern and western tiers are far more crucial in a general election than in a primary. Mr. D'Amato proved that in 1986 when Mr. Green fared better in New York City, but Mr. D'Amato retained his seat by trouncing Mr. Green in the suburbs and upstate.
Often, the candidates gently tailor their messages to the upstate crowds. Mr. Green, for instance, speaking to aides, described his support by the Democratic chairmen of the seven most northeastern counties as a "yarmulke on New York State." But in the speech later at Pete's restaurant, he said they "formed a cap on the north country."
In terms of issues, all three candidates put more emphasis on the upstate economy, which has not kept pace with the growth downstate. On the stump, the candidates often face questions ranging from their views on the dairy industry to the Russian economy.
But despite their efforts, voters say the New York City candidates still have work to do. At The Crystal Restaurant in Watertown -- which opened in 1919 and still has an "All Legal Beverages" sign dating from Prohibition -- Jim Walsh, a lifelong Democrat, said he felt little attachment to any of the primary contenders.
"I like Ferraro, I used to watch her on Crossfire," said Mr. Walsh, who is 67. "But I don't like her husband and his antics. Mark Green doesn't mean much to me because he's never been brought to the forefront here. He's pretty much a city boy. Schumer, he's another. He's a House of Representatives guy. That's all I know about him."

HEADLINE: $200,000 Lost in an Investment Gone Bad

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Sometimes it can be hard to have sympathy for the kinds of people who fall for securities schemes: the greedy, the gullible, the gamblers. But in the case of the Bennett Funding Group, lawyers say, most victims were careful, conservative people who thought they were putting their money somewhere safe.
People like Richard Schiff, 77, a retired businessman from Long Island who now lives in Boca Raton, Fla. Mr. Schiff lost his $200,000 retirement account by investing in Bennett. While he is not impoverished by the loss, Mr. Schiff said, "That income would have been very useful." 
 The son of a Russian immigrant who ran a small lumberyard in Brooklyn, Mr. Schiff made a career selling plastic laminates, like Formica, and, with his wife of 53 years, brought up two children. Heart problems forced him to retire about 20 years ago.
When Mr. Schiff invested in the Bennett group, he thought he was buying "leases from the Federal Government for mail trucks," he said, with an interest rate of 9 percent. In 1996, after having invested $135,000 directly in Bennett leases, he agreed to put $65,000 from his individual retirement account into what he thought was a Bennett-sponsored fund; four days later, the Bennett companies filed for bankruptcy.
A supporter of Mr. Breeden, Mr. Schiff said he was happy to be finally recouping money from his investment. But the status of the money in the fund remains unclear.
Haunted by the fear that the Bennetts or their associates would somehow get control of that money, Mr. Schiff has hired lawyers to protect his interests and those of the other fund investors. And despite his ill health he has traveled to Utica to appear in bankruptcy court in the case.
"It's not only to recover my money -- I won't stand for somebody getting away with stealing," he said. "I'm angry the system allowed this to happen."

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 474 words

HEADLINE: More Jobs, Less Security

 BODY:
As America pauses for Labor Day, more people have jobs than ever before and the unemployment rate is close to its lowest level in a generation. At the same time, people are less likely to keep their jobs for long periods, and the level of layoffs is considerably higher than it was in earlier economic cycles. These facts are indicative of a vibrant, competitive economy that provides less security, for either workers or the companies that hire them, than the American economy seemed to offer in decades past.
This lack of security is reflected in numerous ways. Companies are more likely to cut costs quickly in response to competitive pressures than they once were, leading to more layoffs during the current economic recovery, which has endured for eight years, than in previous ones. Deregulation of many industries, from trucking to telecommunications, has led to new patterns of competition in which some companies must shed workers while competitors are hiring. 
 The society has changed to cope with that movement. Pension plans, for example, are more likely to be defined contribution plans, such as 401(k)'s, which can move with a worker, rather than defined benefit plans in which benefits are forfeited if a worker does not stay with a company for at least five years.
That mobility of workers -- sometimes voluntarily through getting better jobs and sometimes involuntarily through layoffs and downsizing -- reflects a worldwide trend. Countries that have accepted it tend to do much better economically than those that have not, although at a cost of increased worker anxiety. Japan is only grudgingly moving away from the lifetime employment policy that damaged the competitiveness of Japanese companies during this decade. Neither Russia nor China has yet dealt adequately with the large state enterprises that have provided employment -- and social services -- for millions but that cannot profitably make products that people want.
For much of the 1980's and 1990's, economic statistics seemed to show that real wages -- what workers make, adjusted for inflation -- had stagnated in this country. Some thought that reflected the declining power of unions -- which now represent about 13 percent of workers, down from a peak of 23 percent -- as well as fears of job loss. The problem may have been overstated, however, because inflation was actually lower than the consumer price index indicated and recent figures show a better picture.
The August unemployment report, released Friday, showed that real wages had risen about 2 percent a year for the past two years. That may not sound like a lot, but it is the largest such gain in a quarter-century. Workers are now benefiting from the combination of a tight domestic labor market and an Asian recession that is holding down the prices of many things people buy.

INTERNATIONAL A3-8
 
Warning of Chaos in Russia Unless Political Fights End
Viktor S. Chernomyrdin warned on national television that Russia has entered a fiscal nosedive and that further political squabbling could lead to social chaos, on the night before Russia's Parliament was to vote again on whether to confirm him as the country's Prime Minister. A1
 
Floods Ravage Bangladesh
More than 20 million homes in Bangladesh have been swamped by monsoon season flooding that has lasted almost two months, twice as long as other recorded floods. The waters have inundated more than half of the country, killed more than 520 people, shut down roads, damaged more than 4,000 schools and wiped out a big portion of the rice crop. A1 

Embassy Bombing Arrests
Investigators have arrested two more suspects in the bombing of the United States Embassy in Tanzania and have made significant progress in determining how the bomb was made and taken to the embassy, Federal Bureau of Investigation and local police officials say. The arrests came in the same week that agents investigating the simultaneous attack on the American Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, began focusing on a Muslim businessman from the Comoros Islands. A3
 
Eternal Leader in North Korea
North Korea announced that it had revised its Constitution to make its former "Great Leader," Kim Il Sung, the country's "eternal President." President Kim's son Kim Jong Il, the country's longtime "Dear Leader," will in effect be head of state, as chairman of the National Defense Commission. The action leaves North Korea without a living President. A5
 
Rice Cost Threatens Indonesia
Experts are warning that the dramatic increase in the price of rice in Indonesia is the biggest threat to stability in the country, as it struggles to regain its political and economic footing. Food riots have already erupted in parts of eastern Java and could spread to major cities like Jakarta. A6
 
I.R.A. Leader on Disarming
Gerry Adams, the leader of the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, said that he could not guarantee that the I.R.A. would agree to disarm during talks in the new Northern Ireland Assembly. But last week, Mr. Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, had emphasized that sectarian warfare was a thing of the past. A8
 
Nonaligned Countries Meet
Delegates from 113 countries held a summit meeting last week in the South African coastal city of Durban. The chief issues the delegates were said to have discussed were not those topping the Clinton-Yeltsin agenda in Moscow; in fact, the Congo war eclipsed planned talks. It was the 12th meeting of the nonaligned movement, founded as a forum for nations that are neither pro-American nor pro-Soviet. A4
 
NATIONAL A9-12
 
Republicans Optimistic About Midterm Elections
As they take to the trail this Labor Day for the traditional opening of the fall campaigns, Republican and Democratic candidates say the Lewinsky matter, a jittery stock market and tumult abroad have thrust them into the most unsettled, and unpredictable, election season in years. The uncertainty has already altered the calculations of Republicans, who say they have the most to gain, particularly from President Clinton's difficulties. By contrast, Democrats find themselves on the defensive. A1
 
Surge in Union Strikes
The recent strikes at Northwest Airlines, General Motors, Bell Atlantic and U S West represent the biggest surge in major walkouts in years and, industrial relations experts say, point to a new aggressiveness on the part of the nation's labor unions. Even though union membership is slipping and the economy is slowing, the experts say, unions have grown bolder because of the tight labor market, more combative union leadership and the teamsters' gains in last year's U.P.S. strike. A12

Hiring Bonuses for Teachers
Long accustomed to being supplicants within the labor force, candidates for public-school teaching jobs -- especially in special education, math and science -- are being put in the decidedly unfamiliar position of being wooed with financial sweeteners. In Baltimore this summer, prospective special education teachers were in such demand that those with just a year's experience were offered the starting salaries of four-year veterans. In Massachusetts, nearly 200 of the promising rookie teachers who apply to work in the commonwealth's schools next year will receive $20,000 signing bonuses. A9

A citizens movement to protest the high price of gasoline has become the hottest political issue in El Paso, drawing in state officials and becoming entangled with a contentious proposal to open a pipeline from the Gulf Coast -- a kind of cavalry charging to the rescue. A9
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8
 
Swissair Flight Recorder Is Found in Nova Scotia
Divers found one of the two flight data recorders from Swissair Flight 111 on a rocky stretch of sea bottom littered with debris and three major pieces of wreckage of the MD-11. The discovery in Peggy's Cove, Nova Scotia, raised hopes that investigators would soon know why the plane crashed offshore last week, killing everyone aboard, after a pilot reported smoke in the cockpit. No additional remains of the 229 victims were identified, nor were large numbers of victims found. But officials were clearly relieved that a Navy diving tender, the Sechelt, had found one of the plane's two "black boxes." The box was brought ashore, where technicians immersed it in fresh water and sealed it for immediate shipment to a Transportation Safety Board laboratory in Ottawa. Also, the medical examiner said that the victims' remains were simply in poor condition and DNA analysis could not be performed on all of the remains, so some would be frozen until lawyers and ethicists could decide what to do. A1

Khallid Abdul Muhammad, the chief organizer of a weekend youth rally in Harlem, was the focus of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's stepped-up defense of police officers who stormed the stage at a the rally on Saturday. The Mayor gave conflicting explanations for the police action. First he said the rally's organizers had flouted a court-ordered deadline for ending the rally. Later he said the police moved in when Mr. Muhammad began inveighing against them. Organizers and community leaders in Harlem accused the city of using excessive force and threatened to sue. A1
 
New Focus on Upstate Voters
In the upper corridors of New York State, these final days before the Sept. 15 primary are treating Democratic voters to the spectacle of three quintessential New York City politicians striving for votes by grasping for ties that stretch beyond the five boroughs and their suburbs. They face a beguiling challenge: how to connect to the voters of western, central and northern New York, who are generally skeptical and often feel as shunted to the margins politically as they are geographically. HEADLINE: Can the Global Economy Really Stabilize Itself?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
If there is a bright side to the recent turmoil in the financial markets, it is the attention focused on the ways in which the United States benefits from a robust world economy. In "Rebound on Wall Street" (editorial, Sept. 2), you recognize that it is important for the United States "to get the world growing again." 
 All of this is welcome relief from the chorus of alarm raised by prominent commentators over the past few years. Ignoring long-established economic principles and empirical data to the contrary, they consider global trade a zero-sum competition among countries and a significant threat to American workers.
If this were true, the demise of our foreign "competitors" in Asia and political instability in Russia would foretell glory days for the United States. The concern with which markets and commentators alike have greeted current developments represents a welcome and overdue reaffirmation of the importance of world economic growth to our domestic economy.
 
KENNETH OBEL
Chicago, Sept. 3, 1998

HEADLINE: Can the Global Economy Really Stabilize Itself?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
There are two key points that Ron Chernow overlooks in "Hard-Charging Bulls and Red Flags" (Op-Ed, Sept. 2). First, no investor on Wall Street loses a nickel until he actually makes the decision to sell his stock. One hundred shares of Exxon remain 100 shares, whatever their value on the current market. 
 Second, the dividends from stocks remain precisely today where they were three months ago (or may even have risen), whatever the trading price. These are powerful reasons to remain committed to one's market holdings.
 
HAYFORD PEIRCE
Tucson, Ariz., Sept. 2, 1998

HEADLINE: Can the Global Economy Really Stabilize Itself?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It is not only "an irony" that "the apparent health of the American economy may end up hurting the world," as you point in your Sept. 2 editorial "Rebound on Wall Street." Tearing down national barriers to capital flight, which is what leads to the kind of "capital starvation" you allude to, is a key and essential tenet of our trade policy. 
 The Multinational Agreement on Investments, an important trade treaty being negotiated in Paris with the full support of the United States, will increase capital mobility to the point where investors in developed nations will have smaller countries by the throat.
In addition to limiting the rights of nations to impose environmental restrictions on foreign investors, including limits on foreign ownership of natural resources or the media, the treaty would have a cumulative effect: placing investors' rights over traditional rights of national sovereignty.
 
SETH BARRON
New York, Sept. 2, 1998

HEADLINE: Can the Global Economy Really Stabilize Itself?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Michael M. Weinstein (Economic Scene, Sept. 3) suggests that stocks rarely steer the economy and that there is no need to lower interest rates because doing so will not help the United States or foreign economies much. He implies that the United States economy will continue to prosper regardless of the stock market or Federal Reserve interest rates. 
 The conclusions are debatable. Since we sell as well as buy products abroad, recession outside the United States is bound to spill over to this country. Furthermore, there is a moral obligation to help our neighbors who have helped us to control inflation by selling us inexpensive products. Lower interest rates can reduce the danger of recession and this relationship applies globally. A few ounces of preventive action now can save pounds of problems for the less fortunate nations and the United States.
 
GEORGE J. KROL
New Haven, Sept. 3, 1998

HEADLINE: Nonaligned Movement Meets, Out of the Spotlight

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 6

 BODY:
Meanwhile, 6,200 miles to the south . . .
While President Clinton, representative of the world's lone superpower, was in Moscow last week bear-hugging Boris N. Yeltsin, master of a former superpower, delegates from 113 countries were holding another summit meeting in the South African coastal city of Durban. 
 It was the 12th meeting of the nonaligned movement, which was founded in 1961, largely at the urging of India, Indonesia and Yugoslavia, as a forum for nations that were neither pro-American nor pro-Soviet and considered themselves the blades of grass that suffer whenever elephants got together in Moscow and Washington.
Naturally, with the cold war past, the week began with reporters pestering them with the same question: "Nonaligned to what?" The summit's diplomats had a ready answer: Nonaligned to a world that still reflects post-World War II and colonialist priorities. Nonaligned to a global economy in which small countries lose their shirts overnight when speculators dump their currency. Nonaligned to a United Nations where the Big Five still have the veto and will risk their soldiers' lives in Bosnia but not in Congo or Rwanda.
As the week went on, the meeting's official agenda was eclipsed by talks about the Congo war. As they ended with no cease-fire and talks about further talks, the focus shifted back to the main nonevent.
The chief issues the delegates were said to be discussing were not those topping the Clinton-Yeltsin agenda in Moscow. They included Congo, American cruise missile attacks on sites in Afghanistan and the Sudan, the switch by India and Pakistan from nonnuclear to nuclear states and Libya's hesitation to send suspects in the Lockerbie plane bombing to the Netherlands for trial.
But one had to take the word of leakers for it. Since most of the nonaligned movement's countries are less than open, reporters were barred from the hall where they were meeting. Instead, reporters sat in rows at a cavernous exhibit hall nearby, watching BBC television on big monitors and trying to arrange interviews with delegates by calling their South African military escorts.
Officials from a few nations deigned to cross the street to speak with the press.
Pierre Buyoya, the President of Burundi, who came to power in a 1996 coup, appeared to plug his new autobiography, "Mission Possible." A Thai diplomat came to endorse a candidate. A Congolese delegation got into a scuffle with a self-proclaimed transition government of Congolese exiles who had sneaked in past security.
The meeting's 514-paragraph final communique was not issued until the midnight after it ended. By then, nearly everyone had left. "We made 300 copies," said Awie Marais, the chief spokesman. "There weren't 30 people left to pick them up."
But there were some serious moments.
Yasir Arafat came to reiterate his intention to declare an independent Palestinian state next May.
The Foreign Minister of the Sudan came early to outline his request that the summit demand a United Nations inspection of the factory destroyed by American cruise missiles to determine whether it produced chemical weapons or pharmaceuticals.
The Foreign Minister, Mustafa O. Ismail, had wanted to show slides of the destruction, but the news conference room had been adorned with potted palms and ficuses, blocking its screens. As Mr. Ismail tried to leave, he was so mobbed by journalists desperate for quotes that he stepped off the dais into the scenery, crushing a pot of chrysanthemums.
For the first time in the nonaligned movement's history, an American team was present to keep an eye on charges like the Sudan's. They were granted "guest" status, one rung down from "observer."
Several diplomats speaking on condition of anonymity said the Americans lobbied in the halls to temper the communique on some issues, such as preventing Iraq from inserting language saying it had fully complied with United Nations weapons inspectors, and asking that Libya give up the Lockerbie suspects.
The Americans also took part in a delicate debate troubling many delegates. The nonaligned movement has long opposed nuclear weaponry, and now two of its leaders, Pakistan and India, have set off bombs. Diplomats said the two wanted language creating a "second tier" of nuclear states, separate from the long-villified bomb-owners, the United States, Russia, France, Britain and China. Other states did not want to condemn India and Pakistan, but wanted to urge them not to "weaponize."
In the final document, many hairs were split.
India and Pakistan were not mentioned. Conferees "noted the complexities arising from nuclear tests in South Asia, which underlined the need to work even harder to achieve their disarmament objectives."
The United States attack on the factory in Sudan was condemned as "unilateral and unwarranted," but no mention was made of inspections, and no judgment made about what was in the plant.
The United States and Britain were urged to keep negotiating with Libya over trial details. The two, in conceding to a trial in the Netherlands, had refused to discuss other concessions.
The no-flight zones over Iraq, enforced by the United States and its allies, were "deplored" and member states were urged to help lift the sanctions, but Iraq was not judged to have earned an end to the sanctions by complying with weapons inspectors.
As always, the summit endorsed clauses championing the Palestinians over Israel and Cuba over the United States.
The summit meeting did slip off the course its South African hosts wanted to steer it on. They wanted a new focus on money, particularly the widening of the gap between rich and poor, the domination of small debtor nations by the the International Monetary Fund and the vulnerability of small countries to raids on their currencies by speculators. The final document mentioned such issues, but did not shift the focus away from politics to economics.
And the most sought-after character at the meeting was a definitely a political figure. President Laurent Kabila of Congo arrived unexpectedly on Wednesday, avoiding being welcomed by Mr. Mandela. He was reported to have demanded the first speaking slot of the 86 reserved for national leaders. Denied it, he borrowed the early slot of an ally, Namibia's President, and spoke about his military problems.
His aides said he would then hold a news conference "somewhere on the street" because the Congolese-exile incident proved that the pressroom was unsafe. Later, word slipped out that he would talk at a nearby Hilton Hotel. He kept reporters waiting for five hours, then tried to slip past them to an elevator. Cornered, he promised elections in six months and left. He departed on a plane at 4 A.M., skipping a breakfast meeting about the war and leaving the summit meeting to muddle on without him.

HEADLINE: Phnom Penh Journal;
High-Minded Machiavelli, or Cambodia's Spoiler

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Sept. 5

 BODY:
"Read this," said Sam Rainsy, leaving the room to dress for a political rally. "A different point of view."
It was a pro-Government newspaper with a front-page editorial that declared: "Mr. Sam Rainsy, the Machiavellian, maverick, opportunistic, selfish, foolish and irresponsible politician, a self-proclaimed opposition leader, must be prosecuted to the full extent of the law." 
 It is a famliar characterization here in a country where Mr. Sam Rainsy, 49, seems intent on keeping the political pot boiling until he can achieve his goals. Not only the Government but also many diplomats see him as a power-hungry spoiler too convinced of his own righteousness to even consider a compromise with his rivals.
Of course, Mr. Sam Rainsy's own view and that of many Cambodians is different. He sees himself, as do many supporters here and abroad, as a democratic idealist who has "lost any illusion about working with rotten people in a rotten system."
He is ready to paralyze the Parliament, to bring down the Government, to force this exhausted and poverty-stricken country into a new round of elections and confrontations if that is what it takes to achieve what he calls a revolution.
"I dream of a modern Cambodia," he said, returning from his bedroom in a clean white shirt. "I have lived more than half my life in Europe and I have spent many months in the United States and I can see the difference between a modern society and a backward society.
"To me, a modern Cambodia means, first, the rule of law. It sounds elementary, but it is crucial. Without that, we just have a feudalistic system of warlords, of people who have guns and money and who are just above the law."
He was clearly referring to the power structure of Hun Sen, who has led the country -- first as a Communist, then as a Prime Minister, then as the leader of a coup -- for most of the last two decades.
"They pretend we have a market economy but I call it a jungle economy," Mr. Sam Rainsy said. "The difference is, there is no legal framework. This is a real revolution because they are powerfully entrenched interests."
Six weeks after a parliamentary election in which his party, the Sam Rainsy Party, finished a distant third, Mr. Sam Rainsy has brought the country to a standstill with a vigorous campaign of protests and rallies and political maneuvers that threaten to block the formation of a new government.
In Cambodian terms, his campaign is already something of a revolution: he is not using guns. Instead, in a style he has perfected over the last few years, some diplomats say he is taunting Mr. Hun Sen's Government to use its guns against him, to discredit itself and make martyrs of him and his followers.
On March 30, 1997, unknown assailants threw four grenades at a rally he was leading in a park, killing 16 people and wounding more than 100. Mr. Sam Rainsy blamed Mr. Hun Sen for the attack; Mr. Hun Sen said Mr. Sam Rainsy himself was behind it.
Now, for the last two weeks, he has led thousands of people in a rambunctious sit-in at the same park, which he has called Democracy Square. Through determination, intelligence, political astuteness and physical courage -- and with the partnership of his wife, Saumura -- Mr. Sam Rainsy has become a powerful political force.
Speaking of him and his wife, who was educated in France, one Western analyst with long experience here said, "They are people who have a zeal and who see themselves as historical figures in a struggle for the future of Cambodia."
Educated in France and Britain, eloquent in three languages, Mr. Sam Rainsy inspires strong feelings of both adulation and mistrust.
He has unsettled many foreigners with the gutter language of his attacks on Mr. Hun Sen and with his diatribes against the Vietnamese minority. A wave of violence has taken the lives of at least five ethnic Vietnamese in the last few days.
Largely because of his efforts, the parliamentary election held on July 26 has produced only political turmoil. In a vote Mr. Sam Rainsy disputes, the election was won by Mr. Hun Sen's Cambodian People's Party, which took 64 of the 122 seats.
In second place, with 43 seats, was the royalist party of Norodom Ranariddh, who was ousted by Mr. Hun Sen in a coup a year earlier from the co-premiership the two men shared. The party of Mr. Sam Rainsy, who had in turn been ousted from the royalist party by Prince Ranariddh in 1995, won 15 seats.
None of the three parties won the two-thirds needed to form a government. Mr. Sam Rainsy has persuaded the Prince to join him in his protests and in his refusal to form the needed coalition with Mr. Hun Sen.
It is not clear that the Prince is as convinced as Mr. Sam Rainsy of this position. But analysts say Mr. Sam Rainsy may have maneuvered him so deeply into his protests that it will be difficult for the Prince to do an about-face and accept pomp and financial rewards of the coalition government Mr. Hun Sen is offering.
Mr. Sam Rainsy may or may not be sincere in the democratic ideals he espouses. But he shares with his two rivals a frank and deep-seated mutual animosity that is more than enough to sustain his campaign against them.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sam Rainsy, besieged by supporters in Phnom Penh last week. He lost the election to the Cambodian People's Party of Hun Sen, but together with the royalists, the other losers, he continues to lead demonstrations. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Asian Markets Surge, Pushed by Japan

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Monday, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Asian markets surged today, with a rise in Japanese shares and the yen helping spark a 7 percent leap in Hong Kong stocks and a 2 percent rise in Australia.
Tokyo, Seoul and Singapore exchanges rose more than 2 percent, while Malaysian shares, whipped about recently by new currency controls and political turmoil, rocketed more than 26 percent. 
 Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index shot up 486.98 points, or 6.50 percent, to 7,975.45 on a firmer yen and lower interest rates after government steps to strengthen its currency-board monetary system. By midday it had surged to 8045.13, up 7.43 percent.
Tokyo stocks ended a volatile morning session sharply higher on technical factors, but the market was still jittery over global financial woes and stalled financial stabilization bills, traders said.
Some said a remark on Friday by the United States Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, that Japan must use public funds to help banks raised hopes for a swift decision by Japan on a fund injection for the banks, helping buying-backs in bank shares.
At midday, the benchmark Nikkei average was up 387.76 points or 2.76 percent at 14,430.67. Early losses on the Nikkei were wiped out by active buying in the futures, aiming to take short-term gains.
The dollar fell more than two yen from an early high to trade at 132.55 yen by mid-morning in Tokyo, traders said.

LENGTH: 1734 words

HEADLINE: An Election Season Shadowed By Crises at Home and Abroad

BYLINE: By Richard L. Berke

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:
As they take to the trail this Labor Day for the traditional opening of the fall campaigns, Republican and Democratic candidates say the Lewinsky matter, a jittery stock market and tumult abroad have thrust them into the most unsettled, and unpredictable, election season in years.
The uncertainty has already altered the calculations of Republicans, who say they have the most to gain, particularly from President Clinton's difficulties. 
 Newly emboldened, Republican officials have revised their earlier predictions of modest gains and now say the party could capture more than a dozen additional seats in the House and, perhaps, even pick up five seats in the Senate. That would hand Republicans the magic 60 votes needed to cut off a filibuster when Democrats try to block a vote.
By contrast, Democrats find themselves on the defensive, and party leaders are lowering their expectations; most have stopped brazenly forecasting that they will retake the House.
"I feel so much better than a couple months ago," said Brent Siegrist, the Republican leader of the Iowa House. "I do think Clinton's troubles help us."
Although Republicans now have the slimmest House majority held by any party in the last half century, few Democratic leaders are upbeat about their party's prospects for retaking the House, and some party candidates are distancing themselves from Mr. Clinton.
"I'm running my own race -- and I don't plan on running any events with him," Ken Lucas, a Democrat who is locked in a tight House race in Kentucky, said of the President. The latest Democrat to spurn Mr. Clinton is Gov. Parris N. Glendening of Maryland, who said he "will not pursue the attendance of the President" as planned for a fund-raising event next month.
Here in Boston, at the annual meeting of the American Political Science Association, the corridor chatter among academics was not about political theory but fresh gossip about the Lewinsky investigation and how it would play out on Election Day. Perhaps a telling piece of evidence was that among the hundreds of academic papers presented, the association ran out of copies for one in particular demand: "Compassion, Political Trust and Public Opinion."
Representative Jim McDermott, a Democrat from Seattle, said the "formless uncertainty" in the electorate may be welcome news for Republicans trying to maintain their 11-seat majority in the House. He suggested that voters may want to keep Republican control of Congress as a check on the turbulence in the White House.
"In many ways, what people want is stability in our Government, which I think bodes well for incumbents," Mr. McDermott said. "I wish they wanted to throw out the Republican majority and bring in Democrats, but I think the uncertainty fosters the stability."
Voter participation in the statewide primaries this year has been the lowest on record, which suggests that turnout in November could be the lowest in history, according to a report by Curtis B. Gans, director of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate. He and other experts said that could bode well for Republicans.
Their hope is that while Democrats will be uninterested, Republicans will be energized by Mr. Clinton's troubles and will eagerly head to the polls to vote against his party.
"It doesn't look like '94, where we had a bump up out of anger," Mr. Gans said. "What you have at this point is disengagement but not profound anger -- except on the Republican right." If conservative voters are motivated by their anger at Mr. Clinton, he said, that would give Republicans an edge in close contests.
Yet for all the theories about depressed Democratic turnout and an excited Republican electorate, polls thus far have not shown any major upheaval in how people expect to vote or broad disaffection with the Democratic Party. Despite signs that Mr. Clinton's personal approval is eroding, his job approval rating remains impressive. And despite Democrats' complaints that the Lewinsky debacle is crowding out their efforts to talk about issues, there is no statistical evidence that Mr. Clinton is dragging down Democratic candidates.
In fact, much of the sense of a changed electoral landscape in both the Republican and Democratic parties is founded on anecdotal evidence. Two weeks ago, Stuart Rothenberg, an independent political analyst, predicted that the Democrats would pick up two or three seats in the House. Now, he says, the Republicans could capture 10 or 15 seats.
Asked to explain his change of heart, Mr. Rothenberg said: "I don't have micro or macro data that shows either a national move or a move in individual races. We're going on gut here. You don't discount gut. But you don't go too far."
Throughout most of this year, politicians in both parties, noting that voters seemed relatively content and disengaged from politics, had forecast a status-quo election, where incumbents would be safe and Republicans would cling to control Congress by roughly the existing margins.
But despite the buoyed spirits among Republicans, there are still two months before Election Day. Politicians around the country say they are bracing for a political hurricane with untold consequences: they know it will hit but they do not know when -- or with what force.
Even so, a big, substantial shift in the makeup of Congress would be a surprise because far fewer than 100 House seats are considered hotly competitive. There are fewer open seats than is traditional and many incumbents face particularly weak rivals this year. A surging economy through much of the year and unusually high approval ratings for Congress discouraged many challengers from running.
Several candidates said the biggest wild card will be the report by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, and it may be issued this month. This is the first time since Watergate in 1974 that a general election campaign has occurred amid a full-scale Presidential crisis. But by Labor Day of 1974, after Richard M. Nixon had resigned from the Presidency, it was already clear to most strategists that Republicans would take a huge hit that November. (Republicans lost 48 seats in the House and five in the Senate.) This year, it is not as clear what the reverberations could be for Democrats.
Candidates also said that the steep downturn -- and partial rebound -- of the stock market last week and the economic and political crisis in Russia starkly reminded them how outside forces could intrude on their carefully laid campaign strategies.
"These developments have changed what was a very placid election season to one that has a lot more uncertainty," said Chris Bayley, a Republican running for Senate from Washington State. "Six months ago everyone assumed that since the economy was good, incumbents would be favored and it would be harder for challengers." Citing the crisis in Asia, he said, "Everybody is much more nervous now."
William Carrick, a veteran Democratic strategist in Los Angeles, put it this way: "I've never seen anything like this -- it's a very, very strange season. We're all analytically groping for what is this election about: Is it a referendum on the President? It doesn't appear to be so. But it's clearly not a referendum on Congress. Then you add in this enormous reluctance by the American public to even get engaged in following the politics of any of this."
Although many Republican candidates said they were uncertain whether to make the Lewinsky matter an issue, several said they now planned to raise the broader topic of trust. The Lewinsky situation also seems to have brought a broader overlay of moral scrutiny to the campaign, and on Friday led to an admission by Representative Dan Burton, an Indiana Republican who is one of the President's most persistent critics. He acknowledged that he is the father of a child born out of wedlock.
"I think every one of us is going to have to run on integrity," said Fay Boozman, a Republican running for the Senate from Arkansas. "I think there is a strong sense of the lack of integrity of elected officials, and the breaking of the public trust by elected officials. Bill Clinton is the headliner of that because he is the President, but it crosses party lines."
Even some Democrats, spurred, perhaps, by the strong rebuke of Mr. Clinton last week by Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, said Mr. Clinton's problems would force them to discuss issues like morality. "Here in this particular race, integrity and taking responsibility for your actions and honesty are big factors," said Mr. Lucas, the Democrat running in Kentucky. "And I think the recent events in Washington are highlighting that."
Yet some Democrats said they feared that all the talk of trust would drown out the discourse about their party's marquee issues like education, overhauling the health care system and preserving Social Security.
"It will distract from the ability of candidates to articulate the issues we think are important," said Jay Inslee, a Democrat seeking a House seat in Washington. "It's kind of like a wreck on the freeway. The traffic going the other way is watching the wreck instead of paying attention to where we're going. It's a distraction."
In fact, many candidates in both parties have felt somewhat neglected as the news media focus their energies less on electoral politics and more on scandal in Washington.
Even the high-profile contests like the race for governor in California and the Senate race in New York have drawn relatively little attention. Contributing to the dilemma for candidates is that, judging by the polls and by interviews with strategists, no single issue seems to be gripping voters.
"They ask about anything under the sun," said Representative Adam Smith, a Democrat from Washington. "But no real issue is grabbing folks."
David Osterberg, a Democrat who is taking on Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, is so frustrated by his failure to draw attention that he is trying a new stunt: paddling across the state in a canoe.
Tom Rath, a longtime Republican strategist in New Hampshire, predicted that rather than energize voters, the Lewinsky matter would make voters even less engaged.
"I just think people want this whole process to go away," he said. "There's a tiredness in the electorate. They don't have the stomach for a highly contested election season."

HEADLINE: Joy. Frustration. Motherhood.

BYLINE: By Leah Hager Cohen; Leah Hager Cohen is the author, most recently, of "Glass, Paper, Beans: Revelations on the Nature and Value of Ordinary Things."

DATELINE: BELMONT, Mass.

 BODY:
The thing that got to my sister was not being able to give either job -- work or parenting -- a hundred percent. This was before she had her fourth child, when she was still a wage earner.
It wasn't that she couldn't handle working the long hours at the office as well as at home, or making the twice-daily transition between roles. What she found intolerable was the feeling that she was constantly shortchanging both her work and her family. It was the parceling out of her energy, and the skimping compromises this forced, that eventually drove her to quit her job. 
 At the time, I was a little aghast. Pregnant with my first child, I was joyously eager to become a mother, yet I couldn't fathom abandoning my own work as a writer. Obviously lots of women don't have the economic luxury to give up their paying jobs, but lots of women also love their work and find the emotional cost of leaving too expensive. My own work: I thought of it that possessively, that absolutely, as some cherished object I might actually hold in cupped hands.
As a child, I spent a fair amount of time fantasizing about different jobs. I wanted to work on a fishing boat, in a pineapple canning plant, on a kibbutz, on Broadway; I wanted to be a piano tuner, a cop, a shoe shiner, a cabdriver, a lady-in-waiting to the queen.
Each occupation was a portal to another aspect of life, and it was somehow my impression that we were supposed to pass through as many of these as we could. At the time, it seemed almost farfetched that I wouldn't eventually work all of these jobs. How else would I learn what life was like? How else would I get to know the people in the world with me?
Slowly it dawned on me I would probably never tune pianos, or can pineapples, or wait on a queen. One by one, these possibilities were jettisoned as I made other choices. Later came motherhood, and with it the curtailing of a whole new set of experiences.
The wildness of that old dream seems ludicrous these days, from the confines of a kitchen filled with spilled cereal and sticky dishes and small children requiring sippy cups and clean diapers and visits up in my arms.
Mothers' work is in a way so circumscribed, our world so narrowed, so diminished. I still do "my own work," but, like my sister, I find it compromised. I do not read the paper. I no longer set out to cross borders, geographical or social. I have less of me to give over to wandering, to forging connections with people outside my daily sphere.
For most of my life, I equated work with journeying, with venturing outward in the world, extending oneself toward the unfamiliar. Now I find myself engaged in work that is by its nature tethering. Mothering entails focusing on that which is small and immediately before us. To the extent that it consumes energy that might otherwise have been spent engaging the world, it makes for a more restrictive, insular existence.
Years ago, at a folk art exhibit, I found myself transfixed before a wonderful quilt -- as I remember, it combined velvet with corduroy with calico, a bold and unapologetic assemblage of fabrics. Next to it, a card bore a homespun quote from the 90-year-old quilter: "I likes to work piecemeal, because something always calls me to get up and do something else."
Women's work has historically been a jumble, a patchwork, a piecemeal affair. Through the work of caring for children I am stretched and exposed, distracted and dazzled. These days I may sit down to write and a small hand will come pulling me down a path I've never seen before. I am learning to love the mishmash, boldly and unapologetically. We cannot help but keep journeying, witnessing, connecting. Life won't allow it, no matter our occupation.

HEADLINE: Take Me Back to the Ballgame!

BYLINE: ALISON ZIMBALIST


HIGHLIGHT: In this lesson, students examine the role of sports in American society, analyzing both positive outcomes and its exclusive nature. Students then reflect on how the lessons that they learn in activities in which they participate as children may carry with them into their adult lives. 

 BODY:
Overview of Lesson Plan: In this lesson, students examine the role of sports in American society, analyzing both positive outcomes and its exclusive nature. Students then reflect on how the lessons that they learn in activities in which they participate as children may carry with them into their adult lives.
Author(s):
Alison Zimbalist, The New York Times Learning Network
Suggested Time Allowance: 40 minutes
Objectives:
Students will: 
1. List positive aspects of participating in extracurricular activities. 
2. Read and discuss "Ex-Little Leaguers: The Boys of Summer Once Really Were Boys." 
3. Analyze the role of sports in American society. 
4. Examine the exclusive nature (in history and today) of sports on local and national levels. 
5. Write a narrative piece that discusses how a favorite activity enjoyed in youth will help shape more successful adults.
Resources / Materials:
pens/pencils 
paper 
classroom blackboard 
copies of "Ex-Little Leaguers: The Boys of Summer Once Really Were Boys"
Activities / Procedures:
1. WARM-UP/ DO-NOW: In the first five minutes of class, students list positive aspects of participating in sports or other extracurricular activities on a piece of paper. They then share their responses while the teacher writes them on the board. Next, ask students to list any negative aspects of participating in sports or other group extracurricular activities; again, the teacher writes them on the board. 
2. Read "Ex-Little Leaguers: The Boys of Summer Once Really Were Boys." Then, discuss answers to the following questions: 
a) On which players did the article focus--the Little League world champions from Toms River, New Jersey or major league players? Why were they the focus of the article? 
b) What were some of the major league players' memories of participating in Little League sports? 
c) What percentage of major league players were once Little Leaguers? How does the article relate the Toms River champs to the major leaguers in the article? 
3. Analyze the role of sports in American society. Why do we see sports stars as heroes? Why do we encourage our children to play sports? Why is there a seeming assumption that everyone loves sports, and how do we react to people who criticize them? How do we regard negative things in which sports heroes become involved (drugs, crimes, Mike Tyson charged for alleged rape, O.J. Simpson accused of murder)? Are we more willing to excuse bad behavior in sports stars than in "average" citizens? 
4. Examine ways in which sports can be exclusive. When baseball originated as a sport, what races of people could not participate? (non-whites) Who changed that? (Jackie Robinson) What about participation by girls and women in sports? What options did girls have when the major leaguers in the article participated in Little League? What options to girls have now? 
5. WRAP-UP/ HOMEWORK: The underlying meaning to the article is that participation in sports (or any other hobby) as a child can teach invaluable life lessons and change people's lives. At the top of a piece of paper, students write the activity that they most enjoy participating in now. Next, students list accomplishments that they have had so far in this activity and specific goals that they would like to reach. They then list all of the positive outcomes of participating in this activity (specific skills related to the activity, interpersonal/social skills developed, intrapersonal skills developed). Finally, students incorporate this list into a narrative piece of writing, discussing how this activity and these skills will be able to help them in their adult lives.
Further Questions for Discussion:
--Why, in our society, is sports such a beloved form of entertainment? 
--Why, in our society, do we view athletes as "heroes"? 
--Do we react differently when athletes commit crimes than we do when "average" people commit them? 
--How have sports historically been exclusive to certain groups of people? How have some of these exclusions changed? What exclusions still remain? 
--How can participation in sports benefit a young player? 
--How might participation in sports be detrimental to a young player? 
--What lessons can participating in sports teach a young player? 
--How can these lessons be transferred to experiences off of the playing field? 
(particularly in the worlds of academics, personal growth, and interpersonal 
relations)
Evaluation / Assessment:
Students will be evaluated based on participation in class discussions and written narrative writing piece.
Vocabulary:
league, counterparts, nostalgically, unabashed, boisterous, discerning, veterans, camaraderie
Extension Activities:
1. Debate the role of money in professional sports. Why are some players "worth" more than others when they are a part of a team? Is this fair? Should there be a limit on how much a player can earn? Why do professional athletes make so much money, and what does this say about the role of sports in American society? (grades 6-12) 
2. Research Jackie Robinson's heroic fight to "break the color barrier" in professional baseball and how he subsequently influenced the world of sports. Locate newspaper articles about him, and discuss them with classmates. (grades 6-12) 
3. Investigate Title IX legislation (which mandates that federal monies allocated to schools must support women's and men's sports equally.) How does your school's athletic program meet or not meet the needs of girls? (grades 8-9, 10-12) 
4. Interview parents, grandparents, and other adults to find out about sports that they played when they were in school. What leagues existed, and how did a person join? What games were most popular? (6-12) 
5. Students can research the origins of a sport commonly played in the United States. Where did it come from? When did the sport originate? How was the sport originally played? What changes and advancements have been made in this sport since its very beginnings? (6-12)
Interdisciplinary Connections:
Math- Trace the statistics of one particular athlete in the course of his or her career thus far. Percentages and graphs can be calculated. Then, each student can write a brief biography of the athlete, along with why he or she is a role model to the student, and create a poster dedicated to the athlete which includes this player's calculated statistics. 
Science- A lesson or unit can be developed around the "physics" of sports. Using baseball as an example, how does the ball's speed, where it hits the bat, and how it is propelled by the bat affect where it lands? How do the curve and speed of a ball being thrown affect the ball's force on the glove of the player who catches it?
Academic Content Standards:
Grades 6-8

Benchmarks: Knows a variety of forms of diversity in American culture; Knows major conflicts in American society have arisen from diversity; Knows basic values and principles that Americans share

Benchmark: Understands that while a group may act, hold beliefs, and/or present itself as a cohesive whole, individual members may hold widely varying beliefs, so the behavior of a group may not be predictable from an understanding of each of its members

Benchmarks: Understands that the context in which something is learned may limit the contexts in which the learning can be used; Knows that human thinking involves the interaction of ideas, and ideas about ideas

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
KEFALIDIS, NIKOS

 BODY:
KEFALIDIS-Nikos. Of Manhattan. On September 2, 1998, aboard Swissair 111. Best friend and beloved husband for 18 years of Laurie. Dearest and devoted father of Melanie (17), Elias (14) and Marisa (8). Loving son of Kerasia and Symeon Kefalidis of Alexandroupolis, Greece. Cherished brother of Chrysanthos Kefalidis of Athens and Efthimia Melidis of Alexandroupolis. Caring uncle of four nephews. Nikos spent the first nine years of his life with his family in Alexandroupolis, Greece, his birthplace. He then attended Anavryta College, a boarding school near Athens, as a scholarship student. He later studied at the University of Athens, graduating with a degree in economics. In 1970, he immigrated to the United States and became a U.S. citizen several years later. As founder and President of KLM Construction, Inc., he developed residential and commercial real estate projects throughout New York City. In 1989, he was instrumental in founding Beta Steel Corp., a privately held steel mill in Portage, Indiana, of which he was Chairman of the Board of Directors. In addition to his business ventures, Nikos was active in numerous community, political and religious organizations. He was appointed a member of the Democratic National Committee in 1994. He served on the Archdiocesan Council of the Greek Orthodox Church in the Americas and as Vice President of the Board of Trustees of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York City. A Memorial Service will be held at The Cathedral, 319 East 74th Street (between 1st and 2nd Avenues) on Tuesday, September 8, 1998 at 6 PM, with His Eminence, Archbishop Iakovos presiding. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory either to The Greek Children's Fund at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021, or to The Dalton School Scholarship Fund, 108 East 89th Street, New York, New York 10128.
KEFALIDIS-Nikos/d. You had bestowed upon me your kindness and trust. To you, I always look as a mentor, role model and source of inspiration. In my heart, I will carry the flame of your soul for the rest of my life. Hesky Brahimy.
KEFALIDIS-Nikos. Laurie, Melanie, Elias, and Marisa, you were Nikos' joy of life. Nikos lived for you and lives in you. We are completely heartbroken for you and sharing your grief. We love you. Hesky and Sholeh Brahimy
KEFALIDIS-Nikos. The directors and employees of Beta Steel Corp. of Portage, Indiana express their own deep sorrow while extending profound sympathy to the entire Kefalidis family on the untimely death of our founder, Chairman of the Board of Directors and indomitable helmsman. Through times both good and bad, his vision, wisdom and compassion provided us with the courage to do the right thing, as well as the strength to endure and overcome misfortune. He stood by all of us, supporting and encouraging us, more than just as an employer, but as a genuine friend. His door would always open, in response to our knock for every single need, whether personal or professional. We mourn the loss of an exceptional leader, a dedicated executive, a loyal friend and-in every sense of the definition-a "good man."
KEFALIDIS-Nikos. The Dean, Board of Trustees and community of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan and Cathedral of the Holy Trinity mourn the tragic loss of our beloved friend, colleague, Trustee & Vice President, Nikos Kefalidis. His generosity of spirit, warm smile & commitment to his church and the community will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Laurie, children, Melanie, Elias and Marisa, his parents, brother, sister and nephews. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, at Holy Trinity Cathedral, 319 East 74th Street, at 6 PM. Presiding will be his Eminence Archbishop Iakovos. "May his memory be eternal." Rev. Dr. Robert Stephanopoulos, Dean

We are privileged to have worked with this honorable, talented and compassionate man, often throughout the nights, on dynamic and creative projects. We will remember Nikos for embracing life, for his unending energy and for his fierce dedication to his family and to his community. We will miss him. We extend our heartfelt and deepest sympathy to his wife Laurie and their children Melanie, Elias and Marisa.

He touched us all with his dedication to humanitarian and spiritual values and especially his devotion to his beloved family. Nikos will be truly missed. Our hearts and prayers go out to his wife, Laurie, and to his children, Melanie, Elias and Marisa. John and Eva Fondrier Athens, Greece

Our lives have forever been enriched by his kindness and humanity. His spirit will remain in our hearts. Laurie, Melanie, Elias and Marisa, we love you. Joanna and Bob
