PUB-DATE: September 8, 1998

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1823 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Bankruptcy The Asian Way;
No Sinking, No Swimming, Just Floating Face Down

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: SAPPORO, Japan

 BODY:
No business failure in Japan has been more traumatic than that of Hokkaido Takushoku Bank, one of the nation's biggest financial institutions. Its collapse last year sent the entire financial system into a tailspin and set off alarm bells that are still ringing in markets worldwide.
But now, take a walk inside the marble-pillared, wood-paneled halls of the bank's headquarters here on the northern island of Hokkaido. On a recent morning, more than 120 customers bustled about, making deposits and withdrawals. 
 It is not that the bank rose like a phoenix from the ashes. It just never burned up. After announcing that the bank had failed, the Government plugged it into a life-support system, and nothing really changed. It will be acquired soon by another institution, but many of its money-losing operations could continue indefinitely under another name.
Something similar is happening throughout Asia: corporations are "failing" in record numbers, but many keep on going anyway. As a result, the feeble are not eliminated, the fat is not trimmed, and the region's long-term prospects suffer.
A common refrain among Westerners is that there should be more out-and-out business failure in Asia. "Capitalism without bankruptcy is like Christianity without hell" is a line heard regularly.
But governments and legal systems routinely protect tycoons from their own incompetence, setting the stage not for a Darwinian struggle but for survival of the flimsiest.
"Just about every country has problems of this kind" in Asia, said Rajeev Malik, regional economist at Jardine Fleming International Securities Ltd. in Singapore.
Not that it is totally sink or swim in the United States; the Government did help rescue the Chrysler Corporation in 1979. And when an American bank fails, regulators try to broker a rapid transfer of ownership so that the old bank may close its doors on a Friday and reopen on Monday with a new name, and the customers barely perceive a change.
While under bankruptcy protection, American companies can dismiss workers fairly easily and radically reshape themselves. They might reappear stronger and more efficient, or they might be broken up and sold. But in Asia, big companies often hang on until they simply expire in a cloud of debt, rather than liquidate themselves or file for bankruptcy protection to restructure. In most countries here, the legal framework for bankruptcy is vague and loosely formed, management is given little protection against creditors, and there is rarely any thoroughgoing change. In countries that have known little but expansion for four decades, the idea of layoffs or dragging dirty linen through the courts makes banks and companies highly uncomfortable about bankruptcy.
"It's a real challenge," said Oh Soo Geun, a law professor at Inha University in South Korea. Insolvent conglomerates, particularly in South Korea, he said, "are really too big to kill."
So while large companies in Asia may become insolvent, or cannot keep operating without help, they tend not to file for bankruptcy. Indeed, the executives of such companies may not know how badly off they are, and many simply choose to pretend that little has changed.
Governments, fearful of economic chaos, frequently approve. So failed companies hang on in corporate limbo, neither collapsing nor expanding, and relying on government handouts and good luck.
To be sure, Asia has seen bankruptcies for years, with the number soaring in the last year. But formal bankruptcies have mostly been at small and medium-sized companies, while corporate giants generally manage to hang on.
Governments are understandably loath to shut down insolvent or cash-squeezed banks, for fear of provoking chaos in the financial system. Washington stepped in when the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company failed in 1984.
But economists cite several reasons failed companies should, in general, be formally put to rest.
First, the disappearance of bad companies takes overcapacity out of the system and improves the prospects of better-managed companies.
Second, without having to face a day of reckoning, companies and financial institutions might take foolish risks. If they bet right, they know, they will prosper; if they bet wrong, they will still muddle through.
Third, in a market economy, bankruptcy is the consequence of mismanagement. Without companies and banks going out of business, no valid threat exists to encourage prudent practices.
Still, this logic might not convince workers at failing companies in Asia, particularly these days, when there are no other jobs to be had and no safety net available. So in Japan, since the failure of Hokkaido Takushoku, the Government has suggested on several occasions that no more big banks will be allowed to fail.
In South Korea, the Government not only declared a moratorium on large-scale bankruptcies but also basically forced banks to lend good money after bad to save some feeble conglomerates.
So workers are as busy as ever at Kia Motors, which officially failed in the fall, but was not put into bankruptcy. Earlier this year, Kia introduced two new cars, including a van, called the Carnival, which has become a national hit. It certainly did not hurt sales that the company appealed to the patriotic spirit of consumers in its advertising.
The company, with assets worth more than $6 billion, keeps making cars with support from its main banks and the Government. Kia is unusual in that it still has value, although an effort to auction the company failed after the four bidders did not satisfy the Government's conditions for the sale.
Korea First Bank and Seoul Bank, both teetering, have been judged too big to fail or to file for bankruptcy, so they, too, are being supported by the Government and put up for auction.
One big problem in Asia is that bankruptcy rules are so harsh -- far harsher than in the United States -- that companies do anything to avoid the process. In Japan and Korea, when a corporation files for bankruptcy, the rules require that management be dismissed, the court appoints a trustee management and there is no automatic protection from creditors, so entrenched managements have little interest in taking this route.
In the United States, since managers are allowed to stay, weak companies often turn to bankruptcy to avoid creditors and regroup.
Southeast Asia is also facing challenges. While failed companies may go out of business and dismiss employees, there is no smooth procedure to protect creditors and iron out their claims or to parcel out a bankrupt concern's remaining assets. All this aggravates the bad-debt mess at the banks.
In Indonesia and Thailand, banks have not disclosed the full extent of their bad debts, making it hard to assess the risk of their insolvency. Thailand, for instance, though it shut down most of the country's rickety finance companies, nationalized four commercial banks that were technically insolvent. Still, it is trying to rejigger its bankruptcy rules.
"Bankruptcy law is a big issue," said Peter Sikora, an analyst at Standard & Poor's in Melbourne, Australia.
One sticky issue is that in the West it is still generally accepted that the rights of creditors and shareholders should prevail. There is no such view in much of Asia.
Take Sanyo Securities, which in November filed for reorganization, a last attempt to save the company and avoid bankruptcy. Shareholders will be huge losers, but the court-appointed trustee kept workers on the payroll and tried -- unsuccessfully -- to find a buyer so that the company could avoid liquidation.
So shareholders were watching as the company's brand name was offered free, in hopes that a buyer would retain employees. As was hoped, many workers found new jobs, so the number remaining has fallen to 900 from 2,300.
 Sanyo said on Aug. 31 that in September it would keep only 200 workers to help liquidate the company.
One reason the Government arranged for North Pacific Bank to take over Hokkaido Takushoku Bank, often called Takugin, instead of letting it go out of business, was to preserve the jobs of its 5,700 employees. The case offers insight into how failures are likely to be handled in the future.
"We are taking over most of Takugin's employees," said Masanao Takei, president of North Pacific Bank. "There will be no job problem."
Takugin failed because of a liquidity squeeze and because it simply lost credibility in the interbank market, the lifeblood of the financial system. While it never filed for bankruptcy -- the Finance Ministry issued a one-page order to improve business -- the failure provoked the collapse of some of Hokkaido's biggest companies and helped sink the entire island's economy.
So the Government tried to save the pieces. On a breezy Saturday last fall, Mr. Takei got an urgent call from the Finance Ministry. Standing in the hall of The Hokkaido Daily newspaper, where he was attending a seminar, Mr. Takei was asked for the first time if his tiny bank would take over this city's largest, but sickest, private institution, with 5,700 employees. And the official on the line stressed that he would like an answer as soon as possible.
Mr. Takei left the newspaper building, rushed to his office and met with two aides for nearly five hours to thrash out the risks and opportunities and to formulate counterproposals and demands. He could only guess at how bad the bank's problems were. (The Finance Ministry "wouldn't tell us," he said, adding, "I don't think they would tell us such matters until we answered yes." )
At about 7 o'clock that evening, Mr. Takei called in his decision: Yes, but he would not take the bad loans. Two days later, the Finance Ministry announced that Hokkaido Takushoku had failed, and the banking system descended into a shaky meltdown for a few months.
"We made the decision to avoid chaos and confusion in the local economy," Mr. Takei said. "What we are doing now is a test case for all of Japan."
Indeed, it has been. The tiny North Pacific, with only $15 billion in assets, will be swallowing Takugin, the nation's 20th-largest bank, with 10 trillion yen ($76 billion) in assets.
Paradoxically, the announcement that Takugin had failed suddenly made it more reliable. Now customers are at least sure that a healthy institution is taking it over and that its deposits are guaranteed, while they have no such assurances about banks that have not failed.
The bank is still the local government's paying agent, and many depositors, like Kazuko Horii, are rallying behind it. "My ordinary account here is just like my purse," said Mrs. Horii, 61, who was at the bank with a friend, Sachiko Yoneta. "Other banks are facing similar dangers, and the Japanese Government policy is that North Pacific Bank will take over this bank. So, if you compare the two situations, I think this bank is better."

HEADLINE: Tourism Thrives, but Portfolio Jitters Could Quiet the Boom

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
The summer travel season ended yesterday with expectations that it had set another record and with forecasts of record tourism again this fall.
The nonprofit Travel Industry Association of America had estimated that Americans would take 251 million trips this summer, 3 percent more than last year, and it has predicted a record 196 million travelers this fall, a 5 percent increase over last fall. 
 But while the association's forecasts have generally been close, since they take travel intentions as their measure of the likelihood of travel, those intentions are unusually iffy now, given the unpredictability of the economy, the unreliability of the weather and the fickleness of would-be travelers.
So projections for fall travel may be shaken by the same uncertainty that bedeviled this summer's travel plans. Who, for example, could have foreseen the Northwest Airlines strike, which has affected about 150,000 passengers a day, including many would-be tourists, since it began two weeks ago? Or who could have predicted the recent stock market slide?
The Wall Street selloff could play a big role in fall travel. Tourism in the autumn depends heavily on retirees and other older people who prefer to travel then, when there are fewer crowds and lower prices than in the summer, but who also pay particularly close attention to swings in the market.
While the Travel Industry Association has found a steady increase over four years in the number of people who say they intend to take children with them on vacation in the fall (40 percent this year), it has also found that travelers planning to take the longest trips this fall will be ages 65 or older (15 nights average) and retired (14 nights).
While 41 percent of respondents to the poll said they expected to spend less than $500 each on fall pleasure trips, people on their longest trips of the season planned to spend an average of $871. But those averages appear likely to dwindle if travelers' stock portfolios continue to decline.
Meantime, many cities and states had either a record or a robust summer season, the result of a strong economy, low gasoline prices and generally favorable weather.
Cape Cod, for example, had a "great summer," according to the Falmouth Chamber of Commerce, helped by an influx of European visitors. The $51 million in July room rental revenues in Ocean City, Md., topped last year's July revenues by almost 10 percent and exceeded the previous July record of $48 million, set in 1995. Unseasonably warm weather beginning in April is expected to lead Michigan to report a record number of summer visitors, while similar good weather helped fill Minnesota's hotels, resorts and campgrounds, and, tourism officials say, is likely to continue well into the fall. Visitors to Connecticut this summer helped that state take in $2.3 million more in hotel taxes than it collected last summer.
The Carolinas also attracted plenty of tourists this summer, at least until Hurricane Bonnie forced the evacuation of visitors along with residents late last month. An estimated 120,000 of the 200,000 people ordered to leave the coastal areas of Horry and Georgetown counties in South Carolina were tourists, according to Governor David Beasley. North Carolina officials estimated that the hurricane inflicted more than $1 billion in damage along the coast and cost the state millions more in lost tourism revenue.
Although Hurricane Earl pounded Florida's Gulf Coast last week, doing substantial damage, it departed before the crucial Labor Day weekend.
Texas tourism, second in size only to that of California, had to cope with sweltering heat in the Dallas area last month as well as forest fires in Mexico earlier this summer that created smog conditions and led to a statewide health alert.
Like the smoke from Mexico's fires, the effects of Asia's economic crisis were felt inside United States borders. Hardest hit was Hawaii, which managed to attract 26,670 more visitors from the United States mainland during June and July than it did in those months last year, but lost 51,540 visitors from Asia (mostly Japan) over the same months of comparison. August figures are not expected to show any improvement.
California also felt the effects of the Asian downturn, as did even Las Vegas, Nev. -- although after it doubled its advertising budget for the summer, to $5 million, the number of visitors in May rose 1.3 percent over those last May, while June's visitor figures rose 1.1 percent over those of the previous June. Preliminary figures for July, which have not yet been compiled, indicate a further gain over 1997, which itself saw a record 30.5 million visitors.
"Those were pretty modest increases," acknowledged Rob Powers, public relations director for the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority, "but they marked a turnaround from the first quarter of this year, when visitation was down a couple of percentage points." His tone made it clear that in a city with 106,000 hotel beds to fill each night, soon to rise to 126,000, even modest increases are welcome.

HEADLINE: Greenspan's Words Taken For Golden

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
With markets tumbling and economies crumbling at an alarming pace, investors and governments around the world were looking for a lifeline from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, when he spoke in California on Friday night, and Mr. Greenspan gave it to them.
His suggestion that the Fed might have to consider cutting interest rates if the global financial crisis continued to worsen -- as vague and conditional as his statement was -- was seized on by investors in Asia, Europe and Latin America today as a possible sign that Mr. Greenspan was preparing to ride to the rescue. 
 Although other reasons contributed to a rally by stocks overseas, Mr. Greenspan's remarks were considered an underlying cause.
In Japan, the stock market was up 5.3 percent. In Hong Kong, the rise was 7.9 percent. London stocks jumped 3.5 percent, and in Latin America, where markets last week were almost in free fall, stocks posted big gains in all the major markets that were open, including Mexico's and Argentina's.
The buying could well continue on Tuesday when Wall Street returns to work after the three-day holiday weekend. Any rate cut by the Fed, after all, would be protection against recession and a downturn in corporate profits at home, and it would make stocks a bit more attractive relative to bonds.
But it is an open question whether Mr. Greenspan can halt or even slow the spread of the crisis. With the domestic economy still growing at a robust pace, there is no guarantee that the Fed will reduce rates anytime soon. And even if the Fed did ease monetary policy in the United States, that would not by itself solve the problems underlying the global crisis, especially the lack of political will in many countries to take the tough economic and financial steps necessary to restore confidence.
Mr. Greenspan may be the world's most influential economic policy maker, but even he does not have the tools to solve single-handedly a crisis that has spread from Thailand throughout Asia, into Russia and in recent weeks into Latin America.
Indeed, just after speaking at the University of California at Berkeley on Friday night, Mr. Greenspan joined Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin in trying over dinner in San Francisco -- with no apparent success -- to impress upon Japan's new Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, the need for Japan to take quick, bold action to strengthen its banking system and reawaken its economy.
Yet markets around the world seemed to shrug that off, at least for today. Japan's willingness to get its powerful economic machine running again, however, is likely to prove far more important in determining the course of Asia and the prospects for global recession or recovery than any change in policy by the Fed.
"I don't know why the markets' enthusiasm for the possibility of a Fed easing would outweigh despair about the lack of immediate urgency among Japanese policy makers," said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities.
In the same way, the markets gave short shrift to the continuing political turmoil in Russia, where the lower house of Parliament today again rejected President Boris N. Yeltsin's choice for prime minister. Russia is not a global economic force, and many of its problems are all its own, but more politicians in many countries share, in varying degrees, its unwillingness to toe the line dictated by the impersonal and unaccountable forces of market-based capitalism.
Even where governments have taken their medicine, as in Thailand or to a lesser extent South Korea, the process of rebuilding banking systems and inefficient, uncompetitive industries will take years.
"The Fed can't do anything for Russia," Mr. Levy said. "It can't do anything for Japan. It can soothe the markets, but it can't address the underlying problems."
It is not that a Fed easing of interest rates would not have positive ramifications for economies struggling to keep the crisis from swamping them. Reducing rates in the United States would help nudge investors to think about sending their money elsewhere in search of higher returns, perhaps helping to reverse the flood of money from abroad that has swept into the United States in search of a safe haven.
A rate reduction by the Fed could also help persuade the European central banks to join in with rate cuts of their own, helping bring down the interest rate structure worldwide. Lower rates around the globe would take some of the strain off the growing number of governments that are fighting to roll over public debt, help banks and other financial institutions and stimulate economies that have stalled or slipped into recession.
"I would not underestimate the influence that Greenspan and the Fed can have," said C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
Mr. Bergsten said Mr. Greenspan could also assure the world that the crisis was not unfolding in a total policy and political vacuum, with governments seen as weak and international institutions like the International Monetary Fund running out of money and under fire as ineffective.
"A rate cut by the Fed could be fairly sizable," Mr. Bergsten said. "It might be magnified by concerted action from Europe. And it signals that somebody is in charge and providing leadership, which has been a sorely missed variable. It may be that leadership has to come from the central banks."
Still, before cutting short-term interest rates by any significant amount in the United States -- the Federal funds target rate has been 5.5 percent for nearly a year and a half -- members of the Fed would have to agree that the domestic economy is threatened by the global crisis so much so that inflation is no longer a threat.
Mr. Greenspan appeared to ally himself with those who think the United States could feel the impact of the crisis more directly in coming months, saying on Friday night that it is "just not credible that the United States can remain an oasis of prosperity."
But a contingent within the central bank has been openly fretful that wage and price pressures are building in the United States economy. Although that contingent has given up pushing for a rate increase, it is unclear whether Mr. Greenspan, who prefers to avoid splits within the policy-making Open Market Committee, has the ammunition or the inclination to push through a rate increase at the next Fed meeting, on Sept. 29.
In his speech on Friday night, Mr. Greenspan mused at various points on the various crosscurrents facing the Fed.
He restated his belief that price stability, or at least significant progress toward it, is necessary to bring down interest rates and increase business and consumer confidence -- prerequisites to investments that yield increased productivity and higher living standards.
Yet he also referred bluntly to fears of a general fall in asset and product prices. "Presumably, the onset of deflation, should it occur, would increase uncertainty as much as a re-emergence of inflation concerns," he said.

HEADLINE: American Fashion Tries to Get a Jump on Europeans

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE C. R. WHITE 

 BODY:
For nearly 30 years, American fashion designers have presented their twice-yearly runway collections at the tail end of a month of shows in the fashion capitals of Europe. And for just as long, American designers have groused about getting short shrift -- their creativity underappreciated, their businesses thwarted by their last-to-the-market schedule.
Now, a revolution is taking place in the global fashion order. Americans are preparing to stage their women's wear shows, which showcase garments for retailers and the press, ahead of the rest of the world. 
 A renegade band of New York-based designers led by Calvin Klein, Donna Karan, Helmut Lang, Nicole Miller and Vivienne Tam will present their spring 1999 collections in various locations around the city starting on Monday, getting a jump on the European collections scheduled for September and October in London, Milan and Paris.
"The people who are serious about the business have wanted this to happen for some time," Mr. Klein said. "It's a great thing for American fashion."
The Americans expect that the scrambling of the calendar will help them expand their businesses by allowing them to get their clothes into stores more quickly. "Everyone wants earlier and earlier deliveries," Ms. Karan said. "The old system wasn't making sense."
There is also a significant intangible benefit to the move. Americans -- often cast in the role of Rodney Dangerfields on the global fashion stage, hungry for respect -- hope to prove once and for all that they are creative leaders as adept at setting trends as Europeans like Giorgio Armani and John Galliano. "Certainly, this will be a situation where they can't say that anymore -- that Americans are copying," Ms. Miller said.
Although no one can put a figure on how much money is likely to flow from stores into designers' coffers as a result of the earlier shows, retailers acknowledge the potential economic and psychic benefits of being first on the global schedule.
"What I hope it will prove is that Americans are creative on their own and not look like they're copying Italians or the French," said Peter Marx, vice president of Saks Jandel, which owns five designer stores in the Washington area.
Ann Stordahl, senior vice president for Neiman Marcus, said: "Emotionally, it will be exciting to see the Americans go first." But she added: "If that's the impetus for doing this -- if it's ego driven, that's discouraging. This is causing some very big changes in how we organize our travel."
Many designers are unapologetic that the move will enhance the reputation of Americans as mavericks. Mr. Klein, Ms. Karan and Ralph Lauren are among those who have been stung by criticism that their clothes looked too derivative of Europeans. But designers play down the move as a bid to establish creative supremacy; first and foremost, they say, it is a necessary adjustment to a business that has increasingly become global.
"The advantage is that we will be able to go into production much earlier," Mr. Klein said. "I as a designer who now has a global business had to have collections ready earlier. It's from the business point of view that this really makes sense. It gets misinterpreted when people think it's designer egos. Egos are not what it's about."
About two dozen designers are preparing to present their spring collections next week. A larger group, including Oscar de la Renta and Mr. Lauren, will stage shows as originally planned, after the Europeans, from Oct. 30 to Nov. 6 in tents in Bryant Park. They will be under the aegis of Seventh on Sixth, the show-production arm of the Council of Fashion Designers of America. For the following season, the entire slate of Americans will show in February, ahead of the Europeans. The tentative dates are Feb. 14 to 19.
This shift will mean a calendar of spring shows in September instead of in early November, and fall shows in February rather than in April.
What do European designers make of this American revolt? Didier Grumbach, president of the Federation de la Couture, the French organization of designers, said he would urge young French designers to present their fall 1999 collections, on or off the runway, in January, ahead of the new New York shows. The move, he said, was already afoot. "It will happen because it's what all the young houses must do," Mr. Grumbach said. "The actual system is the worst of all. It kills the new designers because no one knows who created what. The one who copied delivers before the one who invents. The only way is to take their orders in January."
In New York, the switch has sent a frisson of excitement and jitters up the industry's glamorous spine. "In the beginning I was a bit frightened," Ms. Tam said. "I said, 'How am I going to get everything ready?' I'm going to work late and make it happen because in the long run it will be good. It will take one or two seasons to get it smooth."
John Bartlett, who is in Italy this week preparing for the February show, plans to return his women's and men's collections to New York in February. It was a blow when Mr. Bartlett, one of the most exciting American designers of the last three years, moved his shows to Milan after signing an agreement with Genny S.p.A., an Italian fashion house. Mr. Bartlett said orders from European and Asian retailers exploded after he began introducing his line in Italy. He now gets 50 percent of his orders from abroad.
When he showed in New York, he said, too often retailers would come to his showroom with empty pockets and flagging spirits. "What we found, the way the New York stores are now, and the reason we showed in Milan, is that when stores come in, they've spent all their money," Mr. Bartlett said. When they did order, it was so late -- just three months before the clothes were scheduled to hit the selling floor, compared with five months for European orders -- that there was a pell-mell rush to get clothes into stores.
For stores, an earlier runway date allows earlier deliveries, and earlier deliveries mean a longer sales season. "The bottom line is getting the clothes into stores early," Mr. Bartlett said. "First in, first out."
At this point, retailers aren't promising to open their wallets wider just because they see Americans first; but most agree that retail business could be spurred by earlier deliveries. "I don't know if I'll buy more," said Michael Gould, the chairman of Bloomingdale's, which does about 70 percent of its business with American designers. "But if earlier shows help get the clothes into the store on time -- say, by Aug. 30 for fall merchandise, it's great."
In the case of big stores and big designers, the earlier schedule may actually have little impact on the size of orders. Stores like Neiman Marcus sometimes write 40 to 60 percent of their order a full two months before the show, especially from names like Calvin Klein, Ralph Lauren and Donna Karan. They are given designated store space that must be filled, said Ms. Stordahl of Neiman Marcus, who is senior vice president and general merchandise manager for women's apparel.
How well a collection sold the previous season is as powerful a factor in the size of an order as what a designer puts on the runway, retailers said.
Business considerations aside, switching to earlier show dates presents Americans with a chance to throw off the yoke of appearing unduly influenced by Europeans. Mr. Klein, in particular, has sometimes been criticized for showing clothes that were derivative of the minimalist stylings of Mr. Lang, an Austrian who moved his business from Vienna to New York last January.
Asked to respond to the criticism, Mr. Klein said: "American fashion has had an impact around the world, and we don't get credit for it because they show first. Now people will see the influence of Americans. It will be easier to put what we do in its proper context."
Paradoxically, it was Mr. Lang, the New York newcomer, who initiated the schedule upheaval when he announced this summer that he would show in September. Having staged his runway shows in Paris for some six years, Mr. Lang was used to presenting his line earlier than the old American calendar allowed. He would likely have remained an aberration had Mr. Klein not announced the very next day that he, too, would show in September.
Soon the situation snowballed, with more than a dozen designers saying they would also show two months earlier. The unified shows in Bryant Park were in danger of collapsing, with some designers showing in September and the remainder in November. Seventh on Sixth quickly polled designers to find out whether they wanted to move dates. The answer, while not unanimous, was yes.
Why American designers continue to be viewed as inferior by some retailers, journalists and customers is a mystery. Fifty years ago, American stores and designers did diligently and openly copy the French, then considered global style leaders. But much has changed. Many fashion insiders have long considered Americans leaders, not imitators.
"It's funny when people say Calvin is influenced by someone else, because no one has had more of an influence than Calvin or Ralph Lauren, who influence everybody in the world," said Robert Duffy, partner of the designer Marc Jacobs and an executive at Louis Vuitton.
British editors travel to New York to see Tommy Hilfiger's show and gather the latest information on sneakers; hip-hop style is considered cutting edge in cities around the world, and the idea of simple, comfortable dressing advanced by American life and stores like the Gap are the template for modern dress.
Some fashion insiders wonder if, by showing so much earlier, American designers might unintentionally undermine the very respect for creativity they crave. There is concern that designing clothes almost a year before they are to be worn may stunt designers' creativity.
The new schedule of women's shows will have a domino effect on the industry. The New York fall men's shows, typically held in February, may now be moved earlier, said Fern Mallis, executive director of Seventh on Sixth. This month, designers must already begin selecting fabrics, arranging production schedules and sketching styles for next February -- tasks most are used to doing in November. There will be no Christmas vacation in Cape Town this year, as Mr. Bartlett had planned.
The change is particularly hard on American designers like Mr. Bartlett, Mr. Jacobs, Mr. de la Renta and Michael Kors, who design their own collections as well as European lines. "It's going to be a nightmare from a design standpoint," Mr. Duffy said. "For the design staff there'll be no Christmas, no New Year. They won't be happy. My production staff is delighted. They get more time to work on the collection."

HEADLINE: In Bellwether District, Clues to Lewinsky's Impact

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Representative Ted Strickland sat in the back seat of the Ford Explorer, with its air-conditioner set up high, waiting for the start of the River Days parade, which has been the highlight of the Labor Day weekend in this Ohio River town as long as anyone can remember.
"In a normal year," he said, "I would have had two or three months of hand-to-hand combat by now, but so far this year, there's been almost no campaign. I spent most of my time this summer doing Congressional work." 
 Mr. Strickland, a 57-year-old Democrat, won his seat in 1992 on his fourth try. He lost it in 1994, then took it back in 1996. Each of the last three races has been a gasper, with the winner taking 51 percent, the loser 49, making this district, the Ohio Sixth, something of a national bellwether. Presidential races have been close, too, with George Bush winning by 2,720 votes in 1992 and Bill Clinton by only 4,488 in 1996.
This is precisely the kind of district that the Republicans would like to take to pad their uncomfortably narrow majority of 21 in the House of Representatives, and the Democrats need to hold onto if they are to have a chance of winning a majority of their own.
The race here has an additional significance as well. This is also the kind of religious, straitlaced district both parties will watch to measure the import of President Clinton's relationship with the former intern Monica S. Lewinsky.
Thus far, there are few overt signs that the Lewinsky matter will bedevil Mr. Strickland, although there is enough unease that he and other Democrats are willing to openly scold a President of their own party before Election Day.
At this stage in the campaign, at least, local issues are the dominant concern. But the flames of partisan passion have not truly begun burning here in the rolling hills of the Sixth, a lovely if economically forlorn region stretching east along the river from the exurbs of Cincinnati for more than 150 miles to Marietta, the oldest town in the Midwest, which was founded in 1788. People are talking about the heat -- it was over 100 degrees this weekend -- and not about the campaign.
Lieut. Gov. Nancy Hollister, 48, the Republican nominee, is a more than presentable candidate, a moderate, a supporter of limited abortion rights, with roots in the region.
But Ms. Hollister had to fight a nasty primary against four more socially conservative rivals, including Frank A. Cremeans, who beat Mr. Strickland in 1994 and lost to him in 1996. That emptied her campaign treasury. After a summer of fund-raising, she has only about $200,000 on hand, but Mr. Strickland has more than twice that.
Ms. Hollister trails in the polls, by as much as 10 points in one, by a smaller margin in others. Both candidates expect a tight finish.
"I always run as if I'm a thousand votes behind," she said in an interview this afternoon, sitting cross-legged on the floor of her Marietta living room. "All I have to do is convince people that the less government, the better. My opponent tries to dip into the Federal goodies bag for the district, but I would deliver Federal dollars directly to the localities for them to spend."
The two candidates disagree on how to reform school financing after a court decision declaring the present system unconstitutional. They talk about jobs, which have been a problem hereabouts for decades; Portsmouth alone has lost shoe factories and a steel mill, and with them half its population. The median family income is the lowest in the state, at $21,761 a year.
But what of Mr. Clinton and Ms. Lewinsky?
Some Ohio Democrats, including Mr. Strickland, have openly criticized the President. Representative Marcy Kaptur of Toledo denounced him in a speech last week for having dragged the nation and his family through "a year of deceitful melodrama" and told The Cleveland Plain Dealer that even resignation would not constitute adequate atonement. More subtly, Mary Boyle, the party's Senate candidate, produced a video that showed her with Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator John Glenn, whom she hopes to succeed, but not with Mr. Clinton.
"I like this man personally," Mr. Strickland said. "I've supported him on most issues. But not many people get to be President, and not many people are as smart as he is. What a waste! He has endangered everything he's worked for and I've worked for. His Presidency might actually end prematurely.
"I'm amazed and very sad and disappointed, like my constituents, and angry, too. But people's anger is not out of control yet, and I don't think it will affect the way they vote this fall. But it might; it could."
Mr. Strickland, a former Methodist minister who still greets male acquaintances with an evangelical "how are you doing, my brother?" is also a graduate psychologist. In his former occupation as a counselor at a local prison, he said, he had "encountered all kinds of behavior." But he had nonetheless been astounded, he added, "by the risks the President took, the repetition, even when his actions had already got him in trouble, again and again."
As for Ms. Hollister, she said Mr. Clinton had "violated the code of ethics and behavior you have to hold yourself to as a public official." At the moment, the Lewinsky case is not entering into many voting decisions here, she said, but by October, she suggested, "things may look different."
Debby Allard, the editor of The Portsmouth Times, said that because Mr. Strickland had spoken out against Mr. Clinton's behavior, "I can't see many people at all around here punishing Strickland for the President's sins."
The situation could have been worse for him if Mr. Cremeans had won the Republican primary, local people say. He has a strong appeal to the religious right -- the former head of the Christian Coalition, Ralph Reed, was an adviser for a time -- and he might have been better able to stir up socially conservative voters on the Clinton issue.
This is an old-fashioned world with traditional values, less inclined to live and let live than Cincinnati and other big Ohio cities. The big River Days parade, for example, was a page from a simpler past, with homemade costumes and floats, fire engines, Model T Fords, Model A Fords, high school bands and an American Legion honor guard. The one truly contemporary note was the names of the cheerleaders who rode on long flatbed trucks: Bethany and Tiffany, Lindsay and Brittany, Courtney and Ashley, with nary a Jane or a Mary in sight.
What worries him, Mr. Strickland said, is a low turnout in November. With most people prosperous, with continuing cynicism about politics and with no crisis abroad, voters might stay at home, and that would help Ms. Hollister, the Congressman suggested. The best solution, he said, would be "for Clinton to go for broke, cast aside this excessive caution, set inspiring goals."
But few in Washington see much chance of that, and many think Mr. Strickland's fears of a low turnout will be realized. In a study earlier this year, Curtis Gans of the Center for the Study of the American Electorate predicted a "sharply reduced" turnout compared with 1994, and suggested it was likely to hurt Democrats because of disproportionately heavy participation by more highly paid voters, who tend to be Republicans.
Mr. Strickland has done what he can to insulate himself against adversity. He works hard at the minutiae of constituent service, returning each weekend to the district, plying the byways of an area without a city of more than 25,000 people.
Always a fairly centrist Democrat, Mr. Strickland has inched far further to the right in the last two years. He was one of only 15 Democrats to vote to end the income tax by 2003; he backed a constitutional amendment banning flag-burning, and he opposed the President on several trade issues. That has led Ms. Hollister to accuse him of lacking principle and bowing to electoral expediency.

HEADLINE: Greenspan's Hint of Rate Cut Sends Value of Dollar Down

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
The dollar fell 2 percent to a four-month low against the yen and slumped to a nine-month low against the mark after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, suggested that United States interest rates might be cut in coming months.
"The Fed has changed its stance on rates; it's the only reasonable thing to do," said Gerry Celaya, a senior currency analyst at American Express Bank who expects the dollar to fall further. "The dollar hasn't yet seen its lows." 
 The dollar fell as low as 130.50 yen, the lowest since April 24, from 133.75 late Friday in London. It had recently been at 131.82. It fell to 1.7208 marks, the lowest point since Nov. 13.
Mr. Greenspan suggested on Friday that the recession in many Asian countries and other emerging markets might rein in American economic growth. "It's just not credible that the United States can remain an oasis of prosperity unaffected by a world that is experiencing greatly increased stress," he said.
Steve Barrow, a currency strategist at Bear Stearns International, said, "Greenspan probably went as far as we could have expected in suggesting the Fed will move to a neutral bias" from a bias toward raising interest rates.
"We could see the dollar slide through 1.70 marks and 130 yen rather quickly," he added.
Paul Duncombe, an investment director at State Street Global Advisors, which manages $500 billion worldwide, said: "A lot of store is being put into the U.S. cutting interest rates. The dollar is probably a little oversold against the yen."
The dollar was also hurt as investors, including United States hedge funds, bought yen to pay off loans used to invest in emerging markets like Russia and Latin America, which have plunged.
In recent months, many investors had used so-called yen-carry trades to borrow yen at Japan's low rates and then converted the yen to dollars to seek higher returns overseas.
"I'm bearish on the dollar because so many investors are closing their yen-carry trades to compensate for losses in emerging markets," said Tetsu Aikawa, a foreign exchange manager at Sanwa Bank Ltd.
The yen also got a lift after Japanese officials warned investors that their currency had further to rise.
"It's hard to buy dollars after the officials said they want to see the yen strengthen further, even though it has risen," said Toyomitsu Sakata, the head of treasury and foreign exchange sales at Commerzbank in Tokyo. The rise has been nearly 10 percent in two weeks.
Eisuke Sakakibara, Japan's vice finance minister for international affairs, said Japanese and American officials "still share concern about excessive weakness of the yen."

HEADLINE: Korea Bid Expected To Go to Rothschild

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Creditors of the insolvent Halla Group, which owns Korea's biggest auto component manufacturer, appear likely to accept an offer by Rothschild Inc. to buy four of the group's companies for $1.8 billion, according to Korea Exchange Bank, one of Halla's biggest creditors.
The United States investment banking arm of the Rothschild family's financial business will lay out its final proposal this afternoon. 
 "We and other creditors will detail our positions by October," said an official at Korea Exchange Bank, which is in charge of loans owed by Halla, "but I haven't come across any strong objectors yet."
A successful turnaround at Halla could lead to more business for Rothschild and other international banks that specialize in mergers and acquisitions. It could also relieve burdens at Korean banks, which have not received interest payments for at least six months on 10 percent of their loans because of a deepening recession.
Rothschild asked Korean creditors to write off 3.83 trillion won ($2.8 billion) of debt out of 6.209 trillion won owed by Halla. It would then make a one-time payment of 2.37 trillion won to creditors of the four companies.

Murdoch's BSkyB May Bid For British Soccer Team
B Sky B, Rupert Murdoch's British satellite broadcasting unit, confirmed that it was in discussions to acquire the Manchester United soccer team for a reported $950 million. The move comes after Mr. Murdoch's United States holdings have acquired stakes in American sports franchises. Page C4.
 
Russian Bank Chairman Resigns
The chairman of Russia's central bank, Sergei Dubinin, resigned amid mounting financial chaos in that country. He criticized Parliament's failure to act more quickly to help resuscitate the economy. Trading in the ruble was halted on the Moscow Interbank Currency Exchange barely an hour after opening because no traders were willing to sell their dollars. A12. 

New Record for Summer Travel
The summer travel season ended yesterday with expectations that it had set another record and with forecasts of record tourism again this fall. The nonprofit Travel Industry Association of America had estimated that Americans would take 251 million trips this summer, 3 percent more than last year, and it has predicted a record 196 million travelers this fall, a 5 percent increase. C5.
 
Learning to Live With Volatility
For employees of technology start-up companies, whose net worth is often dependent on stock options, the recent swings in stock prices require coping with volatility unimaginable to many investors. A1.
 
Goldman to Discuss Offering
Goldman, Sachs & Company has told its 11,500 employees worldwide to participate in a conference call this morning in which Goldman's leaders are expected to discuss the planned offering of shares to the public. C2.
 
Merger Season May Be at an End
As the summer vacation season ends, Wall Street investment bankers may find the flurry of merger activity earlier this year has subsided. As stocks have fallen, some bankers worry about which deals may fall apart. C2.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
In Sosa's Hometown, It's a One-Man Show

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: SAN PEDRO DE MACORIS, Dominican Republic, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Sammy Sosa was a hero here in his baseball-crazed homeland long before he and Mark McGwire began their pursuit of Babe Ruth and Roger Maris. So when the Cubs and the Cardinals squared off this afternoon in St. Louis with Maris's major league home run record up for grabs, it was as if 8 million people had dropped whatever they were doing to root for him.
"The streets are almost as empty as when the Government decrees a curfew," said Gerardo Mota, a hotel maintenance worker here who had shuffled his work schedule to watch the game at a bar and betting parlor in the same neighborhood where Sosa grew up. "Everybody is watching, either in their homes or in places like this, because we all want Sammy to break that record." 
 No matter that by the end of the day, Sosa's chances of getting there ahead of McGwire had nearly disappeared; McGwire hit his 61st home run, tying Maris's record, while Sosa remained stuck on 58. Their faith unshaken, Sosa's friends and neighbors began looking for new ways to frame the remarkable achievements of their idol, who grew up poor but talented in a town that boasts that it has produced more major league players per capita than any place in the world.
"Even if McGwire gets 62 first, Sammy is going to be the first dark-skinned player to hit 60 home runs in a season, and that's a real distinction," said Kelvin Garcia, a 16-year-old shortstop who had attended an Atlanta Braves tryout earlier in the day. "Hank Aaron never homered 60 times in a season, and neither did Orlando Cepeda, Tony Perez, Roberto Clemente, Tony Armas or anybody else."
Sosa's countrymen have followed his exploits intently ever since he signed his first contract as a 16-year-old with the Texas Rangers, and they were thrilled when he agreed to a $42.5 million deal with the Cubs two years ago. But it was only after he hit his 48th homer on Aug. 19 off Kent Bottenfield of the Cardinals, breaking the single-season record for most home runs by a Latin American player, that the whole country dared to dream that Maris might be next.
The day after the Latin American record fell, Dominican newspapers put Sosa's feat on their front pages, where it competed with Fidel Castro's impending arrival for a Caribbean summit, the Cuban leader's first visit here in four years. The record Sosa broke had been held by another native of San Pedro de Macoris, George Bell of the Toronto Blue Jays, but that did not seem to matter.
"It is amazing to me just how happy and enthusiastic people have been over the last month," Sonia Sosa, the slugger's older sister, said during an interview this morning at the boutique she runs at the 30-30 Plaza, a shopping mall the slugger built after hitting 33 homers and stealing 36 bases in 1993. "I walk down the street, and people run out of their houses or drive by on their motorbikes and yell, 'He's got 57, and we're all pulling for him!' "
Throughout the Caribbean, the attitude has been much the same. For a month now, newspapers in Panama, Venezuela, Puerto Rico, Nicaragua and Mexico have been publishing boxes with Sosa's and McGwire's daily home run tally, while radio stations have been breaking in on their regular programs every time Sosa hits a home run. "Sosa is carrying the flag for all of us in Latin America," Luis Pimentel Escobar, a parking attendant in Panama, said last week. "Every time he hits a four-bagger, he is reminding everybody that baseball is our game too."
Dominicans are even more sensitive than other people in Latin America about the way they are portrayed in the United States, and they flinch every time this country is linked to drug trafficking or illegal immigration. So the burst of publicity that has come with Sosa's ascent has been welcomed by all classes and political tendencies as a chance to change the country's image.
"Sammy is a wonderful kid, and what he has done is great for baseball, great for the Dominican Republic and great for San Pedro de Macoris," said Manuel Rodriguez Robles, a former mayor here. "He has projected this country and this town onto the world stage in a way that no Dominican has ever done."
Sosa's rise from rags to riches is the source of much of the popular adulation he enjoys here. One of six children of a widow who cooked meals for factory workers to eke out a living, Sosa as a child "shined shoes, sold oranges, washed cars, did any kind of work that was honest," as he put it in an interview last year, to help his mother make ends meet.
"Sosa had to overcome all kinds of adversity, economic and social, that McGwire never had to face when he was growing up," said Luis de la Cruz, one of the fans watching the game at Josecito's Betting Parlor today. "That makes what Sammy has done all the more admirable and extraordinary."
One of Sosa's initiatives here is a baseball school, which opened late last year. Talented teen-age players from families of "limited means" are recruited from around the country, given scholarships, housing, food and training that includes clinics personally taught by Sosa. Already, five graduates have been signed by four different major league teams.
Naturally, all 16 of the players enrolled in the academy today proclaimed themselves Sosa supporters. But the most passionate of them was probably Simon Soriano, a 16-year-old who plays right field, Sosa's position, wears Sosa's number, 21, on his jersey and even mimics his idol's batting stance.
"I'm a photocopy of Sammy Sosa," he said proudly this morning. "I hope he hits two home runs today and that McGwire strikes out four times. Sammy has already broken the Latin American record, the Cubs' team record and the record for the most homers in one month. He deserves to break this one too, and I know he will."

HEADLINE: At State U., No Room at the Dorm For the Invited but Not Expected

BYLINE: By JO THOMAS 

 BODY:
So many more freshmen than had originally been expected showed up at the University of Maryland at College Park last month that dozens were sent to spend the semester at the local Quality Inn.
"I think we have it better than the other freshmen," said Carrie Smith, 17, settling herself on a Sesame Street blanket. "They don't have air-conditioning or cable." 
 Some of the overflow at the University of Delaware in Newark was happily camped in luxury apartments normally reserved for university guests. And at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Antony Zoeteman, 18, spent his first two weeks living in a dormitory study lounge with three other students, bunk beds and several sofas.
Large state universities across the United States are seeing freshman enrollments surge this fall, forcing officials to scramble to find beds, instructors and classrooms. Colleges usually offer admission to more applicants than they expect to attend, to insure that dormitories and classes are filled. But this year, some were caught by surprise at the number taking them up on the offers.
Officials say students are opting for public institutions because the big state universities are doing a better job of marketing their strong points, because parents are worried about the economy and want good value for money and because some of the more expensive private institutions have reached the limit to the financial aid they can offer as their overall costs go up.
Fall enrollment figures are still incomplete for many universities, some of which will not start classes until later this month, but one of the largest overflows so far occurred at the College Station campus of Texas A&M University, where a freshman class of 7,400 arrived last week -- 1,200 more students than had been expected earlier this year, when offers of admission were sent out.
"Every time I was told the estimate for the freshman class," said Ronald G. Douglas, executive vice president and provost at A&M, "it kept getting bigger."
"I'm glad they're here because they can't get bigger," he added with relief. There are 34,000 undergraduates at the College Station campus, one of seven A&M campuses.
Huge freshman classes, with 200 to 500 more students than anticipated, have also arrived at the University of California at Berkeley, Rutgers University, the University of Arizona, Oregon State University and Pennsylvania State University.
It is too soon to tell who -- if anyone -- will be the enrollment losers as large public colleges get more crowded.
The University of Delaware enrolled 270 more freshmen than it had anticipated. Larry A. Griffith, director of admissions, said the university had "for a long time been a quietly excellent place academically," but recently had been raising more money for new buildings and had begun marketing itself more aggressively.
"I believe the next group of 'public Ivies' is emerging and that our experience at the University of Delaware is true of the best public universities," Mr. Griffith said, "which show well under the increased scrutiny by parents, students and the ratings guides."
At Rutgers, New Jersey's state university, there was an overflow of 470 freshmen.
"I believe more people are discovering us," said Diane Harris, associate director of undergraduate admissions. For a total cost of $10,000 a year, she said, a New Jersey resident "can get an excellent education at a research university."
"You get a very good value," Ms. Harris said. "I don't know why they don't all come to the university."
Daniel J. Saracino, assistant provost for enrollment at the University of Notre Dame and a former president of the National Association for College Admissions Counseling, agreed that first-rate state universities "are good buys."
"Kids can apply to the privates," Mr. Saracino said, "and if the financial aid isn't what they want, they can rely on fine public schools."
"Private schools that have always counted on financial aid to level the playing field may not be able to continue to pour the money in," he added, pointing to what he said was the growing gap between college costs and what students and their families actually pay. "The discount rates have gotten way too high, 30 to 40 percent, and there has been a leveling off in many cases. It's kind of a poker game in admissions offices across the country. Some are saying the pot is too rich for me, and I'm going to fold; enough is enough."
Some private colleges and universities have also reported significant increases in the percentage of freshmen who accepted offers of admission this year. Alfred University in Alfred, N.Y., had an overflow of 50 freshmen in the largest freshman class in 25 years. It had to rent a dormitory from Alfred State College, across the street.
Harvard University reported that 80 percent of applicants who were offered admission this year accepted, the highest rate in 20 years. Alex Huppe, director of the office of public affairs, said Harvard was able to hold its new freshman class to 1,650, "right on target," because it kept a long waiting list from which it usually planned to fill its class.
The large public universities may also be seeing the first signs of a surge in the number of high school graduates, which started to grow in 1995 after a long decline and is expected to peak in 2008 at 2.9 million, above the record 2.8 million in 1979.
"There is a baby boomlet that is just now starting to hit higher education," said Robin Zuniga, a research associate at the Western Interstate Commission for Higher Education, a nonprofit inter-government agency in Boulder, Colo.
"This is just the beginning of it, and it's a tidal wave," Ms. Zuniga said. "If the schools were surprised, they shouldn't be. And if they're feeling pressure now, they're going to be feeling a lot more."
One sign of that pressure, admissions officers at both private and public institutions said, was the decline this year of what they called the "summer melt rate," the number of students who accept an offer of college admission in the spring and then write or call to say they have changed their minds.
Kent H. Jones, dean of enrollment and college relations at Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., said: "We typically lose 10 percent of our original enrollments between May 1 and the beginning of classes in September as students are taken off waiting lists at other colleges, change plans or defer enrollment for a year. This year, our summer attrition is 6 percent of our original deposits -- unprecedented in our experience."
"As a result," Mr. Jones said, "we will open with a first-year class of 597, which is 22 over our target of 575."
College admission is an inexact process, university officials readily acknowledge. When the percentage of candidates accepting admission changes without warning, the results are significant at a large university. This year's increase of 2 percent at Illinois resulted in a freshman class of 6,464, the largest in the university's history and nearly 397 more than expected.
Over the summer, the university added to its teaching staff. The English department, which this semester has 3,000 freshmen in classes limited to 22 students, exhausted its supply of teaching assistants from its own graduate students and other departments and turned to former graduate students, faculty spouses and writers living in the community. Dennis Baron, the department head, said the last teaching assistant was hired the day after classes began.
Similar freshman enrollment shocks hit the University of Wisconsin, the University of Washington and the University of Michigan last fall. Each took steps this year to get the numbers down, becoming more selective and making fewer offers of admission.
Julie Peterson, a spokeswoman for Michigan, said, "Some students who are now sophomores have to go back and take some required courses where there wasn't room for them last year as freshmen."
Penn State has been trying to reduce the size of its freshmen classes since 1995, when it was caught by surprise by 760 extra freshmen at its main campus, an event that forced the university to appeal for rooms in private homes.
This year Penn State accepted 1,000 fewer freshmen, said John Romano, vice provost for enrollment management and administration, but more freshmen decided to enroll, so the class of 5,100 at the University Park campus is just as big as in earlier years.
Enrollment at University Park has grown to a record 41,000, from 37,000 in 1995. The university has added 100 faculty members since then.
At Delaware, which has 15,000 undergraduates, Mr. Griffith said he did not see the boom coming. When applications arrived, he said, "we got the 15,000 we typically get," and after making offers of admission, expected a class of 3,350. "For the first time, we made the class before May 1, and I thought great, and then the deposits kept rolling in.
"We looked at each other and said, it'll be O.K., well, maybe a little high, and when the smoke cleared on May 10, we were just below 3,800," Mr. Griffith said. "I went on vacation and prayed for a hot summer. We did have a nice melt, and we ended up at 3,620."

HEADLINE: CLINTON'S LAWYER SEEKS EARLY LOOK AT STARR FINDINGS

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
President Clinton's private lawyer asked today that Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent prosecutor, let him review at least a week in advance any report he submits to Congress, in a sign the White House is readying a defense against possible impeachment hearings.
The request came with Mr. Clinton facing wrenching decisions about how to reassure Democrats as criticism of his handling of the Lewinsky episode mounts within his own party. 
 With the House of Representatives returning to session on Wednesday and midterm elections just two months away, the prospect of Mr. Starr's report has electrified the political atmosphere here, alarming Congressional Democrats and causing some to distance themselves from the President.
But the White House is still scrambling for a strategy to take the political initiative in the country and the Congress away from Mr. Starr, some of the President's outside advisers say.
One option being urged on Mr. Clinton is that he disclose embarrassing information by candidly answering reporters' questions about his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.
In a letter to the prosecutors today, David E. Kendall, Mr. Clinton's private lawyer, wrote that out of "fundamental fairness," Mr. Starr should let him and the White House counsel's office review any report early enough to permit them "one week to submit a written reply." That reply, together with the report, might then be given to Judge Norma Holloway Johnson, who has been supervising the grand jury in Mr. Starr's investigation, or sent straight to Congress.
Mr. Kendall argued that Mr. Starr might transmit his information to Congress but that he was not authorized by law to prepare a report that summarizes or analyzes it. And Congress, he wrote, has in the past expressed concern that judgments made in such a report could intrude on its constitutional responsibilities in weighing impeachment.
"We believe that fundamental fairness dictates that we have the opportunity to review such a document and submit simultaneously any reply we wish to make," Mr. Kendall.
Mr. Starr had no comment on the letter, a spokesman said tonight.
White House officials have argued that Mr. Starr, a Republican, will not produce a balanced report on his eight-month-old inquiry into Mr. Clinton's relationship with Ms. Lewinsky. Noting that Mr. Starr's witnesses have not been cross-examined, they are eager to give their own interpretation of the facts.
If Mr. Starr refuses to provide the advance copy, White House aides will argue that he is acting unfairly, trying to sandbag the President by surprising him with a report that they expect to read like an indictment, one adviser to Mr. Clinton said.
After almost three weeks away, the Clintons came back over the long weekend to a capital turned suddenly hostile. Having taken a pasting from Senate Democrats last week, the White House is bracing for the possibility of more criticism from House members who have heard an earful from constituents.
To remind the public and his party of his legislative goals, the President plans a series of campaign-style appearances, beginning Tuesday with his promotion of a school modernization plan.
But, fatigued by weeks of domestic and foreign crises, the President and his aides are also trying to develop a legal and political strategy to deal with the expected report from Mr. Starr. The Clintons' time away from Washington -- first on vacation and then in Russia and Ireland -- has hampered internal planning about the report.
"We understandably don't have a lot of fizz right now," one of the President's outside advisers said.
Another ally of Mr. Clinton said criticism in a speech last Thursday by a fellow Democrat, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, might have shaken the White House out of a sense that Mr. Clinton's high approval ratings in public opinion polls would protect him.
"The White House has relied on polling and missed the real danger of the political slow burn that began moments after the speech," this ally said. "A lot of us are hoping Senator Lieberman's speech is the real wake-up call, causing a major and fundamental change in the President's approach to this issue, not an incremental one or a strategic one."
Had Mr. Clinton delivered a full-throated apology in his brief talk to the nation on Aug. 17, some of his aides believe, he would by now have the high ground in criticizing Mr. Starr. Instead, Democrats' irritation with Mr. Clinton has grown since that speech, said one Democratic consultant advising several members of Congress.
"You do get a sense -- maybe just temporarily -- the sense that people are sort of done with it," he said. "They're done with him. There's not another escape."
Some of Mr. Clinton's aides believe that Democrats have been criticizing him in part out of fear that the Starr report will convey damaging information not yet disclosed.
As a result, some Clinton advisers are pushing his legal team to release all records relating to Ms. Lewinsky that Mr. Starr has obtained, like the logs of her visits to the White House. Then, they argue, the President should answer detailed questions from reporters.
Lanny J. Davis, a former White House special counsel, urged that strategy when Mr. Clinton was responding to accusations about his 1996 campaign finances. He says the White House should now "help reporters write all of the details of this story prior to the Starr report, because fundamentally the only chance we have of a balanced presentation is if we put this information out ourselves."
One White House official argued that because of the scandal, the public was now watching Mr. Clinton "like a hawk" and was "more attuned to what he's saying, not less." As a result, this official said, Mr. Clinton's planned events could benefit him.
The President is scheduled to travel to Florida on Wednesday to raise money for the Democratic nominee for governor, Buddy MacKay, and to promote school safety. He will follow that, his aides say, with a blitz of public appearances to push new safety regulations and health care legislation and to address international economic troubles. In particular, he will emphasize his economic stewardship, his central political theme since he first ran for President in 1992.
But not many issues have mitigated the furor over Ms. Lewinsky recently, despite some powerful contenders: since Mr. Clinton acknowledged the relationship, he has ordered one of the biggest military operations of his Presidency, and the stock market has tumbled more than 500 points on a single day, among other dramatic doings.
"Campaign-style events, I don't know if those can change the subject," a Democratic strategist said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "The problem is everyone really has got their ear to the ground for the big shoe of the Starr report to drop."
In the meantime, it is far from certain that Congress will pass even the budget legislation necessary to prevent a Government shutdown, let alone act on the President's broad agenda.
"It's difficult for the President to talk about restoring integrity to the political process right now," said Representative Christopher Shays, a Connecticut Republican who has been a close ally of the White House in seeking to tighten campaign finance laws.
Some Administration officials say that, away from the uproar, work is getting done.
"In our area, I think he's going to have the best year in his Administration," said Andrew M. Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. Mr. Cuomo predicted an increase in his budget in the coming year to $25 billion, from $24 billion.
Mr. Cuomo said he had noticed an "amazing disconnect" in some 15 cities he has visited since Mr. Clinton's statement about Ms. Lewinsky.
"I'm asked about it by the media in every city," he said, "and the people never comment on it."
