HEADLINE: Drugs Taint an Annual Round of Gay Revels

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
It began in the early stages of the AIDS epidemic as a relatively modest affair, a respite for the living and remembrance of the dead that was held in daylight, so that even the ill might be able to go, and was given a double-edged title resonant of grief.
A decade and a half later, the Morning Party has evolved into a glamorous social event that attracts hordes of gay men to Fire Island and reliably raises enormous sums of money for Gay Men's Health Crisis, perhaps the country's most respected private AIDS service organization. 
 This year's gathering, on Aug. 16, was no different. About 4,500 men went, an estimated $450,000 was raised and a good time was had by many.
But the hangover has been formidable, underlining the way the event has become an albatross around the health group's neck and a flash point in an increasingly bitter debate over the alliances between AIDS service organizations and a network of dance-oriented fund-raisers at which a substantial number of participants are high on drugs.
In the predawn hours leading up to this year's Morning Party, a 35-year-old man from Bronxville, N.Y., overdosed and died. During the event, a security consultant who had been hired by the health group to help weed out drug use -- and who had made a speech imploring partygoers to stay clean -- was among 21 men arrested on charges of possessing illegal drugs.
In the three weeks since, many gay men have questioned the propriety of the group's endorsement of a party that seems to inspire the kind of drug consumption widely thought to increase the likelihood of unsafe sexual behavior and the spread of AIDS.
"It gives the organization not only money, but future clients," said Troy Masters, the publisher of LGNY, a twice-monthly newspaper for lesbians and gay men in the New York region. "In a way, it's like a self-perpetuating machine."
Criticism of this kind has been aimed at Gay Men's Health Crisis for several years. In 1996, a man was evacuated by helicopter from the Morning Party after slipping into a drug-induced coma.
But the complaints seem to be taking on a heightened urgency with the proliferation around the country of other large-scale gay dance events, some of which funnel part of their profits to AIDS service organizations and include the organizations' names in promotional materials.
These events have come to be known as "circuit parties" because they are linked by similar music and because some of them attract the same core crowd, lavishly muscled and wealthy enough to buy plane tickets and plenty of drugs like cocaine, Ecstasy and ketamine, or "special K."
In addition, the array of chemicals taken by at least a few of the men who attend circuit parties has expanded recently to include a liquid anesthetic, gamma hydroxybutyrate, or GHB, that has been implicated in a string of medical emergencies at circuit parties this year. GHB is extolled by some as an aphrodisiac.
Suffolk County law enforcement officials said that GHB appeared to cause the death of Frank J. Giordano, 35, at the Pines on Fire Island around 4 A.M. on Aug. 16, seven hours before the Morning Party officially began on a stretch of beach nearby.
Three other men at the Pines who apparently took the same batch of GHB were brought to hospitals on Long Island, treated and released, law enforcement officials said. Several people who attended the Morning Party said that one of the three men made it back to the Pines in time to join the festivities.
"People are partying harder than ever with substances that are more volatile than ever," said Alan Brown, a New Haven management consultant who annually attends about two dozen circuit parties, from Montreal to Miami, and recently sat on a panel at a gay physicians' conference in Chicago to discuss health issues relating to the events. "People have been leaving parties in ambulances routinely for three years now."
Mr. Brown and other gay men familiar with circuit parties emphasized that many men who attend the events use illegal drugs infrequently, if ever, and that a vast majority of gay men have never been to one.
Officials of Gay Men's Health Crisis, which stages (and profits from) the Morning Party, said that educating the minority of gay men involved in the party circuit about the perils of drugs is a principal reason the organization remains committed to the event, which they said would occur with or without the group's involvement.
Jeff Soref, who was president of its board when the organization began to assume full responsibility for coordinating the event in the early 1990's, said, "G.M.H.C. does need to be involved in harm reduction, and it does need to be where the community is."
Others stressed that during recent years, the organization had intensified its efforts to rid the Morning Party of illegal drugs, distributing written warnings. Many people who attended the Morning Party this year said that drug use was noticeably less prevalent and conspicuous than in the past.
Ronald Johnson, the organization's managing director for public policy, said that linking the GHB overdoses that occurred more than eight hours earlier to the event was gratuitous.
But critics said that the Morning Party, like other circuit events, has spawned several days of nonstop revelry around it, and cannot divorce itself from those often reckless festivities.
"If G.M.H.C. officials don't think they have some responsibility for the overdoses, they're kidding themselves," said Michael Trovato, 41, who spends summer weekends on Fire Island.
Many gay men said the organization could do prevention work at the party without sponsoring it, which they contended tacitly condones the drug-taking throughout the weekend. Several said they had stopped donating money to the organization because of its affiliation with the gathering and knew others who had done likewise, although Mr. Johnson said he had seen no evidence of that.
In some ways, circuit parties are nothing new. Among both heterosexuals and homosexuals, going back several decades, there have been late-night, drug-fueled dance extravaganzas.
But during the last five years, special gay events of this kind have not only multiplied -- they now number in the dozens -- but also clustered into an informal network with its own Internet sites, disk jockeys and preferred body type, gym-toned and sometimes steroid-enhanced.
The circuit embraces New York and New Orleans, Palm Springs and Pensacola, though many events have no connection to AIDS service organizations. It usually features shirtless men dancing all through the night, their energy and euphoria often enhanced by powders or pills.
Gay men knowledgeable about the circuit said that Viagra has also made an appearance, prompting recent seminars in San Francisco and Miami that discussed its interaction with other drugs, including protease inhibitors, the antiviral agents taken by people with AIDS.
But what most alarms many gay men and public health experts is not the drug use itself but the implications for responsible sexual conduct.
"The extent to which gay men use drugs is a strong, significant predictor of becoming H.I.V.-positive," said Ron Stall, a professor of epidemiology at the University of California at San Francisco.
Others said that some circuit parties even feature darkened back rooms and that a few men who flock to circuit extravaganzas also attend sex parties before or after the main event and may not adhere strictly to precautions against H.I.V. transmission.
That has provoked critics into greater anger at AIDS service organizations around the country for staging circuit parties or signing on as beneficiaries.
"Circuit parties got the imprimatur of their local AIDS organizations and -- bingo -- instant, total respectability," said Gabriel Rotello, author of "Sexual Ecology: AIDS and the Destiny of Gay Men" (Dutton, 1997). "And the irony of that is just so awesome."
To varying degrees, officials with AIDS service organizations that are involved in circuit parties are wrestling with that accusation, a process complicated by their difficulty raising money in other ways.
They said that sunny news reports about better treatments for AIDS have left many individual donors with the mistaken impression that the epidemic is waning and have discouraged them from giving as much money as in the past.
"We are more dependent than ever on special events fund-raising," said Bryan Delowery, the events coordinator for the AIDS Information Network, an organization in Philadelphia that stages a circuit party there every January. The event, called the Blue Ball, raises $125,000, more than 10 percent of the group's annual budget.
Profits from the Morning Party, for which tickets cost $100 apiece, account for a much smaller percentage of G.M.H.C.'s annual budget of $25 million. But proponents of circuit parties said the case for them transcends the economic vitality of AIDS service organizations that do crucial work.
They said that many gay men attend the events not to indulge chemical or sexual appetites but simply to bask in an environment free of the bigotry they face elsewhere in society. They noted that circuit parties are by no means the exclusive sites of risky behavior, or even the main ones.
Critics counter that circuit parties, with their special patina of glamour, have an impact beyond their perimeters, idealizing dangerous habits in a manner that has particular influence over young gay men.
The experience of Jeffrey W. supports that viewpoint. He said that when he moved to Manhattan after graduating from college a few years ago, "I had no desire to be part of a drug and intense sex culture."
But he said that the conversations of other gay men he met and the glossy ads he spotted in some gay periodicals piqued his curiosity, and even left him with the impression that the circuit scene was the very definition of gay identity.
"I figured if there were 5,000 other men who are considered the upper crust in the gay world doing this, it must be all right and it must be the norm," said Jeffrey, who spoke on the condition that his last name not be used. "I experimented quite heavily with drugs, and I began to be unsafe."
One such moment occurred in December. Several months later, Jeffrey said, he tested positive for H.I.V.

HEADLINE: In Silicon Valley, Big Swings In Share Price Are Ho-Hum

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: MENLO PARK, Calif., Sept. 5

 BODY:
With all due respect to Main Street investors who grew a bit faint when the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 6.4 percent in a day last week, the young workers riding their stock options on Silicon Valley's roller coaster have a message: really, that's nothing.
Here at Onsale Inc., an on-line auction house where, as at many ventures in the Internet field, virtually every employee has a package of stock options that may (or may not) be a big part of the employee's net worth some day, wild swings in the company's stock price go with the territory. 
 Just in the year and a half since the company went public, the stock has been as low as $4.625 a share and as high as $36.8125, with plenty of dips and rises along the way. In the last week alone, it careened from a low of $13.875 to a high of $21, finally closing at $16.75.
"You get used to it after a while," said 30-year-old Jack Herndon, a marketing director at Onsale, a cyberauction house that sells an eclectic array of goods, mainly computer equipment but also items like rattlesnake meat and a human-shaped inflatable rubber device used for boxing practice known as the Slam Man.
"I came here from a company that went from an all-time high to an all-time low in a matter of months," Mr. Herndon said. "One day it went from 42 to 24 overnight, then down to 11. I watched in 36 hours a significant amount of money not yet in my wallet burn before my eyes. It happens."
More than in almost any other industry, stock options have fueled the boom in Silicon Valley and in other regions of the country where high-technology and Internet businesses are congregated, allowing start-up companies to pay smart, ambitious workers a relatively low salary -- along with the promise of great riches if their sweat and creativity help these ventures succeed.
Along the way, that phenomenon seems to have ignited a singular brand of investment psychology that can be gleaned from talks with employees like those at Onsale, each of whom describes his or her own method of coping with the kind of volatility that might turn the stomachs of the most hardened investors.
"Honestly, O.K., I do check the price at least once a day, just to see where it is," said 29-year-old Debbie Rodriguez, a customer service supervisor. "But, I don't calculate what it's all worth when it goes down. I calculate it for its potential, what I think it's really worth because I know how hard everybody at this company is working, and that helps."
And, said Stefanie Elkins, a manager of investor relations, also 29: "The swings are all a part of the gamble, the whole Silicon Valley mentality. I think there's a whole, almost pioneer attitude, especially with Internet companies -- it's, 'Let's try this, let's see if we can get it to work, let's see if we can get it to a point where the stock options are really worth something.' There's a thrill in trying. If it doesn't work, you move on."
Robert Petrossian, a vice president for engineering at Onsale, said short-term swings in the stock market are not the best way to measure the true value of a company in a fast-changing field like the Internet.
"Being human, I do watch the stock price," Mr. Petrossian said. "It's a way to see how other people value your work externally. But I'm at this company for the long term, and I have my own way of valuing the stock. And from day one, in terms of the fundamentals, nothing has changed."
Many employees insisted that stock options were not the main attraction of the company for them.
"The roller coaster is fun and it's interesting, but it's really not the reason I'm here," said John Dean, a 39-year-old vice president in charge of a new division offering travel products, including weekly time-shares in a Mexican beach condominium for which the bidding starts at as low as $9. (Auctions at Onsale are carried on just as at more traditional ones, where bidders raise their hands. In this case, though, bidders click on an icon to bid, or leave secret instructions as to how high they are willing to bid.)
For Mr. Dean, the real thrill comes when he can watch a last-minute bidding war erupt during Onsale's "Going . . . going . . . gone" feature, a fast-paced affair that means fast profits for the company.
"When those bids go up," he said, "it's exciting. It's better than watching the World Series."
Stock options, which essentially represent an agreement by a company to make shares available to an employee for a specified price in the future, can yield great profits when the company's stock soars, or be worth nothing if it plunges. While not commonly offered in many industries, they are virtually standard in places like Silicon Valley.
"The Internet companies have grown up in an environment where this idea is a part of the culture," said Matt Ward, chief executive of Westward Pay Strategies Inc., a San Francisco-based firm that develops incentive compensation packages for many Silicon Valley companies. "I'm not sure you could even get people to work in this field in a situation where you're not giving them a piece of the action."
Said Jerry Kaplan, a founder and chief executive officer of Onsale: "I like to say that Silicon Valley has perfected many of the principles laid out by Karl Marx. In his terms, workers control the means of production. In our terms, every employee is an owner of the company."
For Onsale workers whose options entitle them to buy stocks at just a few dollars a share, the wild price changes of recent weeks could translate into tens of thousands of dollars in lost or gained wealth.
Of course, low-level workers in the 200-employee company have just a fraction of the share options of a founding executive like Mr. Kaplan. Still, with even those employees generally having options on at least a few thousand shares, the potential rewards are great, and many workers here say it builds camaraderie that would not exist if everyone were on straight salary.
The fluctuations in stock price for Onsale are by no means atypical, especially among Internet companies. But partly because stock options take effect over a set period of time, typically four years, worrying over today's price swings is a bit like worrying about the weather. There's no point to jumping out of windows when the stock plunges, or burning $1,000 bills when it soars -- what counts is what the stock will be worth the day an employee sells it.
"Really, you don't hear employees talking a lot about changes in the stock price, and you don't have a lot of people clicking the refresh button on the browser all day to see what the latest trade is," said Diane Hunt, a spokeswoman for Yahoo Inc., the company based in Santa Clara, Calif., that markets a popular Internet search engine.
In the last year, Yahoo stock has swayed from $17.0625 a share to $103.75. But, Ms. Hunt said: "You don't focus on it. Everyone here knows that if you run a good business, with sound fundamentals, and you stick to your plan, the stock price will take care of itself."
Here at Onsale, many people said outside shareholders seemed to be more concerned about stock-price swings than those inside the headquarters, a drab two-story building in an industrial stretch of Menlo Park, where many workers are so busy they lack time to even decorate their office walls.
Anytime the stock drops, said Brian K. Fawkes, vice president for corporate communications: "I get dozens of calls from shareholders, who want to know why is the stock going down and what are you going to do to make it go up? But not once has an employee come to me and asked why."
Both Mr. Fawkes and Mr. Kaplan usually say that such swings are common and that the company and its workers remain focused on long-term growth. Once in a while, though, says the convivial Mr. Kaplan, author of "Start-Up: A Silicon Valley Adventure," a book about a prior, unsuccessful bid of his into pen-based computers, Onsale employees cannot resist offering callers a more basic explanation for why the stock price dropped: "There were more sellers than buyers today."
Onsale is one of the main competitors in the rapidly growing on-line auction field, a sort of cyberbazaar in which visitors to the company's Web site (onsale.com) are offered a chance to bid on items (including, in a recent charity event, a date at Spago's in Los Angeles with Ms. California) while spectators on the site ("lurkers," in company lingo) watch the action. Many buyers type in comments along with their bids. "Stop bidding -- it's refurbished!" and "Please, let me have it -- need to get this for Grandma's birthday" were two recent entries.
While the company is both a pioneer and current leader in on-line auctions, how it will fare in a competitive field where some experts expect annual sales to climb to $1 billion remains unclear. But even that is part of its appeal to employees.
"It just seemed to me like a lot of really exciting things were happening with Internet companies," said Kristin Westland, 29, a human resource manager, who came here two years ago after spending several years as a struggling actress in Los Angeles (she did manage to land a bit part in a "Seinfeld" episode).
"I was very tired of L.A., the insecurity of all that, the multitude of jobs, never knowing if a break was going to happen," she said. So she gave it up for the insecurity and the never knowing if a break is going to happen of Silicon Valley.
Like many workers at the company, Ms. Westland has no children. Even as she described the excitement of trying to help make Onsale a dominant business in the auction field, she paused when asked whether she would feel the same way if she had a family to support.
"Kids?" she said. "I don't know. Wow. You're really mortgaging your future at that point. I don't know. Kids would make it a whole new ball game."
Still, for now, Onsale's employees seem very happy to put in 12- to 14-hour days for a lower salary than they might otherwise get -- as long as they retain the chance to strike it rich down the line.
"When I first came here, I was like, 'Hey! Stock options!" said Ms. Rodriguez, who came to Onsale from a job selling compact disks and videos in a local store. "This is new to me, this is a first. I actually have stock options in something."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Led by Asia, Stocks Abroad Rise Sharply

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Stock markets surged from Singapore to Seoul today in a powerful rally, fueled by a stronger Japanese yen and interventionist government policies in Hong Kong and Malaysia.
The sharpest increases were in Malaysia and Hong Kong, a pattern that dismayed some free-market advocates, since both recently intervened in their markets. In Malaysia, the Government imposed sweeping capital controls. 
 Rather than flee, investors bought heavily. Kuala Lumpur's stock exchange rose a record 23 percent, to 443.59 points. By shielding itself from the global market, Malaysia has been able to lower interest rates, attracting local investors, particularly big pension funds with ties to the Government.
In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index soared 7.9 percent, to 8,076 points, as investors reacted enthusiastically to lower interest rates and new Government measures to police the market more strictly. Those measures came in the aftermath of a $15 billion Government buying spree to prop up shares.
"We've had a technical rebound in these markets," said Miron Mushkat, the director of strategy at Indocam Asia Asset Management. "With the Government policies, there is a greater desire to inject liquidity into the system."
Mr. Mushkat drew a distinction between Malaysia, which has erected a wall around its economy, and Hong Kong, which is trying to take the sting out of its participation in the global economy by supporting its stock market and devising new rules to ward off foreign speculators.
"Malaysia has closed the door; Hong Kong is repainting it," he said.
 In early trading Tuesday, the Hang Seng was up 2.1 percent. Stocks in Malaysia were down 3.8 percent.
Still, in both markets, it is government policy -- rather than underlying optimism about the local or global economy -- that is spurring investors to buy shares. If the Hong Kong and Malaysian markets were functioning freely, interest rates would probably be higher and shares would probably trade low.
"The performance of the markets doesn't alter our uncertainty," said Jan Lee, the chief economist of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, which has been a big target of Hong Kong's buying spree.
In other Asian markets, the reason for today's increase was external -- the strengthening of the Japanese yen relative to the United States dollar. Analysts attributed the increasing value of the yen to speculation that the Federal Reserve Board may cut interest rates in the United States to reduce the risk of a recession. In Malaysia and Hong Kong, however, the increases were driven primarily by local government policies.
Stocks also rose in other markets. In London, the FTSE-100 index closed 3.5 percent higher, a 180-point advance, its second-largest point gain ever. German shares closed about 2 percent higher.
But in Russia, political and financial chaos continued. The Parliament refused to confirm acting premier Viktor Chernomyrdin, the Central Bank president offered to resign and the ruble fell further.
Officials in Hong Kong said today that their three-week-long intervention had succeeded in driving foreign speculators out of their market. The Government had accused the speculators of improperly manipulating Hong Kong's market in an effort to drive down shares and futures contracts. "We made an incursion, and we want to leave as quickly as possible," said Sir Donald Tsang, the financial secretary of Hong Kong. "We are not in the business of making long-term investments in commercial companies."
Although Hong Kong is no longer buying shares, it has opened a new front in its campaign against the speculators. Today, the Government announced a 30-point plan to tighten the securities and futures markets. The new rules would stiffen penalties for violations of securities laws, increase monitoring of short-selling and restrict the lending of shares for the purpose of short-selling.
On Saturday, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority announced a package of seven measures intended to strengthen the link between the Hong Kong dollar and the United States dollar. The highly technical regulations guarantee, among other things, that licensed Hong Kong banks can convert Hong Kong dollars into United States dollars at a fixed exchange rate of $7.75 to $1.
Sir Donald reiterated the Government's pledge to maintain the fixed exchange rate. And he said Hong Kong had no plans to follow Malaysia down the path of capital controls. "We hate to be in the market," he said.
If Hong Kong is still espousing a free-market credo, Malaysia has swung clearly to a government-dictated approach. Analysts said today's increase on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange was driven by institutional investors with ties to the Government. Foreign investors have effectively been frozen out of the market, since Malaysia's currency, the ringgit, no longer trades outside the country.
Indeed, analysts said another reason for the sharp rise in Malaysia's market was that foreign investors were finding it hard to sell their shares because they could no longer transfer their ringgit holdings out of the country.
The architect of Malaysia's new policy, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, named himself Finance Minister today, less than a week after he dismissed Anwar Ibrahim, his reform-minded protege, who had been both Finance Minister and Deputy Prime Minister. Mr. Anwar's opposition to closing off Malaysia's market had caused a bitter rift between him and Mr. Mahathir.
As Mr. Mahathir tightens his grip on Malaysia's economy, Mr. Anwar is battling charges of sexual misconduct and treason.
Analysts said that shielding Malaysia from the ravages of the global market could pay short-term dividends. The lower interest rates, in addition to lifting shares, could jump-start Malaysia's stalled economy. And the capital controls will insure that Malaysia does not suffer any more painful devaluations. "If the Malaysian experiment is successful, and other Asian countries are still struggling a year from now, it could lead to some disillusionment with naked capitalism and Anglo-Saxon-style markets," Mr. Mushkat said.
But other analysts warned that economic isolationism may give Malaysia the excuse to put off necessary economic restructuring. That is the same argument critics have used to fault Hong Kong's intervention.
Mark Mobius, the president of the Templeton Emerging Markets Fund, said the fund would no longer invest in either Hong Kong or Malaysia. Mr. Mobius said he was worried that Hong Kong's recent actions raised questions about its commitment to the link between its currency and the United States dollar.
As for Malaysia, Mr. Mobius said the Government's restrictions on taking capital out of the country amounted to a "theft of assets."
"If we allow this kind of thing to spread globally," Mr. Mobius said, "the whole financial system will freeze up."

Tissue From Flu Victims
Scientists who exhumed several bodies in Norway said they had retrieved tissue samples from the remains that they hoped would provide traces of the mysterious flu virus that killed more than 20 million people worldwide in 1918 and early 1919. They want to learn why the contagion was so much more virulent and lethal than any flu virus before or since. But the scientists were disappointed to discover that the bodies had been buried in shallow graves, not below the permafrost line, which they had thought would have preserved the bodies almost intact. HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Three Marketers Select Agencies

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
Three marketers have made decisions on their accounts.
Cars.com, an Internet automotive data base service, named Stein Rogan & Partners in New York as the first agency to handle its on-line and traditional advertising account. Billings were estimated at $26 million for 18 months. Cars.com, a unit of Classified Ventures L.L.C. in Chicago, made the decision without a formal review. 
 Weight Watchers International, a unit of the H. J. Heinz Company in Woodbury, N.Y., named Seiden Group in New York to handle the account of its weight-loss centers, which Seiden had handled on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $25 million. Lowe & Partners/ SMS in New York, which once handled those duties, continues to handle media planning and buying; Lowe is part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
And the Texas Department of Economic Development in Austin selected McCann-Erickson Southwest in Houston to handle its Texas tourism account, which had been handled by GSD&M in Austin for more than a decade. Billings for the five-year contract were estimated at $12 million a year. The decision came after a two-month review that had been narrowed to McCann Southwest, which is part of the McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising unit of Interpublic, and GSD&M, a unit of Omnicom Group.

HEADLINE: Unwinding to a Caribbean Rhythm

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
Normally, Marjorie Smith, 50, is a manager of the administrative staff at the World Bank in Washington, an office where people are not known for excessive dress.
But yesterday Ms. Smith, who was born in Trinidad, got herself into an enormous blue and white feathered costume, had her face painted to match, then danced down Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn. "This is my stress-buster," she said. 
 That seemed to be the theme of the 31st annual West Indian American Day Carnival, a pageant that has surpassed the Thanksgiving and St. Patrick's Day parades as the largest and most elaborate in the city.
Yesterday the two-mile route stretching along Eastern Parkway from Utica Avenue to Grand Army Plaza, in Brooklyn's Caribbean heart, was jammed with revelers. They ate jerk chicken, curried goat and black pudding, dressed up in thongs and as peacocks, and danced to a throbbing calypso beat on trucks advertising Guinness stout and Hennessey cognac. Police last night did not have a firm estimate of how many people attended.
The day was stifling until showers cooled things off. The mood was an island sultriness combined with New York attitude.
"Buy six beers, and I'll get you a free face painting," said a vendor, Jerry Vento, 27, of Canarsie, as a woman passed by.
"Six beers -- you can paint my body, baby," the woman shot back.
The parade is the biggest event of the year for New York's burgeoning West Indian community, whose numbers are estimated at 600,000.
"I wait for this," said Reshonah Bennett, 22, a student at the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan. "Fall is coming, so it's like a brand new start."
Ms. Bennett was born in the United States but her parents were born in Trinidad, and yesterday she and four other families from the second floor of her Eastern Parkway apartment building were selling food and drinks along the parade route. They hoped to make $3,000 by 1 A.M.
Dee Baker, 39, of the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, was selling jerk chicken on the parade route for a catering service called Goodies, and dancing at the same time. She came to New York from Jamaica two years ago, and misses home.
"It's not often you get the chance to get the spirit of the old things," she said. "And you can behave in a way that people don't think is strange. It gives us a chance to be Jamaican."
Ms. Baker works part time as a nanny on Long Island, which has made her wonder about why people here work so hard.
"Even though you see the wealth, the people don't act like there's wealth," she said. "People get up in the morning and go to work and then they come home late at night. But at home, we have a life style. You go to work, you leave, and you might call your friends up. We have a lot of entertainment places along the beaches. Or you might meet at a pool. It's definitely less stress."
The usual clutch of politicians made pilgrimages to the parade site. Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, who is running for the Senate, arrived in a coat and tie, but was later spotted in a "Taste of the Tropics" T-shirt as he waved from the top of a double-decker bus and swayed gingerly to a calypso beat.
Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, who is running for governor, wore a blue business suit and blue pumps and danced down the street with the Mystic Promise band. "We're teaching her," said Tessa Caesar, 24, a member of the band.
Many things were for sale, like pina coladas served in pineapples with paper parasols, dolls, jewelry and clothes. Among the T-shirt slogans: "When I Die and Heaven Doesn't Want Me, Take Me Straight to Trinidad"; "Trini to the Last Drop," and "Every Sister Should Have a BMW -- Black Man Working!"
The skies above the parade darkened ominously at 2:30 P.M., and soon after that, they opened, sending some people screaming for the subways. Others ran for cover under the nearest food tent, which created some interesting groupings.
Up near the Brooklyn Museum of Art, Patricia Brown found herself covering up the carrot cake she was selling and standing in her tent next to Sonya Smith, 29, a woman who calls up people who have not paid their Bell Atlantic phone bills; Ms. Smith's son, Deshawn, 9; a man without a shirt who would not reveal his name, and a newspaper reporter.
Ms. Brown said she led spiritual and holistic retreats to Jamaica, and loved the West Indian parade.
As it rained, the anonymous man made a garbage bag raincoat for Deshawn, who was cold. "That's $500, custom," the man said. "This is an original. Stop shivering."
Then he inexplicably started haranguing the group about Monica S. Lewinsky. Ms. Smith rolled her eyes. "Wrong event," she said.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 2; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Waiter, There's an Elbow in My Soup

BYLINE: By Eric Asimov 

 BODY:
"SO, I don't know, what should I tell him?" asked the young woman during dinner at Frank, a crowded little restaurant in the East Village, after telling the sad tale of her unhappy relationship.
I had an opinion about her former boyfriend, but I kept it to myself. After all, I didn't even know her name. I just happened to be sitting at the next table. 
 Short of pointing a telescope through your neighbor's window, few experiences offer better access to the intimate details of strangers' lives than dining in Manhattan restaurants.
Who hasn't had the pleasure of being squeezed onto a narrow banquette where the tables are too close for comfort? Your mind may be on your companion across from you, but you cannot avoid being distracted by the couples sitting on either side. You overhear their conversations, you inhale their perfume, you can almost taste their food. And woe betide you if a cellular phone chirps, as diners dig into their pockets or bags, elbows cocked and ready to do damage.
It is hard to remember, as little as five years ago, dining in such cramped quarters. But today, with rents soaring and restaurants booming, restaurateurs feel justified squeezing in an extra table or two -- even if it means the difference between convivial and claustrophobic. And New Yorkers, who are happy just to get a table in the first place, are putting up with being packed into dining rooms with an almost biological efficiency.
"Well, that's New York," sighed Charles Morris Mount, who has designed restaurants all over the country. "It's the battle of the inch."
Of course, no one accustomed to squeezing into tiny apartments and crowded subways would expect throne-like accommodations in a restaurant. You wouldn't even want them in places like Jean-Claude or Balthazar, bustling French bistros where the tight tables contribute to the air of excitement.
But at restaurants like Frank or Palmetta Plantation House on the Upper East Side, small, inexpensive places where food may be worth the discomfort, the jostling and crowding come dangerously close to ruining the meal.
At the best of Manhattan's midpriced restaurants, from Nick & Toni's Cafe near Lincoln Center to Jo Jo on the Upper East Side to EQ in Greenwich Village, you can expect banged knees and other close encounters.
At EQ, a chic restaurant where tables are placed like puzzle pieces to fit in the tiny dining room, a stout man sitting at the round center table one recent night leaned back in after-dinner repose and was practically in the lap of a diner against the wall.
"The big round table, the dimension was made wrong," Dennis Foy, the chef and co-owner, fumed. "It was supposed to be a 54-inch round, and it's a 60-inch round, which is standard. I lost six inches of floor space, and that infuriated me."
And even though you would expect more luxurious restaurants to be more comfortable, some of the fancier places like Osteria del Circo lack elbowroom.
"The first question a restaurateur asks is, 'How many seats can I put in?' " said Adam Tihany, who designed Osteria del Circo and Le Cirque 2000 and who owns the restaurant Remi. "It's the cost of real estate -- how much money can you squeeze out per square foot?"
Of course, there are other considerations. Like the city's fire and building codes. While the city does not specify the number of people a restaurant can serve, it does require that restaurants maintain clear three-foot corridors leading to exits. The city divides restaurants into two categories, Mr. Tihany said. Those that seat 74 or more people are required to have two exits, with aisles that are clearly identified. Those with fewer than 74 seats don't need two exits but still must have unobstructed aisles.
Before a restaurant opens, it presents its plan for approval to the city's Buildings Department and Fire Department. Once approved, said Vincent Falcone, a fire protection plan examiner in the Fire Department, further inspections are rare, usually only when somebody complains.
"They don't check to see if tables have enough distance," Mr. Tihany said. "They don't care if the operator crams people in, as long as there is a way to get out in case of emergency."
While that probably is small comfort to diners, it is a good thing for restaurant owners, because economics often dictates the need for a higher seating capacity. As uncomfortable as crowded restaurants may be, they ultimately indicate a healthy industry and a healthy economy. Where were the crowds 10 years ago, after the 1987 stock market crash, when restaurant after restaurant went under?
And though there are no figures for restaurants alone, Garrick-Aug Associates, an agency that specializes in store leasing, reported that the average retail rent -- including restaurants -- has risen steadily over the last two years, to $66 a square foot from $51, while the availability of space has dropped. "Obviously, the higher the rent, you either have to serve more meals or raise prices," Mr. Tihany said. "If the market won't bear higher prices, you have to add more people."
This is especially true of smaller, less-known restaurants, which, without advertising or high profile, must create a buzz to attract more customers. Nothing brings in more people like a crowd.
"Activity is a key to more activity," Alan Mannarelli, who builds and finances downtown restaurants, said. "Other than Chanterelle, who doesn't cram in as many tables as they can?"
Certainly, Frank cannot be accused of neglecting even the littlest nook or cranny in squeezing 32 seats into its tiny, 310-square-foot space. You had better be prepared to enjoy your neighbor's conversation along with your insalata Caprese, or you won't enjoy Frank.
"We wanted to create an intimacy," said Roy Docouto, who built Frank with the owner, Frank Prisinzano. "At other places, you're alone at your table. We wanted people to feel as if they were sitting at the same table together. Strangers have become friends here. It promotes a sense of, 'Say hello to your neighbors.' "
In other words, Frank is making a virtue of necessity. But others do the same by design.
"There's a certain energy to a dining room, and if tables get too far apart, they lose that energy," said David Rockwell, a designer, whose restaurants include Nobu and Payard Patisserie and Bistro. At Payard, for example, the three dining areas have distinct seating schemes: Tiny cafe tables and hard chairs packed into the bakery area, intended for quick bites; a bistro area, with larger tables, that is lively but cramped and noisy, and a more spacious, sedate area on the mezzanine.
"What is a restaurant's concept?" Mr. Tihany asked. "Is it an urban bistro? Four-star dining? Relaxed trattoria? Each of these concepts has a certain energy that dictates the seating."
While New York restaurateurs -- at all levels -- usually have more ambition than space, this problem can inspire creative solutions. EQ is almost a textbook example of a small downtown restaurant making the best of a tight space. Mr. Foy also designed the dining room, which needed to seat around 40 people in 400 square feet. EQ's wide chairs, with their fawn-colored leather seats, are roomy and luxurious, and the lighting is warm and inviting, showing off the fish motif of the cloth banquettes and the subtle pattern of the carpet. But even the finest materials could not extend the dimensions of the room.
"I realized that I had to use every square inch," Mr. Foy said.
In fact, the rectangular dining room, broken up only by a small bar near the entrance, feels comfortable, though not quite spacious. But maintaining that level of comfort requires the stars, and the diners, to align perfectly. For example, the banquette along one wall seats 20 people. Banquette tables generally accommodate groups of two and four. Two tables for two eat up more space than one table for four because the tables must be separated.
EQ tries to leave about 18 inches between banquette tables, said its architect, Vincenzo Fressola, roomier than the 6 inches typical of bistros but not quite the 2 feet of luxury restaurants.
Sometimes, though, fate intervenes, as it did recently when every table was occupied by a couple. Handbags banged into water glasses, and it took real maneuvering to get out of the banquette to go to the restroom.
Opposite the banquette and between the bar and the kitchen is a cozy alcove that seats 10 along three walls, with a table for six in the middle of the floor. With each table occupied, a waiter reciting specials to one must do an intricate pas de deux with another waiter who arrives with food for the neighboring table. Their practiced steps allow them to stay out of one another's way, but trying to follow the waiter's recitation as he dances back and forth is dizzying.
Designers, Mr. Tihany said, begin planning a layout by deciding on the size of the tables for two. Typically, he said, these are 24 inches wide by 27 inches deep in a bistro or trattoria, and 32 inches wide by 36 inches deep in a luxury restaurant.
Fancier restaurants generally require bigger tables for the simple reason that they have more stuff to fit on their thick white tablecloths. You may have no use for a fish fork, but there it is, along with a battalion of wine glasses, butter knives and bread plates, to say nothing of cellular phones and, of course, the check. A simpler restaurant doesn't need to accommodate so much equipment. Bread can sit on the table rather than on its own plate; the same forks can be used for salad and steak.
Oversize plates, made so popular in the nouvelle cuisine days, are another enemy of tiny tables, but chefs still seem too willing to sacrifice table space so they can display their artistic squiggles of sauce and tossed herbs. Needless to say, simple arithmetic makes clear that 12-inch luxury plates, to say nothing of the 14-inch monsters, create a logjam on the tables of a bistro.
No matter how carefully the tables and layout are planned, the restaurant experience still depends on the characteristics of a space. Osteria del Circo, which is run by the three sons of Sirio Maccioni, the owner of Le Cirque 2000, is pretty tightly packed. "The kids liked it tight," Mr. Tihany, the designer, said. "They wanted to feel the energy."
When the dining room is half empty, it can be low-key and pleasant, but as the room gets crowded and the energy bubbles, the high ceilings seem to throw sound back toward the floor, making conversations at nearby tables easier to hear than your own.
By contrast, the new Le Cirque 2000 is more spacious than the notoriously tight original, but it, too, can feel cramped, especially when a series of couples sit elbow to elbow along the banquette in the rear room near the kitchen.
If highly designed restaurants like Le Cirque and Circo represent one typical New York experience, the tiny restaurants that line Cornelia Street in Greenwich Village are another. On a recent Saturday night, restaurants like Le Gigot, Pearl Oyster Bar, Little Havana, Home and Po seemed as crowded as the left-field stands with Mark McGwire at the plate. In these tiny dining rooms, designers have little flexibility.
"You take the architectural formulas, and you divide by 4, and you have the room available to us," said David Page, an owner of Home, a stylish little American restaurant. "The ambiance created by the coziness of the space is somehow related to its success."
Home can seat 32 people at the handmade varnished wood tables in its dining room -- make that 32 average-size people.
"We made the booths as big as possible, given the space we had," Mr. Page said. "But if your waist line is bigger than, say, 40 inches, it's impossible."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
That old American Express standby, the check, will soon be out in that new currency, the euro.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
AMERICAN EXPRESS said yesterday that it would print euro-denominated traveler's checks in time for sales to start on Jan. 1, 1999, the beginning of the European Monetary Union. While the euro becomes the official currency of the 11-nation euro-zone next Jan. 1, with national currency exchange rates fixed to the euro, the circulation of euro notes and coins will not begin until Jan. 1, 2002.
During the three-year transition, consumers will be able to use the American Express euro traveler's checks -- in denominations of 50, 100 and 200 euro -- to pay for goods and services while merchants begin to convert to euro pricing. 
 "We expect the euro-denominated traveler's checks to be accepted by local merchants as soon as they begin pricing their products in euros," said Victoria Handwerk, an American Express spokeswoman. "But during the transition, American Express traveler's checks, as always, can be cashed for local currency if desired at our travel service offices within the euro-zone."
She also said the euro traveler's checks would enable purchasers to travel anywhere in the euro-zone without having to worry about multiple currencies. The euro-zone countries are Germany, France, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Austria, Spain, Portugal, Ireland and Finland.
The new traveler's checks will have a pastel-colored world map on the front and acceptance instructions in English, French and German on the back. They will include security features like those on dollar-denominated checks.
The euro-denominated checks will be available worldwide beginning Jan. 1, 1999, at American Express travel service offices, at some financial institutions, exchange bureaus and travel agencies, including the American and Canadian Automobile Associations. In the United States, American Express card holders will be able to order the euro checks by telephone (800 221-7282) for delivery by mail after the new year.
During the transition, American Express traveler's checks will also be available in local currencies, and will be valid indefinitely. But national currencies and national-currency traveler's checks will not be sold after June 30, 2002, when the euro will become the only legal currency used in the participating countries.
 
Coping With the Strike
While the strike against Northwest Airlines continues to inconvenience travelers in the Midwest, business travelers appear to be taking it more or less in stride. A survey conducted last Wednesday through Friday among corporate travel managers by the National Business Travel Association found that 63 percent of those surveyed had been affected by the strike, but that more than 77 percent had rebooked on other major carriers in anticipation of the strike.
Moreover, 22 percent of corporate travel managers surveyed said that during the strike they had turned to low-fare carriers, niche carriers or new-entrant carriers. And of those, more than 65 percent said they would consider moving the rebooked travel permanently to alternate carriers.
By the way, 57 percent of the travel managers do not want President Clinton to intervene formally in the strike.

No-Paper Ticketing Abroad
Over the next three months United Airlines, part of the UAL Corporation, plans to extend its electronic ticketing service to Singapore; three cities in China (Beijing, Shanghai and Hong Kong); Belgium; France; Germany; Italy, and the Netherlands. The addition of those 7 nations will bring to 12 the number of foreign countries using United E-mail. Australia, Canada, Japan and New Zealand were added this year, while Britain was put on line last October.
United said that the use of its E-tickets, which allow passengers to board planes without paper tickets, reached an all-time industry high of 3.4 million last month. During that month, 56 percent of eligible itineraries were ticketed electronically, an increase of almost 11 percent over August 1997.
Airlines are reluctant to disclose the exact amount of money they save with E-tickets compared with paper tickets, because estimated savings per E-ticket range all over the tarmac. But it is generally believed that the major airlines save about $10 million a month each, which of course explains their eagerness to expand electronic ticketing as far and as fast as possible.

HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing in U.S. Surged in July

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Borrowing by United States consumers grew at a faster-than-expected pace in July as auto and other personal loans surged, offsetting a drop in credit card debt, Federal Reserve figures showed today.
Borrowing rose by $5.3 billion for the month, to $1.266 trillion, after rising a revised $8.8 billion during June. Previously, the Fed said June borrowing had increased $6.7 billion. Before today's report, analysts had expected an increase of $3 billion for July. Economists watch the Fed's consumer credit statistics because it helps them gauge changes in consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of overall economic activity. 
 "Consumer credit has been posting modest gains in recent months, consistent with the conflicting forces of consumer optimism and still high credit card debt levels," said Greg Jones, an economist at Briefing.com in Jackson Hole, Wyo.
Revolving loans, which include credit card borrowing, fell $2.1 billion in July after rising $4.2 billion in June. Auto loans rose $3.5 billion after increasing $2.9 billion.
The pace of consumer credit was rising at a 5 percent annual rate during July, the Fed said. That is down from the 8.4 percent pace of borrowing in June.

HEADLINE: Merrill Lynch's Overseas Loss Is $135 Million

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it lost $135 million in July and August from its business with Russia and other emerging markets, and was now preparing to cut costs after the recent turmoil in financial markets.
The losses are expected to reduce the brokerage firm's net income for July and August to an estimated $102 million, according to Merrill, which made its announcement after the stock market closed. In the third quarter ended Sept. 30, 1997, Merrill earned $493 million. 
 Merrill has never before made such an interim announcement of its earnings, David H. Komansky, its chairman and chief executive, said in an interview yesterday.
A succession of other big American and European financial companies, including Citicorp, Bank of America, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company and the Bankers Trust Corporation, have announced hundreds of millions of dollars of losses in the last two weeks after Russia effectively defaulted on some debt, sending prices tumbling for the securities of developing nations and causing interest margins to widen rapidly for less creditworthy borrowers around the world.
The sudden reversal of fortune for financial services companies, some of the most successful companies of recent years, has been stunning. "It's impressive that so many big and smart institutions were on the wrong side of this trade," said John Keefe, president of Keefe Worldwide, a financial services consulting firm.
Spokesmen for Merrill have said often in the last couple of weeks that their company did not report financial results "intra-quarter," implying that it would wait until it announced its results for the three months ended Sept. 30 before disclosing its losses from Russia and other emerging markets.
Merrill said yesterday that it was making an exception to this policy "because of the intensive public focus on deteriorating conditions in the emerging markets, and the fact that most major international financial institutions have made some form of disclosure."
Merrill said that the emerging markets' losses it announced yesterday included the cost of marking down its inventories of securities to market value, allowances for its own exposure to third parties with losses in emerging markets and losses from its own trading. Merrill said that its cash earnings in July and August -- excluding the effect of good will, most of it from its recent $5.3 billion acquisition of Mercury Asset Management, the British money manager -- totaled $138 million.
Merrill's top executives declined to specify what expenses, or how much, they might seek to cut. "We're reviewing our alternatives now," Mr. Komansky said. "Discretionary spending, what can be eliminated, what can be deferred. We have a wide range of alternatives. How quickly to expand. We are in the midst of evaluating all that."
Guy Moszkowski, a managing director and brokerage analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, a subsidiary of the Travelers Group, said: "They clearly had, as they said, $135 million of emerging markets fixed-income trading losses in the quarter. But it's also clear from their other remarks that in order to get to only $100 million or so of profits for July and August there must be substantial additional losses with other credit-oriented bond products.
"This was a very unusual series of events in the credit markets," Mr. Moszkowski added. "But there will be some questioning of their credit controls."
Some other firms, including Salomon Smith Barney and Bankers Trust have reported worse losses than Merrill. "It's obviously not good news, but considering what some others have reported it could have been worse," Raphael Soifer, an analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, said.

HEADLINE: Nikos Kefalidis, 55, a Real Estate Developer

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
Nikos Kefalidis, a real estate developer and founder of KLM Construction Inc., was among the 229 passengers who died on Swissair Flight 111 when it plunged into the sea off Peggy's Cove, Nova Scotia, last Wednesday. He was 55 and lived in Manhattan.
Mr. Kefalidis (pronounced keff-a-LEE-deez) had been on the flight en route to Istanbul for the wedding of a boyhood classmate. 
 He was reared in humble circumstances in the Greek town of Alexandroupolis, near the Turkish border. His ancestors were Greek refugees from the Pontos region near the Black Sea in Russia.
At age 9, he was sent on a scholarship to Anavryta College, a boarding school near Athens, and he later studied at the University of Athens, where he received a degree in economics. He came to the United States in 1970.
"One of the only jobs he could get was as a house painter," said Grant Ruthizer, a vice president of KLM Construction Inc., and of Beta Steel, a privately owned steel mill in Portage, Ind., that Mr. Kefalidis helped found. "Then he moved from being a painter to establishing his own painting company and from that to general contracting and property development. He built several thousand residential apartments in Brooklyn and Manhattan."
There are now some 20 projects in the company's pipeline, Mr. Ruthizer said, including the construction of an 80,000-square-foot Old Navy store on a lot Mr. Kefalidis owned opposite Macy's on West 34th Street in Manhattan.
In June, despite some vocal opposition, Community Board 1 in Queens voted to approve a zoning change that would permit his firm to convert an old Steinway piano factory in Astoria into a $30 million project that would include 142 assisted living units for the elderly and 163 apartments.
Mr. Kefalidis was also involved in the development of Showboat Casino, a riverboat complex in East Chicago, Ind. "He had a passion for the deal and for negotiating, and he loved property," Mr. Ruthizer said.
In 1986, Mr. Kefalidis and a partner bought the village hall of Bellport on Long Island, only hours after they had first laid eyes on it. Asked what had prompted the purchase, he said: "I saw an ad this morning that the building was for sale. We decided to come out and bid on it. We'll rent it out."
He was also a leader in numerous political, civic and religious organizations and became a member of the Democratic National Committee in 1994. He was vice president of the board of the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity on the Upper East Side and on the Archdiocesan Council of the Greek Orthodox Church in the Americas.
"He treated everyone with the same deference and affection, from bricklayer to head of government," said Toli Fliakos, a vice president and assistant chairman of Beta Steel, in whose wedding Mr. Kefalidis had served as best man.
"He once noticed that something seemed to be bothering one of his employees," Mr. Fliakos recalled. "He dragged it out of the man, and it turned out that he was concerned about not having enough money to pay his daughter's private school tuition. Nikos said, 'Is that the problem? Go to the office and get a check tomorrow.' He did things like that all the time."
President Clinton sent a message of condolence to a memorial service for Mr. Kefalidis that was led last night at the cathedral by Archbishop Iakovos, the former Primate of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America.
Mr. Kefalidis is survived by his wife of 18 years, Laurie Doane Kefalidis, and their three children, Melanie, 17, Elias, 14, and Marisa, 8, all of Manhattan; his parents, Symeon and Kerasia Kefalidis of Alexandroupolis; a brother, Chrysanthos Kefalidis of Athens, and a sister, Efthimia Melidis of Alexandroupolis.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nikos Kefalidis. (National Herald)

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE CAMPAIGNS;
A Leading Democrat's Theme: It's a Long, Long Time From Now Till November

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Representative Martin Frost, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, finds himself facing two months of campaigning over uncertain ground for a party whose leader is up to his eyeballs in scandal.
"All I can say is that the situation is impossible to gauge," said Mr. Frost, a 10-term Congressman. "We'll know a lot more in the next couple of weeks. But I think it's going to be a very late-developing election." 
 His main sources of solace, he says, are that he thinks the Democrats still have several shots at wresting seats from Republicans, that campaign fund-raising does not seem to have been affected by the scandal and that the ground is just as uncertain for his opponents, who must guard against appearing to place partisanship above statesmanship.
The calls Mr. Frost has been getting in recent days from nervous and excited candidates have tended to fall into two categories, he said.
"Incumbents are concerned about what's going to happen in the next month, with the release of Ken Starr's report and what Congress might do about it," he said. "The new candidates, who are just trying to get into office, want to talk about the issues we've developed and how they're resonating in the campaign."
Mr. Frost, a lawyer and former journalist who represents the heavily black and Hispanic neighborhoods of south Dallas and south Fort Worth along with a bunch of white suburbs in between, said he had better answers for the newcomers than for the incumbents.
"The reality is that you can't tell at this point what's going to happen in the next month," he said. "And I don't know -- nobody knows -- how the people are going to respond to whatever comes out."
Not long ago, many Democrats were predicting that the strong national economy combined with widespread disapproval of Mr. Starr's approach to his investigation of President Clinton would redound in the party's favor, helping win back a few more of the seats that were lost in the conservative Republican landslide of 1994. Democrats even harbored hopes of retaking control of the House, where a net gain of only 11 seats would restore their majority.
Mr. Frost says that his position throughout the year has been that the Democrats stand a 50-50 chance of winning back House control, and that he sees nothing as yet to cause that outlook to change. But voicing optimism is part of Mr. Frost's job as head of the party's Congressional campaign effort, and even he is not immune to the unease that is growing among Democrats with Mr. Starr's report to Congress expected as early as this week.
"The question is whether Democrats will turn out in November," Mr. Frost said. "Most people's view about the Clinton investigation seems to be, Can't we get this behind us, can't we get this over with? People are just turned off politics. Thus, it becomes an issue of which side can get its base into the voting booth."
He rattled off the uncertainties: How much of the Starr report will be made fully public? Will Congressional impeachment hearings be held, and, if so, will they begin before or after November? What further sordid details might come out? Will the President say more than he already has? And, most perplexing of all in a climate where the President's job approval ratings have remained high despite all the disclosures, will any of it make the slightest difference to voters?
"There's no way to tell how it's going to go," Mr. Frost said.
For Labor Day, Mr. Frost's staff had him on a busy campaign kickoff in and around his home district: a breakfast with labor leaders at a downtown Dallas hotel, a barbecue lunch with an auditorium full of workers at a union hall in a suburb north of Fort Worth, then a sun-baked picnic in a wooded area called Flagpole Hill in the urban sprawl of northeast Dallas.
As in most political circles, the fallout from the President's troubles was a matter of much debate. Former Speaker Jim Wright, who for 35 years represented the Fort Worth district where the union hall is situated, was knocking back a plate of barbecue on the other side of the hall while Mr. Frost worked the room.
"I'll tell you, the situation is so volatile it's hard to make an intelligent judgment," said Mr. Wright, who resigned from the Speakership and from Congress while under fire over ethics in 1989. "I don't think I've ever seen a situation quite like this one."
In one measure of the President's political health, Mr. Frost asserted that requests from candidates for Mr. Clinton to visit their districts had held fairly steady: some candidates want him to come, some do not. It depends on the district and the dynamics of the race.
The Democrats' Congressional campaign committee is in the midst of a series of joint fund-raising events with the party's Senate campaign committee and the Democratic National Committee; the next one is planned for next Monday in New York. That event had a goal of $3 million, but some $3.2 million has already been raised for it, Mr. Frost said, leading some to predict that as much as $3.5 million will eventually come in.
And Mr. Frost said his reports from the field showed that those Republican seats the Democrats believe they have the strongest chance of winning continued to be within reach.
"We've been fortunate in several instances that Republicans who got elected in 1994 promising to abide by six-year term limits are now just two years away from when they'd either have to drop out or break their promise," he said. "So some of them are leaving early to run for another office, opening up some promising opportunities for us."

HEADLINE: Medicare Panacea Turns Patient;
H.M.O's Now Must Treat Their Own Ills

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
Like thousands of other elderly Americans, Eugene DeLorenzo cannot find a Medicare health maintenance organization in his area.
Mr. DeLorenzo, a 75-year-old retired real estate broker and his wife, Yuriko, enrolled July 1 in the Medicare plan of Healthnet, a unit of Foundation Health Systems Inc. Just three weeks later, Healthnet, unable to make a strong profit in the rural Northern California county where Mr. DeLorenzo lives, said it was ending its coverage there. 
 "My first thought was, 'Well, what are we going to do now?' " Mr. DeLorenzo recalled. "It wasn't going to do any good to get angry. That's just the way these H.M.O.'s operate."
With few options, the DeLorenzos enrolled in traditional fee-for-service Medicare, the federally financed health care plan for the disabled and people 65 or older. They may also have to pay hundreds of dollars more in premiums for a supplemental policy to replace the generous benefits Healthnet had offered.
People like the DeLorenzos are fast becoming common statistics. After aggressively recruiting the elderly and the disabled into their Medicare plans, many of the nation's H.M.O.'s are now heavily retreating.
The United Healthcare Corporation, once a darling of Wall Street, recently took a $900 million charge against earnings, in part to scale back its Medicare operations in 35 counties. In the last year, Aetna, Pacificare Health Systems, Oxford Health Plans, Foundation Health Systems, Kaiser Permanente and Blue Cross and Blue Shield associations have canceled Medicare plans in parts of 13 states. Virtually no Medicare H.M.O.'s are available in Utah or in rural Ohio.
With Medicare costs escalating wildly, Congress has long looked to managed-care plans as the prime remedy. Introduced in 1985 to allow private insurers to cover the elderly, Medicare H.M.O.'s provide health care more cheaply than the Government does. They also tend to offer more benefits to consumers and reduce the amount of claims paperwork.
Despite the H.M.O. problems in the Medicare market, Washington is now pushing for even more people to enroll in the plans. Yet financial setbacks for some H.M.O.'s have raised serious questions as to whether they can prosper covering Medicare patients. Though critics of managed care are quick to say they cannot, analysts say that several H.M.O.'s -- namely Humana Inc. and Pacificare, two of the nation's largest Medicare providers -- are making money on their plans, at least for now. But even these companies have had to make adjustments.
"There are a few H.M.O.'s that can be successful with Medicare, and they should prosper," said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a health care analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. Still, he added, "some of these earnings charges related to Medicare, United Healthcare's for example, show just how difficult this business is."
Several problems have bedeviled Medicare H.M.O.'s. For one thing, only 15.6 percent of Medicare's 37.5 million members are enrolled in Medicare H.M.O.'s.
Though the Government says it has overpaid the Medicare H.M.O.'s, the companies say the Federal monthly stipend for each enrollee is not enough to provide extensive benefits. That is especially problematic in rural areas, where Medicare H.M.O.'s cannot enroll enough members to negotiate discounts with local health care providers.
As a result, analysts say, H.M.O.'s must focus primarily on urban markets and must avoid offering generous prescription drug plans, which can attract a disproportionate number of sickly people.
While Medicare has long been a perilous market for many H.M.O.'s, it may soon get even tougher. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 will reduce the Government's Medicare spending by $115 billion over the next five years. Increases in the monthly stipends the Government pays to H.M.O.'s have been sharply reduced, a move that could further lower operating margins, which have always been thin and now hover around 3 percent.
Managed-care companies receive some $5,688 annually on average for each of their Medicare patients, according to the Health Care Financing Administration, which runs Medicare.
Uncle Sam's stipend comes with strings attached. The H.M.O.'s usually agree to provide more benefits than traditional Medicare does -- allowances for prescription drugs, hearing aids and eyeglasses. And they accept the premise that they can make profits by controlling costs better than the Government can.
A key to a healthy bottom line is to avoid a large percentage of sick patients, which can quickly devour revenues. The odds appear to be in the Medicare health maintenance organizations' favor: 90 percent of all Medicare enrollees are generally healthy and require only about $1,200 on average from the Government each year for medical bills, according to the Urban Institute's analysis of the 1996 Medicare Current Beneficiary Survey, the latest figures available. In contrast, the analysis found, the remaining 10 percent, who are sick, cost Medicare some $37,000 a year each.
The trouble is that in metropolitan markets with several competing Medicare plans, H.M.O.'s used prescription drug benefits to entice elderly members and ended up subsidizing lofty prescription drug bills. Moreover, the H.M.O.'s can end their exposure to ailing members only by leaving a county altogether, not by dropping coverage of individuals.
Humana and Pacificare have hedged the likelihood of losses by contracting with doctors to accept a fixed monthly payment for each member, regardless how much medical care that person may need. The policy, called capitation, pushes the financial risk onto the doctor to keep medical costs down.
Humana had 60 percent of its Medicare members in capitation arrangements at the end of the second quarter, aiming to increase the figure to 70 percent by the end of the year. Capitation paid the company big dividends. Revenues from Medicare H.M.O.'s accounted for half of the total earnings at Humana last year.
"Capitation is a great way to share the risk and to control costs," said Arun Kumar, a director at Standard & Poor's. "It works best with populations who are sophisticated about managed care. You see a lot of capitation on the West Coast. It's unlikely to be used on the East Coast, partly because there are a large number of specialists who don't want to share the risk."
To be profitable with their Medicare plans, H.M.O.'s may have little choice but to establish capitation policies wherever they can. Before the Balanced Budget Act, it was common for the Government to give H.M.O.'s annual stipend increases of 10 percent in some counties, a sum that many complained was too little. The increase has now been reduced to about 2 percent.
With a rise that slim -- it is less than half the national medical cost inflation rate -- some H.M.O.'s will have to renegotiate rates with health care providers. But the industry has other troubles. Although the Balanced Budget Act gradually raises the stipend H.M.O.'s receive for rural counties, critics doubt that the increase will be enough. Rural areas often have only one hospital, which has no incentive to lower its rates.
"In some rural areas, there is just not enough of a premium to cover the costs," said Lee N. Newcomer, medical director at United Healthcare. "A lot of people who live in a rural area drive into the city for medical treatment. They incur a city cost while we get paid the rural premium."
H.M.O.'s have also struggled to control their administration fees. Medicare plans, which must be sold in person, are more expensive than traditional commercial accounts, which may be pitched by telephone. Elderly people like to meet with company representatives, and they prefer seeing the plans' benefits and costs displayed in writing.
Analysts say that to survive, Medicare H.M.O.'s must cut back on benefits, a process that has riled consumers. According to Mr. Abramowitz of Sanford C. Bernstein, most H.M.O.'s are giving each Medicare enrollee $1,000 in benefits beyond basic hospital coverage but can afford only $750.
The cutbacks have already begun, and the most expensive perks are the first to go. In nearly every market where H.M.O.'s have slashed their offerings, this has has meant tossing out the prescription drug plan.
"I signed up for Secure Horizons because they had a good prescription drug plan," said Hollie Vinson, 43, who is disabled and lives in Chico, Calif. "Shortly after that, they discontinued the plan."
"I've had to go out and get my own drug plan," she added, "and it costs more than before."
Secure Horizons, Ms. Vinson's Medicare H.M.O., is a unit of Pacificare, one of California's biggest managed-care companies. Pacificare's cuts went a lot further elsewhere: The company ended its Medicare coverage in Utah and in parts of Washington and Oregon because of thin operating margins.
Market woes are so severe that experts wonder if any Medicare H.M.O. can prosper indefinitely.
Consumer groups say a financially sound Medicare H.M.O. may be a horror to its members. Opponents of capitation contend that the policy prompts too many doctors to choose costs over sound health care, saving nickels by canceling tests that are necessary.
Analysts question the effectiveness of the Government's efforts to lure more people into managed care. Under the Balanced Budget Act, those 65 and over can sign up beginning next year for preferred provider organizations, a network of doctors and hospitals that accepts Government payments for Medicare patients, or for a provider-sponsored organization, a network that is usually owned by the providers.
These plans could help Medicare H.M.O.'s by introducing more elderly people to managed care. But an efficient provider-sponsored group can also steal healthy members from a Medicare H.M.O. in its county.
So far, few providers are offering one of the new plans, leaving many experts to question their viability.
Consumer advocates say these new plans could be slow sellers, given the snail's pace at which Americans have embraced Medicare H.M.O.'s. Thirteen states have no Medicare H.M.O. plans at all, and even areas that have usually welcomed new types of health care remain stubbornly suspicious. Arizona and California have among the highest percentages of Medicare enrollment, at 39 percent each, but only 18 percent of New York's 2.6 million Medicare members are enrolled in H.M.O.'s and the penetration in Wisconsin is only 3 percent.
"Giving H.M.O. companies the opportunity to offer more Medicare plans is only going to make matters worse," said Bonnie Burns, a health care consultant in Scotts Valley, Calif. "They will keep the plans that are in profitable areas and drop the others that are not. Some people in some cities will have six plans while people in other cities will have none."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eugene and Yuriko DeLorenzo of Chico, Calif., have been left H.M.O.-less. (Brian Fann for The New York Times)
