HEADLINE: Big Metropolis on Campus;
New York Siren Song Lures More College Applications

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
New York hardly fits the usual image of College Town, U.S.A. And higher education will never dominate the local culture and economy the way it does in, say, Boston or Ann Arbor, Mich. But increasingly, New York is becoming the college applicant's destination of choice.
During the last five years, with financial and media businesses booming, crime plunging and the city re-emerging as the place to be, admissions offices say high school students have been applying to New York's colleges and universities in record numbers. Drawn by the city's glitter, its activity and its range of jobs and internships, they have been inundating the admissions offices at the big elite universities like Columbia and New York University as well as smaller regional schools like Pace and Marymount Manhattan. 
 "New York City is bigger, more exciting, special, wild and crazy," Gosia Rymsza-Pawlowska, a first-year student from Washington, said excitedly as she stood on a Broadway sidewalk the other day, waiting for a cart so she could move her luggage into her new dormitory at Barnard College.
While college applications nationwide have risen slowly -- they grew an average of 11 percent per college at four-year colleges between 1991 and 1996, according to the College Board -- colleges in New York City say their increase has been considerably steeper. This soaring demand, in turn, has allowed the colleges to burnish their images. The more applications they get, the more selective they can be, allowing them to admit better students and raising their rankings in rating guides like those of U.S. News & World Report.
New York University has seen applications rise 145 percent since 1991, to 24,500. Fordham, which has campuses in the Bronx and Manhattan, has seen applications double in the same period, to 7,621.
Columbia University's applications have risen 81 percent in the last five years, to 12,251 for a freshman class of 955 at Columbia College. Even though Columbia has expanded its freshman class by 110 over the past decade, the growth in applications has lowered its acceptance rate to 14 percent, which Columbia officials say makes it the third most selective college in the Ivy League, after Harvard and Princeton.
"We think a lot of this is because of the excellence in the programs we offer," said Columbia's president, George Rupp. "But we know that a major ingredient is that New York is viewed as a hot town and a great place to be."
Surging applications, 3,841 for a class of 549, have also transformed Barnard into the country's most popular women's college, said Judith Shapiro, the president, who also cited the city as a factor. "Students enter the gates, and it really is a community," she said. "But they walk outside, and all of New York is there."
Similarly, Pace University's New York campus and Marymount Manhattan have both seen applications rise 64 percent in five years. At the Juilliard School, Janet Kessin, a spokeswoman, said that while applications to other conservatories around the country have peaked after years of growth, Juilliard's applications have continued to climb.
A growing number of applications and new students are from out of town, forcing some universities to scramble for dormitory space and turning others from commuter colleges into residential ones. Marymount, once a commuter school on the Upper East Side, now draws a quarter of its students from outside the city and has had to rent space on Roosevelt Island and in Brooklyn. St. John's University in Queens has received more than 7,000 inquiries from around the country since it announced plans to build dormitories just a few months ago.
New York is unlikely to become a classic college town, but education officials say no other city matches it when it comes to the number of colleges (about 100 within the five boroughs) or students (half a million). The City University of New York alone has 200,000 students on its 21 campuses, while the Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities, a trade association of private colleges in New York State, says its 39 member colleges in New York City have about 163,000 students.
Students say they are drawn by the reputations and the particular offerings of the colleges they apply to: the dance programs at N.Y.U. or Barnard, for example, or the core curriculum at Columbia. But like Glenn Shor, a freshman from Coral Springs, Fla., who just started at N.Y.U.'s Stern School of Business, nearly all say the city was a crucial factor.
"New York City was probably like the biggest thing for me in choosing a college," Mr. Shor said this week as he waited in the Loeb Student Center for a briefing on jobs and internships, a thick black planner clutched in his hand. "I grew up in the suburbs, but there are so many opportunities here. You can't get much closer to Wall Street. I want to end up there eventually."
Students attending colleges in Manhattan are not the only ones who point to the city's lure. Garrett D. Sidmore, 18, a freshman from Danvers, Mass., at Manhattan College in the Bronx, said he chose New York over business schools closer to home because "everything is out there, connections."
"It'll be easier for me to visit the businesses in the city," he said, "to get the internships, the jobs, meet the people and network that I need to succeed."
While job opportunities are a huge draw, another is the arts and theater, both for aspiring performers and for those who simply want to watch. Nahede Khosrovi, 17, a freshman in the new Fordham-Alvin Ailey program, said she had found few comparable programs elsewhere that would have allowed her to pursue her goal of becoming a dancer while taking high-quality academic courses.
Not everyone understands New York's lure. Nina Narelle, 23, a freshman at Eugene Lang College at the New School, said that when she told her friends in Oregon that she was headed for New York, "they wrinkled up their faces in revulsion."
But she can't get enough of the city. An environmentalist used to spending lots of time in forests, in the two weeks since she arrived, she has explored Central Park, visited the Whitney Museum of American Art, and ridden a bike from 97th Street to 10th Street and back, yelling, "Watch out, buddy," at cabbies who came too close.
"It allows me to step out of myself," she said. "I've gotten lost a lot, but I'm having a fabulous time."
College officials say students in New York can receive an education unlike what they would get anywhere else, and colleges are increasingly setting up courses and internships that focus on the city and its cultural and business institutions.
Columbia University has created a program called Passport to New York, in which students not only have free access to about 15 institutions, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Brooklyn Academy of Music, but also may apply for paid internships at these institutions.
Manhattan College offers a series of classes known as site courses, in which 30 percent of the class time is spent in the city. They range from Skyscraper Architecture to In the Trenches of Wall Street to Theater in the City: Drama and Performance.
"The New York City theater is our campus," said Mary Ann O'Donnell, a professor of English and dean of the School of the Arts. "Students attend performances. That's their textbook."
"We've always had groups of culture vultures," she said. "But now the city is vibrant. And for those who view it from other places, it's perceived as safe once again. It's perceived as the place to be. They are studying abroad in New York."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
The Bulls Stampede Back, Shoving Chicken Little Aside

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Back to work. Back to school. Back to the bull market.
In a rush of emotional buying that peaked in the last half-hour of trading, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 380.53 points for the day, a 4.98 percent jump. 
 Although there were many players on yesterday's stock market stage, the protagonist was Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. In a speech at the University of California in Berkeley on Friday, Mr. Greenspan suggested that the Federal Reserve might cut interest rates if there was a worsening in the financial crisis that has humbled Asia and Russia and now threatens Latin America.
Investors have come to believe, though it is not always so, that falling interest rates inevitably push stock prices higher. Many of these believers stampeded into stocks yesterday.
But traders gave other reasons for the rush to stocks, all having more to do with psychology than with economics. In other words, the world remains an economically precarious place, higher stock prices notwithstanding.
Investors, for example, seemed to return from their Labor Day weekend thinking that the unrelenting selling of the last two weeks had taken stocks to levels that even Chicken Little would consider overdone. It was time to hunt around for bargains.
Investors may also have done a little check of the calendar and found that it was time again to buy. Why? Because since 1981, all bear markets -- defined as declines of 20 percent or more -- have reached bottom after an average of about 60 days. This includes the whipping investors took during the summer of 1983, the crash of 1987, the bear market of 1990 and the decline of early 1994.
Another factor working in favor of stocks yesterday was a flood of buying by investors who had made bets that share prices were going to continue their downward spiral -- buying that Wall Street calls short-covering. This is a type of forced purchase that occurs when pessimistic investors who had sold short -- selling shares they did not own in hopes of buying them back later at lower prices -- see these shares rise in value. Hurrying to cut their losses on trades gone awry, these investors buy back the shares they had sold earlier.
Then there was Abby Joseph Cohen, the Goldman, Sachs market strategist, who appeared on "Face the Nation" on CBS on Sunday to give her cheery predictions for stock prices. Perhaps this audience, more politically oriented than equity inclined, had not yet heard her argument for higher stock prices. Maybe they rushed to call their brokers yesterday morning.
While the surge was impressive, traders said that its steepness, particularly in the final half-hour of trading, looked very much like the work of so-called momentum investors, those who buy only after stocks have made a strong move. Many of these investors execute their trades near the end of the day in the hope that the surge will draw in other investors the following day.
Still, yesterday belonged to Mr. Greenspan. His comments telegraphing the possibility of a rate cut were all that investors needed to get their grooves back.
Does this make sense? Yes and no. In general, lower rates mean lower borrowing costs, a positive for corporate America. But some of the stocks that made the biggest moves yesterday, favorites like America Online, Lucent Technologies and Cisco Systems, do not qualify as interest-rate- sensitive stocks. It is to be expected that bank stocks would rally on news of a possible rate cut, but why should lower interest rates propel the shares of Internet darlings and computer makers?
Conversely, shares of certain companies that would benefit from lower lending and mortgage rates barely budged yesterday. Three home builders -- Toll Brothers, the Lennar Corporation and the Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation -- only inched up.
Yesterday's stock rally, one money manager said, illustrates how the market absorbs news almost instantaneously, leaving no time for investors to mull it all over and no room for error.
Indeed, in yesterday's trading, a substantial cut in interest rates -- one-half of one percentage point, not the one-quarter Mr. Greenspan is famous for -- was almost instantly factored into stock prices. What happens if the Federal Reserve does not ease monetary policy at its meeting Sept. 29? The market would be mighty disappointed.
Even though a possible rate cut gave fuel to the fiery stock prices, traders noted that it should not have been news to investors. Bond traders are already counting on not one, not two, but three rate cuts of one-quarter percentage point each. Investors can see these expectations reflected in the five-year Treasury note, which was trading at a yield of 4.92 percent yesterday -- well below the 5.5 percent yield on Federal funds, the rate the Federal Reserve sets.
Sure enough yesterday, while stocks were racing, bonds yawned. The 30-year Treasury bond yielded 5.36 percent at the end of the day's trading, up from the 5.28 percent close of Friday.
What stock market investors heard in Mr. Greenspan's Berkeley speech was that they now had something they had been sorely lacking for weeks: a tower of strength. With the world in disarray, the International Monetary Fund weakened and President Clinton hobbled, equity investors seized on Mr. Greenspan as the best candidate to save the planet.
For Mr. Greenspan, who has scolded investors in the past for being overly euphoric, to have ignited a new round of stock market euphoria is an odd turn of events.
But the future health of the stock market depends not so much on Mr. Greenspan and interest rates as it does on corporate profits. And those are still looking risky.
Indeed, analysts in Salomon Smith Barney's economics group lowered their profit estimates for the Standard & Poor's 500 stocks for both 1998 and 1999 last Friday. The analysts, led by Mitchell Held, wrote that they were now expecting earnings growth on the S.& P. of just 1.5 percent this year and, more ominously, a decline of 1 percent next year. They said that the downturn in Asia would continue well into 1999 and that growth in the emerging markets of Latin America would slow from 3 percent in 1998 to zero next year. Throw Canada into the mix, a country that has seen its currency plummet and one that accounts for 25 percent of American exports, and you have questions about the health of nearly 75 percent of the market for United States exports.
The report concluded, "Financial market developments of recent weeks will result in slower economic activity on a global scale in the year ahead, dimming the earnings outlook for domestic companies considerably."

HEADLINE: Suspect Held in Colorado Shooting Rampage

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: AURORA, Colo. Sept. 8

 BODY:
A 17-year-old boy in police custody is the sole teen-age survivor and a suspect in a Labor Day shooting rampage that killed five other teen-agers and a woman, the authorities said today.
The police and witnesses said that on Monday, the suspect, Alexander Pagosian, and a friend, Michael Martinez, 18, who were carrying shotguns, pulled bandanas over their faces and entered two houses in the suburbs of Aurora, east of Denver. They shot and killed Greg Medla, 18, his girlfriend, Marissa Avalos, 16, and his mother, Penny Medla, 37, at the first house, and Eddie Morales and Zachery Over at the second house, the police said. 
 A few hours later, Mr. Martinez was found dead in a field about 10 miles away, where he had been shot repeatedly with a handgun, the police said.
Early today, the Aurora police received a call from Mr. Pagosian, which led them to him. Both suspects are from Aurora and the police said they had criminal records. Mr. Martinez was also expelled from high school last year.
The killings constituted the largest multiple slaying in Colorado in recent decades.
"All of them knew each other," J. Michael Stiers, Aurora's deputy police chief, said today at a news conference. He declined to say whether drugs or gangs were involved.
Neighbors spoke today about the crimes, on Harvard Avenue and on Paris Way, two tree-lined streets in solidly middle-class subdivisions.
A witness said the two men had left the crime scene and walked toward Mr. Martinez's home two blocks away.
"They walked out with their guns wide open and headed to the apartments," a 15-year-old boy named Derrick said. Speaking through a locked screen door on Harvard Avenue, he refused to give his last name, saying: "If they are cold enough to walk in there in broad daylight with their guns out, then who knows?"
Another neighbor, Mary Lyle, said Penny Medla's, 7-year-old daughter, Kayla, had run out of her house screaming, "Michael shot my Mom!" The police said Mr. Martinez was a family acquaintance.
"Your economic standing doesn't protect you from it," Mrs. Lyle said, adding that she and her husband had just finished building their house and were moving in. "We built this as our dream house, but it started with a nightmare."
Homicides here in this city of 260,000 jumped last year to 17, from 11 in 1996. In 1993, a robbery here at a fast-food restaurant by an employee left four dead.
But the 1997 homicide rate of 7 per 100,000 in Aurora, Colorado's third largest city after Denver and Colorado Springs, was still half the rate of Denver's rate of 15 per 100,000.
Federal Bureau of Investigation statistics collected last year for the nation's 38 mid-sized cities show Aurora ranking third in violent crime.
For years, Aurora has been a conservative city shaped by military employers -- Lowry Air Force Base, Fitzsimmons Army Hospital and Buckley Air National Guard Base. Since 1990, change has been rapid: Lowry and Fitzsimmons closed and the population surged 17 percent.

HEADLINE: Study Strongly Supports Affirmative Action in Admissions to Elite Colleges

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
A major new study of the records and experiences of tens of thousands of students over 20 years at the nation's elite colleges concludes that their affirmative action policies created the backbone of the black middle class and taught white classmates the value of integration.
The study, which challenges much of the conservative thinking about affirmative action, is to be released today by Princeton University Press in a book titled "The Shape of the River: Long-Term Consequences of Considering Race in College and University Admissions." It was written by two former Ivy League presidents, William G. Bowen of Princeton University, an economist, and Derek Bok of Harvard University, a political scientist. 
 Examining grades, test scores, choice of major, graduation rates, careers and attitudes of 45,000 students at 28 of the most selective universities, the authors say that although they are both advocates of race-conscious admissions policies, they wanted to test the assumptions underlying such policies.
Having completed the work, they say it should put to rest major objections to such policies, especially the notion that both whites and blacks are ultimately cheated by them.
With its rich database and carefully calibrated tone, the study will most likely lead the charge in a liberal counteroffensive to recast the debate over affirmative action, which in the last two years has been rolled back in California and Texas and is under serious challenge in Michigan and Washington.
The counteroffensive, involving books, articles and academic conferences, seeks to broaden the notion of merit beyond tests and grades and hails affirmative action less as a means of overcoming past discrimination -- an older argument with decreasing political support -- and more as a way to insure a healthier future for whites and blacks.
The Bowen-Bok study limits itself to the practice of race-conscious admissions in elite higher education; that is, to considering the race of applicants to be a critical factor in whether they should be admitted -- as important, say, as where they are from or extracurricular activities.
The study begins by documenting the problem: blacks who enter elite institutions do so with lower test scores and grades than those of whites. And as they work their way through colleges like Yale and Princeton and state institutions like the Universities of Michigan and North Carolina, blacks receive lower grades and graduate at a lower rate.
But after graduation, the survey found, these students achieve notable successes. They earn advanced degrees at rates identical to those of their white classmates. They are even slightly more likely than whites from the same institutions to obtain professional degrees in law, business and medicine. And they become more active than their white classmates in civic activities.
The authors call black graduates of elite institutions "the backbone of the emergent black middle class" and say that their influence extends beyond the workplace.
"They can serve as strong threads in a fabric that binds their own community together and binds those communities into the larger social fabric as well," the authors say.
A striking finding was how much an elite education served as a pathway to success for all races. Blacks graduating from elite colleges earned 70 percent to 85 percent more than did black graduates generally.
Blacks and whites reported fairly substantial social interaction at college, which they said helped them relate to members of different racial groups later in life. Finally, the more selective the college, the more likely were blacks who attended it to graduate, obtain advanced degrees and earn high salaries.
The authors' focus on selective universities illustrates what they consider an often-ignored point: the debate over race-conscious admissions is relevant only to about 25 percent of universities. The rest take all or nearly all people who apply.
Professors Bowen and Bok say there are other facts that have been overlooked in the debate as well.
"Until now, this issue has involved much emotion but little evidence," said Mr. Bowen, who is now president of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, which sponsored the study. "When the Supreme Court decided Brown versus Board of Education in 1954, it relied heavily on social science studies. We hope our data influence the current Supreme Court when it rules on affirmative action."
Recent developments show that race-conscious admissions policies, approved within limits by the Supreme Court in its splintered 1978 Bakke ruling, are in trouble with the American public and may face re-examination by the Justices.
In the 1996 Hopwood case, for example, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit barred the use of race in university admissions, both public and private, in Texas, Louisiana and Mississippi. Two cases, expected to go to trial in mid-1999, challenge the undergraduate and law school admissions systems at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor, saying that they give illegal advantage to blacks and other minority applicants. In 1996, California banned the consideration of race in its public university admissions. In the State of Washington, a similar ban is up for voter approval.
"The Shape of the River" draws on data about students who entered college in 1976 and 1989 and on lengthy follow-up questionnaires distributed to them. It focuses on blacks because of the quantity of data available and because blacks have been at the heart of the debate.
Eighty percent of those receiving the questionnaires responded. The database, built by the Mellon Foundation beginning in 1994, provided statistical life histories as well as the views of 45,184 people on education and occupation, income, retrospective views of college, interaction with other races and civic participation.
The 28 institutions involved in the study were Barnard College, Bryn Mawr College, Columbia University, Denison University, Duke University, Emory University, Hamilton University, Kenyon College, Miami University (Ohio), Northwestern University, Oberlin College, Pennsylvania State University, Princeton University, Rice University, Smith College, Stanford University, Swarthmore College, Tufts University, Tulane University, the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the University of Pennsylvania, Vanderbilt University, Washington University, Wellesley College, Wesleyan University, Williams College and Yale University.
Skeptics might argue that the success Professors Bowen and Bok think they witnessed in those studied was simply a result of continuing preferences granted them by institutions and corporations as they rose. But Mr. Bowen said that those who entered college in 1976 were today about 40 years old and had had to demonstrate that they deserved the opportunities offered them.
He added, "The overwhelming nature and magnitude of the results is so striking that it is hard to attribute them to preferences."
Professors Bowen and Bok say in their book that a "race-neutral" admissions policy would be disastrous for American society, reducing black percentages at top colleges to less than 2 percent from 7 percent.
As an illustration of what that would mean, they constructed a rough profile of 700 blacks admitted in 1976 under race-conscious policies. Of the 700, 225 obtained professional degrees or doctorates; 70 are doctors, 60 are lawyers, 125 are business executives and more than 300 are civic leaders. Their average annual salary is $71,000.
A more troubling question, the authors acknowledge, regards the white students whom these black students displaced. Would society have been better off if they had attended instead of the blacks?
"That is the central question," the authors write, "and it cannot be answered by data alone." It is a clash of "principle versus principle, not principle versus expediency." They come down firmly on the side of admitting the blacks, saying that society needs them.
But they added a statistical argument and illustrated it with an analogy to parking spaces for handicapped drivers drawn from an article by Thomas J. Kane in a coming study from the Brookings Institution, "The Black-White Test Score Gap." "Eliminating the reserved space would have only a minuscule effect on parking options for non-disabled drivers," Mr. Kane writes. "But the sight of the open space will frustrate many passing motorists who are looking for a space. Many are likely to believe that they would now be parked if the space were not reserved."
Professors Bowen and Bok point out that if more than half of the blacks accepted at selective colleges had been rejected, the probability of acceptance for another white applicant would rise only 2 percent, to 27 percent from 25 percent.
Like handicapped parking spaces, they say, race-conscious admission policies have a major impact on the minority in question whereas eliminating them would only marginally help members of the majority.
One commonly voiced objection to affirmative action that the authors seek to demolish is the assertion that since blacks admitted through race-sensitive policies do not keep up with their white colleagues, they end up failed and stigmatized, an argument put forth by Stephan and Abigail Thernstrom in their influential book "America in Black and White" (Simon & Schuster, 1997).
"When students are given a preference in admission because of their race or some other extraneous characteristic," the Thernstroms wrote, "it means that they are jumping into a competition for which their academic achievements do not qualify them and many find it hard to keep up."
Professors Bowen and Bok say their data contradict that assertion.
Gen. Colin L. Powell, one of a handful of people given advance copies of the study, said he was deeply impressed by the quality of it.
Asked about the stigma that opponents say affirmative action imposes on blacks who attend these elite colleges, General Powell was dismissive.
"I would tell black youngsters to graduate from the schools magna cum laude," he said, "and get one of those well-paying jobs to pay for all the therapy they'll need to remove that stigma."
Generally, the authors say, their findings offer robust support for the way in which selective colleges have engaged in admissions procedures, examining merit in a broad context and assessing both the needs of the institution and the society.
"If you ask what bothers the public about these admission policies, it is probably the sense that there is some unfairness here," Mr. Bok said. "I have two responses. One is that there is a tendency to equate fairness with high school grades and scores that is not well-founded in terms of admissions practices. Second, fairness is something that really has to be defined in terms of what the institution is legitimately trying to accomplish.
"In the case of universities and colleges, race turns out to be very relevant because we are interested in what students can teach one another and race is a part of that in an increasingly diverse society."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stock Market Gauges Soar As Investors Seem Hopeful
The Dow Jones industrial average jumped nearly 5 percent, or 380.53 points, to 8,020.78, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 49.57 points, or 5 percent, to 1.023.46. The Nasdaq composite index registered its biggest point gain ever, 94.34 points, or 6 percent, closing at 1,660.86, and the Russell 2000 index of small and medium-sized stocks increased 14.86 points, or 4.28 percent, to 361.93.
Analysts attributed the turnaround in stocks to comments last Friday by the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, who gave investors hope that the Fed and other central banks might jointly respond to crises in Asian and Russian markets. Page A1. 

The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell sharply. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, increased to 5.36 percent, from 5.28 percent on Friday. C8.
 
Yeltsin Is Pondering His Next Move
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia was considering his options to calm the economic turmoil in that country after Parliament's second rejection of his choice for Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin. A12.
 
Goldman Veteran to Leave Firm
J. Christopher Flowers, a founder of Goldman, Sachs's lucrative financial institutions merger practice, plans to leave the firm at the end of November. The move comes the same day the firm reaffirmed its intention to end its private partnership and issue shares to the public in November. C7.
 
Brazil Plans Spending Reductions
The President of Brazil, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, announced measures to stimulate exports and contain spending. The plan's goal is to increase exports 15 percent a year, in the hope that they will reach $100 billion a year by 2002. The Government also announced a 20 percent across-the-board budget cut for national agencies for the rest of this year. C6.
 
A Wheelchair-Friendly Bus Concern
Greyhound Lines plans to announce that it will make all 4,000 stops on its nationwide bus system accessible to wheelchair users by October 1999. But groups representing those users said Greyhound planned to equip too few buses with lifts to deliver on the company's promises. A18.
 
American Express's Euro Checks
American Express will issue euro-denominated traveler's checks in time for sales to start on Jan. 1, 1999, the beginning of the European Monetary Union. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. C5.
 
British American Tobacco Up 38%
Shares in British American Tobacco soared 38 percent in London on the first day of trading since the company sold its financial services arm to the Zurich Group. C22.
 
A Smaller Disk Drive From I.B.M.
I.B.M. plans to announce today that it has developed an ultra-small, one-inch disk drive aimed at the market for hand-held computers and consumer appliances. C2.
 
Consumer Borrowing Jumped in July
Borrowing by consumers grew at a faster-than-expected pace in July as auto and other personal loans surged, offsetting a drop in credit card debt. Borrowing in July rose by $5.3 billion, to $1.266 trillion. C2.
 
Orders for New Jets at $5.7 Billion
In the first two days of the Farnborough International Air Show, the aerospace industry's top event of the year, Boeing has received orders with a list price of around $3 billion and the European consortium Airbus Industrie has received orders valued at $2.7 billion. C5.

Equity Inns Cancels RFS Acquisition
Equity Inns has canceled plans to acquire RFS Hotel Investors for $660 million in stock because of the decline in the stock price of Equity Inns. C6.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: ON THE TRAIL;
3 Democrats in Race for Senate Strive to Rally Supporters

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
With Primary Day just a week away, the three candidates for the Democratic nomination for Senate returned to their strengths yesterday, trying to rally key constituencies to counter what has been a lackluster campaign.
Representative Charles E. Schumer brought out James Brady, the former White House press secretary who was disabled during the assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan in 1981, to champion his record on gun control. Geraldine A. Ferraro held a news conference to draw attention to her record and her stands on women's issues. Even as she was doing so, the third candidate for the nomination, Mark Green -- who has also made a strong appeal for the women's vote -- was telling a group of female business owners that Ms. Ferraro does not deserve their support just because she is a woman. 
 In a piece of comic political timing, Ms. Ferraro and Mr. Schumer each scheduled news conferences yesterday for City Hall Park, with hers just wrapping up as his was beginning. But as they have throughout the campaign, the two candidates ignored each other.
In terms of pure visual drama, Mr. Schumer won the day, and sent news cameras into overdrive, when he entered the park pushing Mr. Brady's wheelchair. His speech still slurred by the bullet that entered his brain and nearly ended his life 17 years ago, Mr. Brady read an endorsement speech as Mr. Schumer stood behind him with head bowed.
"Now, I'm a Republican, have been all my life," Mr. Brady said. "But in politics and in life, you have to help those who help you. And nobody has helped us and New York more than Chuck Schumer. I can honestly say that a lot of the reason that we have the Brady law and the assault-weapons ban is because of this man."
Mr. Schumer was the sponsor of and driving force behind the 1993 Brady bill, which strengthened restrictions on handgun ownership. The bill is the hallmark of Mr. Schumer's legislative career, and one of the focal points of his candidacy. He was also instrumental in the passing of the Federal assault-weapons ban.
Mr. Brady's wife, Sarah, the chairwoman of Handgun Control, a nonprofit group that lobbies for gun control, also offered an impassioned endorsement. "More than anybody," she said, "I can speak to this man's tenacity, commitment, his hard work. He is the most amazing machine I've ever seen on Capitol Hill."
Ms. Ferraro countered with Ellen R. Malcolm, the president of Emily's List, a national organization that supports female Democratic candidates in favor of abortion rights by bundling campaign contributions. The group has already raised a considerable amount of money for Ms. Ferraro, although the campaign declined to specify how much, and Ms. Malcolm pledged to do even more should Ms. Ferraro win the chance to take on Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato in the general election.
Ms. Ferraro became the first woman to run for Vice President on a major party ticket when the Democrats nominated her in 1984, and she is clearly hoping that women will make their enthusiasm for her felt at the polls. "This is a race that could come down to women really exercising their right to vote," she said.
To that end, Ms. Ferraro yesterday cited her record on a range of traditional women's issues: her creation of a special victims' bureau to handle domestic violence cases and sex crimes when she was a prosecutor in the Queens District Attorney's office; her defense of abortion rights, and her attempt to get a bill passed mandating equal pay for equal work when she was in the House of Representatives.
"No matter what kind of a female voice that Al D'Amato puts into his commercials, if you look behind the commercials and see what he has done with reference to women when he votes legislatively, you have to know he is not voting in our best interests," said Ms. Ferraro, who has also been endorsed by the New York chapter of the National Organization for Women.
But in Mr. Green's speech to two dozen members of the National Association of Women Business Owners, which he delivered at the midtown Manhattan offices of Anchin, Block & Anchin, an accounting firm, he said he had the strongest record among the candidates in protecting women's rights. He cited his lobbying efforts to get RU-486, the abortion pill, imported to the United States, his work to expose price discrimination against women, and a bill now before the City Council that he co-wrote that would protect victims of domestic abuse from discrimination at work if they need special security accommodations.
When he was Consumer Affairs Commissioner, he said, he wrote a report on discrimination against women by divorce lawyers that led the Chief Judge of the State Court of Appeals, Judith S. Kaye, to impose strict new regulations on divorce lawyers.
After outlining his record, Mr. Green, who is the New York City Public Advocate, took on Ms. Ferraro.
"Now at the beginning of this campaign, when Geraldine Ferraro announced her candidacy, I concluded what counts more than gender is agenda," he said. "And I yield to no one my ardor and accomplishment in the area of women's human rights and economic rights."
Mr. Green went on to say that if the three candidates stood behind a curtain and described their records with their voices modulated to disguise their sex, "I would get the lion's share of support because of agenda, not gender."
With all three candidates now doing extensive advertising on television, Ms. Ferraro perhaps best summed up the political mood.
"This is going to be an exciting race," she said. "It is very tight now."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Dow Rises Sharply on Hope Inspired by Fed Chief

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices continued their wild ride yesterday, but the vertiginous swings left investors cheering as the Dow Jones industrial average vaulted 380.53 points, or just less than 5 percent. Broader market averages also recorded hefty gains, partly reversing their recent steep declines.
Seeking to explain the big jump in equity prices, market analysts and traders said comments made on Friday by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave investors hope that the Fed and other central banks might be coordinating a response to crises in Asia and Russia. 
 They said investors were also encouraged by Monday's vigorous rally in foreign stock markets, an advance that continued yesterday.
The Dow's rise in percentage terms was the biggest since the crash of 1987 but well below the record 15.34 percent rise on March 15, 1933, when the Dow climbed 8.26 points, to 62.10. On Oct. 21, 1987, the Dow gained 186.84 points, or 10.15 percent, to 2,027.85. Yesterday's surge was the biggest point gain ever. Still, the close, at 8,020.78, was 14 percent below the record of 9,337.97 set on July 17. The Dow is now up 1.42 percent for the year.
Analysts said the fact that most stocks were trading at deep discounts to their 52-week highs -- 44 percent on average -- was another factor in yesterday's climb.
"I think we were oversold," said Charles Clough, chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company. "And I don't think it takes much of a change in psychology to spark something of a rally."
In a speech delivered at the University of California at Berkeley on Friday, Mr. Greenspan suggested the Fed was less concerned than before about the threat of inflation and might be prepared to lower interest rates if sagging overseas economies threatened domestic economic growth. Later, a dinner that Mr. Greenspan attended with Robert E. Rubin, the Treasury Secretary, and Keichi Miyazawa, Japan's Finance Minister, led to speculation that Japan might be on the verge of adopting policies to reform its banking system and to bolster its economy.
Still, Mr. Clough and others said they did not view the mere prospect of action by the United States and other industrialized nations, most importantly Japan, as sufficient to send stock prices soaring again.
"It isn't over yet," said Byron R. Wien, United States investment stratagist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, referring to the market's recent volatility.
"This isn't the start of another bull leg," he continued. "First of all, none of the structural problems that caused people to rethink things last month have been overcome. The typical action in a down market is for stocks to get deeply oversold, to rally, and then to retest the lows."
Still, few analysts expected gains as broad or as sharp as the ones yesterday. Four stocks rose for every one that fell on the New York Stock Exchange. The broader market averages also soared.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index jumped 49.57 points, or just more than 5 percent, to 1,023.46. The Nasdaq composite index registered its biggest point gain ever, soaring 94.34 points, or more than 6 percent, to 1,660.86. That was its second-largest gain in percentage terms, behind the 7.34 percent advance recorded on Oct. 21, 1987. And the Russell 2000 index, made up of mostly small and medium-sized stocks, increased by 14.86 points, or 4.28 percent, to 361.93.
Big institutions like foreign pension funds, which typically trade in blocks of 10,000 or more shares, did a preponderantly large amount of the buying yesterday in contrast to their recent tendency to be heavy sellers.
Near the close of trading, just less than $700 million worth of stock was bought in lots of fewer than 10,000 shares, said Laszlo Birinyi, whose firm, Birinyi & Associates, tracks market developments. Individual or retail traders seldom buy or sell as many as 10,000 shares at a time. By comparison, more than $2.2 billion worth of stock was bought in large blocks, Mr. Birinyi said.
"The big difference today is that the professionals were coming back" into stocks, he said.
For a second day, buying was heavy on several foreign markets, especially in Asia. In Japan, the benchmark Nikkei index was up just less than 1 percent after surging 5 percent on Monday. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index rose 1.4 percent after a 7.1 percent surge on Monday. In Europe, Germany's main index rose 3.7 percent and the Paris index was up 2.9 percent. But London's exchange slipped one-tenth of a percent after strong gains on Monday.
On the Big Board, all 30 Dow stocks rose.
American Express, which along with most other financial stocks has been battered recently, climbed 6 3/8, to 80. General Electric gained 6, to 81 7/8, after its engine unit said it expected sales this year to rise 42 percent, to $10 billion. And McDonald's jumped 65/16 , to 647/16 .
The day's gain in the Dow surpassed the 337-point advance last Oct. 28. Volume on the Big Board was the 10th heaviest ever, at 814.9 million shares. Nine of the exchange's 10 busiest days have come in the last month, and four of those have been since the beginning of September.
"The volatility in the market shows nervousness and anxiety on the part of institutional investors," said Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, "while time and again individual investors have shown more restraint and more of a longer-term horizon than many professionals give them credit for."
Mr. Clough, the Merrill Lynch strategist, said that Americans had not significantly changed the amount of money they were putting into 401(k) retirement plans and equity mutual funds. "What has changed are foreign inflows," he said.
In the second and third quarter of last year, he said, foreigners were putting an annual rate of $100 billion into American equities, about four times previous rates. In the first quarter of 1998, that number accelerated to $125 billion, he said. "These are massive, manic liquidity flows."
 
Treasury Prices Drop
With the stock market soaring, the price of long-term Treasury securities dropped significantly, and shorter maturities were down a little.
The same remarks by Alan Greenspan that prompted the rally in stocks led investors to see less need to retreat to the safety of bonds.
Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc., interpreted Mr. Greenspan's remarks as positive confirmation for eventual Fed easing of the current 5.5 percent Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans.
Mr. Harris also cited benign labor costs, which has been one of Paine Webber's key markers for eventual Fed easing.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond dropped 1 6/32 , to 102 2/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, increased to 5.36 percent, from 5.28 percent on Friday.
For investors the loss amounted to about $11.88 for every $1,000 of bonds held.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
MET LIFE ANNOUNCES PLANS TO CUT 1,950 NONSALES JOBS

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company plans to cut 1,950 jobs, or up to 10 percent of its work force, in positions not related to sales. Met Life said yesterday that the planned reductions were part of its effort to lower overall expenses. The big New York-based mutual life-insurance concern said "various factors, including normal attrition and organizational changes," would determine the actual number of jobs that would be eliminated. Details about the amount of money that would be saved by the cuts were not disclosed. In March, Met Life reported 1997 earnings of $1.2 billion after policyholder dividends, which amounted to $1.7 billion. Met Life now employs about 19,500 people at its administrative sites in the United States.

HEADLINE: LIBRARY/PRESCRIPTION DRUG SITES;
Comprehensive Information That Can Be Hard to Find

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:

WWW.IMS-HEALTH.COM
THIS is one of the most comprehensive sites for information on the pharmaceutical industry. The A. C. Nielsen Corporation of the drug business, IMS Health, regularly tallies sales of all prescription drugs in the United States. Wall Street analysts and drug company executives regularly use the site for sales information, but there appears to be plenty of helpful material for others as well -- hard as it might be to find it. 
 The site is particularly useful in identifying the most popular drug for almost any condition. It also has information on treatment trends for certain conditions, including H.I.V. and high cholesterol levels, and on the factors that influence a doctor in prescribing certain medications.
But searching through IMS is akin to strolling through a large pharmacy with confusing aisle signs. The site map is intimidating. For example, the section called Over the Counter, which has news tidbits on nonprescription drugs like Tylenol, has 29 other icons, including Strategic Technologies and Erisco, which is IMS's information systems subsidiary.
If you are looking for prescription drug sales, logic suggests clicking on Product News. But that quickly becomes an adventure in frustration. Type the word Prozac, Eli Lilly's ubiquitous antidepressant, into the search field and you will get zero responses. That is especially odd, given that Prozac was the second best-selling drug in the United States last year.
O.K., maybe this site was not designed for a computer neophyte. I tried again, typing Glaxo, short for Glaxo Wellcome, into the search field under the category Company News. Again, a complete bust. That was even more annoying. Glaxo Wellcome is the second-largest pharmaceutical company on the planet.
An IMS executive said the company's main site was being tuned up. The information about prescription drugs was hidden in the site map in a section called IMS America. But after moving there, then clicking on Pharmaceutical Division and News or Trends, I was able to find the best-selling drug in the United States last year: Prilosec, Astra-Merck's anti-ulcer medication, with sales of $2.28 billion. The nation's top drug seller: Merck? Nope. Try Bristol-Myers Squibb, with sales of $5.69 billion.
The IMS site is updated weekly, with news items added as they occur.

SECTION: Section E; Page 5; Column 4; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 654 words

HEADLINE: POP REVIEW;
Deciphering Pearl Jam's Messages

BYLINE: By BEN RATLIFF 

 BODY:
Though there were no light shows, fabulous clothes or extreme behavior, Pearl Jam's concert on Tuesday night at the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., had meta-messages galore. The band is touring behind its fifth and latest album, "Yield," whose title has widely been interpreted as an uncomfortable capitulation to the irritations of major rock-band life. For Pearl Jam that means dropping a boycott and participating in Ticketmaster's stranglehold on the rock-concert business (the Continental Airlines Arena, as well as Madison Square Garden, where the band plays tonight and tomorrow, sells tickets through Ticketmaster), coughing up a video, talking to the press.
In one sense, the thought of the "Yield" tour sits on the edge of passive-aggressive arrogance. Pearl Jam's enemies are the superstructures that bring the music to the fans, but the fans have sometimes ended up on the losing end of the band's righteous struggles. Putting the worst face on it, the band's new message could be read as "we'll deign to serve you." But that's a simplification. Yielding is a powerful metaphor for hitting one's 30's, for maturing, for making the contorted compromises of adulthood. Pearl Jam has navigated the straits particularly well, and stands just about alone now as the country's great meaningful, brooding rock band, where there once were legions of them. That feeling of importance and grandeur, that arena-rock feeling, was at the core of the band's performance on Tuesday; it was the basic disposition inside the thudding, swirling music and Eddie Vedder's muezzinlike baritone voice. But the surface of the show -- the available space for rock star messages -- was wiped clean. 
 All his body language communicated that Mr. Vedder was walking a tightrope between showman and private man. The members of the band, which now includes the drummer Matt Cameron, formerly of Soundgarden, barely look like rock stars anymore; the guitarist Stone Gossard's bleached hair was the only indication that these weren't just men with ordinary jobs. And Mr. Vedder shied away from the messianic side of arena rock: he wasn't there to preach messages or whip up the crowd's emotions. "I'm through with screaming and echoes that nobody hears," he sang in a new song, "Faithful." When he put his head down and danced in place close to his microphone, or concentrated grinningly on Mr. Gossard's expansive, Hendrix-like solos, they seemed merely interior reactions.
The band played a handful of its hits with what seemed much more than a sense of duty: "Alive," "Even Flow" and "Better Man." But the night's best moments were more experimental, and only for the music's sake: instrumental side trips in the middle of songs where the drive dropped low and the band free-associated with grooves and lyrics and ringing, lingering guitar tones. As a device, it recalls Sonic Youth, another seasoned rock band steadying itself gracefully; tellingly, during one of these side trips in "Daughter," Mr. Vedder quoted a line from the Sonic Youth song "Androgynous Mind" as well as making a passing reference to Bruce Springsteen's "Jersey Girl." Many of the songs just shuffled to a close, dissipating the energy but retaining tension with a strange sense of calm.
Toward the end, Mr. Vedder engaged in the obligatory rock star ritual: he walked around the back of the stage to acknowledge 360 degrees of fan worship. But rather than wave or gesture at them, he just gazed, like someone who doesn't want to overexcite a nervous animal. And as a parting shot, the band played its most oblique and pretty song: "Yellow Ledbetter," whose probably meaningless lyrics have been constantly revised according to time and temperament. Accompanying Mr. Gossard's delicate filigree, Mr. Vedder sang at his strongest and most undecipherable; it was the most graceful of exits, like a slow deflation of a balloon.

HEADLINE: Pack a Vuitton; Paris Is Cheap

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
BORED to tears by endless cocktail-party speculation about whether the gyrating stock market will tarnish the value of $10 million Park Avenue apartments? Take that ennui right over to the Champs-Elysees and buy the same-size prewar palace for a (relative) chanson -- significantly less than it would cost in Manhattan.
Oh, there will probably be a few things missing: a doorman, for one. The French don't have co-ops, so apartments are easier for Americans to buy. Maybe there will be one or two fewer bathrooms. There may also be (catastrophe!) fewer maids' rooms. But you will be buying, generally speaking, more wrought iron, more portes-fenetres (we call them french doors), more courtyards -- and more eccentric layouts. 
 According to a report to be released later this month, the French real estate market is just coming out of an eight-year recession and prices are still low. Lawrence Sicular, the report's author and the chief appraiser for the New York real estate firm of Brown Harris Stevens, stayed with friends in Paris in June and compared the two cities' luxe markets -- creme de la creme vs. creme de la creme. An avowed Francophile, Mr. Sicular lived in Paris in the mid-1970's and is still intrigued by the city and its architecture.
"After doing market reports for two years on Manhattan alone, I decided to branch out," he said. "Having a Paris apartment is a dream for many Americans. It turned out this may be the time to buy."
Although Brown Harris Stevens is affiliated with Christie's Great Estates, which in turn is affiliated with real estate brokerages all over the world, Mr. Sicular said that his report was not intended to promote any particular Paris apartments.
But many Americans aren't waiting for the report -- or the advice. Marie-Helene Lundgreen, an agent with Feau Group, a high-end real estate firm in Paris, said that the number of American buyers has increased in the last 18 months -- from about 10 percent of the firm's clients to between 30 and 35 percent -- because of the perception that Paris is cheap. More than half of her own clients are American, she added, and most of them are from New York, Chicago and Beverly Hills, Calif.
Most of the Americans are looking for a pied-a-terre, but Ms. Lundgreen cautioned that her pieds-a-terre are not holes in the wall: almost all of the desirable ones are going for more than $500,000. But she agreed with Mr. Sicular that at the high end, they are cheaper than in New York. "It is very rare that people spend $2 million here," she said in an interview from her Paris office, noting that New Yorkers were "a little bit astonished not to see a doorman."
Consider this example: In Paris, a seven-room spread on the Place d'Iena, one of the city's most prestigious locations, is for sale for $1.75 million, with $833 monthly carrying charges. Practically untouched since the 30's, the place has an eat-in kitchen and three fantasy tiled bathrooms. The apartment needs some work, Mr. Sicular writes in the report, but it "looks over an old mansion to superb views of the Eiffel Tower, the Pantheon, the Invalides and the Seine."
Reaching the apartment is half the fun. Along Fifth Avenue, apartment buildings sit smack on the street, flaunting their facades. In Paris, apartments like this one are hidden away: you walk through a carriageway into a courtyard, duck under a glass canopy and step into an elaborate scrolled-iron cage elevator, which -- at last -- delivers you onto your own private floor. Inside the front door, the apartment has a paneled salon with plaster moldings, a Louis XV marble mantle, a round Art Deco library, a dining room, three bedrooms, three working fireplaces and three balconies. Upstairs are a maid's room and a bath.
In Manhattan, such an apartment (without the courtyard and the old-fashioned elevator) in a comparable location and with comparable views -- overlooking Central Park, say -- would now be priced at closer to $3 million, Mr. Sicular said, adding that not only would the price be higher but so would the monthly charges. The average monthly charges for a seven-room apartment on Fifth Avenue in the 70's are more than $3,000, he said.
In Paris, rich Americans often head for the Avenue Foch, which ends at the Arc de Triomphe. "Indeed, most of Paris's very few doorman buildings are located here," Mr. Sicular writes. But the French aren't as crazy for Avenue Foch. "It is considered too foreign, too quiet and too attractive to the occasional high-level prostitute," he said. Nevertheless, the grandest apartments are there.
But what about Paris apartments for your average American (accepting the premise that your average American might be buying a spare home away from home in the City of Light)?
The averages tell all. In Paris, the average price of an apartment in 1997 was $149,433, according to the French Association of Notaries. In Manhattan, below 96th Street, the average co-op price was $424,365 in 1997, according to Miller Samuel, a citywide appraisal company.
Ms. Lundgreen doesn't usually handle apartments selling for less than $500,000, but she recalls a one-bedroom near the Place de la Madeleine, complete with air-conditioning (not a given in Paris), marble baths and a granite kitchen. The apartment, owned by an American from California, sold for $230,000 -- to another American from California.
Mr. Sicular saw it. Although he doesn't report on Paris apartments selling for anywhere near $200,000, he is familiar with them. "It's my dream," he confessed. "I spent part of that month looking for a place of my own!"
A copy of the Brown Harris Stevens report is available by calling (212) 508-7275 after Sept. 15. It's free.

HEADLINE: Beijing Dissident's Wife Is Hauled Away Near U.N. Rights Chief

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Security agents dragged the wife of a jailed dissident through the lobby of the Hilton Hotel here this morning and detained her, moments before the visiting United Nations human rights commissioner gave a speech in a nearby room on democracy and freedom.
The dissident's wife, Chu Hailan, was standing outside the hotel, witnesses said, waiting for a chance to ask the commissioner to press the case of her husband, Liu Nianchun. A labor rights campaigner, Mr. Liu, 50, has been in prison for more than three years without trial and his wife has sought medical parole, citing his high blood pressure and other ailments. 
 But plainclothes policemen and hotel security guards grabbed Ms. Chu and bundled her, screaming, through the lobby. She was held in a hotel security room, then taken to a local police station and freed eight hours after she was first detained.
The United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, Mary Robinson, later told reporters that she was deeply concerned when she learned about the incident and raised it with Deputy Foreign Minister Wang Guangya, who assured her Ms. Chu had been released. Later the official New China News Agency quoted a Foreign Ministry spokesman as saying, "Security guards removed a woman from the entrance of the Hilton Hotel because she was disturbing order at the hotel."
In her 10-day visit to China, Ms. Robinson aims to build a constructive working relationship with Chinese officials and nudge the country toward better safeguards for individual rights.
China has pledged to sign the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights this fall. That document guarantees freedoms of assembly and speech, which are often violated here in the name of social order and national security.
Earlier this year the United States secured China's agreement to sign the covenant in exchange for ending the annual pursuit of a resolution before the United Nations Human Rights Commission condemning China's record. Diplomats argued that by joining the treaty, China would subject itself to regular assessments by outside experts, a more effective wedge for change than hostile debates in Geneva.
But once China signs, it could be years before it ratifies the treaty and Chinese officials have said they will file reservations for any sections that are inconsistent with Chinese law.
In her visit, which began last weekend, Ms. Robinson has publicly pressed China to sign the covenant soon. But Government officials have made it clear that she is not expected to meet with any of the country's beleaguered dissidents.
Today Ms. Robinson left for Tibet, where China is accused of using harsh methods to suppress support for the exiled Dalai Lama. Next Monday, back in Beijing, she is expected to meet with the President and Communist Party chief, Jiang Zemin.
Ms. Robinson's talk this morning at the Hilton Hotel coincided with the release of a United Nations report on human development in China. In the speech she said, "China can be commended for efforts to eliminate poverty and to meet the basic needs of all."
But she also said: "The right to development expresses a fundamental value predicated upon respect for all human rights, whether civil, cultural, economic, political or social, together as an integrated whole. None of these can be fully realized without democratic governance and the rule of law."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Post a Sharp Rise in Price

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose sharply yesterday, as the dollar surged in currency trading following an interest rate cut by the Bank of Japan. The 30-year Treasury bond soared 1 13/32, to 103 20/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 5.26 percent, from 5.36 percent on Tuesday.
The yield on the 10-year Treasury note hit a 10-year low of 4.92 percent yesterday. 
 Anthony Chan, managing director and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, believes the reduction by the Japanese central bank in the overnight rate for lending between banks to 0.25 percent and calls by Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan for a coordinated global interest rate cut nearly two weeks ago have clearly raised the level of speculation that the Fed Reserve might soon lower interest rates. And although Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa indicated that the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, had not asked for any rate cut from Japan, bond market investors quickly realized that the original idea for a Group of Seven coordinated interest rate reduction emanated from Japan and not from the United States.
"As a result," Mr. Chan said, "bond markets were buzzing all day with rumors that the Fed would cut interest rates as early as Wednesday or no later than the Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Sept. 29. My suspicion is that the U.S. central bank would prefer to move in an orderly fashion and conduct any changes to its monetary policy only at an F.O.M.C. meeting. Consequently, I suspect that the next move will be decided at either the Sept. 29 or Nov. 17 meeting," depending on how global deterioration affects Latin America.
If policy makers were looking for signs of further weakness arising from the global crisis, they certainly failed to receive that signal from yesterday's wholesale inventories report for July. The report showed a weaker than expected drop, down two-tenths of a percent, in July wholesale inventories, suggesting the pace of import growth will remain tepid in August and September.

HEADLINE: In America;
Simple Lessons in Humanity

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
St. Patrick's Cathedral was filled nearly to capacity for the prayer service that began at 10:30 yesterday morning. Close to 2,500 people were there. They came in very quietly. There were no surging throngs, just ordinary New Yorkers walking in from the bustle of Fifth Avenue.
Khallid Muhammad, the professional race-baiter and compulsive anti-Semite who organized the so-called Million Youth March, should have been there. He might have learned something. It was an interfaith service, a serious effort by people of different ethnic, cultural and religious backgrounds to pray and work together. 
 John Cardinal O'Connor, who led the service, was joined by an extraordinary array of religious leaders. Rabbi Ronald Sobel of Temple Emanu-El was there, and Archbishop Spyridon of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America, and the Rev. Calvin Butts of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, and Imam Pasha of the Malcolm Shabazz Mosque. Sister Marie Danaher of the Intercommunity Center for Justice and Peace was there, and Archbishop Mor Kyrillos of the Syrian Orthodox Church of Antioch.
Oh, there were plenty of different kinds of people there. You could fry your mind trying to figure out how to denounce and belittle each of their backgrounds. You'd need a dictionary of hate, a thesaurus of slurs.
The point of the service was to try and put a spotlight on the all but forgotten problems of poverty, hunger and homelessness in New York and across America. The most amazing thing to me was that a local prayer service with little or no advance publicity pulled nearly half as many people as Mr. Muhammad was able to gather for a march that was supposed to have been national in scope and that had the benefit of several weeks of sensational press coverage.
There is a hunger for mature, reflective, constructive leadership that is being missed by politicians and rabble-rousers alike.
I asked the Rev. Alistair Drummond, the moderator of the Presbytery of New York City, why he felt it was important to participate in an ecumenical gathering. He said: "I think it's very important that in matters touching on what it means to be a human being, and what it means to have human dignity, that we realize that we have tremendous commonality between our faith traditions. The teachings of our Jewish and Muslim and Christian faiths speak with one voice about the obligation to care for the poor and the vulnerable."
He also said, "There must be a place in the public argument for the moral dimension."
The prayer service grew out of a longstanding concern over the way the city has been treating homeless families. The service was not political and no politicians were mentioned by name. But several of the religious leaders have been highly critical of the way the Giuliani administration has been using an ostensible crackdown on fraud as a means of denying services to legitimately homeless families.
In January 1997, in an address on the plight of the homeless, Cardinal O'Connor said: "Do we root out fraud simply by calling all poor people fraudulent, or by punishing a hundred decent people in an effort to screen out perhaps a dozen fraudulent people? We have to be smarter than that as a people, and certainly we have to be better than that."
Yesterday the Cardinal spoke about the continuing plague of poverty among American children, about the enormous number of families that have a lower standard of living now than a quarter-century ago, and about the Americans who, despite a booming economy, go to sleep hungry at night.
He urged his listeners to see others as human beings, not as abstractions. He said "the sterile stuff of government reports" can leave "many of us unmoved and untouched."
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and other politicians should have been there. They, too, could have benefited from the simple lessons in humanity that were delivered in the hour and 20-minute service.
After the service, standing on the steps of the cathedral, Steven Banks of the Legal Aid Society said: "Political leaders often try to make poverty and homelessness into an us-and-them issue. But they're missing the message of gatherings like this."

HEADLINE: Lucas Varity of Britain Plans To Shift Headquarters to U.S.

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Lucas Varity P.L.C., one of the world's largest makers of automotive brakes, said today that it would reorganize as an American company, and issue new shares, in an effort to move closer to its big customers and take advantage of lower borrowing costs.
The company will shift its headquarters from London to Buffalo, and list its shares on the New York Stock Exchange. Shareholders will receive one share in the restructured company, the Lucas Varity Corporation, for every 10 ordinary shares. Holders of American depository receipts will receive one new share for each receipt, which represents 10 ordinary shares. Lucas Industries P.L.C. of Britain acquired the Varity Corporation of Buffalo for $2 billion in 1996, creating the current company. Lucas Varity sold its diesel-engine unit last year and put its heavy-duty brake business up for sale last month. It has been looking for acquisitions, and executives said a base in the United States would give it easier access to capital. 
 Borrowing costs in the United States are about 30 percent below those in Britain, which would cut the cost of acquisitions that the company is considering in the automotive or aerospace industries, Neil Arnold, its chief operating officer, said. Analysts said the company had amassed as much as £1 billion, or $1.7 billion, that it could use to buy another company. By moving its headquarters to western New York, the company will also be closer to its biggest customer, the General Motors Corporation, which is based in Detroit.
"The momentum of the world's auto industry is concentrating on the U.S. because of the strong economy and stable dollar," said Jim Gillette, an auto industry consultant with IRN Inc. in Grand Rapids, Mich.
The company said the decision also reflected the growth in its investor base in the United States.
Lucas Varity said it did not expect job losses in Britain or the United States. It employs about 56,000 workers worldwide. Lucas Varity also said it would buy back as much as 20 percent of its stock, and it announced that profit before charges rose 33 percent in the second quarter, to £53 million. Sales grew 8.6 percent, to £1.1 billion.
Lucas Varity's shares rose to £2.10 in London today, up 2 pence. On the Big Board, its American depository receipts gained 68.75 cents, to $35.

HEADLINE: Release the Report

BYLINE: By John D. Dingell; John D. Dingell, a Democrat, is a United States Representative from Michigan.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Not two minutes after the television networks breathlessly interrupted their soap operas and talk shows to report that Kenneth Starr had delivered his report and 36 boxes of material to the annex of the House of Representatives, my staff received the first official request from the press for a leaked copy.
I haven't seen the independent counsel's report yet, and if and when I do, I won't be leaking it to the press. But I believe it should be released in full to the public and the press at the earliest possible moment. 
 Some disagree and want to keep sensitive information that could damage innocent individuals under wraps. This is a legitimate concern, but it shouldn't be used as an excuse for keeping the full report from the public. There are principled and practical reasons for making the entire report available.
The American taxpayers paid $40 million for Mr. Starr and his staff to compile the report. It may start a process that will force every man and woman elected to Congress to exercise his or her highest Constitutional responsibility -- and decide whether to remove a President from office.
The public deserves the opportunity to judge the report, to judge Mr. Starr's actions, to judge the President and to judge Congress on the basis of all available information. Justice Louis Brandeis's famous observation that sunlight is the best disinfectant still applies today.
Then there are the practical considerations. The report and documents are for the moment squirreled away in a specially built, secure office suite. To enter it, you will need a special access code. Guards will be posted 24 hours a day.
This arrangement will be as effective in containing leaks as the Maginot line was in containing the Third Reich. The President's detractors -- and his defenders -- once they have reviewed the materials, will make every effort to frame the report and documents in the most favorable light. The furious spinning means that we will see more curveballs than Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa combined.
Concerns about the release of salacious or damaging information are real. But let's remember that Congress isn't the only institution charged with protecting the innocent. Prosecutors, special or otherwise, have the same responsibility -- and if public scrutiny shows that Mr. Starr's report has been based on damaging but uncorroborated claims, then he must be held to account.
And let's face it: the damaging details are already out. We live in a world of the Web and 24-hour-a-day punditry on cable television. That a rumor is being spread is often sufficient basis for printing or airing it in mainstream media outlets, regardless of its truth. The talent for euphemism and dry, clinical description has never been more valued at our major newspapers.
During a news conference yesterday, the Congressional leadership and Representatives Henry Hyde and John Conyers of the Judiciary Committee wisely agreed that the report should be released to the American public as soon as possible.
Making the report public would allow every one of us -- the public and the Congress -- to make sound factual decisions. The selective or staged release of the report would only further contribute to public cynicism and distrust of government.
There is no shortage of critical issues facing the Congress, the President and the country. Economies in Russia and East Asia are imploding. Legislation on patient rights and school construction awaits action. The future of Social Security and Medicare are in doubt. Congress has not passed a budget and may fail to appropriate the money needed to run the Government, forcing yet another needless shutdown.
A full and speedy public release of the report would allow Congress and the people to dispense with the matter quickly so that we can move on to pressing issues with far greater impact on the daily lives of Americans.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Milan Trenc)

HEADLINE: Rebuking Ex-Arms Inspector, Albright Defends U.S. Role

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright hit back today at a former United Nations arms inspector and other critics who have accused her of trying to scuttle inspections of Iraq's weapons sites.
In a speech to members of the American Legion, Ms. Albright again held out the possibility that the United States would use military force against Iraq if President Saddam Hussein continued to refuse to allow additional weapons inspections. 
 "The critics are sincere," Ms. Albright said. "We are, after all, on the same side. But they are sincerely wrong when they blame America for the world's failure to uncover the full truth about Iraq's weapons of mass destruction."
Ms. Albright did not mention by name the former arms inspector, William Scott Ritter Jr., an American, who resigned last month and has accused the Administration of undermining the inspection system.
But her remarks, in a speech in New Orleans to a convention of the veterans' group, were clearly a rebuttal to remarks by Mr. Ritter, who testified on Capitol Hill last week that the United States had scuttled the arms inspections in Iraq through "interference and manipulation, usually coming from the highest levels of the Administration's national security team," notably Ms. Albright.
"In recent weeks, some in Washington have suggested that the United States has not done enough to support the U.N. inspectors -- it has even been suggested that we have tried to prevent Unscom from doing its job," Ms. Albright said, using the acronym for the United Nations Special Commission, which is charged with finding and destroying Iraq's weapons of mass destruction.
"In fact, the United States has been by far the strongest international backer of Unscom," she continued. "We have provided indispensable technical and logistical support. We've pushed and pushed and pushed some more to help Unscom break through the smoke screen of lies and deceptions put out by the Iraqi regime."
Aides to Ms. Albright say she is dismayed over the damage that may have been done to her reputation as a result of the controversy created by Mr. Ritter's resignation.
Ms. Albright gained early notoriety in the Clinton Administration when, as the American representative to the United Nations, she led efforts to maintain tough economic sanctions on Iraq despite flagging international resolve on the issue.
Mr. Ritter, a former Marine intelligence officer, has said that the Administration made at least seven efforts since last November to stymie investigations by the Special Commission.
Last month, Ms. Albright acknowledged that concerns about creating a deep split in the United Nations Security Council had prompted her to question the timing of certain inspections of suspected weapons sites in Iraq.
In confronting Iraq, it is best "to be able to choose your own timing and terrain," she said today. "Saddam's tantrums have a political purpose: to spark a reaction, divide the Security Council, isolate the United States and diminish support for sanctions. We have not taken any option off the table, including military force."
Even as Mr. Ritter has criticized Ms. Albright and others in the Administration, he has faced criticism himself from his two former bosses at the United Nations.
Earlier this week Richard Butler, the chief United Nations arms inspector for Iraq said Mr. Ritter's testimony on Capitol Hill was often inaccurate in chronology and detail and had damaged the commission.
And in an interview today, Mr. Butler's predecessor, Rolf Ekeus, who is now Sweden's ambassador to the United States, said Mr. Ritter had sometimes lacked an understanding of the "big picture" of dealing with Iraq.
"I don't want to denigrate him at all, because he's a very, very solid person," Ambassador Ekeus said. "But he's not in a position to know all of the considerations that go into decision making on the commission." He said that in his dealings with Ms. Albright, "I had always found her to be a strong supporter of Unscom."
In testimony today before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Martin Indyk, the Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs, said Mr. Ritter's allegations against the United States "had profoundly undermined the perception that Unscom is independent -- and that will make it harder for Unscom to do its job."
