Warning on Iraq A-Arms
 JERUSALEM, Sept. 9 (Agence France-Presse) -- Iraq is hiding three "technologically complete" nuclear bombs that lack only the fissile material to make them operational, Scott Ritter, the former United Nations arms inspector, was quoted today as saying in the newspaper Haaretz.
Haaretz said Mr. Ritter made the disclosure at a recent closed-door meeting of the Washington Institute for Near East Policy.
Mr. Ritter was quoted as saying that the United Nations inspections committee knew where the three nuclear devices were being hidden and had information on how they were concealed and which officers were guarding them, but had not received an order to inspect the site.
He described the bombs as "technologically complete" and needing only the fissile nuclear material to become operational. Haaretz made no mention of whether Ritter believes Iraq has obtained any such nuclear material.
Mr. Ritter, an American citizen, quit the United Nations inspection team in Iraq last month, saying it was no longer carrying out its task aggressively enough.
He said the United States wanted to avoid new confrontations with President Saddam Hussein and had intervened to keep the United Nations teams from carrying out surprise inspections.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Theater Boom Is Born In Russian Film Industry

BYLINE: By SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Five years ago, Raymond Markovich and Paul Heth carried reels of second-run American films on their laps and candy bars and popcorn bags in their luggage on flights from Los Angeles to Moscow, using their credit cards to finance a hotel movie theater here frequented by expatriates.
Today, the two operate Kodak Kinomir (Kodak Cinema World), one of the world's top-grossing single-screen cinemas, just blocks from the Kremlin. They plan to open up to 15 multiplexes, with 100 screens in all, over the next five years, in an investment projected at $110 million. They are part-owners of a film distribution company with exclusive rights to Walt Disney and Columbia Tri-Star pictures in Russia, so they should have no problems filling their screens. And they say the financial crisis now shaking Russia has affected neither their plans nor attendance at Kinomir, which continues to play to packed houses. 
 From the Revolution in 1917 through perestroika a decade ago, Russians flocked to movie theaters. The brutal Stalin era produced happy movie musicals. Patriotic war movies helped spur the Soviet Union to victory over Hitler. Films made during perestroika helped bring down Communism.
Attendance dropped in the mid-1990's. But despite such continuing economic turmoil as the free fall of the ruble in recent weeks, those who know the movie industry say that Russians, not just Muscovites, are ready to go back to the big screen. Doctors, miners and schoolteachers go unpaid for months, but economic hardship may actually be encouraging people to go to the movies.
"Russians like to be together," said Sergei Livnev, director of the Gorky Film Studios. "They're very communal. They want to watch a movie, then discuss it."
Just two years ago, the Russian film industry was pronounced dead by the head of its own cinematographers' union. Hollywood studios were boycotting the market because of rampant video piracy. And theaters, with an overall occupancy rate of 5 percent, had to rent out space for auto showrooms and nightclubs.
Now, the success of Kinomir, which Mr. Heth said had $3 million in ticket sales and $1.6 million in concession sales in 1997, has inspired Russian and foreign investors to look beyond the economic instability and seek a cut of the action.
Gorky Film Studios is promoting a $94 million project to develop 100 modern movie theaters across Russia, although Mr. Livnev acknowledges that plans may well change if the crisis continues. Down the street from Kinomir, Sergei Lisovsky has refitted a vast 2,500-seat theater and is planning to put up 100 screens for about $120 million. Mr. Lisovsky, whose advertising and concert promotion empire, Premier SV, has distribution rights to Warner Brothers and Miramax films, is building a multiplex and shopping mall near one of Moscow's busy train stations. The only change since the currency crisis, he says, is that his French partners in the project have raised interest rates on their loans.
Moscow's Mayor, Yuri M. Luzhkov, who last year touted shopping malls and hypermarkets, is promoting multiplexes to liven up the city and is courting potential investors such as Warner Brothers. "We're in discussion with a number of groups," said Millard L. Ochs, president of Warner Brothers International Theaters in Los Angeles. "Kinomir has demonstrated what can happen with a single-screen cinema."
Kinomir's home is the former Soviet-built "house of culture" of the newspaper Izvestia, once a gathering place for concerts, Communist films and propaganda sessions. More recently, neon signs and memorabilia for blockbusters such as "Men in Black" have replaced Soviet slogans, and a concession counter serves up Coca-Cola, popcorn and, in a nod to Russian habits, beer.
Financial crises may have deflated such indicators of middle-class well-being as appliance sales, but Russians stood in line for hours last winter to pay up to $25 at the box office and up to $200 to scalpers for tickets to "Titanic." Last weekend, even with ticket prices increased 10 to 30 percent, viewers lined up for "Armageddon." One thing moviegoers have not snapped up is the movie tie-in product, not because such items are expensive, but because they are cheap. "This is not a T-shirt and baseball cap market," Mr. Markovich said. "It's more Gucci and Versace." A coffee bar run by Nescafe and Russia's first T.G.I. Friday's restaurant help make Kinomir a hot spot for trendy Muscovites.
Mr. Heth, 34, came to Moscow in 1993 to deal in timber products. He stumbled into the movie business after his seatmate on a Moscow-bound flight happened to say he was involved in the opening of a movie theater at the Radisson Slavyanskaya Hotel. When the man said he had no advertising for the premiere, Mr. Heth said he and his business partner, Mr. Markovich, could handle it. In fact, the Heth-Markovich partnership then consisted of dreaming up business propositions while patronizing a favorite expatriate watering hole in Moscow.
Mr. Markovich, 32, was working as a lawyer. One of his clients was Paul Tatum, an American businessman who was embroiled in a lawsuit over the business center he ran at the Radisson. Mr. Tatum was shot to death near the hotel in 1996.
Before long, Mr. Markovich and Mr. Heth began to shop around a business plan for a showcase movie theater. Eastman Kodak, which opened a Russian subsidiary in 1993, agreed to back Kinomir.
Mr. Markovich and Mr. Heth's first free-standing multiplex will be on a street that already features a Planet Hollywood restaurant and the Beverly Hills Casino, which is owned by Chuck Norris, the television action-film star.
The interest in multiplexes rose as the resurgent Russian movie industry released 66 new films in 1997, up from a dismal 20 in 1996. Eastman Kodak's subsidiary, Kodak AO, reports an 80 percent increase over last year in sales of the film on which movies are printed. (When the Soviet Union was still intact, production thrived in several republics, including Georgia and Ukraine, and 400 films were released in 1991.)
Vladimir Gusinsky, head of the holding company Media-Most, with a newspaper, magazine and television network already under his belt, has expanded into film production. His new company, KinoMost, plans to develop movie theaters across Russia and build a modern film studio.
The man who heads KinoMost, Vladimir Dostal, the film director, says the number of moviegoers will keep growing if Russians have comforting movies and nice, new theaters to see them in.
"People don't go to movie theaters to watch the news, to watch people being killed," he said. "We will build happy endings. Do you often see an American film where the hero hangs himself and the heroine drowns?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Raymond Markovich, left, and Paul Heth at their movie theater, Kodak Kinomir. Their success has inspired other investors to look beyond Russia's economic instability and seek a cut of the action. (Jacqueline Mia Foster for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. to Send North Korea Food Despite Missile Launching

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
The United States quietly agreed last weekend to send an unusually large shipment of emergency food aid to North Korea, despite the North's recent launching of a medium-range missile over Japan, officials who have been briefed on the talks between the two countries say.
The agreement to provide additional aid, which has angered Japan, comes amid growing signs that North Korea was trying to launch a satellite, as it claims, when it shot off the missile, according to officials of several countries. 
 So far the United States Space Command, which tracks objects in space, has said it cannot find evidence of a satellite. But if the launching amounted to a failed effort to propel a small satellite into space -- which one official said "is the most likely scenario now" -- it would mean that the initial portrayal of the firing as a clearly hostile act was partially incorrect.
Washington's decision to provide about 300,000 tons of wheat and other grains will probably be announced next week, officials said. The State Department declined to comment, but other officials said the announcement was being delayed to put some distance between the missile launching and an American step to keep the North Koreans talking about curbing their nuclear programs.
Japan sharply protested the launching of the missile and immediately said it was reviewing all of its aid to the North. Japanese officials have made no effort to hide their chagrin at the decision to go ahead with aid, arguing that it rewards the North for bad behavior.
But American officials say the Administration is loath to become involved in another confrontation with the North when the executive branch is distracted by the Monica Lewinsky scandal and economic instability around the globe.
The State Department, meanwhile, is interested in keeping the North at the negotiating table because of growing fears that the Communist Government may be looking to break out of the 1994 accord containing the North's nuclear weapons ability.
In the negotiations last week in New York between American officials and North Korea, the Pyongyang officials reportedly agreed to resume a four-year-old process of "canning" nuclear waste at its suspected nuclear-weapons plant in Yongbyon, north of the Korean capital, Pyongyang. That work had halted recently.
While American officials routinely insist that food aid is decided on humanitarian grounds, and is never used as a bargaining chip, diplomats from other countries monitoring the talks say the containment of the nuclear material was a key condition.
The talks came as North Korea celebrated its 50th anniversary as an independent state, and re-elected Kim Jong Il, the son of the country's founder, as chairman of the National Defense Commission, saying that was now the "highest post in the state." His father, Kim Il Sung, who died four years ago, was named "eternal leader." The celebrations included parades and no mention of the widespread starvation that the United Nations says is afflicting the country.
The State Department has been cautious in its public statements about the North. James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said on Tuesday that the United States sought "concrete steps to assure that there is full compliance with all aspects" of the 1994 accord, and took up the issue of missile proliferation and terrorism.
But he declined to discuss details of the talks, or describe the agreements reached.
He also said that while it was "an important question" whether a satellite was launched, "nevertheless there was a missile launched that demonstrated the capability to deliver a payload against ---- "
Then he caught himself, continuing, "at very long range."
It is not clear why American intelligence agencies are having such a difficult time determining the nature of the launching, which North Korea declared was part of the 50th-anniversary celebration. The satellite, it said, was supposed to broadcast patriotic hymns and odes to Kim Il Sung, but American and Japanese officials say they have heard nothing in the frequency band that the North identified for the broadcasts.
One hint that the North may have been trying to launch a satellite lies in the unusual flight path of the missile, a multistage Taepodong-1 that has a range of more than 1,200 miles.
There is some evidence that the third stage of the missile, containing the nose cone, was fired off during the launching. That would be consistent with an effort to place a small satellite into orbit.
But there is no question it would be very small. The North has put a picture of the rocket, or what it says is the rocket, on the Web page of the North Korean Central News Agency (www.kcna.co.jp). Its payload bay appears to be very narrow, not nearly large enough for a traditional communications or spy satellite.

HEADLINE: International Panel Closes Books on Gold Seized by Nazis in War

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 9

 BODY:
An international commission set up 52 years ago to return gold that Nazi Germany seized from central banks of countries it occupied closed its books and disbanded today after returning most of the last six tons to the original claimants.
In early 1997 the Tripartite Gold Commission delayed distribution of the gold, then valued at $68 million, amid disagreements about going ahead despite the possibility that money, jewelry and tooth fillings of Holocaust victims might have become mixed up with it. 
 After some hesitation, France joined the United States and Britain -- the other members of the commission -- in pledging money to a relief fund for individual victims who might have claims on the monetary gold.
About $60 million has so far been promised to the fund by 14 countries, including the three members of the tripartite commission and most of the countries that recently received the last of the gold. The total will probably rise to about $70 million, Stuart E. Eizenstat, the United States Under Secretary of State for Economic, Business and Agricultural Affairs, said today after a ceremony at the French Foreign Ministry to mark the milestone.
"The mystery of how much victim gold was in this may never be known," Mr. Eizenstat said later. "We came up with an estimate of $4 million, but it could be much higher."
The French Foreign Ministry, which has opened the Tripartite Gold Commission archives to the public, said France would contribute $3.45 million to the relief fund. The United States has pledged $25 million, and Britain $1.7 million.
Of the original 370 tons of foreign monetary gold reserves that the World War II Allies recovered from Germany in 1945, only $300,000 worth belonging to Yugoslavia has not been returned. That gold will remain on deposit in the Bank of England, officials said, until Yugoslavia's successor states can agree on its disposal.
The actual amount of gold the Nazis seized from occupied countries' banks and from victims of the Holocaust was much higher than the amount the Tripartite Gold Commission recovered.
Some is thought to have gone to Switzerland, which has been in an uproar for most of the last two years over charges by Jewish groups that Swiss authorities knowingly sold gold belonging to Holocaust victims for the Germans, and that Swiss banks held onto assets of the Nazis' victims instead of trying to restore them to their heirs.
France decided only last year to renew efforts to find the owners of hundreds of artworks seized by German occupation authorities or their French collaborators during the war, and is trying to produce an inventory from files that had lain untouched for most of the past 50 years.
Insurance companies that failed to pay claims to survivors of Holocaust victims and German companies that employed slave laborers during the war are the latest to face class action lawsuits.
The United States has organized a conference in Washington in late November to discuss guidelines for museums, art dealers and galleries on dealing with problems of disputed ownership.
Austria said today that after years of refusing to allow artworks to be shipped out of the country to claimants living abroad, it would now agree to restore to their rightful owners hundreds of art objects confiscated by the Nazis.
"We want to document that at the end of the historically burdened 20th century we want to clear things up once and for all," Elisabeth Gehrer, the Minister for Education and Cultural Affairs, said in Vienna.
Two paintings by the Expressionist Egon Schiele lent by the Leopold Foundation in Austria to the Museum of Modern Art in New York City have been held there since last January because of a pending ownership claim by surviving members of a Jewish family that lived in Austria when the Nazis took over.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
Dollar Rises Against Yen, Masking Recent Weakness

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The dollar rose almost 4 percent against the Japanese yen yesterday after Japan's central bank announced a surprise cut in an important interest rate.
But the sudden surge, which pushed the dollar up to 137 yen, hides the real surprise about the dollar's recent performance against both the yen and the German mark: The dollar has weakened against these two leading currencies despite the economic turmoil and political uncertainty that has roiled world financial markets the last two months. 
 The decline, some analysts argue, is disturbing because it is another indication of how the global economic crisis is having an intensifying effect on the United States.
The drop in the dollar's value, especially against the mark, these analysts say, reflects a belief that the global crisis will spread to Latin America, weakening those economies. In turn, that weakness will restrain large markets for American exports, helping to slow growth in this country and further undercut corporate earnings and the stock market. In the end, the economic slowdown and stock market declines would force the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates.
The suggestion last Friday by Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, that it would consider a rate cut if the foreign drag on the United States economy worsened has only bolstered this view.
As a general matter, when the world shudders, the dollar rallies. On Aug. 19, 1991, for example, when the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, was briefly ousted by Russian hard-liners, the dollar surged more than 3 percent against the mark that day. Now, however, with President Boris N. Yeltsin barely holding on in Russia and the refashioned Communists somewhat in ascendancy, the dollar has not rallied; it is falling. Since Aug. 26, it has dropped 4.7 percent against the mark, slipping yesterday to a 1998 low of 1.7215 marks from 1.7285 on Monday.
The dollar-yen rate has been a barometer of global investors' lack of confidence in Japan to turn its economy around and lead Asia out of economic crisis. Weeks ago, analysts were worried that the yen would fall to a rate of 150 to the dollar, possibly touching off a devaluation of the Chinese currency, the yuan.
But even with yesterday's dollar rally, the American currency is still roughly 7 percent below its eight-year high on Aug. 11, although Japan, despite yesterday's rate cut, has still not put many significant policy changes into effect.
Indeed, some analysts said that the Japanese rate cut had been prompted in part by the yen's surprising rebound against the dollar. Before yesterday, the dollar was off roughly 10 percent, settling in New York on Tuesday at 132.10 yen. This gave the Japanese central bank the opportunity to cut rates without worrying that the yen would plummet near the dangerous 150 level.
The dollar's drop, especially against the yen, stems in part from the unwinding of profitable trades as global investors, including hedge funds, seek to cover their losses from Russia and other emerging markets. This means that they have been selling dollars and buying back yen after making big profits on the decline of the yen all year.
Therefore, the current weakness of the dollar against the yen could be reversed once this type of selling is finished. The surge in the dollar yesterday may already reflect this.
That reversal will be even more likely, analysts said, if the Japanese Government fails to overhaul the banking system and to cut taxes -- measures American officials argue are needed to get Japan's economy out of recession. "Once the dust settles on this, the underlying fundamentals will reassert themselves, especially on the yen," said Jonathan Francis, global strategist at Putnam Investments in Boston.
But according to Avinash Persaud, global head of currency research at J. P. Morgan Securities in London, there are two more important factors at play.
One is a new aversion among investors to taking risk. With Russia's decision to devalue the ruble and the absence of new international help for the economy there, "the appetite for any risk has collapsed," he said.
A barometer of this risk aversion is the spread, or difference, between the yields on United States Treasury notes and bonds and those on the debt of emerging-market countries. That spread has jumped from about 6 percentage points to more than 14 percentage points in a little more than two months.
In this atmosphere, he said, investors are getting out of trades or bets abroad and fleeing to the safe harbor of their local bond markets. This means Japanese are buying back yen and Germans are purchasing marks. "I just want to have less of any exposure -- that is what we are hearing on the dealing floors," Mr. Persaud said.
The second factor is the fear that the economic crisis that began in Asia in July 1997 will strike Latin America in force, harming the economies in a region crucial for American exports and economic strength.
The loss of appetite for risk intensifies this kind of feared contagion. With more investors preferring to stay home, countries like Brazil will have to offer higher interest rates to attract the dollars they need to cover their growing current account deficits, the total of trading deficits in goods and services. This puts even more pressure on these nations to devalue their currencies and makes more speculators bet that this will happen.
And if Latin America is harmed, the drag on the United States economy, which sends about 15 percent of its exports south, could be enough to prompt a cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
Mr. Persaud has looked at the times when the Dow Jones industrial average has fallen 5 percent or more in two weeks and the Fed has moved from a policy of stable or rising interest rates to lower rates. In six of those occasions since 1982, he said, the value of the dollar has fallen.
So for the American investor, more than the outlook for the stock market now seems to hinge on the Federal Reserve. Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues, who meet again at the end of the month, may also influence the near-term outlook for the dollar.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Economic Scene;
Twisting Controls on Currency and Capital

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund, having bailed out Thailand, Indonesia, South Korea and Russia over the last 15 months, is nearly out of money, and Congress is not yet rushing to its defense. But its job is far from complete.
The financial crisis that it tried to snuff out in Asia has spread to Latin America and beyond. Investors are still dumping pesos and rubles in a grab for dwindling reserves of dollars, driving up the costs of imports for consumers and depriving economies of desperately needed foreign capital. 
 With the I.M.F. partly sidelined for now, the debate on how to stop the financial carnage rages at two levels -- what beleaguered countries should do for themselves and what the international community should do for them. One important step the industrialized powers could take -- debt relief -- has worked in the past. But otherwise, the outlines of a solution remain murky as economists find that many of the old panaceas do not work.
The best way to insulate an economy from investor flight is to cut excessive borrowing. But as Argentina, Mexico and other Latin American countries are learning, responsible monetary and fiscal policies are no sure-fire inoculation. Their problems are primarily external, starting with a steep drop in Asian demand for oil and other exports that has siphoned off dollars and scared away skittish investors.
Beyond balancing its books, a country must decide how to link its economy to the outside world. A fixed exchange rate sets the value of a currency in terms of the dollar, providing day-to-day stability for exporters and investors. Some conservatives, like Jack Kemp, the Republican Vice- Presidential candidate in 1996, preach fixed rates in part because such a regime requires a government to protect the value of its currency by maintaining a strict monetary policy.
The ultimate fixed-rate regime is a currency board -- a policy rarely mentioned before the crisis in Asia -- by which a country restricts the issue of its currency to the amount of foreign reserves it accumulates. Argentina prints a peso only when it acquires, through export sales or capital inflows, an additional American dollar. Its currency board thereby assures investors that Argentina holds enough dollars to redeem pesos whenever they decide to cash in their investments.
By linking a currency to the dollar, a currency board in effect transfers control over a nation's money supply to Washington. It is a reflection of desperate times that some respected economists, like Rudiger Dornbusch of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, have embraced the idea of a currency board for Russia. What would have seemed like an unthinkable infringement of a superpower's sovereignty a year ago now seems like Russia's possible salvation.
But fixed-rate systems bottle up tremendous economic forces that eventually spew forth with potentially cataclysmic consequences. Consider Hong Kong. As its Asian trading partners collapsed, its exports plummeted, cutting into its dollar reserves. The shriveling reserves have raised doubts about Hong Kong's ability to maintain the value of its currency by putting up as many American dollars as it takes to soak up as much of its currency that investors might want to sell. That leaves Hong Kong -- like Russia, Brazil, Venezuela and other countries defending their exchange rates -- with unappetizing options: abandoning its currency peg -- almost certainly exposing itself to huge devaluations -- or luring dollars by raising interest rates to levels that risk curbing economic growth.
The danger, as the Nobel laureate Milton Friedman warned more than 30 years ago, is that fixed exchange rates provide only an illusion of stability. Rate changes are infrequent, but when they do come, they can hit with the force of a bomb. Floating rates, which he says are preferable, are adjusted continuously in response to internal and external shocks, diminishing the danger of a calamitous day of reckoning.
Another decision that each country must make is how open it wishes to be to foreign capital. Here again, the intellectual climate is changing. Most economists have preached the gospel of open borders in the belief that capital would migrate to its best use and that competition from abroad would keep domestic entrepreneurs honest.
But recent events in Asia and Latin America -- where the whims of currency traders and short-term investors have tormented seemingly healthy economies -- have led many economists to embrace another erstwhile heresy: capital controls, by which governments control buying and selling of foreign currency. Jagdish Bhagwati of Columbia University, one of the world's foremost advocates of free trade, now encourages countries to consider adopting controls during financial crises. Paul Krugman of M.I.T. endorsed controls earlier this month, which, at least in his mind, influenced Malaysia's decision last week to follow his advice.
Controls are intended to enable a country to loosen its monetary and fiscal policies when it needs to in order to fight off recession without fear of setting off a huge flight of dollars, which can no longer be taken out of the country upon demand. But Jeffrey Sachs of the Harvard Institute for International Development warns countries to limit their use to inflows of short-term investment. If, instead, countries try to block investors from taking their money out at will, controls may wind up driving foreign investors away for good.
Running parallel to the debate over domestic policies is a battle over the role of the I.M.F. It has assumed responsibility -- in Mexico in 1995, Asia in 1997 and Russia in 1998 -- for bailing out countries in financial distress, lending tens of billions of dollars in exchange for commitments by those countries to tighten fiscal, monetary, banking and employment policies. In the case of Mexico, intervention worked well. In other cases, as in Asia and Russia, I.M.F. policies have backfired, at least in the view of critics. Mr. Sachs accuses the I.M.F. of cracking down too hard in Asia, needlessly fueling investor panic.
C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, concedes that the I.M.F. made serious errors as the Asia crisis unfolded, though he says that it has largely corrected its significant miscues since then. Contradicting many of the I.M.F.'s critics in Congress, Mr. Bergsten argues that the world needs a well-financed institution that can lend money to countries in temporary distress, preventing one country's ills from needlessly infecting others. He does, however, call on the fund to better monitor countries before a crisis hits and to intervene earlier.
Mr. Sachs would switch the fund's mission from organizing grandiose bailout packages to organizing negotiations between debtor nations and their creditors. His idea is modeled on the United States bankruptcy system, which allows judges to put creditors on hold while a settlement is reached. Mr. Sachs recognizes that the fund would need a similarly powerful legal lever if it were to play a similar role.
The latest remedy gaining fashion would have the central banks of the United States, Germany and Japan jointly announce a cut in interest rates beyond what Japan announced on its own yesterday. The idea is to harness the cooperative spirit that by some accounts helped solve the problem of a soaring dollar in the 1980's and use it to break the pessimistic mood of international investors. Joint rate cuts would also provide relief to economies with large dollar-denominated debts.
But while the symbolism of joint international action might turn investors into optimists, it is easy to exaggerate the likely effect of a joint rate cut. Interest rates in the West are already low, and the United States is loath to drive them much lower because its economy is, at least for now, growing briskly. Besides, rate cuts do not cure serious ills, like Japan's insolvent banks or Russia's corrupt institutions.
But Alan Blinder, an economics professor at Princeton University and a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, provides a clever political rationale for a joint rate cut. If it were combined with an ironclad commitment by Japan to solve its banking problems -- a necessary step to its recovery and therefore Asia's -- the joint rate cut would rise above symbolism. Still, Mr. Blinder describes the case for joint rate cuts as borderline.
There is, however, one effective remedy on which most economists agree. Russia and other besieged countries cannot pay off their Western loans. Just as debt relief was the key to South America's recovery in the 1980's, debt relief will have to be part of any solution to the current plight of Russia and Asia. The sooner it comes, the sooner a widespread economic rebound can begin.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Profit Warning Pushesthe Dow Down 155.76

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stocks slumped yesterday as several companies warned that third-quarter profits will be lower than expected and euphoria over possible interest-rate cuts seemed to dissipate.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 155.76 points, or 1.94 percent, to 7,865.02, giving up more than 40 percent of Tuesday's 380.53-point surge -- the biggestpoint gain ever. The Dow is now in negative territory for the year, and 15.8 percent below its record 9,337.97 set on July 17. 
 Comments from Procter & Gamble and Merrill Lynch about lower earnings expectations spurred the decline. Procter, the blue-chip household products and food company, fell 7 3/4, or 9.7 percent, to 71 7/8. It cautioned yesterday that earnings growth in the current quarter will be held to mid-single digits. First Call, which tracks earnings forecasts of securities analysts, had estimated profits at 79 cents, which would have been an 8.2 percent increase from the period a year earlier.
Another prominent casualty was Merrill Lynch, which slid 6 3/4, or 10.2 percent, to 59 1/4. The investment banking and brokerage giant had announced after Tuesday's close that it lost $135 million from its operations in Russia and other emerging markets during July and August and followed up yesterday by saying that start-up losses from its new retail outlet in Japan would be greater than expected, some $65 million.
The earnings alerts followed the euphoria on Tuesday, the first day of trading following the Labor Day holiday, when investors and traders had been heartened by a speech last Friday by Alan Greenspan. The Federal Reserve chairman had said that the risk of recession had caught up with the risk of inflation, implying that the central bank might decide to reduce short-term interest rates to head off contagion from sick economies abroad.
But while investors welcomed what Mary Farrell, a senior investment strategist at Paine Webber, called the "safety net" that Mr. Greenspan represented, they pointed yesterday to the persistent fears of what the sharp slowing of the domestic economy and exposure to foreign losses is doing to corporate profits. They also cited political instability, in Washington as well as in Russia and the Far East.
"It's one after another" of such earnings disappointments, combined with the general negative overseas and Washington climate, that is dragging the market down, Ms. Farrell said.
"These things are still with us and have not changed one bit," said Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney.
Indeed, it was widely agreed, part of Tuesday's 380.53-point jump was somewhat artificial in that it reflected forced purchases by those who had been caught short -- traders who had expected to continue to profit from the market's seven-week swoon but who were suddenly frightened that Mr. Greenspan's address might have had a lasting positive effect on the investment climate.
That possibility seemed gone yesterday, especially when it was reported in the afternoon that Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel investigating President Clinton, had sent his report to Congress. The Dow, which had been down about 100 points since midmorning, sank another 50 points in the final 45 minutes.
Other market gauges also closed lower. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 17.26 points, or 1.69 percent yesterday, to 1,006.20. The Nasdaq composite index declined 2.19 percent, or 36.31 points, to 1,624.55. Although the technology-heavy Nasdaq market was down, computer and other high-technology losses were mostly limited to fractions. However, Microsoft rose 9/32, to 102 1/4, and Oracle was up 3/16, to 21 13/16. Some analysts said they thought there were bargains to be had in technology.
Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange more than doubled gainers, 2,172 to 943, with 418 unchanged. Volume at around 704 million shares was moderate, well under Tuesday's 814.9 million, the 10th- busiest day on record.
The declines had been foreshadowed by further bouts of selling overseas, especially in Hong Kong, where the Hang Seng index tumbled 283.80 points, or 3.47 percent, to 7,905.45. Japan's Nikkei index of 225 issues dropped 157.95 points, or 1.06 percent, to 14,755.54, despite a cut in its already minuscule overnight bank rate. Fuji Bank was forced to deny rumors of huge losses in derivatives.
European stock averages fell also, by 2.69 percent in Germany, 1.09 percent in France and less than 1 percent in London.
On the Big Board, retailers were hit hard, with Sears, Roebuck tumbling 4 1/8, to 46 3/8, on profit fears. Wal-Mart was down 1 11/16, to 61 1/16. Stores have mostly benefited from Asian financial problems, which have made imported goods cheaper.
As for lower sales of American products to Asia, which has crippled some export-oriented companies, Rosanne M. Cahn, an equity economist at Credit Suisse First Boston, said this problem was likely "more than half over." She pointed to Asian-bound exports that plummeted at a 42 percent annual rate during the first quarter but that narrowed to a 16 percent rate of decline during the April to June period.

HEADLINE: Battle Over Islander Ice Intensifies

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Sept. 9

 BODY:
Nassau Coliseum, home to the New York Islanders, is the oldest unrenovated arena in the National Hockey League -- and it shows. The ceiling hangs so low that some fans cannot see the ice, and many seats are broken. The Islanders say that the Coliseum, built in 1972, is one reason the team is near the bottom of the N.H.L. in attendance and is losing more than $11 million a year.
In a lawsuit filed in Federal court today, the Islanders claim that the conditions are so unsafe that the team can no longer play hockey in the arena. The suit asks the court to declare that the Islanders have no further obligation under the Coliseum lease and seeks $10 million in punitive damages. 
 "We need a brand new arena," said David Seldin, president of New York Sports Ventures, which bought the struggling team in February for $195 million. "To survive, we've got to attract more fans, and that means not only better players, but a state-of-the-art facility."
The alternative, Mr. Seldin said, is to leave town.
It seems as if nearly everyone on Long Island wants a new coliseum, which could cost more than $200 million. Boosters include Matthew T. Crosson, president of the Long Island Association, and the fans. Thomas S. Gulotta, the County Executive, envisions a new coliseum as part of an ambitious redevelopment of the 70-acre site that would include a convention and exhibition center, a hotel and a public transit system connected to other areas throughout central Nassau.
But no one can seem to agree on a formula to pay for a new coliseum -- whether the money should be public, private or both.
The co-owners of the Islanders, Howard P. Milstein and Steven M. Gluckstern, note that the public financed 43 percent of the Buffalo Sabres's new $127 million arena, 60 percent of the $150 million Tampa Bay Lightning arena and 100 percent of the Nashville Predators' arena. Taxpayers, Mr. Milstein and Mr. Gluckstern said, should do their part for the Islanders, too.
In a recent public statement, Mr. Crosson concurred: "Public funds have been used to build Rich Stadium in Buffalo, Knickerbocker Arena in Albany and minor-league baseball parks in Binghamton, Rochester and Syracuse," he said. "Why not on Long Island?"
He noted that Long Island's population was larger than that of many states and cities and that its economy rivaled those of many countries.
But in a county that has had a series of tax cuts over the last several years, both Republicans and Democrats have been carefully sidestepping the issue of using public funds for a new coliseum.
The Nassau Coliseum is not the only sporting arena in the area that has been found wanting. The new owners of the New Jersey Nets are looking to leave the Meadowlands Sports Complex to a proposed site in Newark. The Devils are also unhappy in the Meadowlands, but their owner wants to move to Hoboken.
Those plans are still in the talking stage. The possibility of a new Yankee Stadium in Manhattan has moved to the suing stage: two weeks ago the New York City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, charged in a lawsuit that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had created a Charter review commission solely to keep a referendum off the ballot in November that would have asked the voters what they think of paying for a new stadium.
George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the principal owner of the Yankees, said at the end of July that he would help pay for a new stadium, but did not say how much he would be willing to contribute.
The Mets unveiled plans for a new domed stadium in April, and they hope to have the city pick up three-quarters of its $500 million price tag. The Mets' owners have also discussed the possibility of expanding the stadium to 80,000 seats to tempt a pro football team back to the city. (The Jets' lease at Giants Stadium in New Jersey expires in 2008.)
And the United States Open is being played at the one-year-old National Tennis Center, which cost $254 million to build. The city helped out by issuing $150 million in tax-exempt bonds to build the center, but the United States Tennis Association makes the payments.
Mr. Gulotta, who would love to cut the ribbon at the opening of a new Nassau Coliseum, has delegated the nettlesome issue of financing to Morton L. Certilman, chairman of the Nassau County Privatization Committee.
As Mr. Gulotta's chief negotiator, Mr. Certilman is trying to work out a deal involving the county, New York Sports Ventures and the Spectacor Management Group, which has a contract with the county to operate the coliseum until 2015.
Mr. Gulotta said that the state government had approved $30 million for the project and that other nontaxpayer money was available through industrial development agencies like the Empire State Development Corporation.
"However, it's my own position that most of the funding should come from the private sector," Mr. Gulotta said. "I believe it's the profit motive that flows from private sector dollars that will ultimately drive the engine of success for a project of this type."
If Mr. Gulotta has his way, the new coliseum will be a sports complex able to house other national sports franchises, like a basketball team, in addition to the Islanders. The old coliseum would become a convention and exhibition center, and county officials envision a new hotel at the complex.
"This is not a plan for just brick and mortar, but about creating a destination point and a kind of atmosphere for the central core of Nassau County," Mr. Gulotta said.
Mr. Gluckstern, however, has a different view. "I really could do without all the rest of it," he said. "All I want is a new coliseum." He said he could afford to continue to lose $11 million dollars on the Islanders for only two more years. "After that, we'll have to go elsewhere," he said. "Time is running out."
He said the Islanders needed to start construction of the arena, which would take two years to build, no later than next summer so that it could be ready for the 2001-02 season.
"We're not only playing in the oldest facility in the N.H.L., but we have the worst lease deal in the N.H.L.," Mr. Gluckstern said in a recent interview at the coliseum. He said that while the Islanders was a "fabulous brand in a large, affluent target market," it suffered from "a severe decline in product quality and an underinvestment in the infrastructure of the business, not only on the ice, but in the arena."
He put much of the blame on the Spectacor Management Group and the county's reluctance to insure that the company followed through on basic repairs and upkeep of the arena.
The most recent dispute involved the installation of a new $3 million scoreboard to be hung from the rafters high above center ice. The project was halted three weeks ago when the Islanders questioned the safety of the hoist for the new sign.
In the lawsuit filed today in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, the Islanders accused Spectacor with "constructive eviction," contending that the sign rendered the arena unfit for occupancy, said Gary Lewi, a spokesman for the Islanders.
An official close to the negotiations, speaking on the condition of anonymity, warned, "If this intramural dispute and legal wrangling continues, and no plans are drafted soon for a new arena, you can count on there being empty ice three years from now, if not sooner."

HEADLINE: Teacher Is Slain on Staten Island; Her Daughter and Son-In-Law Are Charged

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
A Staten Island woman who went back to school as an adult and became a special education teacher was slain the day before school started by her estranged son-in-law, with her daughter trying to cover up his role in the crime, the police said yesterday.
The victim, Vivian Jones, 53, was stabbed and strangled in her home at 21 Egmont Place in the St. George section of Staten Island on Tuesday afternoon as she prepared to begin another school year teaching special education students at P 141 in Brooklyn, the police said. 
 Ms. Jones's daughter, Wendy Perry, 19, called the police around 7 P.M. Tuesday and said that she had come home with a friend and found her mother stabbed and bound in her bedroom, the police said.
But the police said the daughter's story soon began to unravel. And by yesterday morning, Ms. Perry's husband, John Perry, 20, was arrested on a murder charge, and Ms. Perry was arrested on charges of falsely reporting the incident and hindering prosecution, said William L. Murphy, the Staten Island District Attorney.
Deputy Inspector Charles Wells, the commander of Staten Island detectives, said that Ms. Jones had become tired of financially supporting the Perrys, who were both unemployed, and had recently asked Mr. Perry to leave the house because he watched television all day and refused to look for a job. When she got home Tuesday and found him in her kitchen, Inspector Wells said, they argued and he stabbed her with a kitchen knife.
Inspector Wells said that Mr. Perry then strangled Ms. Jones with a telephone cord, carried her body upstairs to her bedroom, bound her hands and feet with duct tape and emptied several drawers to make it appear as if she had been robbed. All this time, Inspector Wells said, Ms. Perry and the couple's 1-year-old child were in the house.
The couple then left the house with the child, the police said. That evening, Inspector Wells said, Ms. Perry came back with the child and a friend and feigned surprise at finding her mother's body. "Ms. Perry just used her girlfriend as a dupe," the Inspector said. Then she called 911, the police said. "That was one of the things that tipped us off," Inspector Wells said. "Her demeanor didn't seem to be proper. She seemed pretty cold for someone who just found her mother dead."
As detectives examined the ransacked house, he said, they grew more suspicious. "It seemed to be a staged robbery," he said.
Detectives questioned Ms. Perry and her friend at the 120th Precinct station house. Shortly after 3 A.M., Mr. Perry was taken in for questioning. The police said that he and his wife both made signed and videotaped confessions to the crime.

HEADLINE: House Republicans to Push for Tax Cut Worth Up to $80 Billion

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
House Republican leaders challenged the heart of President Clinton's domestic policy strategy today, saying they would press for a tax cut worth up to $80 billion over five years and pay for it by dipping into projected Federal budget surpluses.
Their decision puts House Republicans -- already considering impeachment proceedings against the President -- on another collision course with the White House. Mr. Clinton has insisted that the surplus be set aside until Congress and the Administration have agreed on a plan to shore up the Social Security system. 
 For most of this year, Mr. Clinton's "save Social Security first" strategy had kept Republicans from pursuing a big tax cut paid for by the budget surpluses, which are projected to reach more than $1.5 trillion over the next decade.
But Republicans, especially in the House, have grown increasingly willing to push for a tax cut, in part because of their perception that Mr. Clinton has been politically weakened and distracted and in part because of polling suggesting that voters think Congress can cut taxes and still have plenty of money left to save Social Security.
Mr. Clinton again told Republicans today that tapping the surpluses before they materialized would be fiscally irresponsible. Eager to change the subject from Monica Lewinsky, White House officials were clearly happy at the prospect of a policy fight that would play to the historical Democratic strength as defender of the Social Security system.
Mr. Clinton said in an address to Democrats in Florida, "It is a mistake for us to go out and have an election-year gimmick to please people, no matter how pleasing it would be, with a tax cut until we have saved Social Security for the 21st century."
Many Senate Republicans remain wary of challenging Mr. Clinton on the issue, and it is unclear whether the Senate will even take up a tax cut of any size in the few weeks remaining before Congress adjourns early next month. Because of the Senate's parliamentary rules, it would be all but impossible for the chamber to pass a tax cut with fewer than 60 votes. Republicans hold 55 Senate seats and several of the party's moderates have said they cannot support a tax cut of more than $30 billion over five years.
Speaker Newt Gingrich and other Republican leaders in the House, however, contend that it will be hard for the Senate not to act if the House passes a tax-cut bill in the next several weeks. Earlier this summer Mr. Gingrich was pushing for a much bigger tax cut, but today he said he would settle on a smaller package this year in the hopes of pushing through a more ambitious reduction next year.
"I think somewhere in the $70 to $80 billion range would be the most likely tax cut this fall," Mr. Gingrich said at a news conference this afternoon after meeting with his leadership team, referring to the amount of the tax cut over the next five years.
Asked whether the tax cut would be completely financed by using the surplus, Mr. Gingrich replied, "Virtually all of it, yes."
Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, is drafting a tax bill for the Republicans and could have it ready for the panel at the end of next week, aides said.
The bill will probably include a tax cut for some two-income couples, tax breaks for farmers and ranchers who have been hit hard by an economic downturn in agriculture and an increase in the income that retirees can earn without losing some of their Social Security benefits.
Republicans are also considering changes to the alternative minimum tax, which is intended to insure that wealthy people do not escape taxes through shelters and other sophisticated strategies, but which now applies to growing numbers of middle-income people. Mr. Archer has also supported allowing self-employed people to deduct more of their health-insurance costs.
"The American people today are having a bigger percentage of the G.D.P. taken away from them in Federal taxes than at any time in peacetime history," Mr. Archer said, referring to the share of the nation's gross domestic product accounted for by total Federal revenue."That's why we have a surplus. And we believe that it's appropriate to save Social Security and to give back part of that to badly hit Americans."
In addition to the looming confrontation over taxes, Congress appears headed toward a showdown with the White House over the spending bills needed to keep the Government operating. The Administration has issued veto threats against seven bills as passed by the House and two of the Senate versions. With the start of a new fiscal year on Oct. 1, both parties are taking seriously the possibility that a standoff could lead to a partial shutdown of those Government departments whose budgets have not been approved.
Jacob Lew, the White House budget director, said a tax cut that would be paid for by the surplus would be "inviting the kind of confrontation we all hope to avoid," although he said the White House would be happy to consider a tax cut that could be paid for by offsetting spending cuts.
Mr. Lew said it would be up to the Republicans to decide whether to seek a confrontation over the spending bills, which would cut financing for many of Mr. Clinton's priorities or reshape policy in areas like education and the environment.
Democrats had been looking forward to debating Republicans on the campaign trail this fall over taxes, spending and the best way to help Social Security. But with attention focused on Mr. Clinton's battle with the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, it is unclear how much political mileage either party will squeeze from budget issues.

HEADLINE: Five Precious Pages Renew Wrangling Over Anne Frank

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
More than 50 years after they were written in a secret refuge from the Nazis, long-suppressed pages from the diary of Anne Frank have given her story a new twist and set off a furor over exploitation of one of history's top best sellers, only recently republished in a supposedly "definitive" edition.
In the new-found entries -- actually five pages of diary revisions censored by Anne's father, Otto -- Anne picks apart her parents' strained marriage, analyzes her own difficult relations with her mother, Edith, and vows to keep the diary out of her family's hands as "none of their business." 
 "For a woman in love it cannot be easy to know that she will never occupy the first place in her husband's heart, and mother knew," Anne says. "Father appreciates mother and loves her, but not with the kind of love that I envisage for a marriage."
As for her diary -- which became one of the world's best-known books, published in 56 languages -- Anne says, "I shall also take care that nobody can lay hands on it."
The pages augmenting the diary were given last year to Melissa Muller, an Austrian journalist researching the first biography of the Jewish girl in Amsterdam who put an indelible human face on the Holocaust.
But in a peculiar turn, Ms. Muller, 31, is now seeing her new book, "Anne Frank: The Biography" (Metropolitan Books, a division of Henry Holt), come out with only paraphrases of the unpublished material because holders of the Anne Frank copyright denied her permission to quote its contents.
Meanwhile, plans are being advanced for updated editions of the diary to include the new material in full. And an A&E television biography "Anne Frank: The Missing Pages," based on Ms. Muller's book, is scheduled for broadcast on Tuesday with shots of the pages.
In a measure of how intense the maneuvering has become, an Amsterdam newspaper, Het Parool, published the disputed segments last month and also posted them on its Web page on the Internet.
"For me this is terrible," Ms. Muller said in a series of telephone interviews from Europe amid a crossfire of recriminations.
At issue are diary revisions written by Anne as she and her family hid in their refuge from German occupiers, a secret annex over Otto Frank's busy foodstuff warehouse.
The missing entries, which were hinted at in a scholarly version of Anne's diary published in 1986, were supplied to Ms. Muller by Cornelis Suijk, international director of the Anne Frank Center U.S.A. at 584 Broadway in Manhattan and an intimate of Mr. Frank, the family's sole survivor. His wife and two daughters died in German concentration camps.
Mr. Suijk (pronounced SOWK), a 74-year-old economist and Dutch Government auditor with 33 years of affiliations with Anne Frank groups in Amsterdam and the United States, said that Mr. Frank had given him the pages shortly before his death at 91 in 1980 during a German police inquiry aimed at authenticating the diary in the face of neo-Nazi claims that it was a forgery.
By Mr. Suijk's account, Mr. Frank wanted to be able to say honestly that he no longer had any diary material in his possession, and avoid revealing anything potentially embarrassing to him or his second wife, Fritzi, whom he had married in 1953. He also wanted to avoid debate over whether he had done the right thing in publishing Anne's diary in 1947.
"We knew that something was missing but we had no idea who had it," said Bernd Elias, Anne's cousin and the chairman of the Anne Frank Fonds, or foundation, in Basel, Switzerland, which holds the copyright on the diary and receives the revenue from publication.
The pages themselves are being claimed by the Netherlands State Institute for War Documentation, to whom Otto Frank bequeathed custody of the diary. It has asked Mr. Suijk to turn them over but he is claiming a one-time publication right of his own under Swiss law. He has also sought a sponsor to buy the pages to raise money for his Anne Frank Center in New York.
In an interview last week, Mr. Elias said it was "absolutely illegal" for Mr. Suijk to have given the pages to Ms. Muller. Mr. Suijk, in turn, faulted the foundation for amassing what he said was at least $20 million in royalties from the diary without sharing them with Anne Frank causes around the world, including his own center, which runs education programs on the Holocaust.
Ms. Muller said the Swiss foundation was initially enthusiastic over her findings and only withdrew support after she declined to submit her manuscript for review.
Her biography includes new information that for the first time points a strong finger of suspicion at a cleaning woman, Lena van Bladeren Hartog, now dead, who may have tipped off the Germans to the Jewish families in hiding. Ms. Muller said that in going over reports of a Dutch police inquiry of 1948, she found that the woman had admitted discovering that Jews were hiding but offered inconsistent accounts of what she did with that knowledge. The woman was angry over the death of her son, a volunteer in the German Navy.
The powerful Anne Frank legend has been buffeted by disputes before. In 1952, the Broadway version pitted Otto Frank against the novelist Meyer Levin, who had written a stage adaptation that Mr. Frank felt was too focused on Jews as victims and should be universalized.
Ms. Muller said she had no hint of Mr. Suijk's secret when she sought him out. She was particularly eager for information on Anne's mother, Edith Hollander, of whom little had been written -- even by Anne. It was, she told Mr. Suijk, as if "Anne Frank had no mother."
He decided to work closely with her. Still, he said, he met with her for 11 months before deciding to reveal the missing diary material -- three sides of two blue sheets and both sides of a salmon-colored sheet.
According to Ms. Muller's biography, Mr. Frank had been intensely in love with a wealthy young woman in Frankfurt whose parents ruled out the marriage on financial grounds, leaving him heartbroken and, ultimately, devoid of passion for Edith.
In the diary revision on the blue sheets, dated Feb. 8, 1944, when she was 14, Anne, addressing her fictional friend Kitty, talks about going through a period of reflection centering on her parents' marriage, always presented to her as "ideal."
She says she knows "a thing or two" about her father's past and, supplemented by her imagination, concludes that her father married her mother because "he deemed her the right person to be his wife."
"I must say that I admire my mother for the way she has filled that position without a murmur and without jealousy, as far as I can tell," Anne continues. Farther along she says, "Father is not in love, he gives her a kiss the way he kisses us."
As for her mother, Anne says: "Quite possibly because of her great sacrifice Mother has grown hard and disagreeable toward her surroundings and, consequently, she will drift further and further away from the path of love, will gain less and less admiration and, no doubt, Father will eventually come to realize that because externally she has never claimed his full love, she has crumbled away bit by bit internally. She loves him more than anybody else and it is hard to see this kind of love unanswered time and again."
Hence, she says, shouldn't she feel compassion for her mother? "Should I help her? And my father?"
No, she decides. Her mother has never told Anne about herself, nor has Anne asked her to; she describes a silence of near-strangers. She writes: "I am unable to talk with her, I cannot look lovingly into those cold eyes. I cannot, never! -- If she had only one aspect of an understanding mother, either tenderness or kindness, or patience or something else, I would keep trying to approach her. But, as the days go by, I find myself more and more unable to love this insensitive nature and mocking countenance. Yours Anne."
The salmon-colored sheet was Anne's revision of an introduction to the diary. Her parents and her sister, Margot, may be confidants, she writes, "yet my diary and the secrets I share with my friends are none of their business."
Anne's diary is really a succession of books and loose pages. She had been given a blank autograph album bound in red-and-green checkered cloth and secured with a simple keyless lock, for her 13th birthday, on June 12, 1942, a month before the family went into hiding.
Within six months, Anne had filled the makeshift diary, going on to a second notebook, which was lost, and two following notebooks. These became known as version A.
After hearing a Dutch radio broadcast urging citizens to preserve their histories of the war, Anne, over a period of two and a half months starting in May 1944, began revising her diary, rewriting 324 pages, perhaps as the basis for a novel. This became known as version B.
After the annex was raided by the Gestapo on Aug. 4, 1944, Anne's writings were preserved by Miep Gies, now 89, a devoted secretary for her father's business who had bravely kept the family's secret. When Mr. Frank, liberated at the Auschwitz death camp, returned to Amsterdam and learned that Anne and her elder sister, Margot, had died of typhus in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp in early 1945, weeks before the British liberation, Mrs. Gies presented him with the diaries.
Mr. Frank released a heavily edited version of B for its American publication as "Anne Frank: Diary of a Young Girl" in 1947. That became known as version C.
In 1986, the Institute for War Documentation in Amsterdam, which had been given custody of the diaries, published a so-called critical edition, comparing the versions, with scientific analysis, to refute any claims they were forgeries.
A footnote to the A version acknowledged the omission, at the family's request, of a 47-line segment that gave "an extremely unkind and particularly unfair picture of her parents' marriage." But in the B version there was no mention of anything missing -- namely the 74 lines of revisions Mr. Frank withheld.
In 1995, Doubleday, now part of Random House, issued a "definitive edition" timed to the 50th anniversary of Anne's death and including 30 percent more material than Otto Frank had allowed for the originally published C version. But this also lacked the revised entries that have now emerged.
Stuart Applebaum, senior vice president at Random House, said that any move to republish the book with the missing material would have to await a resolution of the legal claims.
"It's impossible for us to get beyond the rancor now," he said. Doubleday, which has North American hardcover publication rights to the diary, and Bantam, which has paperback rights, would not expect to pay additional money to republish with the new material, he said.
Peter Romijn, head of reseach for the Institute for War Documentation, said that a new printing of the critical edition had been planned anyway and now should include the new material.
Ms. Muller said she learned only in June that she would not be given permission to quote the new material in her book, a decision she attributed to commercial considerations as well as a misguided effort to protect Otto Frank.
"It's not terrible that a 36-year-old man may have had an earlier love," she said. Besides, she said, "I don't care what their marriage was like. I care about the relationship of mother and daughter."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Lowers Overnight Rate Near Zero Level

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 9

 BODY:
In an attempt to lift Japan out of its worst recession since World War II, the nation's central bank said today that it would reduce an important interest rate to the extraordinarily low level of one-quarter of 1 percent.
The Bank of Japan had resisted lowering rates, in part because they were already the lowest in the world. Today, however, it conceded that Japanese needed to prevent the economy -- which is already staggering under a burden of shrinking demand, tumbling corporate profit, sliding prices and rising unemployment -- from sinking further. 
 The rate cut, intended to make funds cheaper, comes as economists here and abroad have been calling on Japan to stimulate the economy, the world's second largest, and help avert recession elsewhere.
But with Japanese interest rates negligible, it will be extremely difficult for the central bank here to navigate monetary policy.
"They may have used their last bullet," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Tokyo. "They've already cut rates this far and it's probably helped, but it hasn't offset headwinds from elsewhere."
Traders reacted sharply, sending Japan's currency down almost 4 percent to a rate of 137 to the dollar. Early Thursday, the yen improved, standing in late morning at 135.13 to the dollar.
The Japanese authorities had been willing to risk a loss in the yen, which strengthened considerably in recent days, in an attempt to stimulate economic activity.
"The timing is appropriate in light of the instability in the financial markets," said Masaru Hayami, the central bank governor, at a news conference tonight. "It will help bring stability to the markets."
Mr. Hayami tried to deflect speculation that the rate reduction was made as part of an arrangement, perhaps tacit, with the United States and other major economies to avert a global slowdown.
"There was no international discussion at all," he said.
American and Japanese officials said the prospect of a cut did not come up during Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa's meetings on Friday with Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan.
United States officials in Washington have periodically discussed whether to press Japan for the kind of interest rate cut announced today. Some in the Treasury Department have recently said that a reduction would signal that Japan would welcome a dose of inflation to counteract the deflation that is afflicting the economy. Consumers, the thinking goes, would be spurred to make purchases before inflation sets in, injecting some spending into the economy.
But when interest rates are already hovering just above zero, it is unclear how much economic activity a rate cut can generate. And in any case, American officials say, Japan's problem has not been that rates are too high, but rather than many banks will not lend money at all as they try to stave off insolvency.
"This could be a help," said an American official in Washington who is involved with the Asian crisis, "but not much of a help. By itself, it won't accomplish much."
The interest rate cut is more significant in signaling a shift in policy than in its ability to make funds much cheaper. The overnight interbank rate -- similar to the Federal funds rate in the United States -- has been just under one-half of a percent for the last three years. By contrast, the rate in the United States is 5.5 percent.
One reason the central bank here had resisted lowering the interest rate was that all but one of its nine policy board members had said they wanted to save a rate cut for a real economic emergency.
Another way of easing monetary policy is to increase the supply of funds by printing more money and pouring it into the financial system. But it is one that the Bank of Japan has shied away from because it is not as precise as manipulating interest rates. Today, however, the central bank also said it would supply a large amount of liquidity into the money market, if necessary, regardless of the level of overnight interest rates. Doing so, in essence, could make the borrowing of funds virtually free.
"It's a welcome development but it's probably too little, too late," said Peter Morgan, an economist with HSBC Securities here. "They think that things are bad enough that they can break the glass and bring about a rate cut."
And in a speech in Washington, David H. Komansky, chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch, said today that he doubted an interest rate cut "by itself would be enough to stimulate the economy."
"In order to begin to make progress in Japan," Mr. Komansky said to the National Press Club, "our feeling is that the financial industry, primarily the banks, have to be restructured and there have to be permanent tax cuts. These are going to be very, very painful moves. But unless these actions are taken, or until such times as these actions are taken, I would doubt" that the quarter-point rate cut would affect the Japanese economy.
The central bank's move came a day after a top economic official, Taichi Sakaiya, released an assessment saying that Japan's economy was in an "extremely severe" situation. Mr. Sakaiya added that the global economy was "at the threshold of an extremely difficult phase."
Tonight, the Bank of Japan acknowledged that the level of economic activity had fallen considerably, adding it did not deny the possibility of a "further deterioration."
The further shrinkage in the economy -- deflation -- is particularly worrisome because the Government has been trying to increase growth through public spending. It is carrying out big tax cuts and is already beginning to pour about $120 billion into the economy as part of a huge fiscal-stimulus package.
The Finance Ministry earlier in the day released figures showing that capital spending in the second quarter fell 10.6 percent from the similar period a year earlier, the largest drop in years.
And with deflation, real interest rates become higher for borrowers.
Mr. Hayami, the central bank governor, said the rate reduction had been made in part to prevent Japan's economy from "falling into a deflationary spiral," in which prices and profits collapse faster and faster.
Both Mr. Sakaiya's remarks and the rate cut come two days before the scheduled release of economic data for the second quarter, and some economists said these moves could be a foreshadowing of more bad news. Japan's economy shrank in the first quarter at an annualized rate of 5.3 percent, and while some economists had expected the economy in the second quarter to contract less than 1 percent on an annual basis, that may be too optimistic.
Japan's banks and corporations will settle their half-year accounts at the end of this month, and one of the central bank's main concerns is to keep the markets flush with money to prevent a sudden liquidity squeeze as banks and corporations negotiate for funds to settle contracts and close their accounts. It was such a squeeze last fall that helped lead to the failure of four financial institutions and a market plunge.
"Maybe they know something about the financial system," Mr. Feldman of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter said.
Indeed, in stock market trading earlier today, investors drove down the share price of Fuji Bank, as rumors circulated that the bank had sustained losses of about two trillion yen, or $14.6 billion, from derivatives, risky financial instruments based on the value of underlying securities. Terunobu Maeda, a managing director at Fuji Bank, denied the rumors at a news conference today, saying they were "totally groundless."
"We have lost about 15.5 billion yen at most," he said. Fuji Bank's share price has fallen by more than half in the last two months, and today, it hit a yearly low of 320 yen at one point and ended at 329 yen.
After the close of the market today, Daiwa Securities said it had lost more than $100 million on Russian, Latin American, Asian and other emerging-market debt in August. It was the latest in a series of institutions to announce such losses.
The last time the central bank cut interest rates was in September 1995, when it lowered the official discount rate, the overnight rate it charges private banks, to half a percent. Bankers say it is unlikely to lower that rate now. The interbank rate it lowered today is essentially the money market rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans.
The financial system has been teetering as Parliament debates how to deal with the nation's very large and very sick banks. At issue in particular is the fate of the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, one of the largest institutions.
The Government wants to use tax money to save the bank, while the opposition parties want to attach strict conditions for doing so. The debate had stymied the passage of six bills that the Government hopes will stabilize the financial system.
Today, however, the governing Liberal Democratic Party and the opposition groups seemed close to a compromise that would allow for quick passage of the financial legislation, perhaps before Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi visits the United States to meet President Clinton later this month.
