HEADLINE: Berea Journal;
A College of Few Parties And Fewer Complaints

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: BEREA, Ky., Sept. 9

 BODY:
Nobody calls Berea College a party school.
It has no fraternities or sororities. The campus and most of the county surrounding it are dry. There is no movie theater in town. Only seniors can own cars. Smoking is severely restricted, even though this is tobacco country. And there are no football weekends, because there is no football team. 
 Must be a religious school, you say. Well, yes and no. It was founded in 1855 by the Rev. John G. Fee, a Presbyterian minister, in what was then a wilderness, where the Bluegrass meets Appalachia. But it is affiliated with no denomination and lives by no dogma, fundamentalist or otherwise. And it has Buddhists and Muslims as well as Christians on its faculty and in its student body.
There is nothing drab or monastic about Berea. The campus is a leafy, pretty, neo-Georgian place, the teachers are talented and enthusiastic, a rich variety of extracurricular activities and organizations are available, and there are intramural and intercollegiate teams in a large number of sports.
The entrance requirements are a little odd, especially the one that says only students from families with incomes below $44,000 a year will even be considered. About 80 percent of the student body is drawn from the hard-luck hills and hollows, villages and cities of southern Appalachia. Berea must be the only college in the country that hangs out a sign: Rich kids need not apply.
It charges no tuition. It requires each of its 1,500 students to work at least 10 or 15 hours a week in a wide range of jobs. Some make brooms or weave cloth in the craft shops, some operate the college's computers, some work in the Berea Hospital, and some wait on tables at the Boone Tavern Hotel near the campus.
Which may explain why the students, most of them at least, voice no complaints about the lack of social facilities taken for granted elsewhere.
"We're all in the same boat here," said Tyra Lainhart, 27, a junior from Erlanger, Ky., who came to Berea, married, had a baby, dropped out, divorced, worked as a prison guard and this summer returned to college. "We have a common bond in our economic situation. Nobody has money for a lot of extra stuff. The money you earn from your job goes to pay for books, room and board."
Angela Hale, a 22-year-old senior from Childersburg, Ala., said that when she went home on vacation some of her friends, students at Tuskegee University and elsewhere, talked "mainly about parties and fashion." Ms. Hale, who had never been out of her home state before she came to Berea, said she was glad to be on a campus "where it's never about what you wear and what you look like."
Many of the students said that if they had not come to Berea, they could not have gone to college anywhere, at least not to an institution that seeks to provide a high-quality four-year liberal arts education. Fully 70 percent of them are the first in their families to go to college. Some had never spent a night away from home before coming here. Many take their first plane flight when they make a college-sponsored or -aided trip to Europe during their time here.
"It's a culture shock," said Larry D. Shinn, the college's president. "The leap from Paint Lick or Stone Gap or Stinking Creek to a tough academic environment in the big city of Berea, population 10,000, takes some doing."
Berea was the first college in the South to admit blacks and women on an equal basis. An outgrowth of the struggle against slavery, it was the creation of Mr. Fee and a fiery abolitionist named Cassius M. Clay, who opened meetings by laying a Bible, a copy of the Constitution and a bowie knife on the lectern -- the Bible, he explained, for those who believed in God, the Constitution for those who believed in man, and the knife for those who believed in neither.
Mr. Shinn, a former professor at Oberlin College and administrator at Bucknell University, makes no sweeping claims for Berea's academic standards, though more than 55 percent of its graduates earn advanced degrees and the college regularly scores well in U.S. News & World Report's annual ratings.
"I think I have a realistic notion of what we are and what we're not," he said. "We're not in the top 10 among liberal arts colleges, but we're in the top 50, and we provide an education of real excellence. It's a question of money. Williams College spends $51,000 per year per student; we spend $18,800."
The teacher-student ratio is as good as Harvard's, but teachers carry heavier loads. Students help renovate dormitories. Berea's endowment is $525 million, but it has no tuition income, and it has fewer rich alumni than many colleges. What is more, it turns down the children of the rich alumni it does have, because of the $44,000 income lid. Nonetheless, it raised $17 million last year, more than 80 percent from non-alumni.
The struggle binds the place together and creates "a strong foundation," said one of the college's star students, Addie Sine, 20, from Knoxville, Tenn., the daughter of a single mother.
"It's like our own little culture," she said. "It's a secure place. You know that next year the trees will be in the same place and the teachers will come back because they love teaching here. Most of all, the students will be people who want to be here, who need to be here because it's a chance to make something of themselves, not because someone told them to go to college."
Wendy Stephens, 21, a soft-spoken psychology major from Whitley City, Ky., agreed. What worries her, she said, "is this: When we graduate, into a world where everyone is obsessed with money and possessions, will we be able to deal with real life?"

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
CASE PLANS JOB CUTS AND EXPECTS EARNINGS DROP

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
The Case Corporation said yesterday that it would cut 1,000 jobs by the end of the year in response to expected lower demand for agricultural equipment. The company, based in Racine, Wis., said that it would take a reorganization charge of $70 million to $80 million in the second half of 1998, linked to the job cuts, and that 1998 earnings were expected to be about 25 percent below comparable 1997 results. Case, which makes agricultural and construction equipment and provides financial services, said the reduction in demand was caused by a lower projected farm income in many of the company's major markets and deteriorating economic conditions in emerging markets.

SECTION: Section A; Page 32; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 182 words

HEADLINE: Why Should Russia Get Tough on Taxes?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You claim that the Russian Government's printing of rubles, as proposed by Acting Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, would guarantee a period of hyperinflation and the turning off of foreign investment and International Monetary Fund assistance (editorial, Sept. 5). 
 The Russian economy today resembles Franklin D. Roosevelt's economy in the 1930's, with comparable unemployment of labor and capital. Under these circumstances, the increase in tax collections to move closer to a balanced budget may poison any economic system. When Roosevelt did this in 1937, he produced a sharp decline in economic activity in the 1938 recession rather than any significant increase in the rate of inflation.
The hyperinflation danger is today a bogyman, as can be seen in the experience of Belarus, where wages and pensions are paid regularly and output is growing by double-digit proportions, as a result of the printing of Belarussian rubles.
 
LYNN TURGEON
Ann Arbor, Mich., Sept. 5, 1998
 
The writer is professor emeritus of economics at Hofstra University.

HEADLINE: Why Should Russia Get Tough on Taxes?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I'm not convinced that Russians will get by no matter how tough things get (Week in Review, Sept. 7). 
 I propose that we spend $22 billion a year for five years to insure that every individual over 65 in Russia, some 18 million of them, receives $100 a month in United States currency. This would not by itself solve Russia's economic problems, but it would go a long way toward promoting stability.
The $100 would surely be spent on necessities, opening up pathways of supply and starting up circles of employment and self-employment where little or none existed before.
The $22 billion would reflect our own self-interest. It could also reflect our recognition of the suffering and heroism of a generation, now elderly, that defeated Hitler's armies and endured Communism and the cold war.
 
MARVIN GREGORY
Renton, Wash., Sept. 7, 1998

HEADLINE: LIBRARY/PRESCRIPTION DRUG SITES;
Places to Check Out the Pills for Your Ills

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
IF you are like most Americans, your medicine cabinet is packed with a pricey assortment of pills and potions, evidence that we, as a country, like to feel good. And some of the newer pills -- say, Viagra and Prozac -- can make even others feel good about you.
Americans are the largest consumers of prescription drugs in the world, spending some $94 billion for them last year, according to IMS Health, a health care consulting company. This year's tally should be ever higher, thanks especially to Viagra, a treatment for impotency, which is expected to rack up a record $1 billion in sales in its first year on the market. Stockholders in the world's pharmaceutical companies have come to expect blockbuster sales, so the companies have been forced to churn out blockbuster remedies faster than before. This year, Merck & Company, the nation's largest pharmaceutical company, released five new drugs that treat everything from migraines to asthma. 
 And there are plenty more on the way. Within a year, Lipha Pharmaceuticals, a German subsidiary of Merck, expects to release Campral, a drug to help alcoholics wean themselves from drinking, in the United States. For people who cannot knock off at night, American Home Products will soon roll out Sonata, a sleeping pill that the company says has fewer groggy after-effects than some of its competitors.
It is easy to get buried in the drug avalanche, unable to distinguish the side effects of antihistamines like Claritin and Allegra. If the unthinkable happens and you become impotent, what are Viagra's advantages over Caverject? It makes a difference -- one is a pill and one is a shot.
"Within the last several years, the entire process of pharmaceutical research has sped up," said Dr. Jeffrey Adelglass, a Dallas physician. "With some of the pharmaceutical sites now available on the Web, I can get medical information as fast or faster than anyone else in the country."
Several sites can help you find out how a drug should be taken, while others blow the whistle on the inaccuracy of some of the drug makers' advertisements. The Food and Drug Administration, which regulates the sales and advertising of prescription drugs in this country, seldom requires a company to correct an error in its marketing. But it does have a site with information on drugs' safety records and Government reprimand letters about advertising campaigns (www.fda.gov/cder/ drug.htm). For those interested in what prescription drugs are under development, sites like www.centerwatch.com list clinical trials for pharmaceuticals and medical treatments being developed.
There are other on-line drug information resources, like the National Library of Medicine, which has put Medline, its extensive database of medical information on the Web at www.nlm.nih.gov. Merck & Company, publisher of the drug encyclopedia called The Merck Index, has put The Merck Index of Diagnosis and Therapy on its corporate home page (www.merck.com). The Merck Manual is a more general source of medical information than the Index (which is sold on CD-ROM). It is used extensively by doctors and nurses nationwide.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 11, 1998, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Circuits yesterday about prescription drug Web sites referred incorrectly to Lipha Pharmaceuticals. Lipha is a subsidiary of Merck K.G.a.A., a German company; it has no relationship to Merck & Company, an American drug manufacturer.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Britain Leaves Its Rates Alone

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
The Bank of England left its key interest rate steady today at 7.5 percent but hinted that it might lower it soon.
The decision, which had been expected, was accompanied by a statement saying the nine-member rate-setting committee thought global events might push the British inflation rate below its target. 
 The statement said the panel had "discussed extensively" the potential effect of international developments on British inflation and would continue to monitor the situation.
This was the first time the panel has issued a statement with a "no change" decision and comes after a monetary easing by Japan on Wednesday and recent comments by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, indicating a potential cut in United States interest rates.
The Bank of England's comments are bound to fuel speculation of coordinated action to ease global monetary conditions.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Soars to Another Record

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit in goods, services and investments widened to a record $56.525 billion in the second quarter, the Commerce Department said today. Net foreign purchases of Treasury securities increased as international investors shifted out of United States stocks.
The current account balance is the broadest measure of the nation's international trade, covering goods and services trade, investments and financial transactions between governments. In the first quarter, the current account shortfall widened to $46.735 billion, which was initially reported as widening to $47.210 billion. 
 With the United States dollar in demand as the reserve currency worldwide and the country supplying a fourth of the world's output, the current account deficit -- which represents what the United States pays to other countries to settle all business transactions -- does not trouble most economists. "As long as people want to invest here, then we have no trouble," said Russ Sheldon, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York.
"However, history teaches us that this could be quite a serious problem," if international investors sell their United States assets for economic or political reasons, Mr. Sheldon said.
And this year, weak export demand and a flood of low-price imports, both stemming from the economic turmoil in Asia, are stinging corporate earnings, "further slowing the U.S. economy," said Gerald Cohen, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1547 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Moscow Madness From the Inside;
Investment Bank That Rode Boom Now Faces Bust

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 10

 BODY:
The gleaming marble and glass headquarters of MFK Renaissance, one of Russia's leading investment banks, stands as tangible evidence of the financial gold rush that briefly swept through here. Limousines still park by the firm's front doors, which abut the offices of Moscow's pre-eminent power broker, Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov -- quite a change from just three years ago, when MFK Renaissance operated from the spare confines of a former hotel disco.
But inside MFK Renaissance, beyond plush royal blue carpeting and elegantly upholstered furniture, the trading floor and its computers are eerily quiet. And for good reason. Most of the bank's capital has been wiped out, most of its assets are nearly worthless, and the firm, like many other investment banks that not so long ago were speculating in Moscow's booming markets, is scrambling to stay afloat. 
 "It's like a football game here; every player has taken a hit," said Boris Jordan, 32, MFK Renaissance's avuncular -- and still-optimistic -- founder. "The real issue is who's executing their responsibilities and moving the ball forward. From that perspective, MFK Renaissance is in fine shape and remains a market leader."
Whatever its future, MFK's meteoric rise and sudden implosion is more than just a tale of how quickly this boom town has become a financial ghost town. It is also a parable of international finance in the 1990's that reveals how those who exploited the advantages of free markets and the unfettered flow of capital around the world are being swept up in the whirlwind.
"I think the lesson people will take from this is that the domino theory does work and there can be massive financial contagion," said Tom Ashead, co-head of research at Brunswick Warburg, a Moscow brokerage firm. "But the contagion only revealed weaknesses that were already apparent in Russia, and they were weaknesses many investors chose not to see."
For his part, Mr. Jordan was uniquely positioned to play a role near the center of Russia's awful economic management. While still only in his 20's, Mr. Jordan, a grandson of Soviet-era refugees who emigrated to America, was already a key adviser to the Russian Government. These services were combined with investment banking pursuits that placed Mr. Jordan at the heart of financial schemes that only postponed the day of reckoning for the Russian economy -- and may have made it even worse.
Mr. Jordan, a native of Long Island, was part of a large contingent of Russian-Americans who arrived in Moscow in the late 1980's and early 1990's. Some were motivated by an interest in rebuilding the country. Others simply had dollar signs in their eyes. In either case, it proved easy to set up shop.
"People thought that if you had a Russian accent and some education you could be an investment banker or a stockbroker or anything else you wanted to be," said Andrei Bogolubov, the Russian-American president of AB Image, a public relations firm in Moscow and a consultant to MFK Renaissance. "That seems like a long time ago now."
Mr. Jordan had worked at the American investment banking firm Kidder, Peabody & Company, which no longer exists, and an Irish aircraft leasing company, before taking a job here with Credit Suisse First Boston in 1992. He then managed to win Credit Suisse a position as an adviser to Moscow as the Russian Government began a huge privatization of state-owned companies. That campaign ended up turning them over mostly to insiders -- some of whom are suspected of milking the assets for their own purposes -- and to politically connected robber barons.
Mr. Jordan left Credit Suisse to start what became MFK Renaissance in 1995, the same year that the second phase of privatization began. At the heart of this new phase was a controversial program begun in 1995 and known as loans-for-shares. The program allowed a handful of banks led by a powerful clique of Russian businessmen dubbed the "oligarchs" to lend the Government money in return for receiving controlling stakes in many of Russia's most significant industrial concerns.
It was a process fraught with accusations of sweetheart deals and influence peddling, and Mr. Jordan was at the center of the action. His firm, Renaissance Capital, developed a close alliance with Vladimir Potanin, a former Government official and an oligarch who was the head of Uneximbank, a Russian bank that gained control of several large nickel and oil companies. Uneximbank is an investor in the entity they put together, MFK Renaissance.
Mr. Jordan's ascent, his financial holdings, and his contacts within the Russian Government led officials from the United States to call on him when they were in town. He attracted the hot money of hedge fund gurus like George Soros and Michael Dingman. Mr. Soros has an undisclosed sum invested with MFK Renaissance while Mr. Dingman, who sits on the board of Sidanko, a Russian oil concern controlled by Messrs. Jordan and Potanin, also holds an equity stake in the firm.
Mr. Dingman has been criticized for financial wheeling and dealing in the Czech Republic that ended up ruining many individual investors there, but Mr. Dingman said that criticism was "unfair" and does not apply to his investment activities here. "It's an example of what I didn't do and am not doing in Russia," Mr. Dingman said. "My commitment to Russia is deliberately long term."
In the meantime, as Mr. Jordan and his firm grew richer, the Russian securities market was percolating. New Russian Government short-term securities that paid whopping interest rates, GKO's, attracted a whole new crew of investors to Russia in 1996 and 1997. Suddenly, Moscow seemed to be one of the world's most promising financial centers and MFK Renaissance was one of the most active participants in the GKO market. "It was like you could hear the sound of money being made in the streets," said an executive with an American investment bank here who requested anonymity. "It sorted of wafted up into your apartment or hotel window."
But for some not caught up in the thrill of the money mill's churning, it sounded more like a casino gone wild.
"It was a classic sort of bubble and there was a lot of betting," said Al Breach, an economist with the Russian-European Center for Economic Policy. "People bought because the market was going up, not because the fundamentals were sound. Lots of investors, serious investors, didn't even know there were big Government deficits here. It became ridiculous."
In fact, the GKO's paid such lofty interest rates -- 30 percent to 50 percent annually and as high as 150 percent earlier this spring -- because the Russian Government's deficit was ballooning.
A key factor in Russia's collapse was a failure to collect taxes, which were supposed to replace the revenues previously generated by state-owned enterprises. And with oil prices collapsing, Russia could no longer count on enough money from what had been its most valuable resource. Without enough revenues to pay its bills, and to support ailing local banks that owned the bonds, Russia issued more GKO's with ever-higher interest rates attractive to foreign and domestic investors -- a short-term fix that eventually buried the Government under a pyramid of debt that collapsed last month.
That in turn touched off a devaluation of the Russian ruble, contributing to international fears about the soundness of other emerging markets as well.
"Unfortunately, I think the GKO market didn't bring any real investment to the Russian economy," said Dmitri Vasiliev, chairman of Russia's Federal Commission for the Securities Market. "It just covered very high Government deficits."
Anyone close to the Russian Government, or even remotely familiar with its finances, should have seen that investing in GKO's in the absence of a sound tax policy was nothing but a speculative game.
But Mr. Jordan said he came to Moscow to help rejuvenate the economy and did not see his crucial participation in the GKO market as detrimental to Russia. He said that as an investor he had to be rewarded for the risk he took in buying the bonds and that they were "constructive" until the Government "mangled" them to plug fiscal gaps.
He is also smarting from the malaise created by the GKO debacle. An individual close to the firm and familiar with MFK Renaissance's finances said that the firm's capital, about $200 million at the end of last year, has nearly been wiped out. He said the firm had about $2 billion in assets at the end of last year that are worth about $200 million now -- and many of those assets will be entirely written off.
MFK Renaissance also owes about $100 million on hedging contracts. It is owed $200 to $300 million by local banks, but it has little chance of collecting the money since most Russian banks are now insolvent.
Mr. Jordan, who has spent lavishly renovating a home in the exclusive Zhukovka district outside Moscow, said he had no holdings abroad other than "cash" and was committed to staying in Russia unless his family was threatened by the downturn.
"We pioneered this market and didn't jump on planes when the tanks rolled in 1993 or when the market collapsed in 1995," he said. "We intend to remain at the forefront through this cycle, too."

HEADLINE: Walter Adams, 78, Expert on Corporate Power and Antitrust Issues, Dies

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

 BODY:
Walter Adams, an antitrust expert whose concerns about concentrations of corporate power helped shape Government policy for three decades, died Tuesday at his home in East Lansing, Mich., according to a statement from Michigan State University, where he taught for 46 years. He was 78 years old.
His son, William James Adams of Ann Arbor, Mich., said the cause was pancreatic cancer. Professor Adams learned in May that he had the disease. 
 Professor Adams taught economics at Michigan State from 1947 to 1993 and served as president of the university for nine months in 1969, a time when antiwar and civil rights protests rocked the campus. He addressed those issues with such candor and good humor that more than 20,000 students and 950 faculty members signed a petition asking him to stay on as president. But he said he wanted to teach, not be an administrator.
John Kenneth Galbraith, the Harvard University economist, praised Professor Adams as a "wonderful teacher" who was "a good New Deal liberal."
He served on a Federal committee that Attorney General Herbert Brownell formed in 1953 to study antitrust laws, and he spent many summers in Washington volunteering his expertise to Congressional committees in an era when they had little or no staff.
He wrote or co-wrote 14 books warning of the dangers of concentrated economic power, including "The Bigness Complex" in 1987 and "Dangerous Pursuits: Mergers & Acquisitions in the Age of Wall Street" in 1989, both with Prof. James W. Brock of Miami University of Ohio.
"He raised enduring questions of power and control in economics and in the closely related political arena as well," Professor Brock said. "He kept alive a concern about excessive concentration of power and its dangers to a free society because it undermines good economic performance, retards innovation and tends to spread into the political sphere in lobbying aimed at creating anti-competitive public policies. He taught that we can't rest easy in the delusion that the unfettered free market will take care of everything."
Professor Adams was sharply critical of the Reagan Administration for allowing big corporate mergers. In 1988 he wrote that "the antitrust laws have been subjected to a systematic policy of euthanasia."
But William F. Baxter, a Stanford University law professor who was the Reagan Administration's antitrust chief for three years, said concern about industries in which a handful of companies can set "administered prices" and operate insulated from supply and demand "has gone from the predominant point of view to an idiosyncratic point of view."
Robert H. Bork, the failed Supreme Court nominee who is an antitrust expert and several times jousted with Professor Adams, said that "he saw concentration of industries everywhere and tended to think that industries I would think were perfectly competitively structured were not competitively structured."
Walter Adams was born in 1922 in Vienna. His family moved to Brooklyn in 1935. He graduated magna cum laude from Brooklyn College in 1942 with an economics degree and also studied at the University of Chicago. He earned his doctorate at Yale University in 1947.
In World War II he served in the 83d Infantry Division, fighting in the Battle of the Bulge, and in the 11th Armored Division. He received a battlefield commission as a lieutenant and the Bronze Star. He often described his war experiences as "the Tour de France sans bicyclette."
Professor Adams's playful side showed in an otherwise dry report in 1963 for the Senate Antitrust and Monopoly subcommittee on oligopolies.
Robert F. Lanzillotti, who was then the economics chairman at Michigan State and co-author of the report, said, "We wanted to deal with those economists who saw no merit in the theory of administered prices and who frequently supported their position by citing research that their graduate students were doing but that was not complete or published."
Professor Adams added a footnote on a study of the relationship of prices and profits by Hubertus von und Swickenstein and Boris Przmysy-Watson. Though the names were fictitious and the ruse had been reported, other researchers asked him how to get in touch with the pair.
In addition to his son, he is survived by his wife, Pauline, and two grandsons.
His last book, "The Tobacco Wars," written with Professor Brock, was published last week by South-Western College Publishing of Cincinnati. It was their third book to use the form of a play to teach economics.
Two weeks ago, after word of Professor Adams's illness became known around the Michigan State campus, more than 200 musicians in the college marching band, which he had supported for a half-century, came to his home to play the university fight song and alma mater for him.

HEADLINE: House Panel Blocks New Funds for I.M.F.

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Rejecting pleas by the Administration, a key House committee voted today against full financing for the International Monetary Fund.
The action appears to doom efforts by the Administration and the Senate, which has already approved full funding, to replenish the fund's reserves. But Representative Bob Livingston, Republican of Louisiana and chairman of the Appropriations Committee, held out the possibility that the House could still approve the money under an agreement with the Senate. 
 It is uncertain if Mr. Livingston, who conceded today that he had been on "both sides of this issue," will prevail.
His committee, egged on by Representative Tom DeLay, the third-ranking Republican in the House, voted largely along party lines today to deny the request for $18 billion. Instead the committee voted 30 to 22 to provide only $3.4 billion.
Mr. Livingston told the committee he was voting against full financing in order to buy time to draw up more stringent operating conditions for the fund. He added that he would probably vote to approve full financing later.
He told reporters that those who want the agency to die "may well predominate," but added: "My suspicion is that there is enough support among both parties in both houses that you're going to have an I.M.F."
The White House Budget Director, Jacob Lew, wrote to Mr. Livingston today saying the full $18 billion was critical because the fund's resources were so low. "To reject or delay this funding not only would undermine America's leadership in the world, it also would expose American workers, savers, farmers and businesses to unacceptable economic risks," Mr. Lew wrote.
But it was not at all clear that in the next few weeks, as time runs out and Congress becomes overwhelmed with possible impeachment proceedings against President Clinton, the committee will be able to focus on the technical details.
As the committee voted against full funding, it approved the overall $16.2-billion bill to finance other foreign operations. But the bill has other contentious provisions and many Republicans expect that most of the 13 appropriation bills needed to keep the Government running after Oct. 1 will be folded together in one big package later -- a chaotic process that could bode ill for issues like the I.M.F. if conservatives hold firm.
The bad economic news from Russia and Asia has made some Republicans more reluctant to keep financing the agency. Mr. DeLay rushed to the committee meeting today for only a few minutes to talk about the fund, leaving talks with other members on how to handle possible impeachment proceedings.
Mr. DeLay said it would be wrong for American taxpayers to finance the agency while the agency, which he described as an anachronism in today's global economy, refused to make public its own budget and lending practices.
He also said the agency had lost sight of its original mission. "Instead of providing needed cash to basically sound enterprises, the I.M.F. is now bailing out the bankrupt," he said. He said the fund needed more money to back risky investments and "perpetuate this bail-out cycle."
Standing up for the additional money were several Democrats, who said the agency needed to be reformed but that America should send a strong signal to stem the tide of free-falling markets around the world.
"For all of its weaknesses, the I.M.F. is one of the few tools we have available to stabilize currencies," said Representative David Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin. Representative Steny Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland, said, "The psychology of U.S. action has significant and almost immediate ramifications. What we do matters."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexico's Central Bank Fails in Attempt to Prop Up Peso

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 10

 BODY:
The central bank waded into Mexican currency markets today in a dramatic new intervention, selling nearly $500 million in dollars and tightening cash in circulation in an unsuccessful effort to support the peso, which was pressured by new panic selling in the stock market.
The Banco de Mexico's tough new measures, its first direct intervention in the currency markets since 1995, could not prevent the peso from dropping to a historic low, worth 9.49 American cents. Meanwhile, the bolsa, the Mexican stock market, plunged 9.82 percent. 
 Agitating the Mexican markets were new declines on Wall Street and mounting fears of a Brazilian currency devaluation, which could greatly worsen the continuing investor stampede out of emerging markets that has resulted from the financial crises in Asia and Russia, securities analysts said.
Treasury Secretary Jose Angel Gurria and the governor of the central bank, Guillermo Ortiz, appeared at an evening news conference, apparently orchestrated to calm the markets. Mr. Gurria said Mexico's economy was healthy, but acknowledged that international turmoil might worsen. "We can't say what will happen in Brazil tomorrow, much less next week," he said.
 The monetary measures announced today are likely to lead to further increases in Mexican interest rates, already above 45 percent, and aggravate fears among business people that the country's booming economy could slide into recession.
"The Mexican authorities are getting into some harsh monetary measures now," said Luis R. Luis, a managing director at Scudder Kemper Investments in Boston. "I'd expect rates to go higher, but they have to take these measures because international events are hitting Mexico really hard. We're just seeing a fire sale of assets."
After the peso, which has declined by more than 20 percent this year, again fell precipitously in morning trading, the central bank sold $100 million of Mexico's international reserves as part of a regular system of currency auctions. Under the terms of those auctions, the exchange rate was set as an average of bids from the country's 17 commercial banks, a senior central bank official said.
When that sale had no appreciable effect on the value of the peso, the bank's five-member board of governors decided to intervene with an extraordinary direct sale of dollars, its first such measure since December 1995, the official said. The bank sold an additional $278 million at market rates, the official said. Hours later, the bank sold $100 million more under its regular auction system.
The value of the Mexican peso floats with the market. Unlike Venezuela and Brazil, whose central banks have been selling billions of dollars in reserves to support overvalued currencies that trade within a fixed band, Mexico has not seen any significant decline in its international reserves in recent weeks.
In the news conference, Mr. Ortiz said that today's intervention aimed not to support the peso at a fixed rate but to keep it from declining too abruptly and to supply a market with dollars on a day when there were few sellers.
In addition to the sale of dollars, the Banco de Mexico also moved again to restrict liquidity. The central bank announced that starting today, it would leave the country's commercial banks with 100 million pesos less than they needed, under a system known as daily "shorts." As a result, banks will need to raise interest rates to attract sufficient working cash. Today's measure simply turned up the steam on a measure adopted earlier in the current crisis. Last month, the central bank announced that it would leave banks 70 million pesos short each day.

HEADLINE: Musical Chairs in Moscow

 BODY:
If urbanity, longevity and familiarity with international issues were the qualities most needed for Russia's next prime minister, Yevgeny Primakov would be admirably suited for the job. Few officials are as well versed in Kremlin politics as Mr. Primakov, who has served in senior national security posts under every Russian leader going back to Leonid Brezhnev two decades ago. But since a commitment to democracy and reform are more essential for Russia's future, his selection yesterday by President Boris Yeltsin looks more like an act of desperation than an act of leadership.
The choice of Mr. Primakov was dictated by parliamentary opposition to Mr. Yeltsin's first choice, Viktor Chernomyrdin, no paragon of reform in a previous tour as Prime Minister. Rather than challenging a truculent legislature and calling new elections, which would have prolonged the political crisis in Moscow, Mr. Yeltsin turned to a man who was acceptable to the Communist-dominated body. Mr. Primakov earned that trust through years of loyal party service during the Soviet period and close ties to the K.G.B. After the Soviet Union collapsed he ran the foreign intelligence agency that replaced the K.G.B. and since 1996 has been Foreign Minister. 
 Mr. Primakov is no ideologue, as his smooth transition from one leader and era to the next would suggest. He can be charming, wryly amusing and cold-bloodedly pragmatic. But Russians should not look to him for new reform programs. Instead, he is likely to assemble a coalition government and try to steady the economy through the kind of state intervention that over time crippled the Soviet Union. The question is whether Mr. Primakov will do so cautiously and within the framework of a market system, or try to wrench Russia back toward a managed economy, which would stunt the prospects for recovery.
Mr. Primakov may also harden Russian foreign policy in areas like the Balkans and the Middle East, where he has already opposed American positions as Foreign Minister. His reputation as a defender of Russian interests has served him well in a nation soured on capitalism and increasingly wary of Washington's policy prescriptions.
Mr. Primakov should bring a measure of stability to a country verging on anarchy. He at least commands the respect of many of his fellow politicians and countrymen, which is more than can be said of Mr. Yeltsin. His other attraction to the political heavyweights hoping to succeed Mr. Yeltsin is that Mr. Primakov, who is 68, seems to have no interest in running for president himself. Such are the calculations that pass for leadership in Moscow these days.

HEADLINE: Eating and Hoping at the Concord;
Kosher Hotel's Friends Await Bankruptcy Court Ruling

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES

DATELINE: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 7

 BODY:
At the last meal of the season in the Concord Resort Hotel's 3,000-seat dining room, Table C-8, always the loudest, was even louder than usual.
Swamped by plates of baked lasagna, all 10 people sitting around the white-clothed table were talking and laughing and arguing at once, as comfortable in their spot at the front and center of the room as stage veterans. "This table," Jerry Angel announced, "is the table for the ages." 
 Table C-8, made up of couples and singles from Brooklyn, Manhattan, Westchester, Long Island and New Jersey, is a more-than-quarter-century-old institution at a hotel that has survived through its institutions. Regular Concord guests come to know Table C-8 as the clique of cliques, the mature version of the popular students in high school. Every summer, the members of C-8 meet for weekends here, sharing their three kosher meals a day in the same seating order. At the end of August, they always throw a birthday party for Patty Garcia, their waitress. On Labor Day, they inevitably spend the lunch before checkout hooting and hollering at the shenanigans of the past summer and talking about next year's.
But not this year.
"Next year? said Mr. Angel, C-8's unofficial leader, as competing conversations halted. "We don't know. We just don't know."
This was the last summer of the Concord Resort Hotel as its devotees have known it. The largest and most famous of the Catskill Mountain hotels, where the likes of Jerry Lewis, Woody Allen and Don Rickles paid their dues, is bankrupt, a sorry reminder of the declining fortunes of a resort area once known as the Jewish Riviera.
The family that has owned the Concord since it opened 61 years ago is reluctantly selling it to pay off more than $20 million in debts. The future of the hotel, the largest employer in Sullivan County, with 800 employees, is in limbo.
In three weeks, a Bankruptcy Court judge is expected to announce which of several prospective bidders can try to secure the financing to buy the hotel. One, Value Company, part of an investment group based in Manhattan, has been trying to find investors since January to remake the hotel into a first-class resort, and has an agreement with the Sheraton Corporation to make the hotel a franchise. Another applicant specializes in buying bankrupt hotels and converting them into condominiums. Touro College, with campuses in Nassau County and Israel, has expressed interest in converting at least part of the hotel into a campus.
Even if it remains a hotel, the Concord, one of only a handful of family-owned resorts left in the Catskills, will be different. The absurdly large dining hall, where guests have eaten all they can eat at the same time, much as in summer camp, will surely be gone. So will the kosher-only kitchen, and most likely, some of the employees, many of whom have worked here 30, 40, even 50 years.
Table C-8 and the other faithful guests who call the Concord a second home have known for years that they cannot keep the hotel alive by themselves. It has long become obvious that the guest list has been declining, and so has the hotel. The huge guest rooms, even those in the tower wing of the hotel, built 20 years ago, have worn carpets and faded wallpaper. The traditional guests, adults middle-aged and older who remember the good old days, have been unable to persuade their children and grandchildren to come here, only 90 miles from New York City, instead of to spiffier resorts on an ocean beach. Even on Labor Day weekend, the hotel, with 1,200 rooms, was only half full.
Still, the idea of the Concord's changing in any of its intimate ways -- the notion that the side lobby where the house orchestra performs big-band music might become just another place for potted palm trees or that the exercise classes by Gilda Marx, the art demonstrations by Morris Katz ("the world's fastest painter") and the noisy happiness of Table C-8 might become pressed memories for the scrapbook -- has given the resort the wistful air of a wake.
"I cry," said Irving Cohen, the maitre d'hotel, who has worked here for 55 years. For decades, Mr. Cohen, now 80, has carefully assigned the seating in the dining room to put single women next to single men, a sly talent that has led to more than 100 Concord marriages.
"I've been to more weddings and bar mitzvahs -- it's been a great time," Mr. Cohen said. (As guests stopped by his post in the front of the dining room to say goodbye, his round cheeks were pinched, patted and pecked more than a baby's.) "Now, with everything uncertain and all the employees worrying about their jobs, it's a very sad time," he added. "I think some of the employees are even more upset than the owners."
Robert Parker, one of the five brothers and sisters in their 40's and 50's who inherited the hotel from their parents and grandparents, was sitting just yards away. As chief executive of the hotel, he has not looked happy for a long time, even when joking with guests he has known his whole life. "It should be an interesting few months here," he said with a grimace that was trying to be a grin.
Employees don't blame the Parker family for the hotel's demise. They blame the people who abandoned the Catskills for Atlantic City or more exotic locales. Marilyn Gill, who gave up drug counseling to become a waitress here 26 years ago, compares the situation at the Concord to one at the Catskills hotel in the movie "Dirty Dancing," which she has seen 47 times.
"You know, how at the end of the movie, they talked about the end of an era, people wanting to take trips to Europe instead of driving to the mountains?" she said. "I think that's what happens."
But that film was set in 1963. The Concord held its own until the mid- to late 70's, during the recession.
"I just think people started thinking they could go abroad for the money they'd spend at a weekend here," Ms. Gill said. "But I don't think there's any place that gives you dollar value like the Concord. Three meals a day and all activities included?"
Ms. Gill was sitting in the dining room on a break with Pat Kislowski, who has worked here 15 years, and Eva Molnar, who has worked here for 32.
"There were times when people used to have to beg to have a day off," Ms. Molnar said. "Now, they wait by the phone."
"We all love the hotel," Ms. Kislowski said. "We're all like family." When an old porter who had been at the hotel 25 years developed prostate cancer, she said by way of example, the staff took care of him until his death, then chipped in to pay for a funeral service and a death notice. "It was sad that he had no family," Ms. Kislowski said. "But he had us."
In February, Ms. Gill said, the staff started a petition to get the Governor's help in keeping the hotel open. "We got 600 names," she said. "We wanted him to sit down and listen to us talk about what the Concord means to Sullivan County. He sent us back a form letter."
Some longtime guests refuse to believe that their Concord days may be over. Lenny Weissman of Manhattan, a regular at Table C-12, which was once known as the bachelors' table, said the hotel had been too much a part of his life for 26 years to see it end.
"I got separated in March of 1972, and believe it or not, they had an April in Paris singles weekend here the next month," he said. "That was the beginning for me. From '72 to '95, I got more phone numbers weekends here in the summer than I got for all the other 42 weeks of the year combined. Then I fell in love here."
His career as an Eligible Male ended when he met Judy Borzi. She happens to be the hotel's official matchmaker, but the match she made in this case was for herself. She and Mr. Weissman now live together.
"I've put together hundreds of couples," said Ms. Borzi, who also runs People Link, a traditional dating service in Manhattan. "Then my own vocation became self-fulfilling."
Of all the Concord's traditions, poker and matchmaking seem to inspire the most bragging. At least half a dozen guests claimed to be excellent at one or the other. Barbara and Bernie Schwartz of Queens, Table C-8 members, claim to have mastered both. "I play poker and Bernie has put hundreds of people together," Mrs. Schwartz said.
"There's a lot of lonely people," he said, "for whom this is their only social life." Including, he said, lowering his voice,"some people at this table."
But if the Concord closes, C-8 as a group will most likely survive. "We're all friends," said Joyce Zolna of Verona, N.J. "We see each other in the city. We're already planning a Halloween party."
And if the Concord reopens in another incarnation? "It will be a terrible shame if somebody buys this hotel and changes it," said Cynthia Rechtman, sitting next to Ms. Zolna.
"Though we have so much fun," Ms. Zolna said, "we'll probably come back next year if it's open."
"We'll come back here once," Mr. Angel said. "We'll see what's left and what's not."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Yields Plummet on Expectations of Rate Cut by Fed

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities leaped yesterday, sending the yields on 10-year notes and 30-year bonds down to levels not seen since 1967. The decline shows that investors are betting that the Federal Reserve will cut short-term interest rates, a move that could help stabilize stock markets here and abroad.
In a replay of the almost daily flight to the relative safety of the bond market, investors snapped up Treasury bonds and notes yesterday. The price of the of 30-year bond jumped 1 1/32 , to 104 21/32 , while the bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, dropped to 5.19 percent, from 5.26 percent on Wednesday. The yield has dropped almost half a percentage point since the end of July. 
 The yield on the 10-year note, which is a benchmark for home mortgage rates, fell to 4.77 percent, from 4.92 percent on Wednesday. Its yield has fallen almost three-quarters of a percentage point since the end of July.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said, "The U.S. Government bond market has become the beneficiary of virtually every market-related news event on the planet."
The fact that these yields and the yields on short-term maturities are well below the Fed's 5.5 percent target for short-term interest rates shows that investors are betting on the Fed to lower its target. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, made this bet even more attractive when he indicated last week that the central bank would consider a rate cut if the foreign drag on the United States economy worsened.
But the trade-off for such an easing is more inflationary pressure in the United States. And this is a factor, analysts said, the Fed officials will have to balance against the turmoil in the world's financial markets when deciding what action to take.
In the last year, a stronger American dollar, falling commodity prices and a sharp decline in the prices of imported goods have helped push key inflation indexes lower. These benefits have helped cushion the negative effect, mostly on American exports, from the Asian financial crisis that began in July 1997.
But a cut in interest rates by the Fed could lead to a weaker dollar, lifting the prices of imports.
In addition, a falling dollar would probably help push commodity prices higher by stimulating demand. Most commodities are priced in dollars, which means a falling dollar makes commodities cheaper for many countries, especially those in the developing world. It was such a decline in the last year that made commodity prices fall so sharply.
Yesterday, the Commodity Research Bureau/Bridge index of 17 commodities rose 1.06, to 202.59, and is up nearly 4 percent in the last two weeks. This recent surge has come as the dollar has slumped against the German mark and the Japanese yen. The dollar declined to 1.6843 marks yesterday from 1.7215 marks on Wednesday after earlier touching a 16-month low. The dollar has also fallen recently against the Canadian dollar, which was at record lows just two weeks ago. The weakness of the dollar, analysts say, is in anticipation of a cut by the Fed.
"An easing by the Fed would be unabashedly positive for the developing world," argued Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company. "But an easing is ambigious for the United States. You are reversing the Asia's-pain-is-the-U.S.'s-gain trade."
Robert V. DiClemente, the chief United States economist at Salomon Smith Barney, agrees with such an outlook. But he argued that the increased inflation that might result would be positive.
The alternative, he said, could be a worldwide recession set off by the spread of the economic crisis to Latin America. Such a recession would probably lead to a more dangerous decline in prices known as deflation.
The sharp drop in interest rates has helped offset the economic drag from the financial turmoil in Asia, Russia and Latin America. Thirty-year mortgage rates are below 7 percent and should go lower.
But the benefit of lower interest rates is not being spread to all consumers or companies, which means there is much more of a drag on American growth than the drop in Treasury yields indicates. Consumers still face much higher interest rates on credit cards and other types of borrowing. In addition, the decline in the borrowing rates for corporations has not fallen as sharply as Treasury yields. And the cost of borrowing for less creditworthy companies is rising.
The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it would not proceed immediately with a new bond issue, in part because yields on corporate bonds have become less attractive.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Recipe for Trouble: Falling Dominoes, Leadership Vacuum

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Washington has been so distracted by President Clinton's troubles, by the slow-motion collapse of the Russian Government and by the continuing meltdown of Asia that few here have had time to consider what could set off the next wave of economic turmoil.
But today Washington and Wall Street, two universes rarely in sync, got a taste of what may be coming. 
 The images of Kenneth Starr's boxes of evidence landing on Capitol Hill helped propel the United States markets to another big slide today, and the threat of impeachment proceedings against President Clinton only adds to the sense that the United States is no longer a haven against instability.
So it was telling that after a Cabinet meeting late this afternoon, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin appeared on NBC to underscore that the President is "intensely focused" on world economic events, even while he fights for political survival and apologizes for what Mr. Rubin termed "terrible mistakes."
Mr. Rubin made an oblique argument that keeping the President in his job was essential, saying this is "a time when the world has only one leader who understands these issues."
At the same time, however, the Asian crisis was landing full force in the Americas. Brazil's 15.82 percent market drop today, after days of frantic announcements intended to calm investors who were fleeing its currency, dissolved the few remaining hopes that Latin America would somehow stave off the economic contagion that began in the Pacific. Mexico's currency has declined to lows not seen since the 1995 peso crisis, reviving the fears of that first post-cold war dip into economic meltdown.
There is plenty of economic rationale behind the fear that a breach of the Latin wall could be far more devastating for American companies than the twin crises in Asia and Russia. American exports to Latin America are far greater than to Asia, and American banks are much more heavily exposed to a downturn there. But perhaps just as importantly, if economic turmoil engulfs the region, the contagion will be exploding just over the United States' southern border.
"It's a very scary combination of events," said John S. Wadsworth Jr., the chairman of Morgan Stanley Asia. "The classical solutions to contain the Asian crisis failed. Meanwhile, we have a series of political vacuums at a moment when the complexity of the world's economic and financial situation requires real leadership.
"There's no world central bank, no world equivalent of Alan Greenspan, at a moment when our main problems around the globe are financial. That only magnifies the trouble."
The closest institution that fits that global role is the International Monetary Fund. Until now, the Administration's bet was that the outbreak of new brush fires around the world would persuade Congress to put another $18 billion into the cash-pressed I.M.F., rather than risk being accused of partisan wrangling while world economies melt.
The strategy, though, is clearly failing: Today, the House Appropriations Committee refused to approve a donation larger than $3.4 billion, a step some in the Administration fear could doom hopes of replenishing the fund's coffers. Mr. Clinton, distracted to say the least, is in no position to lobby for more funds. The debate is not yet over -- the Senate approved full financing for the I.M.F. and its view could still prevail when the issue goes to a conference committee of the two houses -- but an aide to Mr. Rubin said today that the funds are "clearly in trouble."
It is always difficult, of course, to say what is spooking markets the most: the prospect of long, drawn-out impeachment hearings, or a recession in Latin America that would hurt corporate profits even further, or just a general nervousness that a remarkable period of world prosperity is grinding slowly to a halt.
But it would be a mistake to underestimate the impact of Mr. Clinton's troubles.
The markets never blinked when the 1994 elections created political gridlock, a Democrat in the White House and Republicans running Congress. In fact, they celebrated. Economies around the world were running on all cylinders, and the Wall Street view was that inaction in Washington could do more good than harm.
This is a very different time, however, and gridlock is a different phenomenon than a leadership vacuum. At moments of economic peril, what governments say, how quickly they react to plunging currencies or market crises, how fast they reassure investors that things are under control, take on new dimensions.
With the President viewed as crippled, at best, that leadership role falls almost entirely to Mr. Rubin and to Mr. Greenspan. If the markets decide that that their joint efforts to convince Congress to finance the I.M.F. are doomed to failure, they may also determine that the United States is in no position to back up its calming words with cash.
"The worry is that we create a vicious circle," one Administration official said today. "All the impeachment hysteria has to affect the market. And as the U.S. market drops, it fuels the drops around the world -- even though they may have other causes. You get into this vicious circle."
The comparisons with 1974, when the House Judiciary Committee was voting out impeachment articles against President Richard M. Nixon, are not very helpful. Markets then were a lot less global. Moreover, the fundamentals of the American economy were weak, hurt by inflation and oil embargoes and huge military spending on the cold war.
Nonetheless, the markets dropped about 25 percent that summer, and kept falling even after the President had resigned.
This time things are likely to be different. The market has already dropped, for reasons that have little to do with Mr. Clinton's fortunes. And what happens in Latin America, or Japan, or Russia will undoubtedly loom far larger in today's markets than events in those countries would have in 1974.
But as one member of Mr. Clinton's economic team put it today: "This would be a hard enough international crisis to handle in normal times. And there is nothing normal about what's going on here now."

HEADLINE: COMPROMISE IN MOSCOW: THE NOMINEE;
Foreign Policy Expert With Little Economics

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 10

 BODY:
In selecting Yevgeny M. Primakov for Prime Minister, President Boris N. Yeltsin has picked a wily diplomat and steely opponent of American dominance.
There is no question that the choice of Mr. Primakov, a foreign policy strategist and former intelligence chief, is a popular one for the Communist opposition and for Russians who miss the stability of Soviet times. 
 What Mr. Primakov has not done, however, is grapple with the task of advancing market reforms in a country shaped by seven decades of Communist rule.
His few pronouncements on economics have been vague musings about the need to use the power of the state to strengthen ailing industries, and complaints about the International Monetary Fund.
By all accounts, his success will depend heavily on the aides who are entrusted with economic policy. And as Russia's new Government begins to take shape, it is looking more like a disparate coalition of Communists, social democrats and market reformers than a coherent team.
"Primakov is not a Communist," said Mikhail Berger, an economic specialist and editor of the newspaper Sevodnya. "He is not red. But he is a bit pink."
Mr. Primakov, 68, grew up in the Soviet Union's lost empire. He was born in Kiev, now the capital of Ukraine, and raised in Tbilisi, Georgia. Of Jewish heritage, he adopted the family name of his stepfather in a concession to the anti-Semitism of Soviet times.
He graduated from the Institute of Oriental Studies in Moscow and became a Pravda correspondent in the Middle East, a profession often linked to intelligence gathering.
When Mikhail S. Gorbachev led the Soviet Union, Mr. Primakov was on the liberal end of the Soviet orthodoxy, but hardly a bold reformer. He ran the Institute of World Economy and International Relations, a leading Soviet research institute, before becoming a Politburo member and Gorbachev aide.
He stepped onto the world stage when he sought to block American military action to reverse the 1990 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. In a feverish round of shuttle diplomacy, he tried to negotiate a compromise to give Saddam Hussein a face-saving way out.
That did not endear Mr. Primakov to the Americans, but it did him no harm at home. Mr. Gorbachev later made him head of the Foreign Intelligence Service, one of the successors of the K.G.B. He was the highest-ranking official to keep his job after the collapse of the Soviet state, a sign of his bureaucratic survival skills.
Mr. Primakov used his intelligence post to weigh in on foreign policy, issuing reports that assailed Washington for trying to take advantage of a weakened Russia.
Those are increasingly popular views in Russia. And when President Yeltsin ran for re-election in 1996, he sought to appeal to nationalist sentiment by making Mr. Primakov his Foreign Minister.
"Primakov represents today's paradigm," said Aleksandr Oslon, one of Russia's most highly regarded pollsters. "He is a conservative. He is wily and without youthful zeal. That corresponds to the popular mood that Russia is not strong, that no one wants to help us and that we need to be wiley."
With Russia's economy in ruins, Russia's diplomats have had limited room for maneuver. A pragmatist, Mr. Primakov has developed a working relationship with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright.
But he has also challenged American dominance in a way that stops just short of confrontation. He has fought relentlessly against NATO expansion. He has frustrated tough action to quell the fighting in Kosovo. He has backed the sale of Russian antiaircraft missiles to the Greek Cypriot Government, a move Washington worries could lead to a war between Greece and Turkey, two NATO members.
"Primakov wants to fix Russia's position as a great power," said Igor Golemiovsky, the editor of the newspaper Novaya Izvestia. "His position is that everyone should have to take account of the new Russia."
With Russians lining up to retrieve their savings from insolvent banks and the value of the ruble changing by the hour, the new Russia does not look much like a great power.
Sergei V. Kiriyenko, the Prime Minister who was ousted last month, was touted as a technocrat who put politics aside to focus on economics. Mr. Primakov is the reverse. He was praised today as a savvy leader who would nurture political ties with the Communists and pro-market forces while leaving the nitty-gritty of economic policy to others.
It is not clear, however, how he would rescue Russia. His economic philosophy, to the extent he has defined it, is a vague melding of capitalist and socialist themes.
In a speech at the Royal Institute of International Affairs in London in June, Mr. Primakov said there was no danger that Russia would return to its Communist past. But he went on to criticize the I.M.F. while endorsing the use of credits to help Russia's stricken industry as part of some sort of Russian version of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal.
"We did not pay enough attention to economic growth because we were focused on macroeconomic financial stability at the request of the I.M.F.," he said. "We can learn from the United States. During the process of recovery from the Great Depression, Roosevelt took some state measures, tax measures that benefited the development of industry."
Those slogans have soothed the left-wing opposition. But just what they would mean in practice and who would define them is unclear.
Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the leader of the liberal Yabloko Party, who called for Mr. Primakov's selection, is a leading candidate for a high economic post. Mr. Yavlinsky's party resembles the social democratic parties of Western Europe, and he has been skeptical of the tough "currency board" plan the Kremlin promoted last week to establish a fixed rate for the ruble.
But he is just one of the politicians who are likely to find a place on in the Primakov coalition. Yuri D. Maslyukov, a Communist member of Parliament and the former head of the Soviet economic planning agency, is likely to become a first deputy prime minister.
Viktor V. Gerashchenko, the head of the central bank from 1992 to 1994, whose "loose money" policies help foster the ruble's plunge, may even be restored to that post, Mr. Yeltsin's spokesman said.
That appointment would not sit well with Boris G. Fyodorov, a pro-capitalist Kremlin aide who has ties to Mr. Primakov. He worked for him during Soviet times when Mr. Primakov led the world economic institute.
Unlike Mr. Yavlinsky, Mr. Fyodorov is a ardent champion of currency controls. And his views of Mr. Gerashchenko are clear. Mr. Fyodorov once wrote a dictionary of economic terms in which he described Mr. Gerashchenko as the "worst central banker in the world."

HEADLINE: Soaring Costs Delay Building of Federal Courthouse

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Ever-rising construction costs, driven by the resumption of large-scale development in New York City, have delayed and may fundamentally alter plans for a new 18-story Federal courthouse in downtown Brooklyn.
The courthouse, planned at Cadman Plaza East and Tillary Street, has already been designed. The General Services Administration received construction bids earlier this year, but allowed them to lapse last month without designating a contractor. 
 "The construction market in New York is booming, and that is having the effect of producing bids that are over budget on the courthouse," said Thomas J. Ryan, the newly designated regional administrator of the General Services Administration for the New York area.
The $194 million cost estimate was prepared in 1994, and the money was appropriated by Congress in 1996. The bids were due in February 1998.
"By the time we went to find a contractor, we were already several years past the market that had formed the basis of the building's cost estimate," said Chief Judge Charles P. Sifton of the Federal Court for the Eastern District of New York, which includes Brooklyn.
Judge Sifton and his colleague Judge Raymond J. Dearie, both of whom have been involved in the project, said the difference between the lowest bid and the budgeted amount rose from $5 million earlier this year to $20 million by the end of summer.
Mr. Ryan said the interval between the estimate and the bidding "was not unusually long, and in many areas of the country would have been inconsequential."
But construction prices have soared in New York in recent years. And a booming industry offers an unwelcome flip side to government agencies, which have been known to take advantage of recessions for their construction projects, because that is when contractors in search of work scramble to lower their prices.
Barring a return to Congress for more money -- a request that no agency likes to make -- Mr. Ryan said the General Services Administration hoped to scale back the Brooklyn courthouse to fit the existing budget and then send it out for bids again.
"It's not an easy thing to come up with additional millions of dollars for a project like this," Mr. Ryan said. "Our attempt right now is to work with the judges to see if there are changes that could be made which would allow the project to go forward under the present budget without compromising the quality of the design."
Some economies the Government might consider are building courtrooms that would be shared by more than one judge; housing some court employees in the old Post Office and Courthouse nearby, which is to be renovated, and replacing some of the limestone facade with a less expensive material.
"We all have the same goal," Mr. Ryan said. "To build a quality courthouse as soon as we can."
But Judge Sifton and Judge Dearie say they oppose any alteration of the original design. "The bottom line is that we need this project," Judge Sifton said. "There is no 'give' in this project. When they did consider cutting back, it was things like the public cafeteria. On a snowy winter day, you can't say to jurors, 'Go over to a crowded diner on Montague Street for lunch.' "
Judge Sifton said 15 judges now share 10 courtrooms in the existing Federal courthouse on Cadman Plaza East, built in 1962, and three more judges may be added to the district.
"Congress will give us the people to do the work, but we won't have a place to put them," he said.
Judge Sifton said the General Services Administration "bungled the bidding process" when it took seven weeks earlier this year to study ways to reduce costs on the project at just the time when construction prices were escalating.
Mr. Ryan declined to discuss the specifics of the bidding process.
As designed by Cesar Pelli & Associates and H L W International, the new courthouse would have a six-story base covering almost the entire site bounded by Cadman Plaza East, Tillary Street and Adams Street. It was on this empty lot that the four-story Emmanuel Celler Federal Building, which contained offices and courtrooms, stood until recently.
From this base, a bow-shaped tower, clad in limestone and glass, would rise an additional 12 stories, to a height of 300 feet. The new building would be joined to the existing courthouse by a pavilion with terraced balconies and an atrium, behind a cylinder of glass six stories high.

HEADLINE: COMPROMISE IN MOSCOW: IN WASHINGTON;
Primakov Well Known and Respected by U.S.

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today welcomed the nomination of Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov as Russia's next Prime Minister, with officials describing him as a sure-footed survivor whose appointment could help defuse a political and economic crisis that had threatened to bring down President Boris N. Yeltsin.
"Obviously the United States knows and respects the Foreign Minister, Primakov," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman. "We've worked closely with him. If ratified by the Duma, we would expect to have a good and close working relationship with Prime Minister Primakov." 
 Although Mr. Primakov has often worked at cross purposes with the United States, notably concerning the Balkans and the Middle East, Administration officials said they found him a reliable partner on other issues. He helped negotiate the agreement that resulted last year in Moscow's acquiescence to an expansion of the NATO alliance eastward.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright phoned congratulations to Mr. Primakov. "They had a very warm and friendly discussion," said James P. Rubin, her spokesman. "Prime Minister-designate Primakov is well known to Secretary Albright and many of us at the department, and he enjoys consideration respect."
Senior Administration officials said that while there was concern here over Mr. Primakov's lack of experience in economic policy, there was relief over the prospect that his nomination might restore stability to the Russian Government.
"Primakov is a known commodity to Washington, a familiar face who inspires confidence," a White House official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "And I'm sure he understands that in the midst of the economic crisis, he'll need to find advisers who have the background in economics and finance that he lacks."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: MARKET PLACE;
A Manic-Depressive Market Befuddles Even the Professionals

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
Investors in the stock market have to be ready for ups and downs. Everybody knows that. But who was prepared for the market's manic-depressive mood swings of the last few weeks? And what do the increasingly violent moves in stocks mean for the market over all?
Investors who thought that Tuesday's stunning surge was the end of the market's late-summer troubles quickly learned otherwise when the Dow Jones industrial average fell 155.76 points on Wednesday. The market continued to cave in yesterday as the Dow fell 249.48 points, or 3.17 percent, to 7,615.54. In the last two days, investors have given up more than they made during Tuesday's record 380-point rise. 
 These are wide swings. But they are not as wide as the gaps in recent weeks between the high and the low each day in the market averages. In two out of three trading days this week, the Dow traded in a range greater than 300 points. Yesterday's range of 338.57 points amounted to 4.3 percent of the gauge's value. And the swings in markets overseas have been even greater.
Moodiness like this used to be an occasional thing in American stocks. Now, going from euphoria to depression is de rigueur. The trouble is, these market gyrations have consequences: they are highly distressing to investors' psyches and exceedingly costly to their portfolios. Extreme volatility in share prices, what investors have been experiencing since stocks peaked in July, makes investing in stocks feel like shooting craps.
Of course, with the Dow around 7,600, it takes a bigger move in points to register a meaningful percentage gain or loss. Nobody expects the market at these levels to move up or down a mere 25 points or so.
But the percentage moves of 4 percent or more that have whipsawed investors recently make the market seem more unstable. And these moves are not limited to the indexes. Consider what happened yesterday to shares of Yahoo, which closed at $79.875. Its high was $80.50; its low $73. That $7.50 range is 9.3 percent of the stock's high.
Internet stocks are volatile, of course, so consider Merrill Lynch & Company. Trading in that stock yesterday had a range of 7.8 percent, from a high of $55.875 to a low of $51.50. The stock closed the day at $55.50.
These are not isolated examples. Neither was their volatility the result of any significant announcement. Many other stocks trade in exceedingly wide ranges, as do the main indexes.
Indeed, in just the last month, almost one trading day in three involved an unusually wide trading range, said Fane Lozman, the chairman of Scanshift, a creator of market display software in Chicago. During the 23 trading days going back to Aug. 10, Mr. Lozman studied the intraday range for the Standard & Poor's 500 September futures contracts, which institutional investors use to trade the market without buying all 500 stocks. He found that on seven occasions, the range for the futures during a day's trading was one and a half times greater than the mean range had been during the previous 30 days. On three occasions, the range was twice as great as it had been previously.
"We are in a new market era of volatility that people have to get used to," Mr. Lozman said. "The average person likes to see a nice steady increase in stock prices. But the speed with which this market goes from one price level to another price level is incredible."
It is also expensive, at least for individual investors. Professional traders like wide swings in stocks because they can make big profits on even the tiniest move in the large blocks of shares that they trade. But for smaller investors, volatility makes getting in and out of stocks costly. Think of the person who sold Citicorp yesterday at its low of $83.50, only to see it close at $88.25. Or the investor who bought Exxon at $70.6875, only to see it close a dollar lower.
What's to explain the market's bungee jumps? One broker, who has seen all kinds of markets over 36 years, thinks that extreme volatility signals a true bear market. "It shows a lack of confidence on the part of professionals, a danger of being long stocks overnight," this broker said. Because his firm does not allow its employees to speak on the record to reporters, he spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Volatility rises during down moves in stocks because shares tend to fall faster than they rise, as evidenced by the fact that bear markets typically end much more quickly than bull markets do. When intense selling starts, specialists and market makers drop their bid prices quickly, looking for the levels where value investors will enter. As a result, wild swings in stocks signal a pitched battle between the short-term investors who are bearish and the longer-term players who are bulls.
Brokers are mixed on what investors should do to protect themselves from the high costs of trading in volatile markets. Some advise investors looking to get into stocks to use only limit orders, which specify a price the investor is willing to pay for the shares. Market orders, in which an investor pays the prevailing market price, are more common and used to buy or sell a stock at any price. But in times of volatility, market orders can be a good way to overpay to buy stocks.
Other brokers advise investors to simply sit out the rough-and-tumble trading days. These people say that on those occasions, the market is simply trying to find a level and that all the churning in stocks makes it impossible to buy with confidence. One adviser said that in the last six weeks he had wound up paying on average 5 percent more than he wanted on market orders. When markets were calmer, he would have no trouble getting shares at the price he had seen on his screen when he placed the order.
Regardless of what investors do to combat the effects of volatility in stocks, they should brace themselves for more yo-yo moves. The swings are unsettling, and nobody is sure whether it means the market is nearer a bottom or just starting a decline. Here's a tiny bit of consolation for individuals: volatility like this even scares the professionals.
