HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE POLLS;
Allies Cling To Results Of Surveys

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Pointing to a diagram showing that most Americans think the country is on "the right track," Mark Penn, the President's pollster, sought today to reassure gathered Democratic donors by inundating them with survey data.
"If you were coming from another planet and didn't read the newspaper," Mr. Penn said, "you would think the Democrats were in an absolutely tremendous position." 
 In fact, as the Lewinsky scandal envelops President Clinton, his advisers and supporters cling to their own polls and public surveys showing that the President's job approval rating remains impressive and that there are no statistical indications that Democratic candidates are being dragged down.
But surveys released today by CBS News and ABC News offered hints that, though far from definitive, Mr. Clinton's support might be softening -- and that there is increased public concern about the scandal.
Even so, Mr. Penn and Democratic Party officials emphasized the mostly encouraging poll results in their addresses at a conference here of the Democratic Business Council, a group of the party's donors from business and labor, as evidence that on Election Day the party could survive the Lewinsky scandal.
After citing his own surveys showing that there "is absolutely no evidence" that Mr. Clinton's general support was slipping, Mr. Penn said that this week he had contacted several other Democratic pollsters, asking whether they had detected an erosion in support for the party. He said they had not.
"The President is not on the ticket -- that issue is not on the ticket," said Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, general chairman of the Democratic Party. "Is this going to dampen Democrats coming out to vote? Not on your life."
Thus far, most polls show that Mr. Clinton's job approval ratings remain steady. In the CBS News survey, his rating stands at 59 percent, the first time it has slipped below 60 percent since the Lewinsky debacle unfolded in January. In August, Mr. Clinton's job approval was 65 percent. Still, the shift is barely significant, statistically, because the margin of sampling error in the poll is plus or minus four percentage points. In addition, even a 59 percent rating is impressive because many pollsters argue that anything over 50 percent is comfortable.
Kathleen A. Frankovic, director of surveys at CBS News, described the job approval numbers as a "mild weakening" in Mr. Clinton's support.
The CBS survey of 738 adults nationwide, conducted on Tuesday and Wednesday nights, found that 36 percent of the respondents thought Mr. Clinton had less honesty and integrity than most people in public life, a slight increase from August. And 71 percent said the scandal would have a serious effect on Mr. Clinton's Administration over the next two years, an 11-point increase since August.
Yet the poll found that people still trusted Mr. Clinton as a leader. Sixty-three percent said he had strong qualities of leadership; 73 percent approved of his handling of the economy and 62 percent approved of his handling of foreign policy.
The survey by ABC News, conducted on Wednesday night, also found slight signs of erosion in Mr. Clinton's job approval rating, which stood at 57 percent, down from 66 percent in August.
But as in the CBS News survey, people seem to separate the President's personal conduct from his job performance. While 28 percent said they trusted Mr. Clinton on a personal level, 58 percent said they trusted him to handle the nation's business. The poll of 509 adults nationwide has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 5 percentage points.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Interest Rates Slide As Stock Prices Tumble
The prices of Treasury securities jumped, sending the yields on 10-year notes and 30-year bonds down to levels not seen since 1967. The yield of the 30-year bond dropped to 5.19 percent, from 5.26 percent on Wednesday. The decline shows that investors are betting that the Federal Reserve will cut short-term interest rates, a move that could help stabilize stock markets here and abroad. 
But the decline in stocks continued to accelerate. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 249.48 points, or 3.17 percent. The Dow is down 18.4 percent since its July 17 peak. Stocks skidded even more sharply in Europe and Latin America. Page C6.
 
Northwest Airlines Accord Reached
Negotiators for Northwest Airlines and its pilots' union reached a tentative agreement to settle their bitter labor dispute, but the accord stopped short of immediately ending the 13-day strike that has disrupted travel in the Midwest and South because the union still has to decide whether to accept it. A1.
 
Mexican Bank Fails to Prop Up Peso
Panic selling swept the Mexican stock exchange, where the chief market index plunged 9.82 percent. The Mexican central bank waded into currency markets selling nearly $500 million in dollars and tightening cash in circulation in an unsuccessful effort to support the peso. C4.
 
The Ruble's Wild Ride
The Russian ruble, after falling to 5 cents to the dollar in recent days, shot back up to 9 cents, so Russians who had bought dollars as a safe haven discovered that they were worth far less. A8.
 
Chip Makers' Brighter Outlooks
Shares of National Semiconductor fell 3.38 percent after the company reported a loss that fell slightly below analysts' estimates. But National Semiconductor executives said that orders had begun to pick up in August and that the next quarter's results could be stronger. Another upbeat assessment came from Intel, which predicted that its third-quarter sales would be 8 to 10 percent higher than the second quarter's. C2.
 
Trade Deficit Climbed in 2d Quarter
The nation's trade deficit in goods, services and investments widened to a record $56.525 billion in the second quarter. C2.
 
Venator-Sports Authority Deal Off
Venator Group and Sports Authority canceled their planned merger because the stock of Venator, formerly Woolworth, has dropped 61 percent since the plans were made in May -- cutting the value of the deal to about $398.5 million in stock and assumed debt, from more than $761 million. C2.
 
S.E.C. Fines Discount Broker
Olde Discount, a brokerage firm, and three of its executives, including its founder and chairman, agreed to pay $7 million in fines to settle S.E.C. accusations of fraudulent sales practices and use of misleading advertising and promotional literature. C2.
 
VW Plans Slave Labor Fund
Volkswagen A.G. plans to announce today that it will create a $12 million fund to compensate surviving former slave laborers. The move comes at a time when American lawyers have filed class-action suits over slave labor against Volkswagen and many other German industrial companies for their use of slave labor during World War II. A10.

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE CLERGY;
Clinton Should Resign, 2 Religious Leaders Say

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR

 BODY:
In a sign that President Clinton's approval among clergy members is eroding in the wake of the Monica Lewinsky scandal, two leading religious figures in New York -- one Protestant and one Jewish -- said in interviews yesterday that Mr. Clinton had lost his moral authority and ought to resign.
The comments -- by Ismar Schorsch, chancellor of Jewish Theological Seminary, and Bishop Richard F. Grein of the New York Episcopal Diocese -- came the day before dozens of clergy members are to attend a breakfast with Mr. Clinton in Washington, a gathering that has become a regular, late summer event at the White House. 
 Dr. Schorsch, a leading figure within Judaism's Conservative movement, said he did not think Mr. Clinton's moral authority had been eroded, but rather "destroyed" as a result of the scandal.
The chancellor, who described himself as a former "great admirer" of Mr. Clinton, said he came to believe the President should step downwhen Mr. Clinton went on national television on Aug. 17 to acknowledge he had had an inappropriate relationship with Ms. Lewinsky, a former White House intern.
In a separate interview, a similar opinion about the President was expressed by Bishop Grein, whose position in New York makes him a senior bishop in the Episcopal Church.
"I think his moral presence in the country has been undercut so badly that he can't lead," he said.
Like Dr. Schorsch, Bishop Grein said he reached that conclusion about the time of Mr. Clinton's television speech.
"Once you're caught in a lie, you're a dead duck," the bishop said. "And it was just about then that I thought, he's got to step down."
The remarks by Dr. Schorsch and Bishop Grein are unusual on two counts. Since the scandal broke last January, many clergy members have taken a cautious approach, urging prayer and restraint in judgment. Those who have called for Mr. Clinton's resignation have often been religious conservatives, a group critical of the President for liberal stands on social policy issues.
Earlier this week, Paige Patterson, president of the Southern Baptist Convention, called on Mr. Clinton to step down at once. Mr. Patterson repeated that position in an interview yesterday but said he did so out of concern for Mr. Clinton, so he would not have to face public exposure from the findings in the investigation by the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr.
"He needs to be alone with God, rebuilding his life and moral commitment and his family," Mr. Patterson said.
Although Mr. Clinton is a Southern Baptist, he and Mr. Patterson come from different wings of the denomination, which has been controlled by theological conservatives since the 1980's.
Neither Dr. Schorsch nor Bishop Grein was among those invited to Friday's White House breakfast. A White House spokeswoman said that "a core group" of religious leaders was invited annually to the breakfasts, and that the White House tried to include others each year.
Dr. Schorsch said he attended a similar event in 1993 and heard the President declare the need for religious tolerance in a pluralistic society. "I was very impressed," he said.
Mr. Clinton has become known for the fluency of his religious language and his willingness to engage in discussions with clergy members, as individuals and in groups.
One nationally prominent minister who will attend Friday's breakfast, the Rev. Joan Brown Campbell, general secretary of the National Council of Churches, said she was not prepared to call for Mr. Clinton's resignation.
"That is a rush to judgment that I am not prepared to make," Ms. Campbell said.
But she added, "The nation has to be clear that when people do sinful acts -- which we all do -- there have to be consequences."
She said she thought that a censure by Congress of Mr. Clinton "might be necessary" for the country to feel it was moving ahead.
Paraphrasing Archbishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa, Ms. Campbell said that without forgiveness, there could be no healing. But for there to be forgiveness, she said, "being repentant is essential."
Dr. Schorsch and Bishop Grein said they had shared their feelings about Mr. Clinton with few others.
"I've not talked a lot about it because I'm so depressed," Dr. Schorsch said. Bishop Grein said he felt bad for the President, the nation "and for everyone else."
Another Episcopal prelate in New York, Bishop Mark S. Sisk, who was recently elected to succeed Bishop Grein when the latter chooses to retire, said he did not think Mr. Clinton should resign because it would be "a risky" time to change leaders while the world seemed unstable, with the crisis in Russia and a recession in Asia.
One religious leader who has declined to comment is John Cardinal O'Connor, Catholic Archbishop of New York. Writing in the archdiocesan newspaper, Catholic New York, last week, he said, "Do I advance the salvation of souls by publicizing my own speculation or by offering my own verdict? I don't think so."
Cardinal O'Connor wrote that he was "very, very busy praying" for the Clintons, for those in Congress who would judge the President and for the nation, "which, in my judgment, is more deeply in need of prayer than at any point during my 78 years as a citizen."

HEADLINE: Northwest and Pilots Union Gain Tentative Accord in Labor Fight

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

 BODY:
Negotiators for Northwest Airlines and its pilots union reached a tentative agreement yesterday to settle a 13-day strike that has disrupted travel in the Midwest and South.
On a day when most of the focus in Washington was on the political difficulties facing President Clinton, he announced the breakthrough personally in an evening statement to reporters on the White House lawn. 
 "I think the strike is over," he said.
Flanked by his wife, Hillary, and Transportation Secretary Rodney E. Slater, Mr. Clinton praised the leaders at Northwest and the Air Line Pilots Association and thanked the members of his Administration, including Bruce Lindsey, the White House deputy counsel who was instrumental in bringing about the settlement.
"I know there are a lot of people who depend on Northwest who are relieved tonight," Mr. Clinton said.
But Northwest would not begin flying again until the union has accepted the pact. In a statement released after the President's comments, the pilots union said its 17-member governing master executive council would meet in Minneapolis on Saturday to decide whether to approve the agreement. Until then, the pilots will remain on strike, it added. The airline has said it will take 8 to 10 days after the pilots agree to return to work before the airline can resume its full schedule.
Northwest and the union said they would not release details of the tentative agreement until the pilots' executive council took action on it.
The Northwest pilots strike has been the longest against an airline since 1989, when machinists shut down Eastern Airlines. All of Northwest's nearly 1,700 flights have been grounded, sharply reducing air travel in Northwest's hub airports in Detroit, Minneapolis and Memphis and the surrounding regions, where the airline was dominant.
One of the hardest hit states has been North Dakota, which depends on Northwest for virtually all of its air service. But in cities like Detroit and Minneapolis, the disruption from the strike was less than many people had expected. Other airlines added flights to the cities, businesses made other arrangements, and people simply stayed home.
The lack of disruption undermined dire predictions by Northwest before the strike as it tried to put pressure on Mr. Clinton to use his executive powers to order the pilots back to work, as he did last year when pilots struck at American Airlines.
"What has happened is that passengers have found it easier to book elsewhere," said Robert E. Litan, the director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution who was hired by Northwest to assess the economic damage of a strike.
Mr. Litan's study said the damage would equal $737 million in the strike's first 10 days. But this week he said his revised estimate was about two-thirds of his original forecast with more than half coming from the fact that Northwest ceased operations and laid off 30,000 of its 51,000 workers.
The pilots walked out on Aug. 29 after two years of negotiations. The main issues in the dispute were pay and job security. The pilots wanted a substantial raise to make up for wage concessions they made in 1993 that helped Northwest avoid bankruptcy. They were also concerned that Northwest would shift their workload to smaller commuter jets flown by pilots who are paid less.
The airline said that it was willing to give the pilots a raise but that it could not afford to pay them more than their counterparts at other major airlines. The union says the pilots receive an average salary of $120,000 a year; the company puts that figure at $133,000.
But behind those apparently narrow differences were years of simmering resentment on both sides. The pilots accused Northwest of dragging its feet while the airline racked up record profits and its top executives cashed in stock options worth millions. The company said a group of radical leaders at the pilots union had been spoiling for a strike since early 1996.
The hard feelings had prevented the sides from returning to the table. Mr. Slater called John H. Dasburg, Northwest's chief executive, and J. Randolph Babbitt, president of the Air Line Pilots Association, to a meeting in Washington last week to see whether there were areas of compromise. Negotiators for both sides met separately in Chicago last weekend with Federal mediators.
But it was not until Mr. Lindsey flew to Minneapolis with Mr. Slater on Tuesday afternoon that negotiations began again in earnest, said those involved in the discussions. By late Wednesday night, after a long day of bargaining, the pilots had a made a compromise offer and the company had responded. A deal seemed within reach.
Yesterday morning, Mr. Lindsey was at the airport preparing to leave when he received a call from the White House. The pilots union was asking for him to return to the talks to help hammer out a settlement. The White House was already signaling that if there was no settlement, the President would order the pilots back to work. By afternoon, the two sides had a deal.
Mr. Clinton then called Mr. Dasburg and Mr. Babbitt to urge both men to wrap up the negotiations as soon as possible, an Administration official said.
One person involved in the negotiations who insisted on anonymity said the pilots had relaxed their wage demands and agreed instead to incentives like stock options.
Whether the union leaders will approve the the deal is an open question. Over the summer, Northwest reached an accord with negotiators for the International Association of Machinists, which represents 27,000 workers, but members voted down the contract in July.
Even if the pilot leaders approve the new contract, the damage to the airline has already been substantial.
Wall Street analysts estimate that Northwest has lost $250 million to $300 million and that it is likely to lose more as it begins fare discounts and other promotions to draw back passengers. The carrier's stock price has fallen more than 60 percent since spring, largely because of the strike.
The pilots have lost the wages they would have earned from flying and have weakened a company in a business in which which profits and growth provide them with the best job security and opportunities to increase their earnings.

HEADLINE: Gov. Weld's Successor in Massachusetts Battles for Own Term

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Funny. Bill Weld made it look so easy.
But as his successor in the governor's corner office on Beacon Hill is finding out, running as a Republican in Democrat-packed Massachusetts is no serene stroll through the fall foliage. 
 Argeo Paul Cellucci, the longtime Lieutenant Governor who took over when the restless Mr. Weld cut short his second term to seek the ambassadorship to Mexico last year, is widely seen as one of the more vulnerable of the incumbents in the 36 races for governor this fall.
The Cook Political Report, a non-partisan political analysis, this summer put Massachusetts among just four states -- the others being Alabama, New Mexico and Rhode Island -- where Republican Governors face races considered tossups.
Political analysts say Mr. Cellucci's tough slogging is not all his fault. Among Massachusetts voters, 48 percent are register as independents, 39 percent as Democrats and just 13 percent as Republicans.
"So right away, the Republicans are at a big disadvantage, and have to get those independents who can go either way," said Gerry Chervinsky, president of KRC Communications Research and the pollster for WBZ-TV and The Boston Globe. "So Cellucci has to be vulnerable; he's an incumbent Republican in a heavily Democratic state."
But that is just one of the reasons Mr. Cellucci (pronounced se-LOO-chee) is struggling.
First, what should have been a light warmup fight, his contest for the Republican nomination in the primary on Tuesday against State Treasurer Joseph D. Malone, has turned into a punishing and decidedly nasty bout. Mr. Malone has been attacking Mr. Cellucci on everything from his personal debt, reported to be about $700,000, to his ethics.
"He has a credit-card mentality," Mr. Malone has said.
Mr. Cellucci says that his assets exceed his liabilities, and that the debt arose in the course of rearing children.
In the last week, as the fight has intensified to the point that state Republican leaders rebuked Mr. Malone for engaging in "gutter politics," the news media have focused on who leaked -- and possibly illegally obtained -- a report on Mr. Cellucci's personal finances. Though its source remains undisclosed, political Poirots figure that the Malone campaign's fingerprints are all over it.
Mr. Cellucci's campaign has been fighting back by accusing Mr. Malone of dirty tricks and attack-dog tactics -- as well as asserting that Mr. Malone has ethical violations of his own -- while depicting the acting Governor as a positive force in the state who has helped cut taxes by $1 billion and sought to improve education.
In fact, pollsters say, Mr. Malone's political assaults thus far may not have taken much of a toll on Mr. Cellucci, and appear instead to have boomeranged on Mr. Malone. A Boston Herald poll published on Wednesday found that 54 percent of likely Republican voters supported Mr. Cellucci compared with 25 percent for Mr. Malone; two weeks earlier, Mr. Cellucci had the support of 50 percent and Mr. Malone 32 percent.
But analysts say those are not the numbers Mr. Cellucci needs to worry about: the real challenge will come from his Democratic opponent.
The front-runner for that role is Scott Harshbarger, the State Attorney General who started his campaign so many months ago -- long before the official announcement in April -- that he seems to have been running for years.
Back last year when Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d still intended to run for governor, Mr. Harshbarger's candidacy looked pale in comparison. But in the wake of the skiing death of Michael Kennedy, his brother, Mr. Kennedy announced that he was dropping out of politics for now. And lately, though Mr. Harshbarger won only a narrow endorsement from his party at the convention in June, polls show the campaign picking up steam.
In debates with his two Democratic rivals, former State Senator Patricia McGovern and former United States Representative Brian Donnelly, Mr. Harshbarger has clearly been concerned more with attacking Mr. Cellucci's record than with his Democratic colleagues -- to the point that Ms. McGovern has begged him to keep Mr. Cellucci's name out of their debates.
Mr. Harshbarger's platform has emphasized his record as Attorney General in fighting the tobacco companies and enforcing environmental laws; he has also promised increased financing and deeper reform for education.
His poll numbers are looking rosy. A Boston Globe-WBZ-TV poll published on Sept. 1 found that 74 percent of Democrats viewed Mr. Harshbarger favorably, compared with the 63 percent of the much less numerous Republican voters who said they viewed Mr. Cellucci favorably.
The strong economic times would seem to favor an incumbent, and despite the state's Democratic leanings, Massachusetts voters have repeatedly forsaken their partisan tastes for Republican governors in the past.
But in a way, analysts say, Mr. Cellucci may suffer from an awkward situation in which his incumbency has been so brief that it leaves him open to attacks on his record while not allowing him to reap its fruits.
"To me," said Tubby Harrison, a Democratic pollster who has done some work for Ms. McGovern in this race, "it's a question of that he hasn't yet proved he's a governor -- he just inherited the Weld mantle."
Of course, Mr. Harshbarger has never been governor. In addition, analysts say he will need to overcome a tricky legacy of his own: voters' association of Democratic candidates with the former liberal Democratic Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, who presided over the state in its last economic downturn.
"They like Harshbarger a little better," Mr. Chervinsky said, "but he still has to convince people he's not another Dukakis."

HEADLINE: The Top Spot at Ford Is Returning to a Ford

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 11

 BODY:
One of the most storied families in American business reasserted its control over the world's second-largest company today as William Clay Ford Jr., a great-grandson of Henry Ford, was named the next chairman of the Ford Motor Company.
Ford's current chairman, chief executive and president, Alexander Trotman, who is 65, announced that he would retire at the end of December, a year earlier than expected. Mr. Ford, the 41-year-old chairman of the Ford board's committees on finance and the environment, will replace him as chairman of the company then. 
 Jacques A. Nasser, 50, president of Ford's worldwide automotive operations, will replace Mr. Trotman as the chief executive and president at the end of the year and will retain his current title.
In splitting the jobs of chairman and chief executive, Ford is following an approach popular overseas but seldom seen in the United States. General Motors, the world's largest company in terms of sales and share of global economic output, divided the jobs from 1992 to 1995 and chose an outside director as chairman, but only after the company's poor performance in the 1991 recession had destroyed Wall Street's confidence in G.M.'s management.
Mr. Ford, whose family holds a special class of stock that gives it 40 percent of the voting rights at Ford, said he had no interest in being chief executive. "Having watched how large this company has become, and how tough it is to manage, I think separating these jobs makes a lot of sense," said Mr. Ford, who is raising four children with his wife, Lisa.
Mr. Ford said that he would continue to run the Detroit Lions professional football team, which his ailing father owns, but that he would devote most of his time to Ford.
Wall Street analysts predicted that the combination of Mr. Nasser and Mr. Ford would work well as long as Mr. Ford had other commitments. The two men have been friends since the early 1980's, when Mr. Ford was one of eight financial analysts reporting to Mr. Nasser, who oversaw Ford's financial operations in Latin America and Asia at the time.
Henry Ford and his grandson, Henry Ford 2d, ran the company from its founding in 1903 until Henry Ford 2d stepped down in 1980. The company has been led by professional managers since then because the younger brother of Henry Ford 2d, William Clay Ford, was in poor health and the next generation of Ford family members was deemed too young.
A Princeton University graduate who spent a year studying business at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Mr. Ford has won a remarkable number of admirers on Wall Street for his intelligence and charisma. But his close ties to environmentalists and his periodic calls for the auto industry to pay closer attention to environmental issues have alarmed some auto executives. Their fear has been that the scion of a billionaire family could put environmental causes ahead of profits and undermine the industry's traditionally united front against pressures from environmental groups.
For example, G.M. and Chrysler executives were furious last January when Ford announced that it would voluntarily make all of its sport utility vehicles and Windstar mini-vans roughly as clean as cars in terms of tailpipe emissions, at a cost of about $100 a vehicle. Ford executives said at the time that Mr. Nasser had made the decision, but Mr. Nasser has said little about the environment over the years and has long been an ally of Mr. Ford.
Mr. Ford mentioned the environment several times at a news conference today, noting at the beginning of his prepared remarks, "My vision for the company is product leadership, the highest quality and customer satisfaction and environmental leadership."
In a subsequent interview, Mr. Ford acknowledged "a tension" between environmentalism and the pursuit of profits in the short term. But in the long term, he said, Ford can distinguish itself, selling more vehicles and attracting better employees, by earning a reputation for being environmentally friendly.
In any case, Ford is earning record profits mainly because of soaring sales of its full-size sport utility vehicles, like the Ford Expedition, and big pickup trucks like the F-250, which burn a lot of gasoline. "I don't think for a second he's proposing Ford stop making Expeditions and F-250's -- this is a company that brought out some of the world's largest and heaviest passenger vehicles," said Maryann Keller, a longtime auto analyst at Furman Selz.
News of the succession overshadowed another Ford announcement today, that it will withdraw from the auction of the Kia Motors Corporation of South Korea and its affiliate, the Asia Motors Company.

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
No. 2 Man Remains No. 1 Ally

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
At the moment of President Clinton's greatest peril in office, Al Gore was where he has always been these last six years. By the President's side.
"I've stood with him as he has led this nation, and, on a personal note, I would like to tell you he is not only a great President, he has been a great friend," the Vice President said this morning in introducing Mr. Clinton at the annual White House prayer breakfast. 
 Later in the day Mr. Gore appeared again with the President, at a memorial service for victims of the embassy bombings in Africa last month and at a White House ceremony to honor Americans who played a role in the Northern Ireland peace accord.
And after the House had made public the report that argues the Whitewater independent counsel's case for impeachment, aides to Mr. Gore said they could not imagine his taking even one step back from his boss.
While Mr. Gore did not issue any immediate public response to the report, Lawrence J. Haas, his communications director, said: "Recent controversies have had no effect on the Vice President's day-to-day business activities or behavior. He continues to do the same thing he's done for the last six years: serve the country by helping the President implement the policies that have done so much to move this country forward. He will continue to do so."
Throughout the eight-month-old scandal, Mr. Clinton has had no stauncher ally than Mr. Gore, a certain Presidential contender in 2000 whose Boy Scout image has provided the Administration a vital means to convey policy initiatives at a time when many voters are distracted by the President's personal life, often at the expense of his political message.
Consistently describing Mr. Clinton as "my friend," Mr. Gore has steadily pounded away in appearances at rallies and town-hall-style meetings, telling Democrats of their need, more than ever, to organize and vote. While he never mentions the President's problems -- and did not today -- often implicit in his message is the expectation that Republicans will use the Lewinsky matter to galvanize their support at the state and local levels to get out the vote.
In remarks on Thursday to the Democratic Business Council, a group of party donors, the Vice President hailed Mr. Clinton as his friend and "the one person who stands at the heart" of the country's economic gains. He closed with what has become his standard conclusion: "Early to bed, early to rise, work like hell and organize."
The wounded status of Mr. Clinton, along with Mr. Gore's abiding loyalty, has helped make the Vice President a valuable campaigner for Democratic ideals and candidates. Not even the Justice Department's investigation into his role in 1996 campaign fund-raising has doused the eagerness of Democratic candidates to have him appear with them, even as some, like Gov. Parris N. Glendening of Maryland, have snubbed Mr. Clinton.
With the midterm elections two months away and the chances for Democratic gains in Congress diminishing, aides to Mr. Gore say he is in growing demand, especially by House Democrats in tight races. They say that he always intended to spend two or three days a week on the road campaigning this fall but that fallout from the report could prompt him to add to that schedule.
The next of the campaign trips begins on Saturday, when Mr. Gore leaves for Oregon and Washington State before joining Mr. Clinton next week at a Democratic fund-raiser in New York City.

HEADLINE: Producer Price Index Declined 0.4% Last Month

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Producer prices registered their largest drop in seven months during August, another indication that falling commodity prices are holding inflation at bay.
The Labor Department said today that producer prices -- prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers of goods -- decreased four-tenths of 1 percent last month. The core price rate, which excludes food and energy costs, fell one-tenth of 1 percent. 
 The decline in prices over all was the largest since January's drop of six-tenths of 1 percent and was the sixth monthly decrease this year. Analysts had expected August's report to show no change in prices over all and an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent in the core rate.
In July, prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent over all. The core rate increased one-tenth of 1 percent.
The Asian recession has reduced global demand for oil and other commodities. "Commodity prices have broken down," according to the ISI Group in New York.
Last month, the Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 commodities, a closely watched indicator of inflation, fell to a 21-year low.
Energy prices decreased 2.3 percent in August as gasoline prices recorded their biggest drop since February 1991. Food prices declined four-tenths of 1 percent.
Prices of intermediate goods fell three-tenths of 1 percent. Excluding food and energy, the intermediate prices dropped one-tenth of 1 percent.
The prices of crude goods fell 2.7 percent in August. Excluding food and energy, they decreased 2 percent.
Prescription drug prices, which had surged earlier in the year, fell six-tenths of 1 percent in August. Prices for over-the-counter drugs also declined.
Tobacco prices increased last month, while producer costs for cars dropped 1.7 percent, the largest decline since October 1990.
In the year's first eight months, producer prices fell at a 1.4 percent annual rate, compared with a 1.9 percent decline during 1997's first eight months.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Bug Turns Up in U.S.-China Trade Relations

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 11

 BODY:
To halt the invasion of a devastating insect pest, the United States said today that it would ban the import of all Chinese goods shipped in raw wood packing material, a move that is likely to strain China's economy -- as well as United States-China relations.
Officials said wooden crates and pallets used to ship Chinese goods to North America sometimes harbor the comely but voracious Asian long-horned beetle, which has emerged from the packing material after it arrived in warehouses to kill trees in five locations around New York and Chicago in the last two years. 
 The ban is likely to result in delays or higher costs for a third to half of China's $62 billion in exports to the United States -- at a time when China has already seen its export growth slowed by weak economies in other Asian countries.
United States officials acknowledged during a news conference conducted by video hookup in Beijing that the restrictions, scheduled to take effect in 90 days, would cause pain for Chinese business -- and for American importers as well. But they said that when Agriculture Department inspectors found the beetles boring through maple trees in suburban Chicago neighborhoods this summer, they felt compelled to act.
"We are very concerned," Dr. Isi A. Siddiqui, Deputy Assistant Agriculture Secretary, said during the news conference. "These new regulations are based on sound science and a real threat to U.S. environmental resources."
Government studies estimated $138 billion of damage to the United States economy if the beetles, which have no natural enemies in the United States and cannot be eradicated with pesticides, move to United States forests.
Dan Glickman, the Agriculture Secretary, said the action should not be seen as a trade sanction, adding that trade between the United States and China had grown to $80 billion this year from $5 billion 15 years ago.
"Our intention here is not to disrupt trade, but to lock out an unwanted guest that poses a serious economic and environmental threat," Mr. Glickman told an audience in Chicago.
The new regulations require that goods from China be packed in non-wood packing material or wood that has been treated with heat or fumigation to kill the insects. It was not clear whether Chinese exporters would be able to adopt new practices in the next 90 days or how much their costs would rise.
Although the Chinese Government had no official comment on the ban, Chinese officials have been aware of the looming possibility for weeks and were hoping to avert it.
"If the ban is imposed, China's exports will suffer, because a considerable amount of our export trade is packed in raw wood," one Agriculture Ministry official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
The Chinese Government has recently issued billions of dollars in Treasury bonds in an effort to stimulate the economy and insulate it against a slowdown caused by economic crises elsewhere in Asia or the summer's devastating floods in China. Although China's exports are still growing, the rate of growth has slowed this year, and a reduction of its thriving export sales to the United States would be hard to bear.
Dr. Siddiqui said the United States Government had been discussing the problem with China's quarantine agency for many months, ever since the beetles were discovered in warehouses. He stressed that the United States hoped to cooperate with the Chinese to minimize disruption to trade.
"Look, this is not an action we wanted to take, but this bug is eating trees in people's back yards and their front yards," said one United States official in Beijing. "Inspectors from the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service are knocking on doors and saying, 'We have to cut down all the trees around your home.' "
In the United States, the beetles have so far been detected in wood packing from China in warehouses in 14 states. They have been found free in the environment in and around Chicago as well as in Brooklyn and Amityville, N.Y.
The beetle was identified as the Asian long-horned beetle by a Cornell University entomologist, Richard Hoebeke, after Brooklyn residents noticed mysterious half-inch holes in their trees. The beetle's larvae drill through trees' bark into the wood, where they undergo metamorphosis into large black beetles with bright white spots and long elegant antennas.
In Brooklyn, as in three subsequent infestations, inspectors had to order the destruction of all affected trees, since there is currently no other way to control the pests.
United States officials disagreed somewhat over just how much of China's exports were packed in untreated wood, with estimates ranging from 25 percent to more than 90 percent, and on how difficult it would be for Chinese to adjust to the new requirements.
Ma Zhongmei, an official at the export department of the North China Air Transportation Company in Beijing, said about one-third of her company's customers packed goods in raw wood. She added that this sort of packing was most commonly used for high-value items, like large machines and factory equipment.
"These customers could have used plywood, but they chose raw wood to reduce cost," she said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Goodbye World!;
2 Asian Economies Seek to Keep Global Markets at Bay

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Sept. 11

 BODY:
When Hong Kong and Malaysia placed curbs on their stock markets last week, the outcry from foreign investors was immediate and indignant. The governments were committing heresy, these critics said, by turning their backs on the free market in the search for a quick economic fix.
But Hong Kong and Malaysia are not playing to an international audience. They are struggling to ease the pain of a punishing economic downturn on their people. In these straitened times, when people are more worried about getting by than going global, building walls around some Asian markets has become an increasingly attractive way of holding the economic typhoon at bay. 
 As emerging markets from Brazil to Russia tumble into crisis, Asia's isolationist tendencies are alarming senior American officials and could set a profoundly dangerous precedent for the global economy.
"We could have an unraveling of the global capital markets if the countries that opt out do better than the countries that stick to the orthodoxy," said Paul Krugman, a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Most major Asian countries still operate reliably open markets. But as the regional financial crisis sinks into a prolonged recession, it has shaken the faith of many here in the free-market system.
"It's no longer writing on the wall," said Sir Donald Tsang, the financial secretary of Hong Kong, who sought to curtail certain types of stock trading and ordered a big government intervention in the stock market late last month. "People have begun to close up. Look at our Malaysian friends."
On Sept. 2, Malaysia discontinued trading in its currency, the ringgit, and imposed sweeping capital controls on its markets. Among the provisions: currency held outside Malaysia will become worthless in a month; foreign investors cannot withdraw their capital for a year. Some analysts said Malaysia had effectively checked itself out of the global economy.
Hong Kong's approach was quite different. Rather than close off its markets, it plunged into them with a ferocity that left investors slack-jawed. Between Aug. 14 and Aug. 28, the government spent an estimated $15 billion to buy shares in an effort to prop the stock market. It also passed new regulations that restrict the short-selling of stocks and rein in the free-wheeling futures market.
Unlike Malaysia, Hong Kong's currency is still fully convertible, and there are no restraints on moving capital in or out of the territory.
Still, Malaysia and Hong Kong have a common complaint: the global market -- with its sharp-eyed speculators and will-o'-the-wisp capital flows -- is causing too much pain. With their stock markets crashing, unemployment soaring and currencies under attack, these governments feel they can no longer give foreign investors carte blanche in their markets.
"We're seeing a general loss of patience with trying to satisfy the international marketplace," Mr. Krugman said. "International investors demand a lot, and it's starting to look like these countries can't do it while rebuilding their economies."
The appeal of capital controls is that they enable governments to pursue economic policies -- such as lowering interest rates -- that might be untenable in an open market. Malaysia slashed rates after its intervention, giving an immediate lift to its stock exchange. If it had tried that when the ringgit was convertible, it almost certainly would have led to a further devaluation.
With Indonesia, Thailand, and South Korea suffering from similar ills, such a strategy might be appealing to their Governments as well. One significant complication is that these countries are receiving loans from the International Monetary Fund, which favors open markets. But Mr. Krugman noted that Russia was getting I.M.F. loans, even though it had suspended trading of the ruble.
Mr. Krugman has been both an observer and a player in the recent debate over free markets in Asia. In an article in the last issue of Fortune magazine, he proposed capital controls as a way for Asian countries to gain breathing space in order to repair their economies.
Scarcely a week after Mr. Krugman's article appeared, Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir bin Mohamad, announced his country's new restraints. Mr. Krugman disavowed responsibility for Malaysia's action, but advisers to Mr. Mahathir said the Fortune article lent a veneer of academic respectability to the move.
"The whole thrust is that in extreme circumstances, government intervention is kosher," said Noordin Sopiee, chairman of the Institute of Strategic and International Studies, a research organization in Kuala Lumpur, which helped draft Malaysia's new regulations.
Meddling in the markets is nothing new in Asia, or in much of the rest of the world, for that matter. Japan and South Korea have both intervened in their stock markets, while Taiwan imposes a modest form of capital controls. China maintains capital controls and a nonconvertible currency. But as Asia's growth exploded in the 1980's, most of the countries in the region adopted at least the semblance of a free market.
And why not? In 1996, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines enjoyed a net capital inflow of $96 billion from foreign investors. Outposts like Hong Kong and Singapore became gleaming financial centers by promoting their hands-off governments and open markets.
Today, Mr. Noordin acknowledged, "the prevailing ideology is that you must not touch market forces."
American officials are rushing to reassert the free-market standard around the world. Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, said in a speech in Washington on Wednesday: "It would be a catastrophe if countries were to develop the idea that somehow withdrawing from the global system was right, and that building the right foundation for a market economy was wrong."
Malaysia has come under withering criticism from foreign investors, who say that its controls will scare off investment, retard economic reform and end up hurting the very people they were supposed to protect.
"Capital controls are like heroin," said Mac Overton, a fund manager at MBF Unit Trust in Hong Kong. "Once you get addicted, it's hard to get off."
Mr. Overton was equally critical of the Hong Kong government, which he said had artificially inflated the stock market by buying so many shares. Moreover, he said the government had imposed voluminous rules and regulations, which made day-to-day investing in Hong Kong an uncertain affair.
"How do I know they're not going to change the rules again?" said Mr. Overton, who said he had sold all his Hong Kong investments.
The economist Milton Friedman, who is a self-described fan of Hong Kong, said the government's intervention was a "crazy idea."
"Hong Kong has essentially undermined its reputation as a financial center," Mr. Friedman said in a telephone interview from his home in Northern California. "It cannot remain a financial center if it manipulates its stock market."
Sir Donald acknowledged that Hong Kong's intervention had alienated some of its staunchest supporters. But he said the government had little choice but to act because the former British colony was under attack by a cabal of foreign hedge funds. In what he called a "double play," Sir Donald said the hedge funds speculated, in succession, against the Hong Kong dollar and the stock market.
Since the Hong Kong dollar is linked to the United States dollar at the fixed exchange rate, the brunt of the attacks was absorbed by the stock market, which dropped 16 percent in the first two weeks of August.
"The attack was sustained and professional, and we believed that if we did not do anything about it, the consequences would be calamitous," said Sir Donald, who will meet with investors in the United States and Europe later this month to reassure them of Hong Kong's commitment to an open market.
Hong Kong's buying spree lifted the stock market out of the doldrums, though it surrendered much of its gains this week. The benchmark Hang Seng index declined 3.5 percent today to close at 7,578.48.
The long-term consequences of the campaign are potentially thorny, however. Hong Kong spent $15 billion of its $96 billion in foreign reserves to buy stocks. And it is now the largest shareholder in several of the territory's leading companies, including the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation. It is unclear how the government can sell off these holdings without depressing the market.
For all that, the government has been widely supported by the people of Hong Kong. A recent survey commissioned by The South China Morning Post showed that economic confidence was rising and approval ratings rose sharply after the intervention.
"The government cannot let it get worse and worse," said Shee Leng Leng, a 29-year-old homemaker. "How do you define a free market? Nobody will regard Hong Kong as a free market if it becomes too bad."
In Malaysia, officials said capital controls would give the Government the chance to repair the economy. They said such repairs would be impossible if Malaysia continued to be buffeted by sudden outflows of capital or speculative attacks on its currency.
"Our belief is that the international currency trading system has gone stark raving crazy," Mr. Noordin said. "Making a rapid rush for a tranquil harbor was a wise course. There seemed to be no alternative."
But outsiders are skeptical that Malaysia will reform its debt-laden banking system or tackle endemic corruption without pressure from the global market.
Prime Minister Mahathir's capital controls are a logical extension of his past practice of blaming foreign currency speculators for the economic collapse. Officials point to a rise in the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange as evidence that Mr. Mahathir's policies are striking a chord with the public.
Appeals to nationalism are not limited to Malaysia. In Hong Kong, which prides itself as the multicultural hub of Asia, the debate over government intervention has taken on a distinct us-versus-them tone, with officials and legislators repeatedly drawing a line between local "investors" and foreign "speculators."
For his part, Sir Donald sought to dispel any notion that Hong Kong was blaming outsiders for its economic ailments. "We love foreign investors here," he said emphatically. "It's a bit unfair to tar my name with some other foreign leaders who might have different notions."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow Gets a Lift Of Nearly 180 In Wide Rally

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Technology and financial stocks led the market higher yesterday, as a few earnings bright spots showed through the fanfare over the release of the Whitewater independent counsel's report on President Clinton to Congress and concerns about the prospects for Mr. Clinton's impeachment.
The jump of 179.96 points in the Dow Jones industrial average, while strong, was not enough to wipe out the loss of 249.48 points on Thursday or to pull the Dow back into positive territory for the year. 
 But the rally did leave the Dow up 2 percent for the week, breaking a two-week decline of 10.5 percent. It is only the second week since the Dow reached its peak on July 17 that the indicator has finished up. The other major market measures, however, recouped all their Thursday losses, ended higher for the week and are up about 4 percent for the year.
The rally faltered a little after the release of the report on President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, but gained steam in the afternoon, raising the question of how much impact news of the report had on the stock market. Investors may have been encouraged by the apparent lack of any major surprises in the report.
But until there is a clearer idea of Mr. Clinton's fate, the impeachment process will probably be more of an excuse to sell while the economic outlook here and abroad and the prospects for corporate earnings in the quarters ahead will provide real direction to the market.
"The issue every portfolio manager has to be grappling with is what is going to happen to earnings," said Douglas R. Cliggott, the United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities.
In Europe, stocks were mixed after sharp declines on Thursday. The Financial Times index of 100 stocks in Britain dropped 18 points, or nearly four-tenths of 1 percent, to 5,118.60, but that was enough to push the index into negative territory for the year, with a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent. The markets in Germany, France and Italy still have gains in the teens for the year despite sharp selloffs since mid-July.
There was a bounce in Latin America, which seemed to get a boost from Wall Street. The Bovespa index in Brazil, which plunged 15.8 percent on Thursday, jumped 13.39 percent yesterday, while the Mexican market rose 2.16 percent after falling 9.8 percent the day before.
But the market environment is unchanged, with the American economy still threatened by the turmoil in Asia, the political problems in Russia and the spread of the global crisis to Latin America. Adding the new focus on Clinton's future, which will occupy Washington and the media's attention in the weeks ahead, seems to leave little fertile ground on which the stock market could build a lasting rally. But it should add to the volatility, which could damage investor confidence.
"We're in an environment where the market can't rocket back," said Jeffrey M. Applegate, the chief United States strategist at Lehman Brothers. "That is why this is not like last October," he added, referring to the swift rebound after the Dow fell 554 points on Oct. 27.
But he also argued that things were not as dire as they appeared. "There is no one person in charge," he said, referring to the leadership needed to help to contain the crisis and the fact that Mr. Clinton and other leaders seem distracted or incapable. But the view that nobody is doing anything, he said, "is just wrong." He added, "I don't think that we are going to stand by and let this crisis push Latin America and even Canada into a recession."
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, will be asked for more details on his and the central bank's intentions when he testifies before the House Banking Committee on the global outlook on Wednesday. The record 380.53-point rally in the Dow on Tuesday was prompted by his indication that the central bank would consider a rate cut if the foreign drag on the United States economy worsened.
His comments, which were made on Sept. 4, have also helped push the dollar lower as investors think both an economic slowdown here and a rate cut will make the American currency less attractive. Yesterday, the dollar fell to 130.82 Japanese yen from 134.23 yen on Thursday; it is down 11.2 percent against the yen since Aug. 11. While the dollar rose slightly against the German mark yesterday, it is down 6.2 percent since Aug. 26.
Intel jumped 5 7/8, to 8415/16 , after the company announced late on Thursday that third-quarter sales should be 8 to 10 percent higher than in the second quarter. Oracle rose 3 3/8, to 25 1/2. Also late on Thursday, the company reported a 30 percent rise in profits for its first quarter.
But it is not clear yet if these positive results are a sign that the technology business is turning around and may, as it did earlier this year, help lead the entire stock market higher again.
Although analysts said it was risky to extrapolate too broadly from these companies' reports, they were considered positive.
"I think we're two-thirds to three-fourths of the way through a down cycle, which means things should stop getting worse," said John Rossi, a managing director at BancAmerica Robertson Stephens.
Financial stocks, which have been among the hardest hit because of losses in Russia and Latin America, also rallied. American Express jumped 8 7/8, to 78 3/8, after announcing that economic problems in Asia and other emerging markets were having little impact on earnings.
The Dow, which rose 2.4 percent, finished at 7,795.50. The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks climbed 28.87, or 3 percent, to 1,009.06, while the technology-heavy Nasdaq index finished 56.31 points, or 3.6 percent, higher at 1,641.64. The Russell index of 2,000 of smaller-company stocks rose 8.65 points, or 2.5 percent, to 353.62, ending a seven-week decline of 25 percent.
In the bond market, the price of the 30-year bond fell 21/32 , to 104, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.23 percent, from 5.19 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Japanese Economy Continues to Shrink
In the starkest sign so far of the depth of Japan's recession, the Government said that the economy contracted in the April-to-June quarter by an annual rate of 3.3 percent, nearly twice as steep a fall as most economists had expected. It was the first time that Japan's economy had contracted for three consecutive quarters.
The data suggest that the core of the economy slid even more rapidly than it did earlier in the year, and there are fears that the recession could worsen. The figures were released after the close of a volatile session in Japanese stocks. The Nikkei index plunged 749.05 points, or 5.11 percent. Page C2. 

Economic Shift Indicated in Russia
Handily winning a confirmation vote in the Russian Parliament, Prime Minister Yevgeni M. Primakov signaled a sharp shift toward a more socialist economic model by endorsing two of the Communist Party's hand-picked candidates for top posts, including the head of the Central Bank. Mr. Primakov gave no details of his economic program but invoked the New Deal as an example of the measured use of Government intervention to rescue a country from economic depression. A1.
 
American Express Resisting Turmoil
American Express, seeking to stem a 41 percent drop in its stock since mid-July, said the turmoil in emerging markets and signs that the American economy was slowing were having only a modest effect on earnings. Its shares rose $8.875, to $78.375.
 
Toshiba to Post First-Half Loss
Toshiba said that it would report a loss for the fiscal first half -- its first for the period in 48 years -- because of plunging memory chip prices, slumping Asian demand and foundering sales of personal computers and peripheral products. The company said it expected a loss of 25 billion yen, or $191 million, in the half ending on Sept. 30.
 
Producer Prices Fell in August
The Labor Department said that producer prices -- prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers of goods -- decreased four-tenths of 1 percent in August, their largest drop in seven months, indicating that falling commodity prices are holding inflation at bay. The decline in prices was the largest since January's drop of six-tenths of 1 percent and the sixth monthly decrease this year. C15.
 
Possible Delay in Microsoft Trial
Lawyers from Microsoft and the Justice Department have tentatively agreed to push the date of the company's antitrust trial back to Oct. 15 from Sept. 23. The possible delay was negotiated after a hearing on Microsoft's request to have the suit dismissed. C15.
 
Homestake Revises Buyout Offer
Homestake Mining and Prime Resources Group have agreed to a revised bid for Homestake to buy the 49.4 percent of Prime it does not own, increasing the transaction's value to $330 million. C3.
 
Coffee Futures Decline 4.4%
Coffee futures dived 4.4 percent amid fears that Brazil will devalue its currency, prompting a wave of selling. In New York, coffee for December delivery fell 4.85 cents, to $1.0415 a pound. C3.

HEADLINE: A Growth Spurt for Union Square Park

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Having been transformed from a haven for drug dealers into a verdant jewel in a resurgent neighborhood, Union Square Park is about to undergo its next big transformation: a doubling of its size by turning adjacent pavement into parkland.
The city plan, to be presented to Community Board 5 on Monday evening, calls for the park to be expanded by 50 to 130 feet on its west side and 10 to 20 feet to the south. A traffic triangle at the southeast corner will be nearly tripled in size to 20,000 square feet to accommodate traffic. When funds are available in the future, the rest of the ellipse-shaped park will be expanded so that it will resemble more of an actual square. 
 "It's a park in transition," said Henry J. Stern, the city's Parks Commissioner. "Just as you wouldn't recognize the park of 20 years ago today, in 20 years you will no longer be able to recognize today's park."
The park, once decrepit, is already considered a major success story of urban revitalization, having helped draw new housing, glittering stores and restaurants, and thousands upon thousands of visitors to what was, little more than a decade ago, a dowdy factory and retailing area. And as the local economy has improved, local businesses have taken on more of the job of caring for the park. Last year, for instance, merchants began picking up half the tab for a full-time gardener.
"Union Square is a classic example of how fixing up a park can make a dramatic change in the surrounding neighborhood," said Marcia Reiss, policy director for the Parks Council, a nonprofit research and advocacy group.
Gary H. Richard, president of the electronics retailer P. C. Richard & Son, which three years ago opened its first Manhattan store in the area, said, "It gets better every day." Referring to the park and the surrounding business district, he said, "There's life all over the place."
Oddly, Union Square was not originally, and never has been officially, mapped as parkland. In 1832, the State Legislature acquired it as "a public space," and as such, it was intended principally to be the place where the roads and people of a growing metropolis intersected. Indeed, its name owed nothing to its historical importance as a meeting place for organized labor, but rather denoted the union of two roads, the Albany Post Road (now Broadway) and Boston Road (now Fourth Avenue).
But in their relentless search for a bit of open space, New Yorkers made Union Square a park in the truest sense. In part, the irregular oval from 14th Street to 17th Street east of Broadway became a stage for history: People gathered there to celebrate the end of the Civil War, to mourn the deaths of Lincoln and Grant and to protest the executions of Sacco and Vanzetti.
But Union Square -- which is to be designated a National Landmark today in honor of its importance to labor -- was also a place for the smaller, more tender turnings of the urban drama. In the 1960's, it had a program to provide day care for shoppers at 25 cents an hour -- called "Check a Child" -- and today, the park's three playgrounds sizzle with nonstop youthful energy.
Despite the public space's ambiguous legal definition, New Yorkers have always insisted that it must first and foremost be a park -- and it has changed forms many times. Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, the designers of Central Park, performed the first make-over in the 1870's, and in the 1930's it was raised four feet to make room for a subway mezzanine. The administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch remodeled it in the 1980's.
Though parks officials are reluctant to give details of the latest plans before presenting them to the local community board, designers say that park visitors can expect antique bishop's-crook lampposts, granite-block and bluestone paving, and ample new plantings of flowers, shrubs and trees.
But the main focus is expansion. "We're expanding the park at all sides below 15th Street," said Lawrence Mauro, a landscape architect who is serving as project manager. He says future plans include new restrooms as part of a full-scale restoration of the crumbling limestone structure at the park's northern edge.
The current project involves two phases. The first is the expansion and beautification of the southwestern corner of the park at a cost of $2.2 million, to be paid from the city's capital budget. The other is the increase in size of the traffic triangle to 21,000 square feet from 6,900 square feet to handle traffic better. Those changes, to cost $400,000, will be paid for by the Metropolitan Transit Authority.
A major goal is to give clean definition to the perimeter of the park, which has been marked by temporary curbs and other barriers. "You now don't know where the park starts," Mr. Mauro said. "By the wall? Out at the curb? People aren't sure where to walk, where to drive."
Two local business groups, the 14th Street Local Development Corporation and the 14th Street Business Improvement District, are responsible for improvements in park maintenance. They have helped the Parks Department with sanitation, security and groundskeeping.
But perhaps the most notable feature of the park is the Union Square Greenmarket, which has become one of the city's biggest markets for fresh produce. When it started, in 1976, conditions were sharply different.
"There were no benches, no lawns, no working fountains," said Joel Patraker, assistant director of the market. He said it was not uncommon for drug addicts to topple farmers' tables and steal money from the upset cash boxes.
Now, 70 sellers come four days a week to peddle 200 varieties of hot peppers, 100 varieties of apples and many other products. The farmers plant flowers and shrubs around the statue of Mohandas K. Gandhi and elsewhere.
"The gardens have never looked better," Mr. Patraker said.

HEADLINE: State Gets $97 Million Welfare-to-Work Grant

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The Federal Government announced yesterday that it was awarding a $96.9 million grant to New York State to help welfare recipients make the transition to regular jobs.
The grant -- $58.4 million of it for New York City -- will be used to pay for child care, training and transportation in an effort to provide the support that welfare recipients need to hold jobs. 
 "Our goal is to insure that when New York's newest workers get jobs, they can keep them," Alexis Herman, the Secretary of Labor, said yesterday in a statement. "These funds will help some of the hardest-to-serve welfare recipients get the support services they need, which can make the difference between success and failure."
In a telephone interview yesterday, Secretary Herman added that the Federal Government was requiring New York State to put up $48 million in matching funds to supplement the Federal welfare-to-work grant.
About 70 percent of the money, government officials said, will be concentrated on chronically unemployed recipients who lack high school diplomas and have low math and reading scores, poor work histories and substance abuse problems.
The grant is part of $2.2 billion in Federal money being awarded to states over a two-year period to finance local programs to help long-term welfare recipients hold jobs as Federal legislation requires states and cities to move hundreds of thousands of such people into jobs.
State and city officials welcomed the grant money. "It's a recognition that New York City and New York State are on the cutting edge of welfare reform," said Anthony P. Coles, senior adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. "The money is going to be used to expand our efforts to move people into work" and "move more people from dependency into self-sufficiency."
Thanks in large part to cuts in the welfare rolls in New York City, the number of welfare recipients statewide has fallen by 547,000, or 30 percent, over the last four years.
"We've had tremendous success in reducing the welfare rolls in New York State under Governor Pataki," said Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Gov. George E. Pataki. "This grant will help us continue that success by targeting those people who need extra help in getting off of welfare."
Eighty-five percent of the money going to New York State will be distributed to individual counties; Mr. Pataki's office will distribute the remaining 15 percent to strengthen employment services for people with special needs and to publicize services for welfare-to-work programs. The grant money can also be used for housing, substance-abuse treatment and job creation programs through wage subsidies.
New York is the 38th state to receive a grant under this program. The Labor Department is completing its work before announcing a grant for New Jersey, and it has awarded $12 million to Connecticut for work transition programs. The Federal Government is also making $711 million in grants available on a competitive basis to community-based groups helping welfare recipients make the transition to work.

HEADLINE: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: THE FINAL PUSH;
Democratic Candidates for Attorney General Still Struggling to Gain Attention

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

 BODY:
With only days before the primary, the four Democratic candidates for attorney general are blanketing towns and cities with letters and fliers, jamming the airwaves with television and radio advertisements and traveling the state in a last-ditch effort to draw attention to a race that has drawn little of it so far.
But one public-opinion poll after another has shown that large numbers of voters have yet to take notice of the race and are undecided about which candidate they will support in Tuesday's primary. That has the four Democratic candidates struggling not only to attract attention but also to stand out in a race in which there are few differences in ideology or in the way they say they would carry out the job of attorney general. 
 "Nobody is running as the flaming liberal of the party, nor is anyone running as the party's centrist," said John Zogby, a pollster who heads the John Zogby Group of Utica, N.Y. "So when everybody is saying the same thing from essentially the same place, it greatly reduces passion for one side or the other."
This is not to say that all things are equal among the candidates, who are Eliot L. Spitzer, a wealthy Manhattan lawyer and former prosecutor; Catherine M. Abate, a State Senator from Manhattan; G. Oliver Koppell, a former Attorney General, and Evan A. Davis, who was a counsel to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Mr. Spitzer has used his vast personal wealth for an advertising campaign that has won him the name recognition that the other candidates sorely lack and do not have enough money to buy.
To the extent that there have been clashes among the candidates, they have centered on Mr. Spitzer and his money. The three other candidates say he is using money from his father, a real estate developer, to buy the election.
"When Eliot comes on the air with more than $4 million worth of television advertising -- sure, it's an obstacle," Mr. Davis said the other day on an Albany radio talk show.
"I'm hoping they are going to see that this television is not the way to evaluate the candidate," Mr. Davis said of the voters.
Mr. Spitzer has shrugged off the attacks as absurd. He has said that using his own money to finance his campaign means that he is beholden to no one. And he has also argued -- and most political experts agree -- that it will take a well-financed campaign to unseat the Republican incumbent, Dennis C. Vacco, who has a formidable campaign war chest.
That fight aside, each of the candidates is, by and large, roaming the state this final weekend in a frantic push to pick up endorsements from prominent politicians and groups and to persuade voters they have the best credentials to be the state's top law-enforcement officer.
In Mr. Spitzer's case, he has managed to get the backing of some important Democratic leaders, many of whom have received political contributions from him. Among Mr. Spitzer's supporters are the county chairmen of Erie and Westchester Counties, as well as the mayors of Albany and Rochester.
Mr. Spitzer's pitch on the stump is simple: his years of experience in the courtroom make him the most suited to defend the people of New York. He has focused on an array of popular issues, from forcing corporate polluters to clean up the Hudson River to using product liability laws to force gun manufacturers to install safety locks on their products.
Ms. Abate is shoring up support among influential labor unions, women's groups, gay organizations and other historically Democratic constituencies.
In her ads and speeches, she continues to point to her experience at running large agencies -- including the New York City probation and corrections departments -- as evidence that she can run an office as large as the attorney general's. And she has spoken passionately about issues affecting middle-class families, from child care to health care.
"As a wife, mother and New York's attorney general, I'll protect our families' health and economic well-being," Ms. Abate says in a 30-second television advertisement that began running this week.
Mr. Koppell was selected by the State Legislature in 1993 to complete the unexpired term of Robert Abrams, but he was defeated in his bid for a full term in office. He has been asking voters to look at his accomplishments during the time he was attorney general, from cracking down on consumer fraud to suing corporate polluters. Mr. Koppell, who also represented the Bronx in the State Assembly for 23 years, has all but locked up support from political leaders in that borough, as well as his former Assembly colleagues.
Mr. Davis remains the outsider. His only prominent supporter is his former boss, Mr. Cuomo, who is now being featured in radio ads urging people to support Mr. Davis. Nevertheless, Mr. Davis is trying to capitalize on his outsider status, casting himself as the anti-establishment candidate and traveling to poor urban neighborhoods with his message.
He is the only candidate who has placed voluntary limits on his own fund-raising and has also refused to take money from unions, corporations and political action committees. He says that makes him the only candidate who is not beholden to special interests.

INTERNATIONAL A3-6
 
Russian Parliament Approves Prime Minister
The Russian Parliament approved Yevgeny M. Primakov as President Boris N. Yeltsin's nominee to be Prime Minister, after twice rejecting Mr. Yeltsin's first choice, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin. Parliament endorsed two members of the Communist Party for the country's top posts, including the head of Russia's Central Bank, raising questions about the future of economic reforms. A1 

Holbrooke Nomination Stalled
The nomination of Richard C. Holbrooke as United States representative to the United Nations has been delayed indefinitely while the Justice Department investigates his contacts with former State Department colleagues after he left the department two years ago for a career on Wall Street. A3
 
Weekend Elections in Bosnia
Bosnians are to vote this weekend for their three-member presidency, members of the Federal Parliament and leaders of the Bosnian Serb Republic and the Muslim-Croat Federation. One candidate getting some support from the West is Ljubisa Savic, whose war record has made him a source of fear. A6
 
Hamas Promises Retaliation
Hamas vowed to avenge with bloodshed the the Israeli Army's killing of two brothers who were key operatives, threatening a new wave of violence after a year of refraining from deadly attacks. Wary of reprisals from the Islamic militant group, Israel put its troops on high alert and sealed its borders with the West Bank and Gaza. A4
 
Cambodian Protest Attacked
The Cambodian Government turned loose a band of thugs to shoot and attack pro-democracy demonstrators. The military warned that it could not allow what it called the "worrying anarchy" of the continuing opposition protests. A6
 
Iran Threatens Taliban
Iran vowed revenge against the militant Taliban movement that controls most of neighboring Afghanistan, with the Revolutionary Guards saying that the Taliban should be given "what they so richly deserve" for killing nine Iranian diplomats. A4
 
Mexican Drug Trafficker Slain
Rafael Munoz Talavera, who was accused of being the mastermind of a drug deal that led to the largest cocaine seizure in history and later fought for control of a drug cartel, was found dead, his body bound and riddled with gunshot wounds, in Ciudad Juarez, across from El Paso, Tex. A4
 
Unrest in Lesotho
The head of the Lesotho Defense Force, Lieut. Gen. Makhula Mosakeng, resigned in a sudden upheaval within the military of the small southern African kingdom. About two dozen of the army's senior commanders were taken prisoner by junior officers reported to sympathize with opposition political parties who say elections last May were a fraud. (Reuters)

Starr Report Makes Case For Possible Impeachment
The House released a scathing report by the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, who accused President Clinton of violating his Constitutional duty to faithfully execute the law by committing such crimes as perjury and obstruction of justice; he cited 11 counts of possible impeachable offenses, all stemming from Mr. Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky. The House must now judge whether Mr. Starr has presented a compelling case for impeachment. The White House angrily responded that the report was a lurid and politically motivated attempt to humiliate the President and to overturn the results of two elections. A1
 
President Clinton tearfully told a roomful of clerics that he had sinned and, with Hillary Rodham Clinton in the audience, asked for Ms. Lewinsky's forgiveness. A1
 
President Clinton's lawyers issued a 78-page response to the Starr report that sought to portray the President's behavior as a personal failing for which he had accepted responsibility but not serious enough to warrant his impeachment. A9
 
The House voted, 363 to 63, to make public the Starr report and to begin the process that could lead to the first impeachment proceedings against a President in 24 years. A13
 
Republicans and Democrats alike said that while there was no single stunning revelation in the Starr report, they were deeply distressed by its graphic and extensive details. A13
 
Ms. Lewinsky told investigators that the President's friend, Vernon E. Jordan Jr., had directed her to destroy evidence of her relationship with Mr. Clinton, the report said. A15
 
Legal and political history offers a vague set of interpretations of the Constitution's declaration that a President can be removed for treason, bribery "or other high crimes and misdemeanors." A7
