HEADLINE: Yeltsin's Choice Easily Ratified; A Shift to Left

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Yevgeny M. Primakov handily won confirmation as Prime Minister from the Russian Parliament today, and signaled a sharp shift toward a more socialist economic model by endorsing two of the Communist Party's hand-picked candidates for top posts.
The appointments -- of a moderate Communist who used to run the Soviet state planning agency and a central banker associated with easy money policies and inflation in the early 1990's -- raised questions about the future of economic reform. 
 Mr. Primakov appeared before Parliament's lower house a day after President Boris N. Yeltsin, capping two and a half weeks of political and economic crisis, named him as a compromise candidate.
After only one day's preparation for a job he said he had not sought, Mr. Primakov's ideas for the economy were necessarily vague.
At Parliament he spoke of bolstering Russian industry, of moving away from a dependency on foreign loans and of giving the Government a larger role in regulating the economy. And he invoked President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal as an example of the measured use of government intervention to rescue a country from economic depression.
"This is not a return to the command and administrative system, no," Mr. Primakov said. "But the state must do this.
"Indeed, it did not occur to anyone to condemn the United States for example, when Roosevelt introduced some elements of state regulation in the economy after the Great Depression. So should we copy the wild capitalism that existed in the past, or should we use the experience accumulated by humankind?"
Mr. Primakov said he would put together a government of "unity" whose first task will be to pull the country out of its deepening social and economic crisis and restore Moscow's dwindling authority over the rest of the country.
"I am not a magician," he said after winning Parliament's approval on a vote of 317 to 63, with 15 abstentions. "Don't expect me to produce any quick fixes."
By appointing Yuri D. Maslyukov, the Communists' leading candidate as Prime Minister, as his top deputy, Mr. Primakov indicated that he had already struck an alliance with Mr. Yeltsin's leftist opposition, which has tried to capitalize on Russia's monthlong crisis to put its people and policies in a new government.
Parliament's lower house today approved a parallel appointment of Viktor V. Gerashchenko as chairman of Russia's central bank, bringing back a Soviet-era banker who in the early 1990's was the nemesis of Mr. Yeltsin's team of Western-style reformers. Mr. Gerashchenko's return, at Mr. Yeltsin's request, was seen by many experts as another important sign that Russia is moving off the path of tight monetary policies, back to an era of free spending and easy credits to rescue failing industries.
Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist Party chief, today all but confirmed that the alliance between Mr. Primakov and the left had been made earlier this week, with Mr. Yeltsin's approval.
"At the closed meeting at the President's office, five candidates were considered," Mr. Zyuganov said in a speech supporting Mr. Primakov's nomination. "The very fact that three of them agreed to work in the same team -- Primakov, Maslyukov and Gerashchenko -- deserves respect."
Mr. Primakov, ever the wily diplomat, today pointedly left the door open for other political parties to join the Government, but gave no word on the fate of the acting Deputy Prime Minister, Boris G. Fyodorov, the only voice for Western-style reform who has remained in power since Mr. Yeltsin began his latest Government shake-up on Aug. 23.
Mr. Fyodorov, who was named this summer as chief of Russia's tax collection service, said today that he would not resign. "Under no circumstances will I go on my own," he told a Russian news agency. "My nerves are pretty strong."
Grigory A. Yavlinsky, head of a liberal opposition party who only on Thursday had hopes of playing a key role in a Primakov government, today took his distance from the new Prime Minister. Mr. Yavlinsky had been the first to publicly float Mr. Primakov's name as a compomise candidate this week, when Russia was headed toward a constitutional confrontation over the nomination of former Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin.
Admitting he had "doubts" about the composition of the Government, Mr. Yavlinsky today issued a thinly veiled warning against the kind of loose money policies that stalled Russia's economic reforms in 1993, when Mr. Gerashchenko was head of the central bank. "We must not allow ruinous printing of money, or the blocking of import duties, or nationalization," he said.
Konstantin Borovoi, an independent member of Parliament, speaking on behalf of five other independent deputies, was even more blunt. "The latest events go to show that this is a collusion, that the President is in cahoots with the Communists, trying to keep his own post by giving up democracy, the path of reforms and the market economy," he said. "This will not work."
This alarmist view echoed dire warnings made on Thursday by Mr. Chernomyrdin, who accused the Communists of trying to stage a "crawling coup," and restore the old Soviet regime and its command economy. But Mr. Primakov today insisted that his coalition Cabinet would be made up of "professionals" who will be required to leave their political agendas at the door.
In a brief television address before Parliament's vote, Mr. Yeltsin urged support for his new Prime Minster whose nomination, he said, had pulled the country back from "the brink of a serious political crisis."
"We have yet to draw the lessons of the present crisis," Mr. Yeltsin said. "In the meantime we must work to overcome it. We must all work in concert."
As the political crisis recedes, Russia's economic crisis moves back to the top of the agenda, and Mr. Primakov's Government will face decisions on a range of issues from the stabilization of the ruble, to the resolution of an endemic banking crisis, to the dismantling of Russia's mountain of internal debt.
Russia has already defaulted on $447 milllion in interest payments due to Germany last month, the first time it has missed its schedule for repaying sovereign loans from other governments. A Finance Ministry spokesman said Russia would fulfill its obligations on the debt, and put the blame for the delay on the deadlock in the Russian banking system, where payments and withdrawals have ground to a halt.
Mr. Maslyukov, a moderate Communist who served as head of the Soviet central planning agency and briefly as Minister for Trade and Industry in Mr. Yeltsin's last Government, is expected to be put in charge of overall economic policy, but whether Mr. Primakov will give him free reign to dictate that policy remains unclear.
During his brief stint in government this summer, Mr. Maslyukov tried to enlarge his staff and widen his sphere of influence to include Russia's mlitary industrial sector -- tactics that come naturally to Soviet-trained bureaucrats.
Mr. Gerashchenko's return to the central bank brings Russia's recent history full circle, back to the days when he and Mr. Fyodorov, then Finance Minister, clashed regularly over monetary policy. In those days, the central bank was a source for cheap credits for Russian industry, a policy that its critics said not only encouraged badly managed factories but also spurred inflation.
In remarks to reporters today, Mr. Gerashchenko, 60, who has been president of International Moscow Bank, said he would react "cautiously" to pleas from his Communist supporters to pump a huge infusion of new rubles into the economy.
Given the depths of Russia's current economic plight, even liberal economists say some printing of new money may be necessary to help the country and its people survive the surge of inflation that followed last month's devaluation of the ruble. Mr. Chernomyrdin, campaigning for the job of Prime Minister last week, said 40 billion new rubles -- or 16 percent of the Russia's current money supply -- are needed to tide the country through the crisis.
In the last week, Mr. Fyodorov has pressed for the creation of a currency board, which would strictly limit the amount of rubles in relation to Russia's reserves of gold and foreign currency. But Mr. Gerashchenko today dismissed the proposal out of hand, calling it foolish for Russia.
Some experts suggested today that Mr. Gershchenko, with his inside knowledge of the workings of Russia's commercial banks, might do a better job than his predecessor at getting control of wayward banks, which had gambled heavily, and lost, on Russia's ill-fated short-term Treasury bills, and risky currency contracts with Western banks.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1466 words

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE POLITICS;
Now, the People Will Have a Chance to Judge

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
For months, the American people have been mere bystanders as the story of Bill Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky unfolded.
Now, with the release of Kenneth W. Starr's report, they have assumed a central and conceivably decisive role in the case. The report is in the hands of Congress, to dispose of as Congress sees fit. A political process has begun, and in political processes, as the Founding Fathers foresaw, the people have the ultimate power. 
 It is by no means clear how they will use it, or what the result will be. One prominent Democratic political consultant told his clients this week that he expected Mr. Clinton to be out of the White House within weeks. Only one President in the last 50 years, it is true, has been in trouble this deep, and that one, Richard M. Nixon, was of course forced from office.
But many clear-eyed people still think that Mr. Clinton will hold on.
The fact is, Washington is lost. There is no precedent for the present bizarre spectacle -- lurid tales of sexual high jinks in and near the Oval Office, poker-faced lawyers in serious suits debating the constitutional implications thereof and rowdy legislators trying to behave themselves.
Is it a movie, or a pulp novel, or an adolescent dream about life in the capital? No, it is real life. Or the closest approximation that the Clinton years -- the Harding era restaged for television -- can produce.
Ever since the Whitewater investigation began, and continuing through the revelations about Ms. Lewinsky, the voters have been telling pollsters that they approve of Mr. Clinton's performance as President, however they feel about his behavior or character. Three new polls, conducted over the last two weeks by CBS News, Gallup and the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press, found no significant change in that pattern.
The polls were taken before the report was released, of course, and it is possible that Mr. Starr's enumeration of 11 possible grounds for impeachment may change many people's minds. The explicit details of the President's repeated sexual encounters with Ms. Lewinsky -- and especially the fact that they took place near the sanctum sanctorum of American government, the Oval Office, several while he was on the phone with members of Congress -- may have an adverse impact as well.
But no matter how ephemeral and imperfect the polls may be, they suggest that if an election were held tomorrow, and Mr. Clinton were legally eligible to run, he would stand a reasonable chance of winning another term.
Which raises a very leading question: Why would the politicians who sit in the Senate and the House of Representatives want to vote to remove from office a President, twice elected by the people of the United States, whose official conduct has met with such consistent approval from the voters?
They might do so if they felt the political winds shifting enough that doing otherwise could put their own careers in peril. Although it is true that legislators can and often do rise above petty partisanship on great questions of state like war or peace and impeachment, and they may do so this time, it is also true that they are as subject to the instinct of self-preservation as any other human beings.
And there are signs that many Democrats' sensitive noses are already picking up the scent of such climatic change. Many senators and representatives who face close races are publicly denouncing the President, and others have made it clear they would be just as happy if he did not campaign for them.
Equally important, Democrats who are considered custodians of the traditions and values of the Senate -- elders like Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia -- have been among the most outspoken.
Three weeks ago, the independent analyst Charles E. Cook Jr., who probably follows Congressional politics more closely than anyone, said that this fall's election was most likely to produce only modest changes, if any, in the makeup of the two houses. In a new survey distributed today, he said the "mid-range scenario" would show Democratic losses of 6 to 10 seats in the House and 2 to 4 in the Senate, with much larger losses clearly plausible.
The legislators might also turn against the President if they hear from the voters, either directly or indirectly, that they want him called to account. Public backing for the President might be quickly eroded not only by the Starr report but also the faltering economy; one reason many voters have given over the past few years for sticking with Mr. Clinton has been a strong stock market and full employment.
Phone calls, faxes and E-mail messages in the next days will count for a lot.
Every President is weak at the stage Mr. Clinton has reached, with only two years left of his second term. The reformer's zeal is spent, and as political attention slowly turns to the question of a successor, the incumbent's power on Capitol Hill wanes. For Mr. Clinton, the problem is intensified.
Unlike Nixon, who resigned in 1974 rather than face an impeachment trial, Mr. Clinton lacks roots in Congress. He never served there, and he has spent little time cultivating the Democrats upon whom his survival may well depend. Some members are last-ditch loyalists; every single member of the Black Caucus, for example, voted today to give the President a chance to study the Starr report before it was released to the general public.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, who could be a pivotal figure, is much less locked in. When he was campaigning four years ago for his present post, he promised to put his colleagues' interests ahead of the President's, and he restated that viewpoint on Thursday.
"I don't see myself as an advocate of the President per se," he told The Wall Street Journal. "I see myself as insuring that the President gets a fair hearing. I draw a very big distinction between the two roles."
The 78-page rebuttal issued by Mr. Clinton's lawyers construed the constitutional language about impeachment as narrowly as possible. That will clearly form one element of his defense. But there is precedent for a broader interpretation as well. During his days in the House, Gerald R. Ford once famously said that an impeachable offense is "whatever a majority of the House of Representatives considers it to be at a given moment of history."
In addition, there is a close parallel, no doubt intentional, between one of the offenses of which the House Judiciary Committee found President Nixon guilty -- failure to "take care that the laws be faithfully executed" -- and one of Mr. Starr's charges -- conduct "inconsistent with the President's constitutional duty to faithfully execute the laws" of the nation.
The other main element of the President's defense is contrition. Almost every public statement in recent days has included a plea for forgiveness. But he has lied and dissembled so often in the past, one of his friends in the Senate said, "that you have to ask yourself which Clinton to believe."
Often, as The Economist said this week, "First apologies are what counts."
Mr. Clinton, it should be emphasized, need not maintain the support of a majority of the House and Senate to survive. In the Senate, a two-thirds majority is required to convict, so he would need only the backing of 34 senators to hang on. In the House, a simple majority would technically suffice to force a Senate trial, but a 225-to-210 vote or anything like it seems an insubstantial, unlikely foundation on which to build a Presidential trial.
Developments now unforeseen could, of course, make things worse for the President -- additional revelations about his conduct or indictments of close aides in the Lewinsky matter, for example. A more heavily Republican Senate could easily be in place for any final vote on impeachment.
Future developments could save him, too -- a foreign policy crisis, perhaps, or a major terrorist attack at home. His lawyers refused today to rule out the possibility of a deal with Congress that would lead to an early censure and head off any more protracted proceeding. Otherwise, the process that began today could last for months, and that is a very long time indeed in politics.
As he weighs his options, again and again, Mr. Clinton will have to ask himself: Survive on what terms, and to what end? He will still have Air Force One and the Marine Band, still meet with Congressional and foreign leaders, still have his political allies, unless he is impeached or resigns. But his moral leadership, that intangible legitimacy that makes a President a force in the country, has been shattered, and reconstituting it, after all that has happened, will be even harder than getting 34 votes in the Senate.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: News Analysis

HEADLINE: Can Remediation Plan Save CUNY?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While mayoral appointees on the City University of New York's board of trustees speak about steering students to the overburdened community colleges for remediation, this is just a sham (Editorial Observer, Sept. 7). Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has stated publicly that his next objective is to eliminate remediation there, too. Next step, privatization! 
 These politicians are on a dangerous path. We are witnessing a bankruptcy of constructive ideas and an inability to project the consequences of denying higher education to New Yorkers of modest or no means. New York requires an educated citizenry to flourish. Preventing people from going to school will have deleterious effects on New York and its economy.
 
EDITH B. EVERETT
New York, Sept. 8, 1998
 
The writer is a member of the CUNY board of trustees.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
ACHESON: The Secretary of State Who Created the American World, by James Chace. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) An engrossing biography of a public servant whose vision, self-confidence and personal integrity are still enshrined in international institutions and American attitudes.
 
DEATH IN SUMMER, by William Trevor. (Viking, $23.95.) The child of a man who has never known love is abducted by a woman who longs for love with something like madness in this novel by an author expert in malformations of the heart.
 
AN EMPIRE WILDERNESS: Travels Into America's Future, by Robert D. Kaplan. (Random House, $27.50.) A journalist traverses the West and foresees an America of corporate fortresses, guarded housing developments, increased auto dependence; he finds it "not so bleak." Thanks.
 
KAATERSKILL FALLS, by Allegra Goodman. (Dial, $23.95.) Little actually happens in this first novel, but the author discovers form and sensibility in the small excitements and grand rhythms of life in an Orthodox Jewish community.
 
LASSO THE WIND: Away to the New West, by Timothy Egan. (Knopf, $25.) Less an inquiry than a didactic tour, this heartfelt jeremiad by a national correspondent for The Times rages against dam builders, big ranchers, real estaters and the dead-hand legend of the Old West, with its chronicle of macho grabbing by the first comers.
 
MACKEREL BY MOONLIGHT, by William F. Weld. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) A political novel and a suspense novel (same novel) by the former Governor of Massachusetts that profits by formidable skill in deft and devious storytelling.
 
RULES OF THE WILD, by Francesca Marciano. (Pantheon, $23.) An impressive first novel whose heroine, a European come to Kenya for salvation, encounters instead a poisonous love affair and an incestuous community of competitive expatriates.
 
SALT WATER, by Charles Simmons. (Chronicle, $19.95.) A delicate, elegiac, regretful novel, by a former editor of this Book Review, in which boy meets girl and dad steals girl on an island off New England in the last enchanted summer of 1963.
 
THE SEEKERS: The Story of Man's Continuing Quest to Understand His World, by Daniel J. Boorstin. (Random House, $25.95.) A synoptic overview of the history of Western religion and philosophy that reminds us what history on the grand narrative scale looks like, by a former Librarian of Congress and formidable scholar, who has won most of the prizes historians can get.
 
THE TENNIS PARTNER: A Doctor's Story of Friendship and Loss, by Abraham Verghese. (HarperCollins, $25.) A wise, lyrical, controlled narrative about tennis, medicine and friendship and their spiritual costs and benefits.

PUB-DATE: September 13, 1998

SECTION: Section 2; Page 77; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 5380 words

HEADLINE: THE NEW SEASON/FILM;
THE ANNOTATED LISTINGS

BYLINE: BY STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
What follows is a selective list; all opening dates are for New York and are subject to change.
 
September
 
PERMANENT MIDNIGHT -- The sitcom writer Jerry Stahl's harrowing autobiography is one of the most candid (and darkly funny) memoirs of heroin addiction ever written. Its screen adaptation, directed by David Veloz, stars Ben Stiller as Mr. Stahl. Elizabeth Hurley is his ex-wife, Janeane Garofalo his agent and Maria Bello his new love. Wednesday. 

ONE TRUE THING -- A high-powered New York magazine journalist (Renee Zellweger) moves back in with her parents (Meryl Streep and William Hurt) to help care for her dying mother. Adapted from Anna Quindlen's best-selling novel and directed by Carl Franklin ("Devil in a Blue Dress"), it aspires to be an East Coast yuppie "Terms of Endearment," with restrained three-hankie performances from Ms. Streep and Ms. Zellweger. Friday.
RUSH HOUR -- Jackie Chan teams up with the comedian Chris Tucker (playing a rogue Los Angeles cop) to solve a kidnapping and avert an international crisis. Friday.
ESMERALDA COMES BY NIGHT The comic title character is a nurse with five husbands. Friday.
A SOLDIER'S DAUGHTER NEVER CRIES -- This Merchant-Ivory film, adapted from an autobiographical novel by Kaylie Jones, daughter of the novelist James Jones, is similar in spirit to the team's 1990 gem "Mr. and Mrs. Bridge." Divided into chapters, it depicts the author's family in Paris in the 1960's, then follows it back to the United States, where the children (Leelee Sobieski and Jesse Bradford) have difficulty adjusting to American teen-age life. Kris Kristofferson plays Bill Willis, the character based on Jones, and Barbara Hershey is his wife. Friday.
SHADRACH -- A middle-class boy (Scott Terra) growing up in Virginia during the Depression learns about life from his impoverished neighbors (Harvey Keitel and Andie MacDowell) and a 99-year-old former slave (John Franklin Sawyer) who returns from Alabama to die where he was born. Adapted from a William Styron short story by Susanna Styron, the author's daughter, and Bridget Terry; directed by Ms. Styron. Sept. 23.
THE LAST BIG THING -- Dan Zukovic wrote, directed and stars in a satire about the cult of celebrity and trash culture. As the editor of a nonexistent Los Angeles magazine, he conducts bogus interviews with a slew of second-rate actors, musicians and comedians. Sept. 23.
THE BRANDON TEENA STORY -- This true story about a young Nebraskan who was raped and murdered in 1993 after being revealed to be a woman won the best documentary prize at the Berlin Film Festival. Sept. 23.
PECKER -- In John Waters's latest camp frolic, Edward Furlong is a happy-go-lucky 18-year-old Baltimore sandwich-shop worker and amateur photographer whose candid snapshots of friends and family make him an art-world sensation. The movie's many oddball characters include his girlfriend (Christina Ricci), who runs a laundromat; his grandmother (Jean Schertler), who has conversations with a statue of the Virgin Mary, and an older sister (Martha Plimpton) who works in a gay strip joint. Sept. 25.
MONUMENT AVENUE --Ted Demme directed and Denis Leary and Ian Hart star in a violent drama about an Irish-American crime ring in Boston's Charlestown section. Sept. 25.
CLAY PIGEONS -- The dark comedy stars Joaquin Phoenix as a Montana gas-station attendant suspected of being a serial killer. With Vince Vaughn and Janeane Garofalo as an F.B.I. agent. Sept. 25.
LOLITA -- After much controversy, Adrian Lynes's film of the Nabokov classic finally makes it into theaters. Although it has its gauzy television-commercial moments, on the whole, it is remarkably faithful to the novel. Jeremy Irons's Humbert Humbert is the epitome of a doomed obsessional romantic, ravaged by desire, and Dominique's Swain's Lolita is even more impressive: a perfect hybrid of seductive scamp and wounded innocent. Sept. 25
RONIN -- This trickily plotted action thriller follows a bunch of former cold war spies through the streets of Paris in a desperate chase for a suitcase. John Frankenheimer directed. With Robert De Niro, Stellan Skarsgard and Jonathan Pryce. Sept. 25.
HIT ME -- In this film noir adapted from a Jim Thompson novel, a lonely bellhop's infatuation with a femme fatale means danger. With Elias Koteas and Laure Marsac. Sept. 25.
AFRICA'S ELEPHANT KINGDOM -- An IMAX spectacular about an elephant herd fleeing a drought. Sept. 26.
 
October
 
WELCOME TO WOOP WOOP -- Stephan Elliott ("Priscilla, Queen of the Desert") directed this camp comedy starring Johnathon Schaech as a New York con man who flees to Australia, where he is held prisoner in a nutty outback town whose boss decrees that no one can leave and that the local movie theater must show only Rodgers and Hammerstein musicals. October.
THE EXTREME ADVENTURES OF SUPER DAVE -- With Bob Einstein, Gia Carides and Don Lake. The legendary comic stuntman Super Dave Osborne comes out of retirement for one last time, to raise money for charity. Early October.
THE SWINDLE -- Claude Chabrol's comedy thriller stars Isabelle Huppert and Michel Serrault as con artists caught up in an international scandal. October.
LA SEPARATION -- In a psychological drama from France, Isabelle Huppert and Daniel Auteuil are a couple whose marriage disintegrates. Directed by Christian Vincent. Oct. 2.
BIKER DREAMS -- Adam Berman's documentary tells the history of Harley-Davidson motorcycles. Oct. 2.
ANTZ -- In the animation wars, Dreamworks' insect movie is beating Disney's ("A Bug's Life") to market. This entomological fantasy features a lowly worker ant named Z (the voice of Woody Allen), who is determined to win the love of the beautiful Princess Bala (Sharon Stone) and enlists his best friend (Sylvester Stallone) in his campaign. Oct. 2.
DEE SNIDER'S STRANGE LAND -- Twisted Sister's lead singer is a maniac who meets his victims in an on-line chat room. Horror. Oct. 2.
A NIGHT AT THE ROXBURY -- Another "Saturday Night Live" spinoff. The world's uncoolest party animals, Steve (Will Ferrell) and Doug (Chris Kattan) Butabi, find themselves in the hippest of all Los Angeles nightclubs, the Roxbury. Oct. 2.
WHAT DREAMS MAY COME -- After Robin Williams dies in a car crash and goes to heaven, his wife (Annabella Sciorra) commits suicide and goes to hell. Cuba Gooding Jr. is the angel who helps him find her. Adapted from a novel by Richard Matheson, it all sounds terribly icky, but then so did the plots of such inspirational crowd-pleasers as "Ghost" and "City of Angels." Oct. 2.
SLAM -- Winner of the grand jury prize at Sundance, where it was a big crowd pleaser, this is the story of a Washington rapper and poet (Saul Williams) who is arrested on a petty drug charge and sent to prison, where he is saved by an inspirational writing teacher (Sonja Sohn). Likely to give a major lift to the poetry slam, that competitive hybrid of standup comedy, rap, performance art and literature that has developed into a national movement. Oct. 7.
HOLY MAN -- Will Eddie Murphy continue the winning streak of "The Nutty Professor" and "Dr. Dolittle"? Here, he is a televangelist hired by the money-losing Good Buy Shopping Network to hawk the most outlandish assortment of gimmicky doodads, and ratings skyrocket. With Jeff Goldblum as the manager of the network. Oct. 9.
SIX-STRING SAMURAI -- A post-apocalyptic rock-and-roll fantasy set in Las Vegas. Oct. 9.
THE IMPOSTORS -- Stanley Tucci directed and stars with Oliver Platt in a comedy about two actors who stow away on a cruise ship. Oct. 9.
ONE TOUGH COP -- This crime drama based on the autobiography of the former New York police officer Bo Dietl (Stephen Baldwin) explores a heinous 1981 crime and a policeman's conflicting loyalties. With Chris Penn, Gina Gershon and Michael McGlone. Oct. 9.
DETROIT 9000 -- A re-release of the well-regarded 1972 blaxploitation film starring Alex Rocco and Hari Rhodes. Oct. 9.
PRACTICAL MAGIC -- Sandra Bullock and Nicole Kidman are witches afflicted with a family curse: any man who falls in love with them will die young. The sisters live with two eccentric aunts (Dianne Wiest and Stockard Channing). Trouble arrives when the more reckless of the sisters falls in love with a violent drifter (Goran Visnjic). Griffin Dunne directed. Oct. 9.
T-REX: BACK TO THE CRETACEOUS -- An IMAX trip back to the age of dinosaurs. Oct. 9.
THE CELEBRATION -- In this black comedy, which won the special jury prize at Cannes, a prosperous Danish family gathers to celebrate its patriarch's 60th birthday. As his three grown children tear at one another, the other guests are exposed to some ugly family secrets. Oct. 9.
THE INHERITORS -- A misanthropic Austrian farmer in the 1930's dies, bequeathing his estate to seven peasants. Oct. 9.
THE MIGHTY -- Two adolescent outcasts -- one big, gawky and slow in school (Elden Henson), the other a tiny scientific genius in leg braces (Kieran Culkin) -- form an unlikely alliance to perform heroic deeds worthy of King Arthur's court. Sharon Stone is the mother of the genius. Oct. 16.
RUDOLPH -- This animated story of Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer features the voices of John Goodman, Eric Idle, Bob Newhart, Debbie Reynolds, Richard Simmons and Whoopi Goldberg. Oct. 16.
THE ALARMIST -- A naive door-to-door peddler of home-security devices (David Arquette) learns about the dark side of salesmanship from his unscrupulous boss (Stanley Tucci). Based on Keith Reddin's play "Life During Wartime." Oct. 16.
BELOVED -- Directed by Jonathan Demme, with a cast headed by Oprah Winfrey and Danny Glover, the screen adaptation of the Toni Morrison novel is this season's ne plus ultra of high-minded literary adaptations. In the first movie in which she has received top billing, Ms. Winfrey plays a former slave in Ohio who is literally haunted by the child she murdered. Oct. 16.
BRIDE OF CHUCKY -- The fourth installment of the "Child's Play" horror series stars Jennifer Tilly and Brad Dourif. Oct. 16.
APT PUPIL -- When a high-school student (Brad Renfro) discovers that a Nazi war criminal (Ian McKellen) has been secretly living in his hometown, he blackmails him into describing the atrocities he committed. Based on a Stephen King novella. Oct. 16.
HAPPINESS -- A pitch-black comic satire by Todd Solondz about the search for personal happiness in a New Jersey suburb finds only boredom, depression, vicious sibling rivalry, soul-deadening work, despair, suicide, murder and pedophilia under the bland, chirpy surface of its characters' lives. The scenes involving a pedophilic psychiatrist (Dylan Baker) with a picture-perfect "Leave It to Beaver" family don't just push the envelope; they rip it open. Oct. 16.
HOME FRIES -- Drew Barrymore is a small-town girl who is pregnant by a man whose whose dead body has been found in a field and who turns out to have been married. Catherine O'Hara is the dead man's scheming widow and Luke Wilson her son from a previous marriage, who falls in love with Ms. Barrymore. A dark romantic comedy. Oct. 23.
ORGAZMO -- A hunky but pious Mormon has a secret life as pornography superhero. Everything is fine until his fiancee finds out. Directed by Trey Parker, a creator of the television series "South Park." Oct. 23.THE CRUISE -- Documentary about New York City observed through the eyes of an eccentric tour-bus guide. Oct. 23.
PLEASANTVILLE -- Two contemporary teen-agers enter the squeaky-clean world of a black-and-white 50's sitcom and teach the innocent cardboard 50's characters about sex and rock-and-roll. As the townspeople learn to feel, they change from black and white into color. More delicate and moodier than "The Truman Show," which it resembles. With Tobey Maguire, Jeff Daniels, Reese Witherspoon and Joan Allen as an ideal, quintessentially repressed 50's housewife. Oct. 23.
LIFE IS BEAUTIFUL -- The Italian comic star Robert Benigni takes on Hitler and the Holocaust in a Chaplinesque serio-comedy that begins lightly, then acquires deepening layers of pathos when a childlike clown played by Mr. Benigni is deported to a concentration camp with his wife and young son. To shield his son from the reality of what's happening, he convinces the boy that it's only a game and goes to great lengths to explain the surrounding horrors. Winner of the grand jury prize at the Cannes Film Festival. Oct. 23.
SOLDIER -- Kurt Russell and Jason Scott Lee star in an action-adventure space western directed by Paul Anderson ("Mortal Kombat"). Oct. 23.
THE LAST DAYS -- James Moll's film examines the lives of five Hungarian survivors of the Holocaust. Even when facing imminent defeat, Hitler brought the Holocaust to Hungary, which then had the largest remaining Jewish population. In just 60 days, 425,000 Hungarian Jews were deported and killed. Oct. 23.
RAZOR BLADE SMILE -- Campy vampiric horror. Oct. 24.
AMERICAN HISTORY X -- Edward Norton is a former skinhead who wants to turn his brother (Edward Furlong) away from a life of bigotry and hate. Directed by Tony Kaye. Oct. 30.
TALK OF ANGELS -- Based on a novel by Kate O'Brien, this romantic drama set on the eve of the Spanish Civil War stars Polly Walker as an Irish convent girl who takes a job as a governess in Spain. She falls in love with her employers' married, politically radical son (Vincent Perez). Oct. 30.
LIVING OUT LOUD -- Holly Hunter is a lonely Park Avenue divorcee and Danny DeVito an elevator operator with whom she develops a friendship that leans toward romance. With Queen Latifah, who displays a fine torch-singing voice. Richard LaGravenese wrote and directed. Oct. 30.
A LITTLE BIT OF SOUL -- Australian medical researchers financed by a powerful mystery man look for anti-aging formula. With Geoffrey Rush and Frances O'Connor. Oct. 30.
JOHN CARPENTER'S VAMPIRES -- The horror director takes on vampires in a story (based on a novel by John Steakley) that sends a vampire hunter portrayed by James Woods into the desert on a mission of destruction. Oct. 30.
 
November
 
A SIMPLE PLAN -- The discovery of $4 million in cash at the site of a crashed airplane changes the quiet lives of the rural people who find it. With Bill Paxton, Billy Bob Thornton and Bridget Fonda. November.
SHATTERED IMAGE -- Another surreal psychological thriller by the art-film director Raoul Ruiz. November.
A LETTER FROM DEATH ROW -- A suspense thriller written, directed and scored by Bret Michaels, lead singer of the rock band Poison. November.
DRY CLEANING -- Anne Fontaine directed this disturbing French film about owners of dry-cleaning establishment whose lives are transformed after they watch a brother-and-sister transvestite act at a gay bar in their sedate hometown. They decide to experiment sexually and adopt the androgynously seductive brother (Stanislas Merhar) as a surrogate son, an employee and a lover. Reminiscent of Joseph Losey's "The Servant." November.
SUE -- A young New York woman (Anna Thomson) loses her secretarial job and her apartment and moves into a seedy hotel. Directed by Amos Kollek. November.
PORT DJEMA -- Eric Heumann won the best-director prize at the Berlin Film Festival for this drama set in an imaginary East African country that is visited by a Parisian surgeon in search of a lost child. November.
BELLY -- The rap lyricist Nas and the rap star DMX play childhood friends with clashing goals. Nov. 4.
GODS AND MONSTERS -- Acclaimed at Sundance, this adaptation of Christopher Bram's novel "Father of Frankenstein" is a fictionalized account of the last days of the openly gay James Whale, who directed the horror classic "Bride of Frankenstein." Ian McKellen is Whale, Lynn Redgrave his housekeeper and Brendan Fraser a young man on whom he develops a fixation. Nov. 4.
RIVER RED -- An abusive father, a parricide and a chain of consequences, set in rural New Hampshire. With Tom Everett Scott and David Moscow. Nov. 6.
THE BIG CHILL -- Re-release of the hit 1983 film about a reunion of 60's idealists. Nov. 6.
ELIZABETH -- This elegant 16th-century costume drama re-tells the story of the brilliant and politically canny English ruler who was crowned at the age of 25. Cate Blanchett stars. With Geoffrey Rush, Kathy Burke, Joseph Fiennes, Richard Attenborough, Christopher Eccleston and John Gielgud. Nov. 6.
THE WATERBOY -- Adam Sandler is a former water boy who wins a college athletic scholarship and wreaks comic havoc in and out of the classroom. Nov. 6.
I'LL BE HOME FOR CHRISTMAS -- Jonathan Taylor Thomas finds himself stranded in the desert in a Santa suit. He hitchhikes home. Nov. 6.
WAKING NED DEVINE -- A comic fable set in an impoverished Irish village, one of whose residents wins a lottery. With Ian Bannen and David Kelly. Nov. 6.
VELVET GOLDMINE -- A rock-and-roll fantasy that borrows its style from Fassbinder and its story from "Citizen Kane," this film is a fictionalized history of 1970's glam rock by the gifted director Todd Haynes ("Safe"). The central figure is a bisexual, David Bowie-like superstar (Jonathan Rhys Meyers) whose career plummets after he fakes his own assassination onstage. Ewan McGregor is his Iggy Pop-like cohort. Nov. 6.
JACK FROST -- A year after the title character (Michael Keaton), a musician on the verge of stardom, dies in a car crash, he returns to earth as a snowman built by his young son Charlie (Joseph Cross). Nov. 6.
THE SIEGE -- Bruce Willis is a United States Army general in a political thriller about terrorism on the streets of New York and a declaration of martial law. With Denzel Washington and Annette Bening. Nov. 6.
CELEBRITY -- No one knows better than Woody Allen the rewards and punishments of fame. And no one is better equipped to find new levels of humor in its pleasures and frustrations. The surest sign that the movie might be a high-water mark in Mr. Allen's career is its selection as the New York Film Festival's opening-night movie. The cast includes Kenneth Branagh, Judy Davis, Leonardo DiCaprio, Melanie Griffith, Joe Mantegna and Winona Ryder. Nov. 13.
DANCING AT LUGHNASA -- This adaptation of the Brian Friel play contemplates the unraveling of a tightly knit Irish Catholic family that includes five unmarried sisters (and the illegitimate son of one of them). The tensions escalate when their only brother (Michael Gambon), who has been doing missionary work in Africa, returns to the fold during an annual festival that's linked to a pagan deity (the year is 1936). With Meryl Streep, Brid Brennan, Catherine McCormack, Sophie Thompson and Kathy Burke. Nov. 13.
MEET JOE BLACK -- Reputed to be the most expensive romantic drama ever filmed, this supernatural romance updates the 1930's Hollywood classic "Death Takes a Holiday," starring Frederic March. Death assumes the form of a recently killed young man (Brad Pitt) to find out why he scares people, and discovers the joys of life and love (with Claire Forlani). Anthony Hopkins is his sweetheart's businessman father. The "Touched by an Angel" syndrome strikes again. Martin Brest ("Scent of a Woman") directed. Nov. 13.
A BUG'S LIFE -- With Pixar animation, the Disney movie further extends the animation technology of "Toy Story." A misfit ant tries to save his colony from a gang of evil grasshoppers, but his ineffectual troops turn out to be the motley refugees of a flea circus in need of mobilization. John Lasseter ("Toy Story") directed with Andrew Stanton. Many celebrity voices. Nov. 20.
THE RUGRATS MOVIE -- A Pickles family adventure spun off from the popular series on the Nickelodeon cable network. Nov. 20.
BLOOD, GUTS, BULLETS
AND OCTANE -- Word of mouth on John Carnahan's no-budget road movie is enthusiastic. Nov. 20
CENTRAL STATION -- A young boy (Vinicius de Oliveira) whose mother is killed in front of Rio de Janeiro's Central Station is befriended by a former schoolteacher (Fernanda Montenegro), who returns him to his father in northeastern Brazil. During the rugged journey, their distaste for each other melts into love. Winner of the best film award at the Berlin festival. Nov. 20.
SAVIOR -- In this antiwar drama, Dennis Quaid plays an American mercenary fighting in Serbia who saves the life of an orphaned newborn baby. With Nastassja Kinski and Stellan Skarsgard. Nov. 20.
I STILL KNOW WHAT YOU DID LAST SUMMER -- Mayhem begins in the sequel to last year's teen horror blockbuster when Julie James (Jennifer Love Hewitt) and three friends visit the Bahamas on an all-expenses-paid trip. Nov. 20.
AT FIRST SIGHT -- Irwin Winkler directed the romantic drama based on a true story about a New York City architect (Mira Sorvino) who falls in love with a blind masseur (Val Kilmer) and persuades him to undergo experimental surgery that will restore his sight. The surgery succeeds but. . . . Nov. 20.
VERY BAD THINGS -- The directorial debut of the "Chicago Hope" actor Peter Berg is a savage comedy about a bachelor party in Las Vegas that takes a deadly turn when a prostitute is accidentally killed during sex. The paranoia, deception and violence escalate, turning buddies against one another. A scathing satire on male bonding, sibling rivalry and empty suburban values. Cameron Diaz is a selfish bride who won't let anything stand in the way of her wedding, and Christian Slater a demonic real-estate salesman with a solution for every problem. Nov. 25.
BABE: PIG IN THE CITY -- The sheep-herding Australian porker who seduced the world three years ago is back, this time oinking into the city to try to bail out Boss Hoggett's debt-ridden farm. Nov. 25.
ENEMY OF THE STATE -- Will Smith and Gene Hackman star in a Jerry Bruckheimer-produced drama about a rising young lawyer whose career is derailed when he is framed for murder by a corrupt intelligence official. Nov. 25.
 
December
 
SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE -- The young William Shakespeare (Joseph Fiennes), suffering from writer's block in the middle of creating an early play, falls madly in love with Viola (Gwyneth Paltrow), an aspiring performer who disguises herself as a man to audition. Out of his sudden passion comes "Romeo and Juliet." Tom Stoppard wrote the screenplay with Marc Norman. With Colin Firth, Ben Affleck and Judi Dench. Dec. 4.
PSYCHO -- Why would the hot director Gus Van Sant ("Good Will Hunting") want to remake Alfred Hitchcock's kinky horror classic, especially when the new version uses Joseph Stefano's original screenplay and Bernard Herrmann's score (dressed up by Danny Elfman)? Why should he choose the beefy Vince Vaughn to fill spindly Tony Perkins's quivering shoes? There must be a reason. With Anne Heche in the shower. Dec. 4.
STAR TREK: INSURRECTION -- Traveling to a planet that is a fountain of youth, Captain Picard (Patrick Stewart) stumbles into an intergalactic conspiracy. The ninth film in the "Star Trek" series should be a hit just like its predecessors. Dec. 11.
LITTLE VOICE -- In a town in northern England, a reclusive young woman (Jane Horrocks) who barely speaks has developed the uncanny ability to reproduce the recorded sounds of vintage pop singers. She finds her soul mate in an equally shy telephone engineer (Ewan McGregor). When her sister (Brenda Blethyn) and a sleazy local talent agent (Michael Caine) decide they can make millions on her gift, she reluctantly decides to go public. Dec. 11.
THE GENERAL -- John Boorman directed this biographical drama about the notorious Irish gangster Martin Cahill (Brendan Gleeson), who was shot dead by the Irish Republican Army on the eve of the 1994 cease-fire. Dec. 18.
MIGHTY JOE YOUNG -- Another mega-beast is resuscitated from Hollywood's B-movie past to go on a rampage, this time through the streets of Los Angeles. With Bill Paxton and Charlize Theron. Dec. 18.
PRINCE OF EGYPT -- Much is riding on the fortunes of Dreamworks' Christmas entry into the animation sweepstakes. The sweeping family-style epic tells the story of Moses (voice of Val Kilmer) and Ramses (Ralph Fiennes). Stephen Schwartz ("Pocahontas") wrote its six songs. Other voices include Sandra Bullock, Danny Glover, Jeff Goldblum, Steve Martin, Helen Mirren, Michelle Pfeiffer, Martin Short and Patrick Stewart. Dec. 18.
DANCING ABOUT ARCHITECTURE -- An all-star cast portrays a cross-section of Los Angelenos observed in various stages of romantic entanglement. With Gillian Anderson, Ellen Burstyn, Sean Connery, Anthony Edwards, Angelina Jolie, Jay Mohr, Ryan Phillippe, Dennis Quaid, Gena Rowlands, Jon Stewart and Madeleine Stowe. Directed by Willard Carroll. Dec. 18.
YOU'VE GOT MAIL -- "Sleepless in Seattle" redux. Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan unite again under the directorial baton of Nora Ephron, but this time they're in New York. He owns a bookstore super-chain and she runs a small children's bookstore his behemoth wants to devour. Naturally, when they meet anonymously in cyberspace, they fall in love. Expect charm, but not much depth. Dec. 18.
AFFLICTION -- Paul Schrader's powerful film is an uncompromising adaptation of a bleak Russell Banks novel set in an economically depressed town in northern New Hampshire. As a police officer (Nick Nolte) copes with grave domestic problems, he becomes increasingly unstrung, venting years of pent-up anger at his abusive father (James Coburn). The movie is cast in a dark-blue winter light, and the performances by Mr. Nolte, Sissy Spacek and Mary Beth Hurt go for the jugular. Dec. 20.
PATCH ADAMS -- Robin Williams's title character is a former mental patient who discovers the healing power of humor and brings his theories to medical school, where he plays the class clown. Dec. 25.
THE WIZARD OF OZ -- The theatrical re-release of the 1939 family classic starring Judy Garland, enhanced with digitally restored and re-mastered sound and other technical improvements. Dec. 25.
THE FACULTY -- "Clueless" meets "Invasion of the Body Snatchers" in this special-effects-laden science-fiction horror film; from a screenplay by Kevin Williamson, who wrote "Scream" and "Scream 2." With Elijah Wood, Laura Harris and Josh Harnett. Dec. 25.
HURLYBURLY -- David Rabe's powerful satiric evisceration of ranting, cocaine-fueled Hollywood machismo was an off-Broadway hit in 1984. Now it's a movie with Sean Penn, Kevin Spacey, Meg Ryan, Garry Shandling, Chazz Palminteri, Anna Paquin and Robin Wright Penn. The epithets fly fast and furious. Dec. 25.
A CIVIL ACTION -- John Travolta stars in this drama based on Jonathan Harr's best-selling nonfiction account of a lawyer, Jan Sclichtmann, who spent nearly a decade fighting two corporations he believed responsible for toxic pollution that affected eight families in a Boston suburb. Directed by Steven Zaillian. With Robert Duvall, Kathleen Quinlan and Kathy Bates. Dec. 25.
THE THIN RED LINE -- World War II strikes again, this time from the pen of James Jones (it's an adaptation of his 1962 novel) by way of Terrence Malick, the esteemed director ("Badlands," "Days of Heaven") who is emerging from two decades of retirement. But will the 1942 Battle of Guadalcanal play as well as the D-Day invasion did in Steven Spielberg's "Saving Private Ryan"? With Sean Penn, John Cusack, Adrien Brody, Jim Caviezel, Ben Chaplin, Elias Koteas, Dash Minok, Nick Nolte, Bill Pullman, Larry Romano and John Travolta. Dec. 25.
THEORY OF FLIGHT -- Kenneth Branagh is a frustrated artist who has a run-in with the law and is sentenced to perform 120 hours of community service. Helena Bonham Carter is the crusty wheelchair-bound caretaker of the establishment to which he is directed. Dec. 25.
DOWN IN THE DELTA -- The directorial debut of the poet Maya Angelou tells the story of Rosa Lynn (Mary Alice), a grandmother who pawns a valuable heirloom to move the family from the mean streets of Chicago back to the ancestral home in the Mississippi Delta. Alfre Woodard is her troubled daughter and Mpho Koaho and Kulani Hassen her grandchildren.With Al Freeman Jr., Esther Rolle, Loretta Devine and Wesley Snipes. Dec. 25.
STEPMOM -- When it comes to high-toned suds, this serious comedy has the field pretty much to itself. Susan Sarandon is a divorced wife who loathes her husband's new girlfriend (Julia Roberts) but turns to her for help when illness strikes. The cat fights turn into a weepy love-in. No one can beat Ms. Sarandon in projecting nobility, and both stars have those larger-than-life dreamy eyes you can get lost in. Dec. 25.
HILLARY AND JACKIE -- In this harsh psychological drama based on real people, Emily Watson ("Breaking the Waves") is the famous cellist Jacqueline du Pre and Rachel Griffiths the estranged sister with whom she reconciles after developing a disabling illness. Expect a mininum of disease-of-the-week sentimentality and a maximum of venomous sibling conflict. Late December.
Early 1999 and Beyond --
THE ASTRONAUT'S WIFE -- With Johnny Depp and Charlize Theron. Directed by Rand Ravich. No matter what, the chameleonlike Mr. Depp will stretch his formidable talents. March 12.
AUSTIN POWERS II -- With Mike Myers and Heather Graham. Diehard 60's swingers never die, they just get nuttier. And that's groovy. June 11.
BLAST FROM THE PAST -- Future shock. Brendan Fraser plays a man reared in a bomb shelter who emerges after 30 years to search for a wife and discovers a world that has changed so much, it is almost unrecognizable. With Alicia Silverstone, Sissy Spacek and Christopher Walken. Feb. 12.
CONDO PAINTING -- A portrait of the New York artist George Condo includes the last recorded interviews with the Beat legends William Burroughs and Allen Ginsberg.
THE DEEP END OF THE OCEAN -- With Michelle Pfeiffer, Treat Williams, Whoopi Goldberg and Lucinda Jenney. Directed by Ulu Grosbard. Feb.22.
THE DREAM LIFE OF ANGELS -- The movie for which Elodie Bouchez and Natacha Regnier shared the best-actress award at Cannes, it explores the deepening bond between two women of opposite temperament and background. Ms. Bouchez is an exuberant vagabond, and Ms. Regnier a moody introvert The directorial debut of Erick Zonca.
ED TV -- Romantic comedy directed by Ron Howard about a man who unknowingly lets his life be chronicled on live television. With Matthew McConaughey, Jenna Elfman, Ellen DeGeneres, Woody Harrelson, Elizabeth Hurley, Sally Kirkland and Martin Landau. "The Truman Show" redux? March 19.
8MM -- With Nicolas Cage, Joaquin Phoenix and Catherine Keener. Directed by Joel Schumacher.
EYES WIDE SHUT -- At last the years-in-the-making top-secret Stanley Kubrick-directed psychological drama starring Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman.
THE FOOL ON THE HILL -- With Jim Carrey. The title says it all.
GLORIA -- With Sharon Stone, Gena Rowlands and George C. Scott. Directed by Sidney Lumet.
A HARD DAY'S NIGHT -- Re-release of the Beatles' 1964 screen debut, with restored scenes. March.
MOD SQUAD -- Another television golden oldie finds new life in the movies. With Claire Danes, Josh Brolin and Giovanni Ribisi. March.
STAR WARS EPISODE ONE -- With Liam Neeson, Natalie Portman and Ewan McGregor. Directed by George Lucas. The prequel to the "Star Wars" trilogy is a guaranteed blockbuster. May 21.
IN DREAMS -- With Annette Bening, Aidan Quinn and Robert Downey Jr. Directed by Neil Jordan.
ISN'T SHE GREAT -- Bette Midler portrays Jacqueline Susann, the "Valley of the Dolls" author, and Nathan Lane is her husband and manager, Irving Mansfield. Written by Paul Rudnick and directed by Andrew Bergman.
THE LEAGUE -- With Al Pacino and Dennis Quaid. Directed by Oliver Stone.
MESSAGE IN A BOTTLE -- With Kevin Costner, Paul Newman and Robin Wright Penn. A love story filmed amid the world of sailing off the coast of Maine.
SNOW FALLING ON CEDARS -- With Ethan Hawke, James Cromwell, Max von Sydow and Youki Koudoh. Scott Hicks directs this adaptation of David Guterson's novel about a Japanese man in the Pacific Northwest who is unjustly accused of murder. Feb. 19.
TOWN AND COUNTRY -- With Warren Beatty, Diane Keaton and Goldie Hawn. Directed by Peter Chelsom.
TRUE CRIME -- With Clint Eastwood, James Woods and Diane Venora.
24-HOUR WOMAN -- Rosie Perez is a high-powered television producer whose life changes drastically with the birth of her first child. Directed by Nancy Savoca.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 815 words

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Bombings Cast a Shadow On East African Tourism

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE bombings at the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania have frightened away travelers from East Africa just as Kenya was hoping for an end to a years-old slump in foreign tourism, and as Tanzania was finally beginning to reap the benefits from a major investment in the travel industry.
Tour operators who specialize in travel in Kenya and Tanzania, which boast some of Africa's best game parks and sunniest beaches, say there have been no mass cancellations as a result of the Aug. 7 Embassy bombings in Nairobi, the Kenyan capital, and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, which left more than 250 people dead. 
 But they report a number of worried calls from prospective travelers, many of them alarmed by the possibility of more terrorist attacks in the region. "People have been calling, and we've been reassuring them that we don't see further problems," said Mary Mkimbo, a spokeswoman in New York for the Kenya Tourist Office.
The State Department, which does not want to see Kenya and Tanzania punished economically as a result of terrorist attacks that were clearly targeted at the United States, has lifted dire travel warnings issued just after the bombings that urged Americans to stay away from the countries. New public announcements put out on Aug. 13 suggest only that Americans "exercise caution" when visiting Kenya and Tanzania.
Embassy employees in both cities have gone back to work, although in new locations. The bombed-out Embassy in Nairobi is expected to be demolished after the F.B.I. has finished gathering evidence. The embassy in Dar es Salaam suffered less damage from the blast, although it, too, may have to be razed. For now, the State Department says, Embassy employees can offer only emergency consular service.
Foreign visitors to Nairobi and Dar es Salaam since the bombings have noted a reassuringly heavy presence of both police and soldiers on the streets of the two capitals. Crew-cut F.B.I. agents fill many of the luxury hotels in the two cities.
Western diplomats and intelligence officials say there is no reason to believe that terrorists affiliated with Osama bin Laden, the exiled Saudi millionaire who is accused of organizing the Embassy bombings, plan to strike again soon in either country.
Still, the televised images of the charred hulks of the American Embassy buildings will likely haunt the travel industry in East Africa for years. "The tourism industry is very sensitive to the news media," said Ms. Mkimbo. "We do expect a little downward movement in the industry."
The tourism industry in Kenya has been troubled for years -- in part because of the opening of new safari destinations in South Africa, in part because of Nairobi's well-deserved reputation for street crime. Tourism industry revenues reportedly dropped to $300 million last year, down from $450 million the year before.
The Government has responded to the slump with a series of actions to lure tourists back, including a marked improvement in the service of Kenya Airways, the national airline, which has gone into partnership with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines. The bombing will doubtless set back those efforts.
Tourism has never been so well-developed an industry in neighboring Tanzania, which is home to Mt. Kilimanjaro, the magnificent wildlife of Serengeti National Park and the exotic island of Zanzibar.
But the lack of infrastructure has worked to Tanzania's advantage in recent years given the dramatic growth in the number of adventure travelers who are willing, even eager to go without the five-star safari resorts that Kenya offers. The number of visitors to Tanzania jumped from fewer than 100,000 in 1980 to more than 300,000 last year, prompting the Government to improve roads needed for safari tours.
"Tanzania has just been underdeveloped for years, and they're beginning to develop it now," said Jalal Ebrahim, president of Safaricentre International, a tour operator in Manhattan Beach, Calif. "There were fewer people in the parks in Tanzania, and that's what attracted visitors. It was more pristine."
Mr. Ebrahim, whose company has been sending American travelers on East African safaris for 13 years, said that his company had received only one cancellation as a result of the embassy bombings -- and that he did not expect many more.
"We had one cancellation from a couple who decided they were just going to wait and see what happened," he said. "Our clients are adventure travelers and most of them are very savvy. They read a lot, they stay on top of world events." They understand, he said, that increasingly terrorism knows no borders.
The United States Embassy in Nairobi is now operating out of the offices of the Agency for International Development on The Crescent, in the neighborhood of Nairobi known as the Parklands; (254-2) 751-613. The Embassy in Dar es Salaam is at 285 Toure Drive; (255-51) 666-015.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 48; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2978 words

HEADLINE: His Debut as a Woman

BYLINE: By Andrew Jacobs; Andrew Jacobs is a reporter for the Metro section of The Times. This is his first article for the magazine.

 BODY:
David Buechner darts around his Upper West Side apartment consumed by that prosaic ritual known as spring cleaning. Few domestic chores carry as much metaphoric heft -- casting off winter's accumulated dust and detritus, embracing renewal and rebirth -- but for the 39-year-old classical pianist, the task has been especially symbolic. Strewn beneath the Steinway grand that fills the living room are piles of tailored Italian suits, unassuming cashmere sweaters and a lifetime's worth of ties, all bound for the Salvation Army. In a newly purged closet, arranged according to hue, hang the season's latest acquisitions: a summery frilled blouse, a plum chiffon dress, a black Chanel gown and dozens of off-the-rack dresses. "I guess this is what they mean when they say 'coming out of the closet,' " cracks Buechner with a weary smile.
This week, when he plays a pair of Chopin concertos at Manhattan's Good Shepherd Presbyterian Church, Buechner will not be wearing the traditional tails and bow tie. Dressed in a white silk gown and matching pumps, hair flowing past the shoulders, the pianist will be introduced as Sara Davis Buechner, making him surely the nation's first concert pianist to undergo a midcareer sex change. 
 After three decades wrestling with his gender, bouts of heavy drinking, a failed marriage and flirtations with suicide, Buechner decided in 1996 to embrace his true self. Last year he began taking estrogen, plunged into a grueling regimen of electrolysis and started to venture out dressed as a woman. "To me, the choice was simple," Buechner says. "Live as Sara or give up on living."
The winner of a dozen international piano competitions, Buechner has earned a place in the classical music world with an eclectic repertory, dizzying technical prowess and a flashy performing style that a British critic once described as "saucy." He has played solo with the world's most prestigious orchestras, including the New York Philharmonic, the National Symphony in Washington, the Japan Philharmonic and the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra in England. He is also a prolific recording artist who has taken on the works of Mozart, Gershwin, Dvorak and the film composer Miklos Rozsa.
Although Buechner had hoped to control the timing of his public coming out, the rumor mill, churning at a furious pace, accelerated the process last spring and forced him to confront the thorny issues sooner than expected. Even those closest to him say they were completely unaware of his secret. Known for a vigorous -- some might call it aggressive -- playing style, a penchant for cigars and a devotion to the Yankees, Buechner was what one friend calls "a guy's guy," a wisecracking, backslapping bon vivant who frequently had a pretty girl by his side. "When David told me what he was going to do, I just assumed he was joking and waited for the punch line," says his longtime manager Douglas Schwalbe. "Needless to say, it came as quite a shock." In retrospect, Buechner recognizes the hypermasculine behavior as a way of masking feminine feelings, saying, "I was desperately trying to fit in, to play the role people expected."
Even in an age when drag queens like RuPaul achieve mainstream status and cross-dressing films like "Tootsie," "Mrs. Doubtfire" and "Priscilla, Queen of the Desert" win Academy Awards and public affection, Buechner's high-profile transformation is a decidedly risky one. As word of his gender reassignment spread through the close-knit classical music world, Buechner, who now asks to be referred to as female, began to endure a string of rejections; seven universities turned her down for full-time positions, she claims, after learning that they would be hiring Sara, not David. Her fall concert schedule, usually packed with appearances from Tampa to Sacramento, is thinner than usual. "Let's face it," says JoAnn Falletta, a friend who conducts the Buffalo Philharmonic, Virginia Symphony and Long Beach Symphony in California, "this is a conservative business based on 18th- and 19th-century traditions. I'm not sure the boards who run America's orchestras are ready for Sara."
Although few states or institutions prohibit discrimination against transgendered people, those who decided not to hire Buechner say it had nothing to do with the sex change. "David Buechner is a brilliant pianist, but when you're talking about a tenured teaching position, there are other factors to consider," says Bernard Dobroski, dean of Northwestern University's School of Music. He declined to elaborate, citing the confidentiality of the selection process. Others simply refused to comment.
Some have hinted that Buechner's decision to orchestrate the coming out with the help of a publicist suggests an awareness of its career-boosting potential, a way of rising above the crowd. It is an accusation that fills her with rage. "Why would I ruin friendships and devastate my family for some dubious gain?" she says. "It just goes to show you how cynical and bitter the classical music world is." In fact, Buechner was so convinced her career would implode that she considered taking a teaching job at a Rumanian conservatory "until the bad press blows over."
To her surprise, however, things have not been as disastrous as anticipated. Both New York University and the Manhattan School of Music, where Buechner teaches, agreed to keep her on, as did Yamaha, the company that provides her concert pianos in exchange for publicity. "As long as it doesn't affect his playing, it makes no difference to us," says Susan Davies Muhler, of Yamaha's artist services department.
If anything, Buechner says her playing has improved since she first sat at the keyboard a year ago dressed as Sara (a name she has coveted since childhood). "I was emotionally tied up in knots and completely disconnected from what was coming out of the piano," she says. "Now when I play, I feel incredibly free, and I think that's reflected in the music." Moreover, the paralyzing stage fright and the bleeding ulcers have vanished since Sara came into being. Friends, too, say that Buechner seems happier than ever. "It's as if she has nothing left to prove," says Jens Nygaard, a longtime friend who conducts the Jupiter Symphony, based in New York. "The anguish seems to have been lifted."
It has been more than 45 years since George Jorgensen emerged from an operating room as Christine and shocked Eisenhower's America. Since then, thousands of men and women suffering from what psychiatrists call gender dysphoria, a profound discomfort with one's sex, have undergone surgery. According to the International Foundation for Gender Education, more than 1,500 Americans surgically alter their genitals each year, and countless others live in various states of gender nonconformity. The so-called transgendered community includes intersexed individuals (also known as hermaphrodites), full-time transsexuals who have no interest in surgery and others who simply cross-dress in private.
For the most part, Americans continue to view such individuals with a mix of curiosity, incredulity and revulsion. In a study conducted last year by Gender PAC, a national advocacy group for gender rights, nearly 60 percent of the transgendered people surveyed said they had been violently assaulted, often by two or more attackers. "RuPaul is funny as long as she stays in a television studio," says Riki Anne Wilchins, the group's executive director. "But try walking to the subway and she'll be a grease spot on the sidewalk before she makes it home."
Although the number of transgendered men and women is thought to be about equal, far more men -- at least 75 percent -- seek sex-change operations, a reflection of the imperfect state of female-to-male surgery. A complete mastectomy can result in significant scarring, and building a penis out of forearm tissue remains risky, says Dr. Sheila Kirk, a transsexual obstetrician-gynecologist who runs a transgender surgical clinic in Pittsburgh. "Most F-to-M's I know live in limbo, a state of endless anxiety about being incomplete," says Jamison Green, who runs F.T.M. International in San Francisco.
According to guidelines developed by the Harry Benjamin International Gender Dysphoria Association, individuals considering surgery should first undergo a "real-life experience" and live openly as the opposite sex for a significant period of time. F-to-M's, as they're commonly called, often find that they have an easier time "passing." While male hormones can produce facial hair and deepen the female voice, little can alter a man's baritone after puberty has thickened the vocal cords. And while many male transsexuals lose their jobs and slip a rung or two down the economic ladder after they come out, female transsexuals often report an increase in economic status after they've become men.
For Buechner, the discomfort with being male began long ago. She describes a childhood in suburban Baltimore that, while intensely lonely, was largely unremarkable. Still, from an early age, Buechner felt far more female than male. At 5, he was sneaking into his mother's closet to try on clothing. "She was such a theatrical person, very charismatic and very stylish," Buechner says. "I always wanted to be like her, to look like her."
It wasn't long before he realized the dress-up sessions were verboten. For years, Buechner wrestled with shame and confusion, bouncing from one therapist to another, hoping to find a cure for his ailment. "Every one of them tried to convince me this was the result of some childhood trauma, which it isn't," she says now. "Finally I just came to accept the fact that I was just born with the body of a man and a head wired like a woman." Anointed a child prodigy by his teachers, music became his solace, and beginning as an adolescent, Buechner plunged into the grueling world of international piano competitions, entering more than two dozen by the time he was in his mid-20's.
After moving to New York at 17 to attend Juilliard, Buechner discovered a city that, while tolerant of unconventional identities, offered little refuge to those who don't fit the neat categories of "gay" or "straight." At lesbian bars he was seen as a predatory man masquerading as a woman. At gay men's bars, he was often dismissed as a weekend drag queen. "Everywhere I went I was viewed as a freak," she says.
Although admittedly bisexual, the majority of Buechner's relationships have been with women. (Contrary to popular perception, many transgendered people are heterosexual.) At 21, Buechner married a Korean pianist, but the conflict led to an acrimonious breakup in 1987. Freed by the divorce, Buechner spent more and more time cross-dressing, hoping that she could get "the compulsion," as she called it, out of her system. Instead, she came to see it as an intrinsic part of her identity. One November afternoon in 1996, Buechner was walking through Central Park. "It was a beautiful, blue-skied day and suddenly I had this revelation," she says. "I realized I could keep fighting or I could embrace my true self. I decided to stop fighting and immediately felt this incredible peace. I consider that day my second birthday."
While ultimately liberating, Buechner's odyssey has also been expensive, emotionally draining and marked by periods of physical pain. The daily doses of estrogen that have shrunk Buechner's male genitals and given her B-cup breasts carry numerous health risks, including breast cancer and potentially fatal blood clots; the hormones spark disruptive mood swings that can drive her into seclusion for days. Just as taxing are the twice-a-week electrolysis sessions that give Buechner the confidence to face the world as a woman. "It's gotten to the point that a little stubble on my face can keep me indoors," she says.
Perhaps as early as next summer, Buechner hopes to undergo surgery that will complete the metamorphosis. The procedure -- removing the penis and testicles and creating a vagina -- will cost more than $12,000 and require a month of recovery. "I'm terrified of blood and I'm a confirmed hypochondriac," she says, "but I can't imagine myself living as a half man, half woman."
On a recent Tuesday morning, Buechner was lying on an massage table in the Upper East Side apartment of the electrolysist Stephanie Fischman, a postoperative transsexual who has a large clientele of transgendered men. Fifteen minutes into the session and Buechner's neck and chin are already carpeted with hundreds of tiny red blotches. "I call it my Homer Simpson look," she says with a laugh as Fischman wields a tiny needle. Besides her cosmetic services, Fischman provides Buechner with advice on how to cope with the vagaries of becoming a woman.
During their 90-minute sessions, Fischman, a fast-talking former construction worker from the Bronx, does her best to soothe Buechner's anxiety. "But the truth is," Fischman says, "life as a transsexual isn't a bed of roses." After Fischman had the surgery six years ago, she lost her job and her family and found herself taunted on the street. "The worst part is the feeling of vulnerability," she says during a cigarette break. "As soon as you come out, anything horrible that happens to you is justified. People think you deserve it."
The session over, Buechner retreats to a York Avenue coffee shop for breakfast, a Yankees cap partly shading her blistered face. Waiters and patrons stare unabashedly, and the blue-haired matron at an adjoining booth switches tables in the middle of her meal. Buechner feels especially dispirited on electrolysis days, when she is forced to leave off makeup and go out as a man. "It's so disorienting," she says over a plate of scrambled eggs. "I don't know quite who I am."
A few weeks later, Buechner is filled with fear and fury. Someone -- she suspects a jealous competitor -- has been anonymously faxing around copies of her revised bio, which is prompting telephone calls from long lost friends who ask if "that crazy story" is true. Most colleagues and friends are taken aback when told the news, and a handful of male friends have simply stopped calling. Buechner has feared from the outset that people will assume she is damaged goods, so she must work harder to prove them wrong. "But no matter how great I play," she says, "the first line in my obituary will invariably read, 'Sara Buechner, the transsexual pianist. . . . ' I guess that's something I will have to live with."
By far the greatest source of anguish has been the reaction of Buechner's parents, who feel ashamed and betrayed. Anthony Buechner, an engineer, once asked Sara to change her last name as well as her first. "You won't be able to play the piano," he told her in a recent phone conversation. "The only job you'll be able to get is at a checkout counter." Elizabeth Buechner, an attorney in Baltimore, is convinced that her child is simply going through a midlife crisis. In Buechner's journal he records her telling him again and again: "This isn't just about you. You have responsibilities. You can be cured. Besides, you'll never be a real woman. You don't have a real vagina."
Anthony Buechner declined to talk about his son but Elizabeth Buechner stressed that she remains proud of her child's accomplishments, "not only as an artist but as a person." She deflected questions about her son's sex change and repeated a statement she had prepared: "David has brought us a lot of joy. We love him and support him," she said haltingly. "There's nothing more to add." His brother, a biochemist in Kansas, openly frets over how to break the news to his two young daughters. "Just tell them that Uncle David has become Aunt Sara and she's much happier now," Buechner says impatiently. "I don't think kids are as disturbed by these things as adults are."
Buechner's tuxedo, mothballed for several months, had to be taken out of the closet in late July for a concert in Lake Placid. Because David had signed the contract the previous winter, Buechner felt obliged to show up as, well, David. She left her makeup bag at home and pulled her wavy auburn hair into a ponytail. "I feel like I'm playacting," she said a few hours before the Saturday-night performance. She found some comfort in knowing, however, that this recital would be David Buechner's last. When the audience rose to applaud and demand an encore, Buechner played an especially sentimental rendition of the Gershwin standard "The Man I Love," a private tribute, she says, to the passing of David. After the concert, she left his clothing behind.
Although she has felt more peace than ever before, the summer months have been filled with alternating bouts of dread and euphoria. Most of Buechner's private students took the news in stride -- a Russian student even gave her some jewelry -- but one of Buechner's favorites, a talented Korean pianist, reacted with disgust. "Your new life will only make mine more confusing," she wrote in the letter explaining her decision to switch teachers. Still, Buechner's spirits have been buoyed by a budding relationship with a Japanese musician, a woman who has thus far weathered the transition.
Even at moments when she feels overwhelmed, Buechner maintains a sharp wit and wry, self-deprecating sense of humor. Walking down a Greenwich Village street one morning for a meeting with the head of New York University's music school, Buechner seems less concerned about the dean's potential reaction than the clippity-clop sound produced by her high-heel shoes. "That's the most annoying part of being a woman," she says. Then she gestures to an elderly woman in a housecoat wobbling by. "But you know, the scariest part of all this," she says with mock earnestness, "is the realization that one day I'm going to turn into a little old lady."
