PUB-DATE: September 13, 1998

SECTION: Section 6; Page 38; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1625 words

HEADLINE: Culture Zone;
Out of Order

BYLINE: By Daniel Zalewski; Daniel Zalewski is an editor of The Times Magazine.

 BODY:
Wandering around the Pierre Bonnard retrospective currently on view at the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, I found myself in search of lost time. MOMA's curators, in hanging the show's 82 paintings, rejected the cradle-to-grave chronology that typically anchors a career survey. Instead, Bonnard's luminous works were grouped thematically -- landscapes in one gallery, still lifes in another -- with a pointed disregard for dates. Youthful efforts from the 1920's were tossed together with canvases painted around 1947, the year of Bonnard's death. The Frenchman's last completed painting, a small, dappled image of a blossoming almond tree, was stuck into the center of the show. The result was an imaginative but odd survey, one in which innocence and experience commingled as one.
Of course, that was partly the point. Museum curators -- and art historians in general -- have recently grown wary of the old-fashioned retrospective. Early career, middle career, late career. How boring! It's seen as far more exciting to hang shows with an eye for the striking juxtaposition, even if a sense of the artist's life gets lost in the shuffle. (Witness the Whitney museum's mix-and-match Edward Hopper survey in 1995.) This fashionable resistance to chronology represents more than a desire to jazz things up, however. The apprentice-to-master narrative that traditionally governs a retrospective, it is said, falsely suggests that artistic lives are marked by constant progress, that later work is somehow a sage synthesis of all that came before. After all, for every artist who flowers in old age, another fizzles. 
 These critiques have some merit. Nonetheless, as the MOMA exhibit sent me ricocheting from decade to decade, I began to suspect I was missing something. Was there a period when Bonnard was particularly florid in his output? When, exactly, did he become close friends with Matisse? Were the sunflower hues of "Cafe 'Au Petit
Poucet' " (Gallery 2) painted around the same time as the vibrant golds of "Large Yellow Nude" (Gallery 5)? Was Bonnard's art affected -- at all -- by the two World Wars he lived through? The show rebuffed such questions. In one placard, the curators acknowledged that Bonnard "went through stylistic changes," but insisted that these shifts were "finally less important than the way he treated his key subjects."
MOMA's concern was not with Bonnard's personal trajectory but with his purely formal innovations: the visual games embedded in his busy interiors, the bold color contrasts in his still lifes.
And yet, much of the appeal of retrospectives is that, like biographies of artists, they offer an opportunity to explore connections between art and life. Consider Bonnard's bathroom portraits (presented out of sequence in two adjoining galleries). In these obsessive works, Bonnard painted his wife, Marthe, eternally in the guise of a young, healthy woman -- even as she fell victim to a prolonged bout with tuberculosis. As a result, there is an added poignancy to Bonnard's later portraits; they are paintings in a clearly elegiac mode. Although a 1925 portrait of Marthe bathing has a somber feel -- she appears confined to a watery tomb -- Bonnard's later variations on this theme display an almost bizarre brightness. The bathroom tiles glitter like Byzantine mosaics and Marthe's submerged flesh glistens with illusory radiance (despite the fact that she was disintegrating before his eyes). As Bonnard aged, the gap between image and reality often grew distended; at times, disturbingly so. Yet such connections were all but impossible to make with MOMA's scrambled presentation.
The same afternoon I visited MOMA, I attended "An Expressionist in Paris: The Paintings of Chaim Soutine," a retrospective at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan. (The show closed in August, but reopens on Sept. 27 at the Los Angeles County Museum.) Here, the curators were even more aggressive about tossing away the time line, organizing the retrospective according to "critical reception." As the exhibit's wall text explained, Soutine's earliest champions in the 1920's celebrated him as a Jewish "primitive" whose raw portraits of working-class subjects contrasted with prettified salon paintings of the day. Paintings that supported this view were placed in the first gallery. After the painter's death in 1943, art critics began to view his talents differently, seeing Soutine's deliriously abstracted landscapes as his peak achievements. Images in this vein were placed at the end of the show. The problem is, Soutine painted many of these expressionist landscapes years before the "primitive" offerings in the first gallery. Confused?
The resulting show felt a bit like Martin Amis's novel "Time's Arrow": completely backward. To wit, Roberta Smith, a Times critic, recommended that visitors could best apprehend Soutine's development by walking through the exhibit from back to front. Fortunately, she pointed out with a dash of sarcasm, "the show is small enough for Soutine's progress to be reconstituted in the mind."
Kenneth E. Silver, an art historian at New York University who was one of the Soutine show's curators, admits that the primary impulse for shuffling the deck was "chronology fatigue." As he puts it, "It's a feeling that has really welled up in my generation of curators." More than anything else, however, Silver was determined to have the retrospective end with a bang -- even though Soutine's life had ended with a whimper. "His style became progressively less daring, in my view," he says. "With a chronological approach, what you would feel as you exited the show is deflation, the sense of a fall from grace. I didn't think that did Soutine a service." At the same time, Silver acknowledges that his temporal sleight of hand "may have misled some visitors about Soutine's life." He recalls with a laugh: "I recently met a woman at a party who loved the show. She told me how much she liked Soutine's early work. But as we talked, I realized that she meant the late work!"
The origins of Silver's chronology fatigue can be traced to the academy, where various theorists have lately portrayed "linear narratives" as oppressive constructs. In a 1995 issue of Art Journal, Patricia Mathews, an art historian at Oberlin College, declared: "Chronological surveys typically misrepresent the history of art as a seamlessly coherent narrative." More generally, she argued, "art historians have fetishized a chronological, diachronic model based on causality and often teleology that supports a linear model of history and an elitist, exclusive lineage of art." Uh-oh.
The upshot of this kind of thinking is that at many top schools, Art History 101 -- conventionally a yearlong march from the Romans to Rauschenberg -- has been all shook up. In revamped surveys from Harvard to Northwestern, the story of art is presented not as a series of periods and movements but as a gallery of themes: the representation of women one week, religious allegories the next, with perhaps a class on abstraction to follow. Works by Caravaggio, Charles Ray and Michelangelo might be squeezed into a lecture on homoeroticism.
Such comparisons, when smartly done, can be illuminating. But for the newcomer, a collage-like approach to history can produce more confusion than enlightenment -- especially when the student has no idea when the Enlightenment actually took place. (Not to mention if it came before or after the Renaissance.) After teaching a nonchronological survey course in 1995, the Berkeley art historian Svetlana Alpers wrote a favorable article about the experience. But she did include the following caveat: "I think one thing that has been lost is the sense that art itself has a history." Such laments are increasingly rare. Indeed, the name "art history" has at many schools been replaced by the term "visual studies."
It's not just people in the art world who are loosening their grip on chronology. The desire to twist time out of joint has even permeated -- of all places -- the biography business. Alain de Botton's whimsical "How Proust Can Change Your Life," published last year, presents a chopped-up, anecdotal biography slyly disguised as a self-help manual. Hermione Lee's vigorous "Virginia Woolf" (1997) is constructed as a series of essays that, in keeping with its modernist subject, avoids a flatly chronological progression. Larry Tye's new "Father of Spin," a portrait of the public relations guru Edward Bernays, also upends the traditional formula, skipping Bernays's childhood and beginning in medias res -- on his wedding day.
Ignoring chronology has its pitfalls, however; as Ron Chernow noted in a Times review, "Bernays's parents aren't fully introduced until page 115, and we don't get a basic description of his appearance until page 142."
The writer Donald Barthelme famously proclaimed that "collage is the central principle of all art in the 20th century," so it's no wonder that the slice-and-dice approach has been embraced by everyone from artists to biographers, novelists to curators. And, admittedly, there's something refreshing about exhibitions like the Bonnard and Soutine. After seeing these radical retrospectives, the straight-up Edward Burne-Jones show recently on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art felt plodding by comparison. Ultimately, though, the nonchronological retrospective -- and fragmented history -- strike me as oxymorons. In her Art Journal article, Patricia Mathews asks: "Are the questions of who did what when really the most important information for a student to absorb in their first art history course? I think not." Maybe it puts me behind the times, but I think I'd say yes, they are.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 66; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: The Swoon of the Swoosh

BYLINE: By Timothy Egan; Timothy Egan is a national correspondent for The Times. His profile of Sherman Alexie appeared in the magazine in January.

 BODY:
For some time now, the Nike swoosh has been showing up in the oddest of places, dropped like an inadvertent product plug amid the news of the day. Just before 39 members of the Heaven's Gate cult swallowed a suicide brew last year, they laced up their new black Nikes for a post-mortem chase of a spaceship they believed was trailing the Hale-Bopp comet. Benjamin Walker, a victim of the Springfield, Ore., school shooting in May, was so heavily swooshed in T-shirt and cap in the photo released by authorities that media outlets felt compelled to crop him to a tight facial mug. And then there's O.J. Simpson, the last athlete any company in the world wants to endorse its product, recently seen wearing a Nike cap.
Sports are the heart of American culture, says Philip H. Knight, Nike chairman and co-founder. He has believed this ever since he started peddling waffle-soled running shoes out of his car trunk more than 30 years ago. He spoke then in a language understood only by people who could run a mile in less than five minutes. Now his company slogans are uttered by presidents and schoolchildren the world over. By Nike's own research, the swoosh brand is recognized by 97 percent of Americans, and every man, woman and child in the United States spends an average of $20 a year on the company's products. 
 But be careful what you wish for: the swoosh, never more ubiquitous, is in turnaround. Having plastered the world with a corporate icon rivaled perhaps only by Coca-Cola's cursive, Nike is trying desperately to tone it down, hide it, possibly even lose it. The week before an anxious annual shareholders meeting, Nike still looks in the mirror and sees a sleek rebel, but others see a bully with a beer gut.
"You can make a lot of mistakes around here, but the brand is sacred," says Knight. "I messed that up."
Knight is pacing inside the John McEnroe Building, the intensive-care ward for the ailing swoosh and the center of power inside the earthen berm at Nike World Headquarters in Beaverton, Ore. He is a reddish-haired, somewhat bulge-eyed hypercompetitor; at 60, he still runs regularly. When sneakers became a cultural force more than a decade ago, Knight was dubbed the most powerful man in sports. But he has been angry much of this year, hearing his company described as the symbol for everything that is wrong not only with sports but also with global capitalism itself.
Knight checks in frequently with Gordon Thompson, the company's lead designer. Thompson's current challenge is the biggest yet: how to persuade a new generation of consumers to latch onto a brand trying to reinvent itself after two years of hard hits.
"Hard to believe," says Thompson, showing a chart that illustrates the evolution of the company logo. "But the swoosh has been a stand-alone logo for only four years. We were growing and growing and growing here in Beaverton, and I guess we didn't totally realize what happened to this thing that was supposed to be just a sports logo." On new shoes, Thompson has started to shrink the icon down to just a wisp of a swoosh, barely visible. "The question we've been asking ourselves a lot here," he says, is whether we should just go ahead and take the swoosh off. That's been a pretty hefty debate."
Just a year ago, on Nike's 25th birthday, coming off the best financial 12 months in the company's history, there was no hint of a future without the swoosh. Its fate, the company said, was linked to the march of sports into every corner of the planet. "The 'swooshification of the world' should more appropriately be deemed the Sportsification of the world," Nike officials wrote in the company's annual report for 1997. "We will mature in tandem with the inexorable penetration of sports into the global psyche."
Brave words. But, as it turns out, the swoosh and sports do not always move in tandem. Profits at Nike, the world's leading athletic-shoe-and-apparel maker, plunged 49 percent this fiscal year, despite record sales of $9.6 billion. (More and more Nikes are being sold by discounters, lowering the profit margin.) The stock price has dropped more than 50 percent this year from highs of a year before. Two months ago, Nike reported its first quarterly loss in 13 years, prompting the largest layoffs in company history and a teary apology from Knight.
Nike still sells more than 160 million pairs of athletic shoes a year, and nearly one out of every two pairs in the United States. But the company had pegged its future growth to Asia, where Nike is one of the most visible American victims of the ongoing economic crisis. Worldwide, Nike has about one-third of the total market for athletic shoes. Its nearest competitors, Adidas and Reebok, are far behind in the United States and abroad, but Adidas is gaining ground. And with Michael Jordan, Nike's franchise player, bound for retirement either this year or next, the company has yet to discover, or manufacture, anyone even close to him.
Those are just a few of Nike's problems. Purists say that the company has corrupted sport. Critics of Nike's overseas factories abound, citing the more than 500,000 workers who often earn about $1.50 a day. Some of these critics peg Nike's current woes to their own efforts to tarnish the swoosh -- or the swooshsticka, as the more rabid Nike-haters call it. "We figured out two years ago that the only way to make our campaign against Nike's labor practices work was to try to make the swoosh uncool," says Medea Benjamin, co-director of Global Exchange, a San Francisco-based human rights group.
From Day 1, Nike has insisted it is a company for athletes. But the greatest secret of the sports-footwear-and-apparel business is that most of the product is bought by people who may want to be like Mike or Ken Griffey Jr. or the Brazilian soccer star Ronaldo, but seldom leave the couch. "The reason the basketball shoes have worked so well is because 80 percent of the people who buy them never set foot on a basketball court -- it's a fashion statement," says Vince Francom, a footwear-industry analyst in Seattle. "The problem with fashion is that tastes change very quickly. There's a big backlash against Nike under way. The skateboard generation doesn't want to wear Nikes because their fathers wear them."
And it is the swoosh that has become emblematic of all of Nike's troubles: a fashion statement losing its edge; a sports pyramid that starts with cheap day labor and ends with poor kids trying to pony up $140 for the shoes, and the lost innocence of young athletes.
Phil Knight and his closest executives have heard so much criticism that they have started to parody it. They've hung anti-Nike cartoons all over their walls and filled their annual report with consumers' hate mail. So the question inside the berm is not whether the swoosh has gotten Nike in trouble, but how quickly to act.
"We're a company founded by distance runners -- some of them pretty slow -- so we have a certain amount of patience," wrote Knight in his most recent letter to shareholders. "Nonetheless, we prefer to be timed by a stopwatch, not a calendar."
Inside Nike's main laboratory in the Michael Jordan Building, shoe scientists in lab coats watch slow-motion X-ray videos of how the 26 bones in the human foot react to different strides. Product developers are finishing a shoe modeled after a goat's hoof -- the Goatster, they nicknamed it, designed to grip vertical rock terrain. It's a niche-market shoe, of course, but who knows how many eighth-graders might want to have the latest in extreme-sport fashions.
Nike is also preparing to sell snowboards, boots, hockey sticks and golf equipment but has dropped a curious new baseball glove. About one-third of the company's sales last year came from clothes, gear, watches, eyewear and other products not worn on the foot. The swoosh is no longer being cloned along with fresh product; instead, new logos, with separate identities, are sprouting from within the berm. A new line of Michael Jordan shoes will soon march out of the factories, carrying the Jordan "Jumpman" logo. (For the recent fiscal year, every major category of Nike footwear sold in America suffered a decline in sales, except one -- the Jordan brand, which increased 57 percent.) An Alpha line of shoes and clothing, vaguely defined as "innovative," will be unveiled later this year, carrying a new logo -- five dots, a sort of elongated ellipsis.
Everything, it seems, is in play. Nike's most famous slogan, "Just Do It," disappeared for a time this year after a decade-long run. As it turns out, women did not take to the admonition quite as enthusiastically as men. "I Can" worked better with women, but it also sounded something like a Special Olympics plug, and didn't go over so well with men. "The saying 'I can' sounds so weak!" one man wrote to Nike this year. "And I ain't weak." Just what is the company slogan these days? "We use them all," says Lee Weinstein, Nike's chief spokesman.
From the outside, the Nike campus looks like a fortress hunkered among the forests and office parks of suburban Portland. From the inside, it feels like a jock's version of "The Truman Show," with militantly casual ex-athletes and creative overachievers hustling between buildings named for legendary Nike stars. Knight says the idea behind the berm was to create a world unto its own for Nike employees when they returned from road trips -- a sort of Vatican for the missionaries of sneakers. It is also supposed to be a place of inspiration, recovery and swoosh indoctrination for Nike's army of athletes.
Athletes with an attitude have always been at the top of the fashion food chain at Nike. At a time when other shoe companies are backing away from endorsements, Nike is still building its roster. It now has more than 3,000 athletes in the fold worldwide, including 72 percent of the players in the National Basketball Association, 60 percent in Major League Baseball and half the players in the National Football League. More than 200 universities fly the flag of swoosh.
The multipierced illustrated man of basketball, Dennis Rodman, was once a Nike guy, but the company revoked his swoosh. "He's a great player," Knight says, "but he's crazy." Shaquille O'Neal, the telegenic center with the high-wattage smile, showed up a few years ago at the Nike campus for a get-acquainted session -- swathed in Reebok gear. Things went downhill from there.
Knight likes winners, of course, but rebels are closest to his heart. The N.B.A. tried to ban the first Air Jordans (they weren't considered regulation sneakers), much to the delight of Knight. There was cheering inside the John McEnroe Building when Casey Martin, the disabled golfer whose cause Knight took up when it looked like a long shot, challenged the golf establishment and became the first man to play the United States Open in a powered cart. "What we are all about," Knight says, "is being against the establishment." Yes, but what happens when you are the establishment, when the swoosh shows up in more country clubs than asphalt alleys?
Nike's response has been to try new ways of "branding." Nike, of course, is not alone in this pursuit. The idea is simply to create a connection between consumer and product, a link often having nothing to do with what is actually being sold. Nike has always tried to sell something more than leather and nylon, promoting the swoosh as a personal statement. But the retail world is littered with once-thriving brandings that have ended badly. L.A. Gear, for example, was an upstart sneaker company that rode the aerobics craze to dizzying heights, then crashed when it tried to put its label on too many other things. Because the swoosh is so ubiquitous, Nike executives realize they now have a hard time using a renegade posture. And Adidas, the German company that was the establishment when young Nike came pounding at the door, has succeeded in an otherwise flat retail-shoe environment by capitalizing on its underdog status to Nike.
"A lot of kids think they are now discovering Adidas for the first time, as it becomes the anti-Nike," says Bob McGee, the editor of Sporting Goods Intelligence.
Further complicating Nike's task, the company's "brand soul" has been especially hurt by the spate of negative stories about its overseas labor practices and its defensive posture. "What's happening to Nike is extremely dangerous for any brand," says John Bowen, a New York consultant and writer on brand resonance. "Consumers today are more concerned about the culture of the organization behind the brand. They want to feel good about the company they are buying from."
I draped myself in borrowed swoosh during the lunch hour one day and went for a run with the president of Nike, Tom Clarke. A former college track coach with a Ph.D. in biomechanics, he is fast, pleasant and open about the company's problems. Nike, the global dominator, can still be cool, he told me, if it sends the right message to the right audience. "A lot of the coolness factor comes from how you communicate," says Clarke, 47, gliding along at a 7-minute-mile pace, slow for him. "I get people who come up to me all the time and say, 'Man, I did not understand that ad at all.' I think that's a good thing." He has a point. But as I ran through the streets of Beaverton with the latest in swoosh-covered tank top, shorts and shoes, I did not feel cool. I felt like a two-legged billboard for a $9 billion company.
The question of how Nike lost some of its coolness is an open debate inside the berm. Most Nike executives simply blame the ubiquity of the swoosh, the icon inspired by the wing of a Greek goddess. It was dreamed up in 1971 by a design student in Portland, a woman Knight hired when he was still moonlighting as an accounting teacher. It cost him $35.
"Clearly, we had the swoosh on everything and it was just ridiculous," says Mark Parker, a Nike vice president for global footwear. "I remember walking into Texas Stadium, and they had taken the swoosh and put it on the stairs, on cheerleaders, on the walls. I said, 'Oh, my God, this is our worst nightmare."'
Others blame a humor lapse in some of the recent ads. Self-important to a fault, they showed perfectly chiseled world-class athletes, buck naked -- an attempt to sell Nike athletic wear.
But if the swoosh does not light up advertising focus groups the way it used to, Nike has another icon that has yet to show a downside: Michael Jordan. Last June, in the midst of Nike's deepening troubles, came the most glorious 59 seconds of the year for the company. Just when it was said that the greatest person ever to play the game was past his pull date, the old man did it again. In Game 6 of the N.B.A. Finals, Nike's franchise player singlehandedly pulled off a victory -- and the championship -- while wearing a pair of Air Jordan XIV's, which retail for about $150. The shoe sailed out of stores.
Clinging to Jordan as long as possible, Nike may bring out a line of Jordan casual shoes, following up with everything from Jordan socks to suits. Nike executives figure that if Tommy Hilfiger and Ralph Lauren, neither of whom ever did anything dramatic on a basketball court, can sell billions of dollars worth of clothing, the world's best-known athlete can do the same, or much better. If Nike takes this step with Jordan, it would mark a huge leap into relatively unfamiliar retail territory. The last time the company tried such a thing, selling so-called "brown shoes" in the mid-1980's, it was clobbered. Knight says the company learned its lesson. Still, Jordan's name is so strong that Nike cannot seem to resist what they see as his Midas touch.
Jordan, arguably the company's best asset, is planning to tour the Nike factories in Asia, arguably the company's worst liability. It was Jordan's idea, says Weinstein, the company spokesman. Jordan has grown tired of all the questions about factory wages and says he wants to see firsthand what the fuss is about. Still, his tour is designed not so much to cheer up factory hands in Hanoi as to connect with a particular brand of swoosh consumers: females. The labor issue keeps coming up in focus groups with girls as young as 12, Nike executives told me.
Phil Knight has seen the future of his industry and it does not have an Adam's apple. Twenty-five years ago, he says, only 1 in 30 school-age girls played sports; today it's 1 in 5. Nearly 40 percent of high-school athletes are girls. And so the Nike poster athlete of the new millennium is a female American soccer player, Mia Hamm. I ran this name by many of my sports-loving friends, all of them ESPN habitues, runners and soccer parents. We buy gear and channel-surf with the best of them. Our reaction was the same: Who? Then I asked my 11-year-old daughter about Mia Hamm, and she looked at me as if I were as dumb as a fence post. With Hamm, Nike has managed to go below adult radar, just as Tom Clarke alluded to on our run.
Hamm is 26 years old, from Chapel Hill, N.C., winner of an Olympic gold medal and a World Championship title. She is beautiful. She can use a verb. She has the right hint of attitude. And if enough people ever start watching women's soccer -- Nike is heavily promoting next year's Women's World Cup, to be staged in the United States -- she may be gold for the Beaverton sneaker company.
"Why shouldn't girls around the world say, 'I want to be like Mia?"' asks Katherine Melchior Ray, the head of Nike women's footwear. At Nike, that refrain can sound like a prayer.
Hamm's sport also happens to be the world's most popular athletic pastime. In trying to build its market share in soccer, Nike signed the Brazilian national team for a reported $200 million and made a long-term deal with Ronaldo, the team's 21-year-old star. It was all supposed to come together this year at the World Cup in France, where Nike spent $40 million on advertising and promotions.
In France, Nike's lightweight, sticky-toed Mercurial shoes were worn by many a soccer player, including those on the United States national team (which Nike also sponsored, and which lost all three of its games). And the shoe has sold well, Nike says. But the swoosh took its share of World Cup hits. The newspaper Liberation accused Nike of promoting "totalitarian esthetics" with billboards around Paris of Aryan-looking youth marching forward for sport. The ads were pulled. "They looked like fascists," says Vince Francom, the industry analyst. "You had to wonder what Nike was thinking. In the championship game, watched by more people than any other sports event in history, Brazil was upstaged -- and soundly beaten -- by the French national team, which was sponsored by Adidas. The French were brash, aggressive, multi-ethnic, a snub to the establishment -- in short, a perfect Nike team. Phil Knight acknowledges as much, with a wince. Worse yet, Ronaldo suffered a seizure before the game and played listlessly, sparking worldwide speculation that Nike pressured the Brazil coach to keep the unfit superstar in the lineup -- a charge that Knight vehemently denies. In the end, he says, Ronaldo and the Brazilians are bound to pay off for Nike. Ronaldo's nickname, after all, is O Dono do Mundo: the King of the World.
One problem: The King still has some name-recognition problems in this country. "Michael Jordan," admits Mark Parker, "had never heard of him."
The wind is calm this afternoon on Lake Nike, the 10-acre body of water on the corporate campus. Knight is sitting inside the company boardroom, the table a massive oval of honey maple. There is not a swoosh in sight. After a year of playing defense, Knight has been on the offensive for months, preparing for next week's annual meeting.
The low point, perhaps, came in April, when the Nike backlash hit very close to home. Outside the Portland Niketown, some 200 people hissed and booed a 20-foot likeness of Knight and urged his company to pay higher wages in Asia. Knight shrugs off most of the criticism, saying it comes with Nike's perch atop the sporting world. But he can still get very emotional about his company.
"I have just two words to say," he told employees earlier this year while announcing the layoff of 1,300 workers. "I'm sorry." Every downward tick of the stock, every slashing parody in "Doonesbury," Knight seems to take personally. And, financially, it does affect him personally; he owns nearly 96 million shares of Nike stock, 34 percent of the company. Married, with two grown children, he has lived in the same house for the past 25 years. But his holdings are worth more than $3 billion.
In college, Knight ran a 4-minute-10-second mile, fast enough to make a team, the University of Oregon Ducks, that is to track and field what Notre Dame is to football, but too slow to win many races. His idea for a global company -- with shoes designed in the United States, manufactured in low-wage factories in Asia, then sold worldwide -- has been remarkably consistent.
The early selling point was that Knight and Bill Bowerman, the Oregon coach and Nike co-founder, listened to athletes. Every ounce shaved off a running shoe was 200 fewer pounds lifted per mile, they used to say. What has surprised Knight is how the big ride to the top happened so quickly, and now, how it has generated so much spite.
"Obviously, we want our trademark to be special," says Knight, mulling over the nagging question of what to do with the swoosh. "But there is such a thing as letting it become too popular. We grew from $3 billion to $9 billion, and there was no forecast for that to happen."
For his part, Knight seems alternately playful and morose about the company's future. When asked about retirement, he laughs. "I want to die here," he says. "Hopefully, not soon."
In May, Knight went before the National Press Club in Washington to announce changes in Nike factory labor practices. He used the opportunity to bait reporters. "I figured that I'd just come out and let you journalists have a look at the Great Satan up close and personal," he said.
During his speech, Knight unveiled plans to set a minimum age of 18 at all Nike footwear factories. The company has also shifted to water-based solvents to bond the shoes, instead of the harmful toluene. Nike started a loan program for young entrepreneurs in Vietnam and Indonesia and promised to set up an independent monitoring system at its factories. Critics were somewhat mollified, but they are still calling on Nike to double wages. Anticipating a row at next week's annual meeting, Nike officials say the focus of their presentations will be on "corporate responsibility." No talk of the Goatster, apparently.
But even in bad times, the company has held to its swagger. "I think as long as Phil is there, the anti-establishment part of Nike is not going to go away," says Neil Goldschmidt, the former Oregon governor and a one-time Nike vice president.
Nor is the swoosh ever likely to disappear completely. Nike may ultimately abandon the swoosh, but the swoosh will never abandon Phil Knight -- it is tattooed on his left ankle.

PUB-DATE: September 13, 1998

SECTION: Section 6; Page 18; Column 4; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 261 words

HEADLINE: Still Living With '68

 BODY:
Mark Lilla's essay "Still Living With '68" (Aug. 16), which pretends to be a comparison of the nature of the 1968 rebellions in Europe and the United States, turns out to be a somewhat smothered cry of complaint about the now commonplace bogeys of the right wing: the depredations of feminism, ethnic-identity politics and the so-called "culture wars." He plays the usual game of blaming what he calls joylessly militant feminists for "questioning the naturalness of the family" and "upsetting the psychologically delicate ritual of seduction."
In the last 30 years, as throughout our history, the most powerful force in transforming American life has been our capitalist economy, unrestrained by the aristocratic and hierarchical traditions of Europe. The extreme pressures on the family and the continued destruction of local community are much more the result of changes in the economy that demand increasing mobility, two-income families and female participation in the labor force than of feminist ideology. 
 Lilla also ignores the rise to economic and cultural dominance of television and the popular-entertainment industry, which began in the 1950's but matured in the 1960's, to forever transform the valences of American life. This overthrow of the cultural hierarchy Americans inherited from Europe, in which classical music, fine art and serious literature stood at the top, has had profound consequences -- some good, some bad -- in all arenas of America life, including those of politics and the family.
 
Sarah E. Murray
Oakland, Calif.

HEADLINE: The Beige And the Black

 BODY:
If the price blacks have to pay to have greater economic equality in America is to become beige, some of us might just want to forfeit the climb to financial bliss ("The Beige and the Black," by Michael Lind, Aug. 16). Strengthening the power of the black family to have access to greater social and economic opportunities should be the impetus for integration rather than for an end to race itself.
 
Mona Rigaud

HEADLINE: Stratford Rethinks Its Base

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
THE past has taken on the nostalgic glow of the good old days in Stratford, when the military contractors and manufacturing provided prosperityand a stable tax base, and commerce thrived without the town government's help.
Lately, as in many other older communities, that glow has become a fading memory. The loss of some of its major industrial taxpayers in the past decade, particularly the closing of a large tank engine plant by the Army, and the difficulty of attracting new businesses, have left the town with something of an identity crisis. 
 Earlier this year, Stratford's Town Council convened an economic development task force of government officials, business people and civic leaders to make recommendations for improving the situation.
Acting on one of the primary recommendations of the group, the Town Council decided to sponsor a retreat next month in which an invited cross section of the community will attempt to create an economic development plan for the future.
"We have to decide what exactly are we looking for in this town," said Debbie Rose, the chairwoman of the Town Council. She said the town must come to a consensus about what it wants its economic focus to be: on high-tech manufacturing, tourism, or perhaps other industries.
"We lived in Oz for a long time," Ms. Rose said. The Sikorsky helicopter plant in the north end of town and the equally large plant where the turbine engines for the M-1 tank, America's main battle tank, in the south end, provided thousands of skilled jobs and millions of dollars in tax revenue for the town. "That's how we rolled along for many years," she said.
Then the cold war ended, the Federal military budget was pared, and the tank engine plant, which had been bought by the Allied-Signal Corporation, was included in the country's military cutbacks. Today, the enormous complex is vacant except for a skeleton crew of Army personnel who maintain it. "We were just left with reality, that things just wouldn't be the same," Ms. Rose said.
Meanwhile, Stratford has watched the adjacent city of Shelton undergo an economic development boom. Office buildings, light industry and dozens of major retailers sprang up along Shelton's central corridor.
Last fall, graduate marketing students from the University of New Haven conducted a survey of business owners in Stratford. Mary Ann Vlahac, their professor, said the survey results identified some things that business owners were dissatisfied about, such as the difficulty of obtaining permits and a shortage of public parking. More than half of those responding to the survey felt that the town government wasn't "business friendly," and that it needed to improve communication with the business community.
Aware of the complaints, the Town Council appointed the task force to propose a plan for improving the town's economic development, and in June the task force presented its report. Its first recommendation was to develop an economic development plan with participation from government leaders, business representatives, labor unions, civic organizations and private citizens.
The task force also proposed that the town form an independent Economic Development Corporation, increase the municipal economic development staff and streamline the town management structure to attract new businesses and help existing ones to thrive. It said that the redevelopment of the tank engine plant, the American Shakespeare Theater and the town's waterfront should be priorities.
Another proposal, to change the structure of town government and create an elected chief executive officer, attracted much of the attention, however. This was not a recommendation by the task force, but rather a suggestion by one of its members, Dan Jacobs, president of the Stratford Chamber of Commerce. While Mr. Jacobs defends the position of the Chamber, he said he regretted that it has distracted so many people from the task force's recommendations.
Stratford's present government is ineffective for the economic development effort that is needed, say Mr. Jacobs and others. The Town Manager, Mark Barnhart, is an appointed professional administrator, and with 17 department heads reporting to him he has little time to focus on economic development. The town's economic development director spends most of her time on her other role as community development director, and there is no one who is employed full time to work on economic development.
The Town Council is made up of a councilman at large and 10 councilmen elected by district. Since 1921, the councilman at large had always been from the party that held the majority of the district seats, and so was elected as council chairman. But in 1995 Rudolf Weiss, a Republican, was re-elected councilman at large only to find the Democrats holding the majority of the seats, and he was not renamed as chairman. In 1997, the reverse occurred when Kent Miller, a Democrat, won the town-wide councilman seat, but the Republicans held the majority and selected Ms. Rose as chairwoman.
"We don't have a strong chief elected official," said Mr. Weiss, who served as the chairman of the task force. He said that in Shelton and other Connecticut cities that have strong, successful economic development programs, "the chief elected official is a kind of salesman for the town."
Mr. Weiss and Mr. Jacob noted that Mark Lauretti, the Mayor of Shelton, and Joseph P. Ganim, the Mayor of Bridgeport, are not totally preoccupied with day to day administrative matters and are able to represent their cities in person when seeking grant money or meeting with prospective developers.
But Mr. Jacobs said that the proposal that the town needs a chief elected official does not mean it wishes to do away with the professional town manager. He said that the proposal was offered as something the Town Council should consider as an economic development tactic, not as something that required immediate action.
"One of the points that was made throughout by everybody is the town doesn't really have a clear cut vision of itself like, say, Mystic," said Mr. Jacobs. "You look at Mystic and you know exactly what it's about."
Having such an identity, he said, would allow the town to focus on attracting specific industries, assemble parcels of land for development, and create tax incentive zones. For example, Stratford has many printing businesses. If printing were to become a priority industry, the town could advertise its tax incentives in printers' trade journals.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2168 words

HEADLINE: From Bust to Boom: A Deeper, Stronger Economy

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
FOR a long view of the Long Island economy, there is Alan Fortunoff, patriarch of the Island's best-known retailing family, who made his oversized imprint on the suburban business landscape when he opened the huge Fortunoff store in Westbury in 1964.
The store quickly became a fixture on Long Island, its success fueled by the region's defense industry and the high-paying jobs it created. But by the 1980's, Mr. Fortunoff said, "all of us were fearful" of the wrenching decline in the industry, dominated by the Grumman Corporation. The Island, it seemed, had been an economic house of cards, falling apart as military spending shrank. 
 But perhaps no business enterprise better reflects the sweeping recovery that has propelled Long Island since the mid-1990's than Mr. Fortunoff's.
His Westbury store, which suffered along with the rest of the Island during the recession, is now part of a 40-store mall, which he opened in September. What stood for 33 years as simply Fortunoff's is now part of "The Mall at the Source," with large outlets of Old Navy, Virgin Records, and the Rainforest Cafe attracting shoppers from the Island's newly emergent cadre of software designers, biochemical engineers and high technology workers.
"It turns out that we haven't lost high-paying jobs, they have just changed sectors," Mr. Fortunoff said. "I can't point to one catalyst, but the void left by the defense industry has been filled."
So much so that factories, warehouses and office buildings that stood vacant 10 years ago -- the ballast of both defense cuts and overbuilding -- are now full, and rents are rising. Home prices, already lofty compared to most of the nation's affluent suburban areas, are soaring.
And demand for workers, which sank into a deep trough in 1992 when the island's unemployment rate reached 8.3 percent, is now so intense that some employers are turning desperate. State figures for July, the most recent available, show an unemployment rate of 3.3 percent for the entire island and a hair-thin 2.7 percent for Nassau County.
Mr. Fortunoff, who built his new mall in a partnership with Simon DeBartolo, one of the nation's largest retail developers, has adopted a particularly aggressive recruiting tactic: he will pay a $200 bounty to any of his college-age employees who bring in another, providing the new hire stays on the job for 90 days.
"The labor shortage has extended from high-tech to low-tech companies," he said. "It makes things difficult for us, but it is also wonderful to think that almost any kid who needs a job can find one."
For residents and business people across Long Island, the robust economic recovery may have seemed overdue, particularly since the Island -- more than any other part of the New York metropolitan region -- had for decades been insulated from recession because of the defense industry.
But by the end of the 1980's, people on the Island might have felt that the collapse of the stock market was only adding insult to injury, because the defense industry had already begun to suffer steep cuts. It was a double-barreled shot that will not soon be forgotten.
"I don't know that things actually got worse for Long Island than they did anywhere else, but it sure seemed like our recovery took a long time in coming," said Brent Harding, a sales associate at Robert Harding Real Estate in Port Washington. Home prices in his town, like elsewhere on the Island, fell in the early 1990's, and he said that as recently as a year ago some houses were languishing on the market for months.
But for home sellers, as for almost everyone else on the Island, the gradual recovery has suddenly turned into a boom over the last year.
"This economy has caught fire," said Pearl Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, a business group. Although signs of resurgence began appearing by 1995, she said the Long Island economy has expanded at its fastest pace over the last year, propelled by high employment, rising income levels among residents and surging levels of spending at retail malls, in the real estate market and among visitors to the Hamptons, Fire Island and other resort areas.
In a milestone recorded by several economists, the Island this year finally regained all of the 88,500 jobs it lost in the recession that lasted from 1989 through 1992, with 24,500 of the new jobs created over the last 12 months. Despite earlier fears that Long Island's recession had been worse and would last longer than elsewhere in the New York region, the Island is now outpacing almost all other parts of the region, including New York City, in job growth.
Experts say the recovery is both robust and diverse. Although not without points of vulnerability, including the potential damage of a downturn on Wall Street or in the Island's rapidly expanding trade in foreign exports, they said the demise of the defense industry has led to a more varied and resilient economic foundation.
"The legacy of the defense industry has in fact been very helpful to Long Island because it has left us with a reservoir of skills that are useful in other industries," Ms. Kamer said.
Gary Huth, Long Island labor market analyst for the New York State Department of Labor, said the technical qualifications that were required for many of the lost defense jobs were so high that they met immediate demand in other fields.
"It is one thing to have thousands of people displaced from routine assembly-line work, but something very different happened here," he said. "Working in defense electronics didn't mean wiring electric sockets, it meant dealing with advanced aircraft systems. This led to easy transitions, and I think a lot of people underestimated the entrepreneurial zeal of these workers."
The defense industry spillover is apparent among several of the Island's fastest-growing companies, including high-technology firms like Computer Associates of Islandia and Symbol Technologies of Holtsville, which have employed many engineers and scientists who had honed their skills in the defense industry.
And the newly diverse economy has provided jobs for displaced workers without lofty scientific credentials, although some at lower salaries. In what she called a "sign of a more cyclically stable labor force," Ms. Kamer said a third of the Island's work force is employed in service industry jobs -- a sector that ranges from management consulting to clerical work -- compared to 25 percent a decade ago.
Still, amid the promise of an ebullient and more secure economic mix, Long Island is confronting growing pains and constraints on its growth that are inherent in both its infrastructure and geography as a 110-mile-long island cut off by water on three sides, and by the urban behemoth of New York City on the other.
One deeply rooted problem is its cost of electricity, until this year the highest in the continental United States. Combined with the costs of gasoline or commuter rail tickets, lofty property and school taxes, electrical bills have long been a source of consternation for both residents and business owners.
But some long-awaited relief has come since the state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company in May produced a 20 percent rate reduction for at least five years.
Although such savings are hardly enough to allow much change in the financial plans or spending habits of most residents, some experts suggest that the reduction may have a broader psychological impact by bolstering confidence that an economic problem once thought to be intractable has been brought more closely under control.
"It gives business a sense that their needs are being addressed and that they can look down the road with some sense of security, at least for five years," Mr. Huth said. For homeowners, "it has a wider meaning than just a few dollars of savings, since it affects something that was just considered a burden to bear."
To be sure, not all residents are counting on the state-designed electric rate reduction to be a permanent solution, and some suggest that it rests more on politics than sound financial planning. That is because the rate cuts are being made possible through a package of state subsidies, which are in turn being paid for through increased state borrowing.
"Sure, people are happy to see the bills of Mom and Pop's business go down, but there is still a lot of mistrust," said Dr. Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. "The cynical view is that this state support is simply a way of bribing voters, and if rates start to creep up after the next election, that cynicism will increase exponentially."
Business executives, economists and planners say the current surge of economic expansion has underscored its longstanding problems of traffic congestion. Although the Island's huge grid of expressways and commuter rail lines provides one of the world's best systems of private and public transportation to and from a major city, its shortcoming is its paucity of transportation links to the hubs of employment on the Island itself.
Nor are its roads and rail lines sufficient to provide the kind of access to jobs that might be filled by people living elsewhere in the New York region. Combined with the high cost of housing, which discourages new residents, that means Long Island's labor shortage may be an intractable drag on further growth, the experts said.
Still, executives like Mr. Fortunoff and economists like Ms. Kamer say worries about whether there will be enough workers to meet Long Island's resurgent demand miss a key point. The most positive evidence about the Island's economy suggests little threat of a sudden downturn, they say, even if the current pace of expansion cannot be sustained.
Such evidence underscores the deeply rooted shifts that have taken place over five years or less, having more to do with economic diversity than with rising profits or employment levels.
Among this evidence, according to a recent study by Ms. Kamer, is the Island's emergence as a formidable participant in global trade. In place of its defense industry, she said its base of entrepreneurial companies has quickly forged a thriving business in exports of computer equipment and services, high-technology consulting and other products.
Although government data that tracks such exports lags far behind that on employment and some other indicators -- the most recent data for Long Island exports is for 1996 -- it shows a sharp upswing, even as exports from the rest of New York State had declined. From 1993 to 1996, Ms. Kamer said, the value of the Island's annual exports swelled from $2.8 billion to $3.68 billion, while the total of the state's exports fell from $28.19 billion to $27.97 billion.
The time lag in such government record-keeping means that the impact of the sharp economic downturn in Asia, and its affect on Long Island exporters, is hard to measure. For some, the Asian problems have clearly hurt: Ms. Kamer pointed to a 25 percent reduction in this year's second-quarter profits at Arrow Electronics, a fast-growing company in Melville, and a warning of slower profit growth by Computer Associates, with both companies blaming the Asian downturn.
But compared to some other national hubs of export activity, Long Island for now appears on firmer footing, her research showed. That is because less than 20 percent of its exports are destined for the Far East, according to the 1996 data, with by far the biggest share going to the more stable economies, including those in Canada and Europe.
Other evidence of stability for the Island can be found in office vacancy rates, which rose to above 20 percent at the height of the recession in 1992. That high level, creating huge losses for developers and property owners, was attributed to a wave of speculative, high-risk office construction fueled by the financial euphoria of the late 1980's.
Now, real estate executives say, fresh memories of financial ruin have discouraged banks from lending and developers from building. With little new construction, office vacancy rates have remained low.
"We are seeing a mini-boom in leasing activity, and the speculative building will start sprouting up," said Joann Saul, manager of research for Cushman and Wakefield of Long Island, a commercial brokerage, referring to developers putting up buildings before having commitments from tenants.
Her company's records show the vacancy rate for the Island had fallen to slightly under 11 percent by the end of last year and has remained roughly unchanged since then.
But while the commercial real estate market is stable, home sales have surged in a wave of price increases and bidding wars that brokers say reflect the sharpest upturn in memory.
"I don't think we have ever had so much competition among buyers," Mr. Harding of Robert Harding Real Estate said. "We have really come back strong, and I see no signs of things slowing down."

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:

45 Prendergasts on View
Forty-five works by Maurice Prendergast, selected from a collection given to the Williams College Museum of Art by members of his family, go on display today through next Jan. 3 at the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College. 
 These are not the works that made the artist one of the early 20th-century icons of American Impressionism, but they constitute an intimate and insightful cache. Among the oils, watercolors, drawings, pastels and monotypes are abandoned sketches, drawings of works in progress, paintings that no one ever bought and paintings that Prendergast kept for himself.
His entrance into the world of art was almost short-circuited by his family's financial troubles, forcing him to leave school after the eighth grade. Oddly enough, his employment as a clerk in a dry goods store was where his sense of color, line and composition first developed in the sketches he drew for women's dresses.
From there he moved into commercial art, earning enough to study in Paris and return to the United States, where he quickly established a following in Boston, New York and Philadelphia.
A discussion of the works in the exhibition will be conducted today at 3 P.M. by Nancy Mowll Mathews, curator of the Williams College collection. Admission to the lecture is $6, and a donation of $4 is requested for museum admission, with discounts available.
The campus is on Anderson Hill Road. For lecture reservations, call 251-6103.
 
Avant-Garde Films
A series of 20th-century avant-garde films will be screened at the Neuberger Museum over the next few weeks. The first batch of four 7- to 15-minute films made in the 1920's is scheduled for Wednesday, beginning with "Return to Reason," Man Ray's negative silhouettes of nails, string, salt, springs and other materials placed on unexposed film. Second, "Emak Bakia" reveals Ray's early Dadaist affiliations, and "An Andalusian Dog" by Salvador Dali and Luis Bunuel is a Surrealist work supposedly created in the subconscious minds of the two men. "Anemic Cinema" by Marcel Duchamp is a succession of visual and verbal puns in the Dada mode.
Three films produced by Maya Deren in the 1940's will be shown on Sept. 23, and the final program of three films from the 50's and 60's will be presented on Oct. 7.
Greg Taylor and Iris Cahn of Purchase College's Theater Arts and Film faculty will introduce each session at 7 P.M. in the Museum Study. Admission will be $4 a session with discounts available. Call 251-6100 for more information.
 
A Jay Project Milestone
A 10-year multimillion dollar outbuildings restoration project under way for the last three years at the John Jay Homestead in Katonah, is approaching its first milestone -- the completion of work on the main barn.
In celebration, the Friends of the Homestead will hold a country fair next weekend, from which it hopes to raise more funds to help with restoring the 1812 carriage barn as a carriage and riding museum, and the late 18th-century farm manager's cottage as a small house museum. The main barn is to become a farm museum and venue for special events. Four thousand people who visited last year's fair, including patrons who attended an invitation-only party, put a total of $25,000 in the restoration kitty.
Next Saturday and Sunday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. the Jay house, on a 64-acre State Historic Site, will be open for tours. Next Sunday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. the fair will be in progress, offering a wide array of diversions, from hayrides and pony rides to magicians and storytellers, beekeeping and falconry demonstrations, blacksmithing and pottery making, two Russian circus performers and a troupe of Morris dancers.
The homestead's importance is in its history, which began in 1801 when John Jay, first Chief Justice of the United States and one of America's founders, retired with his family to what was then a simple farmhouse, which he proceeded to remodel. It stayed in the Jay family until the 1950's, becoming larger and more elegant with each generational addition and renovation.
It is on Route 22, three miles north of Bedford Village, and admission will be $15 a car, no matter how many passengers. Call 232-5651 for more information.
 
Trout Unlimited Meeting
The first meeting of the season for the Croton Watershed Chapter of Trout Unlimited will take place on Tuesday at 7:30 P.M., at the Fox Lane Middle School, Route 172 in Mount Kisco.
As it does each year, the chapter devotes this gathering to tall tales of fishing since the last meeting in May. Members and guests can bring in slides of their fishing expeditions, and they can stretch the catch by up to four inches a trout without so much as a catcall from the group. Fly-tiers will be present to give expert demonstrations, and coffee and doughnuts will be served.
Trout Unlimited is a national nonprofit organization dedicated to being a watchdog of the reservoir systems and the ecological health of streams and waterways for their fishing potential. The chapter meets for fishing- and fly-tying-related lectures and special programs on the third Tuesday of each month from September through May. For more information, call 946-7161.
 
Wide-Screen Videos
Three presentations of high-definition wide-screen video will be screened today by Cine Muse at the Philipstown Depot Theater in Garrison's Landing. Audiences will have an opportunity to check out the distributor's claim that detail and color are five times greater than conventional video.
A double bill for children at noon and 3 P.M. features "Anansi," which will be narrated by Denzel Washington and will have music by UB-40, and "Puss in Boots," narrated by Tracy Ullman with music by Luc Ponty.
Additional programs at 5 and 7 P.M. are more suitable for adults. "Henri Matisse and Midi" and "Paul Cezanne: A Life in Provence" examine the artists' lives and work in half-hour segments.
At 7 P.M. "Broadway Remembers" begins at Bowling Green and ends in Washington Heights with stops along the way for visits with Ed Koch, Donald Trump, street performers and others.
Tickets are $6, $3 for children. There are two numbers to call for reservations, directions or more information. They are 424-3900 or 424-3960.
 
Mushroom Walk
Don Shernoff, vice president of the Connecticut Mycological Association and an old hand at mushroom walks and talks, will conduct a program at the Greenburgh Nature Center today at 2 P.M.
Before going out to explore the center's trails, everyone will gather in the manor house where Mr. Shernoff will present a large collection of recently gathered mushrooms and fungi of the edible and poisonous kinds. He encourages his audiences to bring in specimens found in their backyards and neighborhoods for identification as well.
The center is on Dromore Road off Central Avenue in the Scarsdale section of Greenburgh.
The $4 fee includes admission to the museum. Call 723-3470 for more information. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/50th Street from Broadway to Seventh Avenue;
Once the Home of Horses, Now the Home of 'Cats'

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
BEFORE the old Times Tower or the Astor Hotel, before the theaters, the nightclubs or the peep shows, when it was not Times Square but Longacre Square, the area north of 42d Street was the horse center of New York City. Now, more than a century after it was built, the last vestiges of the American Horse Exchange, which became part of the Winter Garden Theater between 50th and 51st Street from Broadway to Seventh Avenue, may soon disappear.
Light industry settled along the slice of Broadway north of 42d Street in the 1860's, and by the 1870's wagon factories, harness shops and horse dealers concentrated in the area, named Longacre after the carriage district in London. 
 In 1881 William K. Vanderbilt and a group of investors built the area's biggest building, the American Horse Exchange, on the blockfront of 50th Street from Broadway to Seventh Avenue, stretching most of the way up to 51st Street. Vanderbilt's associates included leading millionaire-horsemen like William Jay, George Wetmore and Frederic Bronson -- "gentlemen of vast means," as they were called by The New York Times in 1894, to whom profits were "of no consequence."
They wanted only that the exchange be self-sustaining, that it provide a scrupulously reliable center for thoroughbred horse trading. Period accounts made it clear that there were plenty of lemons in the equestrian market.
The Times quoted auction fees ranging from $5 a head on horses costing under $300 to 5 percent on those over $1,000, and said that the two-story brick building was "the safest in the city."
But in 1896 fire swept though the American Horse Exchange, almost leveling it and killing about 60 of the 265 horses stabled there, the property of owners and dealers from as far away as Chicago, Michigan and Kentucky. Six thousand people crowded around the blazing building, sometimes blocking horses from escaping. The New York Times said that, through the windows, "crazed animals could be seen dashing blindly about in their terror." Loose horses were recovered from all over midtown.
Vanderbilt reconstructed the American Horse Exchange in 1897. His architect, A. V. Porter, reused a portion of the surviving walls to create a two-, three- and four-story structure with a high covered ring 160 by 80 feet, bridged by open trusswork and with perimeter walls of brick with round-arched windows. In the opening exhibit, Chester, a brown gelding owned by Adelaide Doremus, won in the category of best saddle horse.
Automobiles became familiar on city streets just after 1900, but in 1906 The New York Tribune derided the "totally erroneous impression that the horse is going out of fashion," pointing out that Americans owned $1.2 billion worth of horses -- 17 million animals as opposed to the 14 million of 1890. The Tribune confidently predicted a very long wait for "the funeral rites of genus equus."
BUT automobiles became increasingly popular, especially to the elite served by the American Horse Exchange. In 1910 the Vanderbilt group leased the entire site to Lee and J. J. Shubert for another theater in the Shuberts' growing chain. The Times remarked that this would "remove the last notable landmark of the old horse and carriage trade" and that, even then, the recently arrived automobile dealers were being pushed farther north by theater and hotel construction. Longacre Square had been renamed Times Square in 1904.
The Shuberts were economical, reusing much of the original perimeter walls of the American Horse Exchange and apparently using the riding-ring trusswork for the theater auditorium. They put a new temple-style front on Broadway and, at the 50th Street corner, a three-story nightclub space that extended back behind the old walls to 50th and Seventh. Their architect was W. Albert Swasey. Research by the Landmarks Preservation Commission indicates that Al Jolson made his Broadway debut in the opening theater production in 1911, "La Belle Paree."
According to Maryann Chach, archivist at the Shubert Archive, the first nightclub to open in the corner building was Palais de Danse, followed by the Montmartre, the Plantation Club, the Singapore and, by the 1950's, the Hawaii Kai restaurant.
Early photographs indicate that by the 1930's the theater facade was already covered with enormous signs, a tradition that continues today with the billboard for "Cats," which opened in 1982 and is the longest-running show in Broadway history.
Hawaii Kai closed about a decade ago, and the Shubert Organization kept the space vacant. "Times Square really hadn't turned around until three years ago," says Jeffrey S. Davis, assistant facilities director for the owner. Now that it has, he says, they are seeking a new tenant for the 12,000-square-foot space, one that would invest at least $1 million in renovation.
Such a renovation would most probably eliminate the multiple layers of history on the upper floors: Sections of the 1890's trusswork and round-arched windows, a 1910's lightbulb-studded skylight and the 1950's grasscloth wall coverings. Mr. Davis said he hoped for an agreement with a tenant this fall. Last year the Shubert Organization refaced the former Horse Exchange's 50th Street front in new brown brick, cool and reserved, in a design by Menz & Cook.
One thing that is to happen before the end of the year is the completion of the new brick facade on the Seventh Avenue side. Right now, it is an architectural leftover, with the old doors and windows of the American Horse Exchange, until now a most peculiar survivor in the new Times Square.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The American Horse Exchange, on Broadway between 50th and 51st Streets, above, circa 1910. (Office for Metropolitan History); Part of it incorporated into the Winter Garden, left, where "Cats" opened in 1982, is soon to get a partially new facade. (Librado Romero/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
For Affluent Elderly, an Array of Housing Choices

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
SATISFYING the needs and desires of America's increasingly large elderly population has become a hot new market for builders. Diverse requirements for people aged 55 and older, in various states of physical and financial health, have produced a profitable alliance between developers and health service providers, and a bewildering array of choices for customers.
One way of defining the choices available is in terms of need for assistance. Those who qualify for so-called independent living accommodations require no assistance at all with normal activities; others who have to be helped with dressing, bathing, and medication schedules fit into the assisted-living category. Still others need acute medical monitoring and treatment that have to be provided by a licensed skilled nursing unit. 
 Developers are designing and constructing the buildings to whatever level of luxury the traffic will bear. That includes everything from libraries to swimming pools, cocktail lounges and saunas. But when they offer lifelong care they are required to provide a variety of licensed health services, on call or in-house, that varies from state to state.
For Connecticut's substantial segment of wealthy older citizens, a smorgasbord of alternatives is filling a gap that resulted in part from a 1993 state-mandated moratorium on the construction of nursing homes. Intended to reduce Connecticut's Medicaid liability, the measure is still in effect, causing long waiting lists in many places.
Affluent older residents, glad to be rid of the burden of maintaining a large family home, are signing up for alternatives like 1,500-square-foot apartments that can cost half a million dollars, plus monthly charges that may reach $36,000 a year. In exchange they are assured of continuing care for the rest of their lives, and the reimbursement of 90 percent of the purchase price when the unit is resold after they leave or die.
Rentals in assisted-living residences range from about $2,700 to more than $4,000 a month for units of 350 to 750 square feet.
The high cost "is still much less than a private room in a nursing home at $10,000 a month," said Suzanne van Vechten, Director of Social Services in Wilton, where three proposals are under consideration.
Some town planners say that more projects are being proposed than can be absorbed, with some finding acceptance, and others fighting an uphill battle against zoning regulations and local opposition.
Brighton Gardens, an assisted-living prototype by the Marriott International hotel chain, was recently rejected in Greenwich, as was a complex by National Assisted Living. Both were planned for King Street, where there are no sewers or public water lines. When Carematrix, a Needham, Mass., developer, made an application on River Road in the Cos Cob section of Greenwich, the Planning and Zoning Commission decided the proposed facility had too many units. The commission, however, invited Carematrix to return after making suitable adjustments.
BUT when Greenwich planners tried to formulate townwide regulations for assisted living in order to give further consideration to these proposals, the 230-member Representative Town Meeting sent a negative Sense of the Meeting Resolution to the Planning and Zoning Commission. "The message was, 'We like assisted living, but not this way,' " said Diane Fox, the Town Planner. "There are no guidelines and no ideas about passing new ones."
David Reis, a North Branford developer who spent three years overcoming opposition to his life-care project in Redding, said, "Towns only have regulations that allow nursing homes, not assisted living." His $100 million development, called Meadow Ridge in Redding, finally was approved and has begun construction on 36 acres. Eventually to contain 382 units, it is scheduled to open in 2000 with 228 one- and two-bedroom independent living apartments of 1,000 to 1,500 square feet that will cost $360,000 to $450,000. Monthly charges of $1,800 cover housekeeping, utilities, swimming pool, dining room meals, shops and other amenities.
Brighton Gardens communities, which are rentals, have been approved for construction in West Hartford and Woodbridge, and one with 125 units has been open in Stamford for six months. Five levels of care are offered, plus a special center for residents with early to mid-stage Alzheimer's, a component that many developers are adding to their plans.
Assisted-living fees are $2,870 to $3,420 a month for studios, $3,570 to $4,000 for 1-bedroom apartments, and $500 for an additional person. Prices increase by $350 a month as levels of care rise according to the resident's needs. Monthly fees for Alzheimer's care are $3,800 for a semiprivate suite and $4,370 to $4,670 for a private suite.
Edgehill, Marriott's top-of-the-line life-care model, under construction at 2015 West Main Street in Stamford, charges entrance fees of $225,000 to $710,000. Applicants have to qualify financially and they have to be capable of independent living if they are admitted at the minimum age of 62. Monthly charges range from $1,950 to $4,000, and include 25 meals a month, housekeeping services, cocktail parties, swimming pool, billiard room, ballroom with a stage, and a health club. Edgehill is scheduled to open in the spring of next year, and binders have been taken for 198 of its 207 apartments.
Residents of Wilton opposed a Marriott application for a Brighton Gardens so strongly that the company withdrew the proposal. "Our regulations only permit that type of use on Route 7, River Road and Route 33," said the Town Planner, Wendy Johnson. The site, at the intersection of Range and Wolfpit Roads, drew criticism from a number of residents, among them Barbara Kukowski, a Range Road resident. "No one objects to senior citizen housing," she said, "but it should not be placed in a one-acre residential zone. People are afraid of impacting property values, and increased traffic."
Ms. Johnson said, "There are no plans to alter our 1996 Plan of Development," which would rule out such a facility at the Range Road site.
A proposal by Sunrise Assisted Living of Fairfax, Va., for 65 units on a five-acre site along Route 7 is within zoning regulations for density and land use, and has been approved by the Wilton Wetlands Commission, but it still has to pass muster on drainage, grading, lighting, parking and impact on the neighborhood at the commission's meeting tomorrow.
THE average age of assisted-living residents nationwide is 82 and the average stay is two years, according to John Noone, vice-president of development at Sunrise.
Manor Care of Gaithersburg, Md., proposed one of its Arden Court residences, which are solely for early and mid-stage Alzheimer's patients, on Route 1. It was approved by the Wilton Wetlands Commission and comes up for a vote at the same meeting tomorrow. "The Planning and Zoning Commission has reached a consensus to deny it," Ms. Johnson said. She cited unmet parking requirements and added that the town's regulations for congregate housing, under which the application was made, do not cover Alzheimer's units.
Other Arden Court facilities are currently being built in Farmington and Hamden.
The Greens in Wilton, built and operated by Transcon Builders of Cleveland, opened this April and is two-thirds occupied. Its residents have priority in moving to the company's existing Wilton Meadows Nursing Home next door. Primarily a nursing home builder, Transcom has nursing homes in Hamden and in Greenwich, where it is doing what many such companies are doing -- building assisted-living wings onto their nursing homes.
Arguably the most ambitious project in the state so far -- a 1,000-unit proposal in Monroe by Senior Campus Living of Baltimore, "doesn't fit into any of our regulations," said Dan Tuba, Monroe's Town Planner. "We are not sewered," he said.
Wayne M. Rush, Senior Campus Living's development director, noting that his company's application included a request that Monroe change its zoning regulations, said: "We are waiting for the Monroe Planning and Zoning Commission to consider our application. If it comes to a reduction in size, we wouldn't be interested. When you get to 1,000 to 2,000 units there is an economy of scale that allows us to deliver a certain level of quality."
Monroe has, however, granted approval for an independent- and assisted-living project of 140 units on 22 acres to J K Keillor Land Engineering Associates, a local builder. "They will run in the $170,000 range," Mr. Tuba said, "but the developer is looking for somebody to manage and operate it."
At public hearings, he said, there was little interest one way or another, except for one person who worried that too many older people might create a voting bloc that would be unwilling to approve school budgets.
It is generally acknowledged that Connecticut has awakened late to the assisted-living trend, and an attempt is being made by the legislature to catch up. At its last session, the General Assembly passed an Act Concerning an Assisted Living Demonstration Project. It clears the way for a pilot project of three identical assisted-living complexes of 100 units each to be built in urban areas, aimed at Medicaid-eligible people.
"We came to the realization that we no longer have the luxury of an all or nothing philosophy -- you can stay home or go into a nursing home," said Mark Ryan, Deputy Secretary of Connecticut's Office of Policy and Management.
Requests will be made for proposals from developers, and annual appropriations are expected to become available after July 1999. This money, per project, includes $5 million for Medicaid services of which half would be reimbursed by the Federal government; $1 million additionally for debt service on construction-renovation costs of $12 million, and $1.8 million more for rent subsidies.
"Next we hope to reach low middle-income people," Mr. Ryan said, "but middle-income will be in limbo for a while. Our challenge is to convince the legislature to subsidize them. It's less expensive than having them spend down their funds and go on Medicaid."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Ms. Honeycutt, Mr. DeScherer

 BODY:
Amanda Ann Honeycutt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Honeycutt of Dunn, N.C., was married yesterday to Christopher Kaltman DeScherer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. DeScherer of New York. The Rev. Carl Butts, an uncle of the bride and a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Inn at Bingham School, a bed and breakfast in Mebane, N.C.
Ms. Honeycutt, 29, is keeping her name. She is an economist at the Research Triangle Institute in Research Triangle Park, N.C. She graduated from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and received master's and Ph.D. degrees in economics from the University of Maryland. Her father is a salesman at Bemco Sleep Products, a mattress wholesaler in Dunn. Her mother, Betty Honeycutt, is an employee trainer for Sprint, the telephone company. 
 Mr. DeScherer, 27, was until July an associate at Cahill, Gordon & Reindel, a New York law firm. He is a legal consultant in Raleigh, N.C., to the Environmental Defense Fund. He graduated from the University of Virginia and received a law degree from Georgetown University. His father is a senior partner in Willkie Farr & Gallagher, the New York law firm.
