HEADLINE: On the Hudson, a City Within Jersey City

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
PILE DRIVERS pound great beams of steel into the earth and cement trucks pour out their burdens as office and apartment towers keep rising on the Jersey City shore -- particularly on one vast, once-desolate tract called Newport that sparked the riverfront's rebirth.
Where not much more than a decade ago there was a mazelike swath of weeded-over train tracks, lonely freight cars, rotting piers and stilled factories, a budding skyline has emerged along the 7.5-mile Jersey City waterfront. 
 At Newport alone, the 600-acre site is already dotted by seven apartment towers, two office buildings, a three-level mall, an 11-theater movie complex, an international supermarket, 16 restaurants, a helipad and a thickly masted marina -- all embraced by a riverside esplanade. And more buildings are rising.
Construction began in May on a 575,000-square-foot office complex. Ground was broken last month for a 444-unit residential building. Work is to start on a 200-room hotel by the end of October. A retail satellite to the mall is to begin by the end of the year. And construction of another rental building is scheduled for 1999.
When all of that construction is complete, it will constitute about 35 percent of the $10-billion development envisioned in the Newport master plan by the Lefrak Organization and its ebullient 80-year-old chairman, Samuel J. LeFrak.
At the same time, along the rest of the Jersey City shore -- where deep-draft cargo vessels arrive from all over the world and most of the metropolitan area's orphaned cars are barged for future scrapping (albeit having previously been reduced to very compact models) -- the state's tallest office building, 101 Hudson, stands 60 stories high, fresh residences front canals at Port Liberte and piers at Harborside, industrial parks have been cleared, development sites assembled and new construction begun.
A sugar factory is being converted into luxury condominiums. A 41-story office building is going up on the old Colgate toothpaste plant site, near the dockside 25-foot-high Colgate clock. A 26-story apartment building is under construction at the Hudson Exchange development. And old warehouses in the WALDO section -- that's Work and Live District Overlay, in officialese -- are becoming loft-studios for artists.
There remain, to be sure, less glistening facades and not so desirable habitats along many of the older streets of Jersey City, further inland. But there is no denying the burst of economic strength fueled by activity along the river -- and sparked, particularly, by Newport.
"Newport is, by far, the largest project anywhere in the city," said Bret Schundler, the Mayor of Jersey City. "Because it was the first location to enjoy significant development, they really broke the ice for redevelopment of the entire city. And because it is such a massive tract, it makes a huge contribution in terms of jobs and revenues."
Newport is Jersey City's single largest taxpayer, generating $14 million a year in real estate revenues alone.
But that, Mayor Schundler added, "is just in basic terms."
"Additionally, you have the shopping opportunities, the restaurants, the boating," he said. "It adds so many different positive elements to our waterfront" -- all part of the still-realizing dream of Sam LeFrak, the chairman and, at 80, still the eminence of the Lefrak Organization.
Sir Samuel J. LeFrak, the business card he readily proffers proclaims in elegant script, displaying no less than six heraldic coats of arms, ranging from the Knights of Malta Cross to the Order of the Lion of Finland, in raised goldleaf.
"I'm a doctor, too; I have several honorary degrees," he says.
Mr. LeFrak is hardly demure about himself or his accomplishments.
One balmy afternoon last week, standing in the bow of his 94-foot yacht a quarter-mile off Newport, wearing a Panama hat, sunglasses, tan suit and bright orange tie, Mr. LeFrak thrust both arms outward, formed V-for-victory signs with both hands and -- perhaps half-jokingly -- shouted, "We own the river!"
Hyperbolic, perhaps, but there is no minimizing his accomplishments: They are set in concrete. The Lefrak Organization, largely under Samuel LeFrak's four decades of leadership (though the Lefrak Organization uses a lower-case "f" in its name, Sam, who is of French descent, decided to keep the upper-case "F" written by a French-speaking doctor on his birth certificate), has built an estimated 200,000 apartments in the metropolitan area, mostly in classic postwar, six-story brick buildings in Brooklyn and Queens that were given the names of the 50 states and, when those ran out, of Presidents and colleges. But also in larger-scale developments, like Lefrak City in Queens, where 5,000 apartments were built in the early 60's. And at Gateway Plaza in Battery Park City, where 1,800 apartments were created in the early 80's.
"When you cut my vein, concrete comes out," he said last week.
IT was in 1983 that Mr. LeFrak first inspected the Jersey City shore, 1.5 miles of which would eventually become Newport. Richard S. LeFrak, his son, and at 53 the more staid and detail-oriented president of the Lefrak Organization, recalled those days and the effusion that came with another of his father's grand designs.
"Sam went out to visit and came back and said to me, 'Richard, I've been dreaming about something like this my whole life,' " Richard LeFrak said.
"He looked at me like I was crazy," Samuel LeFrak said.
"My father recognized immediately, in terms of its strategic location, its transportation infrastructure, that Newport would have tremendous potential," Richard said.
What the elder LeFrak actually saw was the desolation left by defunct railroads -- "miles of railroad ties and packs of railroad dogs, roaming free," he said.
But in his mind's eye, Mr. LeFrak saw a large tract suitable for mixed-use development: relatively affordable residences, office space at reasonable (compared to Manhattan) per-square-foot rates, readily available retail opportunities, sites for recreation, a PATH station 10 minutes from Manhattan, direct connections to major New Jersey highways and an on-site entrance to the Holland Tunnel -- not to mention the view, especially at sunset.
"I saw the west bank of the Hudson looking on the magnificent facade of the Manhattan skyline," Mr. LeFrak said. "And when the sun set I saw one of the most beautiful views in the world reflecting off that facade."
He was not the first developer to see the site's potential. In fact, two other companies, both with long experience in creating shopping malls, made earlier proposals to the city. And later, at the urging of the first bank to finance the land acquisition, they became partners with the Lefrak Organization in the rebirth of that barren tract of rail yard.
Jersey City's role as a mainland terminus for four of the nation's Northeast rail lines was far in the future on the day in 1630 when the first Dutch settler, Michael Pauw, arrived, said Kenneth French, chief of the Jersey City Public Library's New Jersey Room. Pauw promptly named the area Pavonia, in honor of himself.
Paulus Hook, a peninsula of what would be incorporated as Jersey City in 1838 (and adjacent to Newport), was the site of a significant Revolutionary War battle when, on Aug. 19, 1779, Gen. "Light Horse" Harry Lee, grandfather of Robert E. Lee, ousted the British from their final fortifications in New Jersey.
And during the Civil War, there occurred a rather bizarre turn of events. "About a year before Lincoln was assassinated," said Mr. French, "the President's grown son, Robert, was in Jersey City at the Pennsylvania Railroad terminal and fell onto the tracks as the train was coming. But he was pulled to safety by Edwin Booth, the well known actor and brother of the man who would kill his father a year later."
During the late 1800's and through the first half of this century, the railroads dominated the shoreline -- literally fencing it off from the city -- until containerization made it possible to move shipbound cargo directly onto and from trucks.
The current Hudson County Executive, Robert C. Janiszewski, recalls how, as a 10-year-old boy in the sweltering summers of the late 50's, he would "sneak through little gaps in the fence -- of course, I don't know how those gaps got there -- to cool off in the river."
It was not until the late 70's, after 20 years of bankruptcy proceedings, Mr. Janiszewski said, that the rail yards finally became public property -- "and I didn't have to sneak through the fence anymore."
Richard LeFrak said that "real estate people" had been interested in the property since the early 70's, "but Jersey City in those days was pretty rough, old-style machine politics; a tough town to do business with if you're an outsider."
But by the early 80's, the city was prepared to assist qualified developers in assembling portions of the property. Unlike most urban renewal projects, however, where a municipality buys land, writes down the cost and offers pieces for development, Richard LeFrak said, "Jersey City did not have the resources, so they created a mechanism by which the private developer had to purchase property from the city outright, at market rates."
ORIGINALLY, Mr. LeFrak said, the Glimcher Company, a Columbus, Ohio, developer of more than 100 shopping centers, and Melvin Simon and Associates, now one of the nation's largest real estate investment trusts, planned to develop a regional shopping mall on what would become the Newport site. "There were 600,000 people in Hudson County and they had to travel to Bergen County for their mall experience," he said.
But because the city was requiring retail, office and residential development, Mr. LeFrak said, the Simon and Glimcher companies were "referred to us by Manufacturers Hanover," and the Lefrak Organization became the prime developer.
It took about three years after Samuel LeFrak's initial tour to complete assembling the property. And the final agreement with the city called for a development that, on completion, would include approximately 4.5 million square feet of office space, 9,000 apartments, 2 million square feet of retail, 1,200 hotel rooms, a helipad and a marina. Newport constitutes all the land between Hoboken on the north and Sixth Street on the south, the river to the east and Luis Munoz-Marin Boulevard on the west.
"It's all privately financed, a variety of banks and insurance companies," Richard LeFrak said. "The most interesting thing is that we received no help on the infrastructure from the municipality. We had to build all the roads, the sewers from scratch."
"The original financing from Manufacturers Hanover was to buy the property and also finance the mall," Mr. LeFrak continued. "That was in excess of $200 million."
The Newport Center Mall, developed in conjunction with the Simon organization, is 1 million square feet of retail space, including 165 shops and three anchor tenants, Sears, J. C. Penney and Stern's; an 11-theater Cineplex Odeon complex and 5,000 parking spaces. It opened in October of 1987. And on a recent weekday, it was bustling.
Simultaneously, the LeFraks developed the first 1,500 rental apartments -- financed by $135 million in Federal Housing Administration, market-rate insured bonds issued by the New Jersey Housing Finance Agency. "So the first phase was about $350 million," Mr. LeFrak said.
In 1988, the Lefrak Organization broke ground on two additional buildings -- a 450-unit condominium, the James Monroe, and a 475,000-square-foot office building, the Newport Financial Center. The condominium building was financed by Citibank at about $60 million.
About 80 percent of the units were sold immediately, Mr. LeFrak said. "We chose to keep the balance of the units as rental, though we are now back to selling them again" -- at about $225 per square foot.
The office building was financed by Nippon Credit Bank, for about $75 million. "The Recruit Company of Japan, which specializes in ultra-high tech buildings, invested a huge amount of money in the infrastructure of the building," Mr. LeFrak said, "and turned around and subleased to tenants like Charles Schwab and Republic Bank."
The next phase of development was Newport Tower, a 1-million-square-foot office building. "That was done by the Simon organization, not us," Mr. LeFrak said. The major tenants include First Chicago Trust and Brown Brothers Harriman.
Then the real estate recession hit. "We went through a very long period when there was no money for development, between 1991 and 1995," Richard LeFrak said. There was even a point in 1990 when a $1.1-million mortgage payment was missed, and the payment schedule had to be renegotiated.
But, in Mayor Schundler's estimation, the company's contribution to the city never waned. "They slowed down during the recession, but they did not stop building altogether," he said. "What that reveals is that they are experienced developers who know how to build what the market is immediately able to absorb. And, as a result of that track record, the money is always there for them to do one building after the next."
In 1995, the LeFraks started work on Towers of America, a group of four residential buildings on a peninsula jutting into the Hudson. The first, the 32-story Riverside, has 346 rental apartments. It opened last October. Currently, rents for a two-bedroom range from $1,875 to $2,900.
The second building, the 35-story Atlantic, has 444 units. It opened on Aug. 15. Four days later, Susan Nehama and her husband, Serge, a corporate finance lawyer, moved into a two-bedroom apartment, for which they pay rent of $2,435. The next day, their son, Samuel, was born.
"We were living in Park Slope," Mrs. Nehama said, cuddling Samuel, with the family's Alaskan malamute, Bartleby, by her side. "We were subletting, but they sold the co-op. And we couldn't find anything for the rent we were offering -- $2,500."
The Nehamas saw an ad for the Atlantic, and called. "First of all, the view," Mrs. Nehama said, listing the reasons why she is happy with the move. "Then, the big kitchen, nice cabinets, good appliances. The PATH train to downtown. Then there is the mall, and the wildest supermarket you've ever seen -- every ethnic food group imaginable.
"And when you go out at night on the promenade there are tons of couples with their children. You feel like you're living in a yacht club."
CONSTRUCTION on the third building in the Towers of America complex, the 35-story, 440-unit East Hampton, has just started. And work will begin within a year for a fourth building in the quadrant, the Southhampton.
In May, ground was broken for the 15-story, $90 million Newport Office Center III, a 575,000-square-foot building that the LeFraks are financing out of their own capital. And, within weeks, construction will begin on another Lefrak-Simon development, a 200-room Marriott Hotel costing $25 million.
"At the completion of this phase of development," Richard LeFrak said, "we will have finished about 3,500 apartment units out of our total of 9,000 on site; we will have completed about 2 million feet of office space out of 4.5 million, and our retail total would be 1.2 million square feet out of our 2 million allowable. We're talking approximately 35 percent of the total." The rest of the development, he said, should be completed in about 10 years.
In one breath, Samuel LeFrak -- inching toward his 81st birthday -- declares that the Newport project "is my pinnacle. This is one of the things I will leave my heirs, my contribution, giving the people what they want and need."
But in the next breath, he says: "Even though many of my peers and colleagues have departed to their rewards, I am at the top of my game. I want to build 1,200 affordable apartments at the foot of the Williamsburg Bridge."
And, in assessing a man used to getting his way, who can tell?
"I believe in the golden rule -- the guy with the gold makes the rules," he says.
Earlier, on the boat, he recounted how, while sitting at a dockside restaurant several years ago, he chose the aquamarine-like facing for Newport's bay-windowed residential towers: "I said, 'Bring me romaine lettuce; there's your color.' "

HEADLINE: On Politics;
On One Mayor's Mind: T-Shirts and a Lot More

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson reports from New Jersey for The New York Times.

DATELINE: WILDWOOD

 BODY:
One of the perks of being the mayor of a shore town is the right to drive on the boardwalk. Everyone knows this.
In this old resort city, the police use sensible golf carts to patrol the boardwalk, but Mayor Fred Wager noses his exhausted old municipal Chevy up the ramp and parts the startled tourists (Ma! There's a car on the boardwalk!) like Moses at the Red Sea. As he drives, he looks around him, waiting for mayoral insights: "Too damn many T-shirt places," he mutters. "Maybe we need a new ordinance." 
 Traditionally, mayors have worried about garbage and street lights and stray dogs. They got involved with retail outlet issues mostly when the stores in question sold something illegal or immoral, just as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has taken on the porno shops in New York.
But T-shirt shops? Yes. In the age of mayor as showman, impresario, economic development guru and chief booster, fine tuning the retail mix is something that comes with the territory.
These days, Fred Wager worries a lot about keeping Wildwood economically afloat, decades after its prime years as a busy family summer resort came and went. If that means the Mayor has to add the role of booking agent to his other duties, so be it.
So there's a genuine rodeo on in Wildwood this weekend, with everything from bareback riding to calf roping to barrel racing, and sanctioned by the Professional Rodeo Cowboy Association to boot.
"I did that," the Mayor said, gesturing to a poster for the rodeo. "They said I was crazy when I called up the rodeo people and told them to come down here. But we got the fire truck out there and wet down the sand for them and it was just like what they were used to, and they said, 'OK!' "
A new convention center, another of the mayor's projects, is in the works, one suited to mid-size groups like the state firefighters union, which faithfully comes to Wildwood each fall. And in his longest shot, Mr. Wager wants to put a casino on a parking lot downtown.
There was a time when economic development took care of itself, when downtowns had more demand for space than they knew what to do with, and when there was a waiting list of businesses trying to invest on Main Street.
In some places still -- Princeton, and particularly Princeton's Nassau Street, come to mind -- demand remains so strong that mayors and city councils are kept busy managing growth, not trying to get more.
But in Wildwood and other places where boom times of the 1950's and 1960's rolled in and then receded, economic development is not automatic any longer. And while western mining towns and New England farm settlements may have been allowed to decline more or less gracefully until they disappear, cities are harder places to walk away from.
"People used to just move away, but today there is too much of a core investment in most places to just give it up," said James W. Hughes, dean of the school of planning and public policy at Rutgers. "As a result, it has become part of the political culture to expect the politicians to take the leadership role in saving the downtown."
So Mr. Wager drives along the boardwalk and worries about the kinds of things that used to be the problems of businessmen, not politicians.
The trolley, which trundles tourists up and down the boardwalk, costs $1.75 for a ride -- too much, the Mayor believes: with a lower price, maybe the half-filled cars would carry more people past the shops, T-shirts and all. He makes a mental note to ask about the trolley fare when the ride's franchise is up for renewal.
Then he worries about the bicycles on the boardwalk. They are supposed to be off by 10 A.M., to give the cash-carrying, money-spending foot traffic an unimpeded chance to sample the arcade games, the saltwater taffy shops, the pizza joints and the T-shirt emporiums. But here it is, nearly 11, and the bicyclists are still weaving in and around the growing number of pedestrians. Mental note: enforce bike ban after 10 A.M.
Then the Mayor begins to worry about a problem that most coastal towns would consider a blessing -- between the boardwalk and the sparkling ocean lies an immense beach, 400 yards of open sand, combed and sifted daily by the city's beach machinery.
While dozens of other shore communities spend millions pumping beach sand onshore, the vagaries of tide and wind and current have conspired to dump too much sand on Wildwood, the Mayor thinks.
Too much sand means a water's edge too distant to produce easy, commercially rewarding wandering from shoreline to boardwalk storefront, and too distant from boardwalk restrooms for toddlers experiencing a suddenly urgent need of a bathroom. Too much sand for people to cross, period,
"Too much sand," the Mayor mused. "I wish someone would take some of it away."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE;
Last Call for New Bars? Trendy Clothiers Move In

BYLINE: By ALISA TANG 

 BODY:
A cluster of trendy clothing and accessory shops are popping up in this neighborhood, in storefronts that once might have become that standard Lower East Side institution: the bar.
The change stems partly from the belief of the fashion world that the cool crowds that made the night scene in the neighborhood might also want to shop there during the day. But it also results from an anti-bar policy that Community Board 3 instituted in May 1997 and that will continue through the year 2000. Under the policy, which the board calls a moratorium, it will oppose all liquor licenses along a three-block stretch of Ludlow Street from Houston to Delancey, and along two blocks of Rivington and Stanton Streets, unless the establishment has a full kitchen, a fact that the board will verify. Even for bars with kitchens, the board may still oppose the application. 
 Of course, the board has no power to grant or reject licenses; that is the province of the State Liquor Authority. But the board's approach does deter new bars, said Marcia H. Lemmon, a local resident who fought for the policy.
"We think it has psychologically prevented bars from coming to the neighborhood," Ms. Lemmon said. "Bar owners realize that neighbors don't want only bars in the neighborhood."
In the last year and a half, four clothing and accessories stores have opened in vacant storefronts, and another three are set to open this fall, all near the intersection of Ludlow and Stanton Streets.
Ms. Lemmon said she she hoped the new stores would help the Lower East Side's economy and tone down the loud, crowded night life that keeps some residents sleepless.
Another optimist is David Gatenio, the owner of the 47-year-old Carl and Sons Clothing on Orchard Street. "In the next five years," he said of this influx of pricey, trendy stores, "the L.E.S. will be just like SoHo and even better because the buildings are newer."
But while many store owners and residents agree that the bar scene is oversaturated, many also fear that as these jet set stores move in, rents will skyrocket -- as they did in SoHo.
Terry Gillis, the owner of TG-170, a six-year-old clothing store on Ludlow Street, worries that large corporations will open boutiques. "The idea of this neighborhood is that smaller businesses can afford to open up," she said. "With big corporations, the rents get jacked up and entrepreneurs can no longer afford to come in."
Apartment rent is what concerns Pam Karp, an actress who has lived on the Lower East Side for eight years. "In a few years this neighborhood will no longer be for lower-income people," she said.
Tony Melillo, who hopes soon to open Nova USA, a clothing store on the northwest corner of Ludlow and Stanton, felt the heat from this debate recently when someone wrote "Go Back to SoHo" on his new storefront. A typed note left on his window told him, "We don't want you rich bohemian kids." ALISA TANG

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2762 words

HEADLINE: Back to Vietnam, This Time toBuild

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam

 BODY:
THE last time Samuel F. Champi was in Vietnam, he was a 24-year-old Army engineer, building a 1,000-foot-long steel bridge across the Ban Thach River on the central coast. The bridge was to be a crucial link on the main north-south highway used by American military convoys, so he pulled round-the-clock shifts to complete it by early 1969.
On a tropical afternoon nearly three decades later, Mr. Champi stood stiffly in a gilded reception room here as the deputy chairman of the People's Committee of Ho Chi Minh City awarded him a license to build 40,000 low-cost apartment units in the suburbs of this teeming city, once known as Saigon. If completed, the project will be one of the largest American business investments ever in Vietnam. 
 For Mr. Champi, now 53 and a contractor in Bernardsville, N.J., it would also be a chance to return to Vietnam and pick up where he left off -- as a builder in a land where Americans mostly destroyed.
Not that he would put it that way. Mr. Champi says he has few misgivings about his experiences in the Vietnam War. And he rejects the suggestion that he is coming back on a personal odyssey to right old wrongs or to put the war behind him. "I don't think we owe the Vietnamese anything, because we were doing what we thought was right for them at the time," he said.
Still, he concedes that history hangs over the project. Three of his partners are Vietnam veterans, and so is the retired admiral who brokered the deal, Edward D. Sheafer Jr. Mr. Champi's company, Point Enterprises International, is named after the United States Military Academy at West Point, where he and two other partners were part of the class of 1966. Over all, that group suffered one of the highest mortality rates in the war of all West Point classes.
"You could say this is an accident, but it ain't no accident," said Tom Carhart, a partner and classmate of Mr. Champi's who was wounded twice as an infantry officer in Vietnam. "I was a soldier, and I did my duty as a soldier. But we caused a lot of damage in that country. It's nice to go back and do some good."
Mr. Carhart and Mr. Champi are among growing numbers of veterans who are returning to Vietnam to forge ties in a place where they once fought in battle. Several executives at Vietnam offices of American corporations served in the war; so did many of the American consultants, entrepreneurs and even diplomats who are now active here. Pete Peterson, the United States Ambassador to Vietnam, is a former Navy pilot who was shot down by the North Vietnamese and imprisoned for more than six years; Charles A. Ray, the newly appointed consul general in Ho Chi Minh City, served tours in Saigon and Da Nang as an Army staff officer.
Most veterans here, like thousands of other Americans who have arrived since President Clinton lifted the trade embargo in 1994, are hoping to make money in this awakening land. With 75 million people, a plentiful supply of cheap labor and one of the few economies in Southeast Asia that is still growing, Vietnam is a tempting target for sharp-eyed business people.
But for veterans, there are motives beyond the monetary one. Whether they feel at peace with their experience here or are still nursing scars, the war has left a lasting imprint on them. Because they were witnesses to the anguish borne by the Vietnamese, most believe they can play a part in healing the wounds between the United States and Vietnam.
"There is a real feeling of happiness on both sides that former enemies can work together in a positive way," Mr. Ray said. "The best people to bridge the past and the future are the people who were here in the past. That will make it easier for Americans in the future to get on with business."
Certainly, the veterans are dogged in their determination to succeed in a country where many foreign investors have failed. Like most new arrivals, Mr. Champi and his partners have found doing business here nearly as difficult as fighting a war, complicated by capricious regulation, endless red tape and the hostility of Communist bureaucrats to free-market principles.
The obstacles are so great that some American companies, like Chrysler, have pulled out of Vietnam, while others, like Procter & Gamble, have fallen into vicious squabbles with their state-controlled partners. Asia's financial crisis has compounded the problem by forcing the main investing nations, like Singapore, Taiwan and Japan, to scale back their ambitions in the country. New foreign investment in Vietnam plunged to $1.15 billion in the first six months of 1998, 15 percent less than in the corresponding period last year.
MR. CHAMPI believes that his housing project will be one of the rare successes because it meets a crying need. With a population that has swelled to 5.5 million, Ho Chi Minh City is seriously overcrowded. Families of 10 cram into tiny apartments; people sleep on the sidewalks on bamboo mats. In 1994, the government announced a plan to address the overcrowding by moving two million people from the city center to outlying districts. But to do that, it must supply them with affordable places to live.
"We're not here to build luxury hotels or take advantage of the labor force," Mr. Champi said. "We're here to build something there's a great need for. It's not something that we have to sell them on."
Even so, after two years of tortuous negotiations, Point Enterprises could still see its efforts come to nothing. The company has an agreement in principle for the municipal government to buy $321 million of apartments over 11 years. The partners stand to make a profit of $39 million, but first they need financing to build a factory that would churn out the pre-cast concrete slabs for the apartments.
To get the financing, they will need a guarantee from the municipal government -- and perhaps the national one, too -- that the city will honor the contract terms. On Aug. 18, Mr. Champi and Mr. Sheafer received a verbal commitment for such a guarantee from city officials. They are now nervously awaiting the written document.
"If we're unable to finance this deal, it's going to bring the sharks out," said Mr. Carhart, a gregarious man whose free-flowing pessimism neatly balances Mr. Champi's reserved confidence. "This is a crap shoot. It's a high-risk venture thousands of miles from home."
But the partners have not wavered, despite having invested $250,000 so far with no assurance of a return. They have maintained their resolve by drawing on a lifetime of close friendships and a shared experience that makes Vietnam a passion as well as a project.
In addition to Mr. Carhart and Mr. Champi, the partners are John W. Morris, a retired Army lieutenant general and chief of engineers of the Army Corps of Engineers; Vincent Casillo, a New York City contractor, and James P. Fabiani, a senior executive at a Washington lobbying firm. With the exception of Mr. Fabiani, all are West Point graduates, Vietnam veterans or both.
Mr. Morris was Mr. Champi's regimental captain at West Point and later a group commander of the Corps of Engineers in Vietnam, where he again supervised Mr. Champi. At 77, with service in World War II, Korea and Vietnam behind him, Mr. Morris is a sort of guiding light for the group.
"I've always felt the Vietnamese deserved a better shake than they got," he said. "They were caught in the middle of historical forces."
Mr. Casillo played middle linebacker on the West Point football team in the same years that Mr. Champi, who is 6 feet 5 inches tall, played tight end. They graduated together in 1966, and even though they did not serve together afterward -- Mr. Casillo was assigned to duty in Europe -- they stayed in touch.
"People who go to West Point are conditioned to be particularly close," Mr. Casillo said. "When you are with a group of people who came from the same system, there's a camaraderie that never ends."
Although the West Point contingent had already teamed up to explore projects overseas, it was a Naval Academy graduate, Mr. Sheafer, who put them on the road to Vietnam. A bluff, barrel-chested man who had risen to rear admiral and director of naval intelligence, he had been struggling to build a consulting practice in Vietnam since he retired from the Navy in 1995.
Like Mr. Champi, Mr. Sheafer is not one to dwell on the war. But as a career military officer, he felt its lingering effect. He served several tours of duty in Vietnam between 1963 and 1970, at one time commanding a minesweeper that prowled the coastal waters near the border between South and North Vietnam.
In one memorable incident, he said, he watched helplessly as two fishing boats smuggled ammunition across the border from the south. He tried to block the boats, but the Navy's rules of engagement barred him from firing on them unless they fired first. He ordered an air strike, but the bombers arrived after the boats had landed in the north and emptied their cargo.
For years afterward, Mr. Sheafer labored in a military that had been demoralized by its failure in Vietnam. He said he did not come to terms with the war until 1984, when he paid a midnight visit to the rotunda of the United States Capitol. The body of an unknown soldier from Vietnam, who has since been identified as an Air Force pilot, Michael J. Blassie, was lying in state there before its entombment at Arlington National Cemetery.
"I was standing there in my dress uniform, and suddenly I began crying, not because of my own hostility, but because of the futility of the whole thing," Mr. Sheafer recalled. "There was no good legacy for these people. What did they die for?"
BY the time he retired, the American military had rehabilitated its reputation with the Persian Gulf war. But to him, Vietnam was still unfinished business. So when a lawyer he knew approached him about starting a home security company in Vietnam, he jumped at the chance.
Mr. Sheafer plotted his return methodically. He recruited his own interpreter. He played up his admiral's rank and connections to senior American officials.
But the going was slow. He had trouble making contacts with the right Vietnamese officials. The lawyer who promised to open doors for him failed to deliver. He spent long days in an office set up in the lounge at the upscale but somewhat dreary New World Hotel here, waiting for the phone to ring.
Finally, in late July 1996, he won a meeting with Vo Viet Thanh, the chairman of the People's Committee of Ho Chi Minh City. As it happened, Mr. Thanh had been a general in the North Vietnamese army and had supervised intelligence operations. Mr. Sheafer and Mr. Thanh chatted about the shadowy world of military intelligence, and a rapport was established.
Mr. Thanh told Mr. Sheafer that the city's biggest need was for cheap housing that could be built quickly. He said he had an immediate need for about 200,000 apartments, with a long-term goal of 500,000. Mr. Sheafer replied that he would find an American contractor who could do the job. Through Mr. Carhart, who is his neighbor in McLean, Va., Mr. Sheafer stumbled onto Mr. Champi.
AT first, Mr. Champi was fearful about going back to Vietnam. But he made a happy discovery upon his arrival: Younger Vietnamese did not care about his background, while older people, many of whom had fought in the North Vietnamese Army or with the Vietcong, felt a sort of kinship with him.
"I think all military people have a bond, regardless of what side they were on," Mr. Champi said. "We were all doing our jobs for our country."
Over the next 18 months, Mr. Champi and Mr. Sheafer made a dozen trips to Ho Chi Minh City. Their goal was to persuade the municipal government to agree to buy as many apartments from them as possible. Eventually, they hammered out a deal for 40,000 units at an average price of $8,025 each.
The apartments, 320 to 860 square feet in size, will be stacked in four-story blocks, using prefabrication technology developed by a Finnish company, Partek Concrete Engineering. In that process, a factory produces standardized panels of pre-cast concrete, which are then assembled quickly into buildings, eliminating the need for structural steel girders, beams or columns.
Despite the Lego-block construction method, Mr. Champi said the finished buildings could last 100 years. To sell the design, he flew a team of Vietnamese architects to Singapore to inspect apartments built with the same technology.
The negotiations would follow a serpentine path, with breakthroughs in one session often being erased in the next.
Initially, for example, the government pushed foreign investors to establish joint ventures. So Point Enterprises took on a Vietnamese company as a minority partner. But last February, the Vietnamese partner -- a company that collects bills for the city government -- petitioned to change the terms of the joint venture in a way that would have relegated the Americans to mere subcontractors.
The move stunned Mr. Champi and his partners, who had put up all the seed money for the project. Fortunately for them, it came just as a ground swell of anger and frustration with joint ventures was developing among prominent foreign investors, including Procter & Gamble.
In March, Vietnam's Prime Minister, Phan Van Khai, agreed to allow foreigners to own 100 percent of business ventures in any industry not deemed strategically important, like oil and gas or communications. Point Enterprises received permission to sever ties with its Vietnamese partner and go it alone.
Still, Mr. Carhart said, "there are other impediments to doing business in Vietnam." Progress is often slow, and "individuals that approve projects have to answer to higher-ups, so no decision is ever final," he explained.
At the ceremony in Ho Chi Minh City where Mr. Champi received his investment license, the deputy chairman of the People's Committee, Tran Thanh Hai, tried to sound definitive. "We are committed to extend our support for the continuation of the project," he said as he gingerly raised a glass of champagne.
Ambassador Peterson, who had come from Hanoi to attend the ceremony, struck a more cautionary note in a speech. "Issuing licenses is the easiest part of the job," he said, "Implementation is the key word."
At a reception after the ceremony, several Americans who live in Ho Chi Minh City handicapped the project's future with weary cynicism. They predicted that the partners would suffer more setbacks before they broke ground. "They're about 5 percent of the way there," said Peter N. Sheridan, a Vietnam veteran who, like Mr. Sheafer, helps put together ventures.
Vietnamese officials know all too well that their country has a bad reputation among foreign investors. But they say the Government is working to clear the bureaucratic underbrush. One official noted that when Vietnam decided to open its economy in 1986, the Government expected to have a decade or more in which to move from central planning to a market economy. But foreign investment began flooding into Vietnam by 1991 -- and with it came calls for accelerated change.
"Of course, things are not as smooth as we would wish," said Nguyen Dinh Mai, the vice director of Ho Chi Minh City's department of planning and investment. "But they have improved a lot."
ODDLY, given the time and money they have invested, the partners of Point Enterprises seem almost fatalistic about the outcome. Mr. Champi said he would treasure his trips to Vietnam even if he never got to put up an apartment block. "That may sound naive and unbusinesslike, but it's true," he said.
For Mr. Carhart, the mere act of returning to Vietnam was its own reward. As an infantry platoon leader, Mr. Carhart saw fierce fighting in the war, and was shot twice in 1968. Then he was recruited into Operation Phoenix, a controversial program supported by the Central Intelligence Agency that sought to root out Vietcong agents working in South Vietnam, sometimes by killing them.
"I have terribly mixed feelings about Vietnam," Mr. Carhart said. "On the one hand, I did my duty. On the other hand, I've grieved deeply."
Last October, on one of his business trips to Vietnam, Mr. Carhart took a day off and visited the small town south of Ho Chi Minh City where he was based during his tour with Operation Phoenix. The house where he had planned his missions, he said, had been converted into a convent.
"Going back to that town put wings on my heart," he said. "You can't go home again, but you can sure close the circle."

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Hispanic Businesses Try to Move Up the Charts

BYLINE: By EDWARD LEWINE 

 BODY:
THE tiny office behind the displays of lamps, doorknobs and coffee grinders was crowded Tuesday morning. Natan Wekselbaum and three associates were plotting the expansion of his East Side housewares emporium Gracious Home to Broadway and 67th Street, where a branch is to open this month.
"It was a hardware store, a 25-foot storefront" when it opened on Third Avenue between 70th and 71st Streets in 1963, Mr. Wekselbaum said. "But little by little we listened to our customers and just kept adding on." The store now measures 33,000 square feet and sits on both sides of the avenue. 
 Gracious Home, which took in $30 million last year, is among the relatively small number of Hispanic-owned companies in the city with revenues in the multimillions. Joel Russell, an editor of Hispanic Business magazine, said that there were 94,000 Hispanic firms in New York State but that only 17 of them were on his magazine's list of the 500 Hispanic businesses in America with the highest revenues. The list was compiled from responses to a questionnaire.
"The statistics don't say that Hispanic businesses aren't starting in New York," Mr. Russell said. "They are. But they aren't growing to the size to get on our list."
Of New York City's 70,000 Hispanic businesses, only 10 are on the magazine's roster. They have annual revenues ranging from about $5.5 million to $275 million, and operate in such diverse areas as construction and tourism.
There are a variety of theories about the sparsity of Hispanic heavyweights in New York. Israel Bulbank, a Cuban immigrant and president of the Unalite Electric and Lighting Corporation of Woodside, Queens -- No. 313 on the list -- said it was hard in general for Latino business people to find investors in corporate America, so those who live in states like California and Florida, which are closer to Latin American money sources, have an easier time. Mr. Russell also said that entrepreneurs in rapidly expanding cities found it easier than those in more established places, like New York.
George Herrera, president of the United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce in Washington, said the problem was linked to the high cost of real estate, which makes it difficult to open a large business in the city. "New York is more of a retail economy," he explained.
But some companies grow large nonetheless. Consider Dial-a-Mattress, a business familiar to local television viewers, who are regularly exhorted by the company's advertisements to call 1-800-Mattres and "leave off the last S for savings." The venture was started in 1976 by Napoleon Barragan, an Ecuadorean immigrant. As Mr. Barragan, tells it, he began his career by working in a furniture store in Long Island City, Queens.
"One day I was reading The New York Post," he said, "and I saw an ad for Dial-a-Steak. So I said, 'Let's try mattress.' " His company, which is still situated in Long Island City and delivers mattresses around the nation, estimates that it will have revenues of $90 million this year. Mr. Barragan is now working with his son Luis -- his likely successor -- to expand abroad.
Dial-a-Mattress is typical of the city's larger Hispanic-owned businesses. Many were founded in the 1960's and 70's and grew slowly. Many are still run by their founders, middle-aged or older men who are now thinking about passing on the business to a son. Though for some the majority of their trade is with the Latino community, the larger companies have broken out of the ethnic economy.
"These are firms that have penetrated the general marketplace," said Mr. Herrera, adding that he suspected many of the larger firms had the backing of non-Hispanic business people.
Many owners of larger companies said that being Hispanic was incidental to their work. "To be in business is something that anyone can do," said Mr. Wekselbaum, who was born in Cuba. "It doesn't have anything to do with background."
But some of the smaller large companies, those with revenues in the $5 million to $15 million range, rely heavily on Latino business. La Rosa del Monte Express, for example, was founded in 1968 as a moving company in the Longwood section of the Bronx. But soon the founder, Hiram Rodriguez, began to specialize in moves between his native Puerto Rico and the United States.
He said being Hispanic had been a huge help. "The Hispanic community is really growing," he said. "They really support us."

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Aiming to Thwart Theft Behind the Counter

BYLINE: By NOELLE KNOX 

 BODY:
KELLY GREEN and Karri Carter spent a night late last month in McLean County Jail in Bloomington, Ill. Both were sales clerks from the nearby Wal-Mart, arrested in the store and charged with ringing up sales to phantom customers, recording bogus returns and then pocketing cash refunds of more than $300.
Ms. Green, 31, and Ms. Carter, 27, who are scheduled to be arraigned this week, declined to discuss the case; Bryan Holmberg, a spokesman for Wal-Mart Stores, would say only that "this kind of incident is very rare." But if they are convicted, the women will become another statistic in a rising tide of employee theft in retail stores. 
 One of the few disadvantages of a robust economy, human resource administrators say, is its effect on hiring practices, especially among retailers. The nation's unemployment rate has held at well below 5 percent this year; in some states, like Minnesota and New Hampshire, it is skirting 2 percent. The shrinking labor pool, consultants say, gives employers fewer hiring choices, exacerbating other changes in employment patterns that have contributed to worker theft in recent years.
"The employment base is low, and retailers are not getting a lot of people who are extremely qualified," said David Johnston, director of training and research for LP Innovations, the loss-prevention subsidiary of J. Baker Inc., a Canton, Mass., retailer that owns the Casual Male Big and Tall clothing chain. "If the company doesn't have an effective screening program, they're going to get whoever comes in off the street."
Retailers reported a surge in employee theft last year, according to the latest National Retail Security Survey by the University of Florida. The companies in the survey attributed 47 percent of all lost cash and merchandise to the light fingers of their workers, up from 41 percent in 1996.
"We have never seen employee-theft numbers quite this high," said Richard Hollinger, a sociology professor at the university. The survey, now in its eighth year, polled 201 retailers nationwide.
If the survey results are accurate for the industry as a whole, workers stole $13.3 billion of the $28.1 billion in cash and merchandise that retailers lost last year. By comparison, shoplifting -- which gets far more publicity as a source of retail crime -- accounted for only $9.6 billion, or 34 percent. The remainder was lost to vendor fraud and administrative error.
To deal with theft problems, more retailers are running employee background checks through organizations like the United States Mutual Association, a clearinghouse on theft and fraud cases. Much of the information it collects about employee theft and shoplifters is provided by the retailers themselves, to be shared with other retailers.
Robert Ralicki, vice president of marketing for United States Mutual, which counts Sears, Roebuck and Gap Inc. among its subscribing companies, said it had 2.5 million cases of employee theft in its data base. That number, he said, should double within two years as more retailers contribute information.
"Retailers have limited resources they can devote to background checks for entry-level personnel," he said, "but they want to know if John or Jane Doe has a track record of dishonesty before they give them access to their cash and merchandise."
RETAILERS are also spending millions of dollars a year on new technology to combat employee theft, a category of spending that barely existed a decade ago.
Among the fast-selling items are cash register software programs that track unusual transactions, like a high number of voided sales or several returns to one credit card. When the software senses trickery, a nearby closed-circuit camera focuses on the employee.
The Sensormatic Electronics Corporation of Boca Raton, Fla., said that new orders for employee-surveillance technology soared 17 percent last year and have more than doubled over the last five years; by comparison, Sensormatic said, its shoplifting technology sales have grown just 25 percent over the same period.
"We are seeing more business from small and midsize retailers because the technology is more affordable and they can't afford not to use it," said Donald R. Taylor, director of market planning for Sensormatic.
Surveillance equipment for a small store can cost $5,000 to $10,000 -- and the investment may well pay off. According to the University of Florida study, an employee who steals will take an average of $1,058 in cash or merchandise in a year, while a shoplifter will walk away with an average of $212.
Beyond the smaller pool of available labor, other changes in employment patterns are contributing to the rise in employee theft, retail security consultants say. Retailers that stay open later or operate seven days a week, for example, tend to rely more on part-time employees, who may lack a strong sense of loyalty to the company.
High turnover, another abettor to theft, also dogs the industry, because an entry-level retail job is no longer seen as a first step on a career path. And working conditions at retail jobs can also lead to a discontented work force. Security experts say that employees caught stealing often said they felt unfairly treated, overworked or underpaid.
Steve Kasserman, a loss-prevention officer at the Bi-Mart Corporation, a discount chain based in Eugene, Ore., has his own explanation for this kind of thinking. "If you pay someone $6.50 an hour to stand on their feet," he said, and to take whatever insults the public dishes out for seven to nine hours a day, "they get mad, and eventually they'll take it out by stealing."
Jealousy may also be a motivation, especially in the era of executive stock options. "Whenever you have a chief executive officer who makes millions," Mr. Kasserman said, "the lowest ranks of employees will always feel the need to play Robin Hood -- with the exception that they never return any of the goods or money."

GRAPHIC: Chart/Graph: "Sticky Fingers"
In recent years, employee theft has eclipsed shoplifting as the main cause of lost cash and merchandise at retail stores. Last year, retailers attributed almost half their losses, or $13.3 billion of the $28.1 billion in missing cash and goods, to thefts by workers. Shoplifters were held responsible for $9.6 billion, or 34 percent. The remaining losses are chalked up to vendor fraud or administrative error. HEADLINE: VIEWPOINT;
Little Industries Mean a Lot to Manhattan

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin, a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy in Malibu, Calif., writes often about urban issues.

 BODY:
WITH the Wall Street money machine suddenly in turmoil, New Yorkers might increasingly see their economic salvation in unfashionable places like Varick Street. Made up largely of older brick industrial buildings just three or four subway stops from the world's financial center, the area is a key part of the city's $3 billion printing industry.
Yet there is growing apprehension among Varick Street printers. As rents soar in surrounding areas, many of them fear they will soon be forced to find new homes farther from their clients in Manhattan's flourishing media, arts, business-services and financial industries. 
 "Fewer and fewer people feel they can remain in Manhattan, said Stuart Leventhal, executive vice president of Empire Graphics on Varick Street, the sole New York City manufacturer on last year's Inc. magazine list of the nation's 500 fastest-growing private companies. "There's a feeling that the real estate interests don't want printers and related businesses around."
These fears have been compounded by recent announcements by Trinity Real Estate, the area's premier landlord and the real estate arm of Trinity Church, that many leases with printers will not be renewed. In the trade publication Printing News, Steve Heyman, director of commercial leasing at Trinity Real Estate, suggested that Trinity wanted to move out companies it considered too noisy, too dirty and too smelly.
Mr. Heyman said in a subsequent interview that some printers, particularly those using the latest desktop technology, could remain in the district because they did not offend more conventional office clients. In the last decade, he added, many printers have failed to make payments, moved out or closed up shop. By retrofitting the buildings for office tenants, he said, Trinity can gain a more stable client base and charge rents that are two or three times those now paid by printers.
Varick Street is emblematic of the continuing struggle to preserve economic diversity in a city increasingly dominated by one sector -- financial services. Although New York has long served as the nation's financial capital, recent studies show that the city's reliance on financial services and related businesses has reached new, perhaps alarming, levels.
In the bull market of the 1980's, according to a recent report by H. Carl McCall, the New York State Comptroller, Wall Street accounted for 23 percent of the city's income growth. In the bull market of this decade, the financial sector has contributed 56 percent of the earnings increase.
As the Wall Street expansions of the 1960's did, the recent boom has energized the city's economy. But it has driven up real estate costs for industrial companies as developers and landlords try to lure more upscale tenants. A recent survey of manufacturers by the New York Industrial Retention Network found that more than half the manufacturers in Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island thought real estate costs had increased significantly in the last year; in Manhattan, 77 percent of the manufacturers agreed.
SUCH real estate pressures, said Fred Levine, chairman of the Industrial Technology Assistance Corporation and president of Marcus & Wiesen, a garment maker in Queens Plaza, contributed to a loss of 30,000 manufacturing jobs from 1992 to 1997. Even successful executives like Mr. Leventhal blame the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for pursuing zoning policies and subsidies that favor housing, offices and high-profile retailers at the expense of small manufacturers.
But Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission, disputed the notion that City Hall is biased against manufacturers. He said regulatory changes and tax cuts had helped create more than 4,000 mostly small-scale manufacturing companies, which he saw as representative of the future of New York's industrial economy.
"Our goal is to do nothing that displaces viable manufacturing districts, but you can't solve every problem," he said. "We can't tell a landlord what he can do with a commercial lease." He added that many of the lower-level jobs lost in manufacturing could be made up by the retail and tourism sectors. And the media, computer and business-services companies now found in the space abandoned by printers and blue-collar industries also diversify and enrich the economy, he said.
Mr. Rose suggests that the pressure on manufacturers is part of a process that began four decades ago.
After World War II, New York City was one of the world's most diverse industrial economies, with roughly a million workers. Its factories made everything from steel pipe and machine parts to furniture, books, brochures, light fixtures and apparel.
Fernand Braudel, the late French historian, noted that these small businesses, most employing less than 30 people and often clustered by industry in areas like Varick Street, offered customers almost instant delivery of specialty goods in ways that would be impossible for more remote suppliers in less diverse economies. He and others contended that these sectors helped cushion boom-and-bust cycles.
But by the 1960's, New York's industrial sector really began to shrink, as companies fled the city's high taxes and land costs. Today, manufacturing employment is roughly 260,000, a quarter of the level of the immediate post-war period. And in the last quarter-century, the deterioration has accelerated; in apparel, the largest New York industrial sector, there are roughly 80,000 workers, a third as many as in the mid-70's.
Some people, including Robert Fitch, an urban economist at New York University, say the shrinkage has contributed to the city's growing income inequality which, according to a recent study by the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities, a research center in Washington, is now the widest in the nation. Although not as high-paying as jobs in securities, media and other elite sectors, New York's dwindling manufacturing jobs pay more than $39,000 a year, on average -- 20 percent more than hotel work and nearly twice as much as retail jobs.
OF course, New York is not the only city that has seen a precipitous fall in industrial employment. Between 1978 and 1997, manufacturing jobs in the nation basically stagnated at roughly 16 million. But in urban centers, the number of such jobs fell from 4.1 million, to 1.6 million, according to the Industrial Technology Institute, a research center in Ann Arbor, Mich.
But in a handful of other places, including Phoenix, Houston and Los Angeles, industrial employment has been growing. Houston, for example, has added a total of roughly 20,000 industrial jobs the last three years. Although much of the growth is connected to the petrochemical and refining industries, the city has also seen gains in food processing, machine tools and transportation equipment.
Bill Gilmer, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Houston, traces this resurgence, which followed precipitous declines in the 1980's oil bust, to two important factors: the development of highly concentrated expertise in the energy sector and an immigration trend that has provided motivated labor and entrepreneurial zeal. Houston's success can also be traced to its relatively low taxes, low real estate costs and business-friendly attitude.
Los Angeles, though, seems more relevant to New York. Los Angeles County, the region's urban core, also has relatively high taxes and real estate costs. But after a sharp decline in manufacturing jobs at the end of the cold war, it has rebounded, becoming the country's leading industrial area last year. It has added roughly 30,000 industrial jobs since 1995.
Interestingly, Los Angeles's current manufacturing economy parallels the old New York model of small, highly diverse companies. It has seen job growth in food processing, metals, bicycle parts, furniture and aerospace. But perhaps most significant has been the growth in the apparel and textile sectors, which have added more than 15,000 jobs since 1995.
While some people trace the growth of Los Angeles manufacturing to its big pool of low-wage workers, including many illegal aliens, similar conditions exist in many other cities, including New York. More important may be the development of dense networks of supplier firms, designers and a wealth of aggressive entrepreneurs, including many immigrants from Asia, Latin America, the Middle East and North Africa.
Nowhere is this more pronounced than in downtown Los Angeles. Once largely filled with unoccupied, dilapidated factories and warehouses, the area has seen industrial vacancy rates drop to the low single digits.
To Orly Dehan, president of the apparel maker Tag Rag, it is the proximity to suppliers and other essential services that makes downtown Los Angeles such an appealing industrial area. Designers, factories and factors -- the financial middlemen between manufacturers and retailers -- are within a 10-minute walk or drive of one another, explained Mr. Dehan, who came to Los Angeles via Montreal and Morocco in the early 1980's.
"When I go to New York," he said, "you can sell in Manhattan, but the factories are in Pennsylvania."
PROXIMITY is precisely why companies like Empire Graphics -- which employs 60 people, mostly members of minorities -- prefer to stay in places like Varick Street. Like other bastions of New York manufacturing, including custom furniture and food processing, printers thrive on close interaction with customers, suppliers and, perhaps most important, with one another. Indeed, despite real estate prices that are often at least 50 percent higher than in the outer boroughs, most of the city's fastest-growing industrial companies continue to cluster in Manhattan or in places like Long Island City, just across the East River in Queens.
All this may seem out of place in an era of instantaneous global communication, but such face-to-face links are still important.
"Our customers don't want to spend money and time to check the work we're doing for them," Mr. Leventhal said. "They want to be able to walk, get in the cab or subway to check the proofs. When push comes to shove, the ability to be local and close -- to see what's going on -- is more important than being in the global village. That's why we're still here."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
The Sellers? Hint: They Don't Live Around Here

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
More sellers than buyers. That's the glib explanation for why stocks couldn't keep a good head of steam going last week. After a fine showing on Tuesday, when the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 380 points, sellers took back the reins. The Dow ended the week mustering a 2 percent gain.
Where is all the selling coming from? Anecdotal reports have had institutional investors bailing while individuals hang tough in their portfolios. Robert Adler at AMG Data Services concurs, reporting that money continues to head into stock mutual funds, despite recent market volatility. 
 In the week ending Wednesday, $1.6 billion went into large-capitalization growth funds; lesser amounts flowed into small-stock funds. Net of sales, a total of $1.4 billion went into equity funds for the week.
More significant, employee contributions to mutual funds via their retirement plans still seem to be on automatic pilot. "The small investor-401(k) base hasn't appeared to have stirred at all," Mr. Adler said.
What is stirring is the foreign investor, a huge force in the market for United States Treasury securities and an increasingly important one in stocks. By many accounts, foreign investors have been responsible for much of the recent divesting of stocks. "Heavy selling at the market opening is a sign of overseas investors' getting out," said Jack H. Shaughnessy, president of Boston Advisors Inc., a money management firm. "It concerns me, because since 1995 foreign investors have been a big factor behind rising stock prices."
The Federal Reserve Board released data on Friday about investment in the second quarter of 1998; they show a big slowdown in net purchases of American equities by foreign residents even before the market's summer swoon. While these investors bought a net $116.1 billion of stocks in the first quarter, net purchases in the second quarter were just $55.4 billion.
Pushing overseas investors out of equities is the decline of the dollar against the Japanese yen and the German mark. The dollar is down 11.2 percent against the yen from its Aug. 11 high; it is down 4.8 percent against the mark in the same period.
When foreign investors buy American stocks, they subject their portfolios to currency risk in addition to the risk that the shares will decline. As the dollar weakens, foreigners' investments lose ground, even if the prices of the underlying shares remain the same. When the stocks themselves fall, the foreign investor is doubly hurt.
Mr. Shaughnessy says he thinks foreign selling of stocks began in earnest on July 21. That was the day Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, testified before Congress, saying investors' expectations for continued high levels of corporate earnings growth had risen to possibly unsustainable levels. "Foreign investors either stopped buying then or they started to sell," Mr. Shaughnessy said.
Foreign selling of American stocks is likely to continue through the end of the month. That's because Sept. 30 is the end of the first half of Japan's fiscal year. "In September and March, Japanese investors tend to move into cash," explained Carl B. Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y. "They take profits as best they can." Since they have big losses in Japanese stocks, they'll probably be selling American stocks. It also means that unless big buyers emerge elsewhere to support stocks here, investors can expect further weakness.
