HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
If the Yankees Had McGwire, Would McGwire Have the Record?

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Put Mark McGwire in this season's Yankees lineup, and how many games do they win and how many home runs does he hit? Those are questions that will never be answered, but are tantalizing to ponder.
When it became clear to the Oakland Athletics that they had to trade McGwire last year because they were going to lose him as a free agent, the Yankees jumped in at the last minute and expressed interest. 
 "The Yankees wanted to buy Mark for cash," Sandy Alderson, the Oakland president, recalled. "But we rejected the idea. I think their proposal was intended to bait the hook, but it was too late in the day and that wasn't the road we wanted to take. In spite of the fact that we weren't going to get value for value, we wanted to acquire players."
Had the Yankees succeeded in securing McGwire and re-signing him for this season, they and he would have benefited. As strong as the Yankees' lineup has been this season, he would have made it significantly stronger. And if he had remained healthy all season, as he has with St. Louis, there's no reason to think he couldn't have hit all of those home runs with them.
The most difficult problem would have been persuading him to accept what could have been the largest contract ever given a baseball player to remain in New York. That he stayed in St. Louis was even something of an upset.
"We were in New York, then we went home and we made the trade and he had to go back to Philadelphia," a member of the Oakland organization said. "He said, I'll help Tony out, finish the year with him, but no way was he going to stay there. They overwhelmed him."
The Cardinals had some advantages that other teams did not. Tony La Russa, who had been his manager in his first nine years in the major leagues, was the St. Louis manager, and some of the coaches were the same, too. Walt Jocketty, the general manager, had also been in Oakland, as the assistant general manager.
Alderson himself felt McGwire would decide to stay in St. Louis even though he had clearly expressed a desire to play in southern California, where his son lived. "Mark is a humanist," Alderson said. "Those human or personal considerations and relationships mean more to him than geography, as long as he could reconcile the situation and the camaraderie he found there with his desire to be with his son more frequently."
Jocketty, who had relentlessly pursued the trade, thought he had a chance to keep McGwire in St. Louis. Before he made the trade, he studied the southern California teams and decided that not many options would be available to McGwire there. Then the St. Louis fans clinched the deal.
"The first week of September," Jocketty related, "I got a call from his representative, Bob Cohen. Mark wanted him to come to St. Louis and talk to us about a new contract."
The trade and the contract should make Jocketty the executive of this year as well as last.
Some people in St. Louis were critical of the trade, the general manager recalled. "They didn't know Mark McGwire," he said. "I think they compared it to the Blues' deal with Wayne Gretzky. They gave up some young talent and he walked at the end of the season."
But McGwire stayed, and St. Louis is where he broke the home run record. "None of us who were associated with Mark were happy about losing him," Alderson said. "This was not a trade for value. It was strictly an economically compelled trade. Of course we would've loved to have this happen in Oakland, but that hasn't transpired. It's not clear it would have happened in Oakland."
Nor in New York, but it's fun to wonder.
 
The McGwire Effect
Working for the Cardinals, Mark McGwire is making money for other teams. Based on the larger crowds that paid to see him play in Chicago, New York, Pittsburgh, Miami and Cincinnati the past month, McGwire has created about $2.6 million of revenue in additional ticket sales. Add in concessions and parking, and McGwire is a one-man fund-raiser.
He is also making money for himself. A clause in his contract pays him $1 for each Busch Stadium admission beyond 2.8 million; the Cardinals reached that figure in their last home game, which happened to be the game in which he hit No. 62. He has now picked up an extra $7,599 and should earn about $425,000.
"We'll be happy to pay it," General Manager Walt Jocketty said.
McGwire, however, holds another unique position in the baseball economy. He is the only player who ever filed for a salary cut in arbitration. In 1991 McGwire had a $2.85 million salary and earned $25,000 for being named to the All-Star team.
After hitting .201, he submitted the same $2.85 million for a 1992 salary, but it represented a cut because of the bonus he had earned. He and the Oakland Athletics, who filed for $2.45 million, compromised at $2.65 million, and he made an extra $250,000 in bonuses.
 
Johnson Called the Record
Randy Johnson called it two and a half years ago. Speaking in spring training of 1996 about the possibility of someone breaking the home run record, Johnson, then with the Mariners, tabbed his former teammate at the University of Southern California.
"People probably forget about him because he's been injured so much," Johnson said of Mark McGwire. "I'd like to see him with a full year." If McGwire got that year, Johnson added, "I would bet money that if anybody did it, it would be Mark McGwire before anybody else."
McGwire, incidentally, is the first member of a team other than the Yankees since 1919 to hold the home run record. In 1920, Babe Ruth hit 54 home runs, breaking the record of 29 he set the previous season with the Boston Red Sox. Roger Maris succeeded him.
 
Drew's Quiet Debut
 After focusing unfavorable attention on himself for a year by shunning the Philadelphia Phillies' efforts to sign him, J. D. Drew gained a promotion to the major leagues last week when more attention could not have been focused elsewhere. He reported to St. Louis the day Mark McGwire hit his 62d home run.
"He hit 61 before we played yesterday," Drew said before his first game with the Cardinals, referring to his game with their Memphis minor league team. "I was hoping I didn't miss 62 while we were playing. It's nice of him to wait."
Drew made his major league debut in that game, striking out as a pinch-hitter two innings after McGwire broke the record. The next night, after McGwire batted twice before a sellout crowd in Cincinnati, Drew took his spot in the batting order and hit his first home run.
 
Santo Remembers
After it happened, Ron Santo said simply: "What can I say? It just happened, that's all." But 29 years later, the former Chicago Cubs' third baseman had plenty to say when he was asked about a play that was pivotal in the outcome of the first race between the Cubs and the Mets for a post-season spot.
The play occurred in a game between the Cubs and the Phillies in Philadelphia on Sept. 11, 1969. The Cubs had squandered a nine-and-a-half-game lead and had tumbled out of first place the night before with their seventh successive loss. This night they wanted to stop their skid and pull even with the Mets.
They had a 1-0 lead in the third inning, and Dick Selma, their pitcher, had a 3-2 count on Rich Allen with two out and runners at first and second. When he went into his stretch, though, instead of pitching to Allen, Selma threw toward third, figuring he could catch Tony Taylor, who was running with the pitch.
But the throw caught Santo by surprise, and the ball sailed high over his head. The stunned look on his face remains vivid three decades later. Taylor scored the tying run on the pitcher's error, and the Cubs went on to lose.
Santo, now a broadcaster with the Cubs, explained from the safe vantage point of 1998 that he and Selma had worked on a play in spring training that year that was designed for use in the Allen situation.
"He would say to me, 'Knock the ball down,' " Santo related. "That was his clue to me that when he started in the stretch he was going to come to third base. Now this is in September, and we have not had this play on once the whole year.
"Dick Allen's the hitter so I'm playing behind the bag. Moonie yells over, 'Knock the ball down.' I'm thinking, yeah, I'll knock the ball down. I'm getting ready and all of a sudden he throws the ball over my head. I said later what are you doing, and he said, 'We had the play.' I said what play? I said we haven't done that play all season."
Leo Durocher was not a happy manager those days. The division championship was rapidly slipping out of his grasp, and he was powerless to turn his fortunes around.
"I don't want to go in the clubhouse," Santo said, describing the scene. "Durocher is livid. He's all over Selma. I'm standing there and I can't interfere with him because he's so angry. When he stopped yelling, I said, 'Skip, we had that play,' and I explained it to him. He said, 'Moonie, how could you do that when you haven't done the play all year?' "
But Santo all of these years later still accepted some of the blame. "You'd think he would have called me over," he said. "I felt just as guilty of losing that ball game as Selma."
 
Interleague Play's Future
The executive board of the Players Association is in the process of approving interleague play for next season, though the vote will not be unanimous. Some players oppose the format because of the extra travel problems it creates. Representatives of the players and owners hope to work out those problems by the 2000 season.
Although the owners' labor representatives indicated before this season that they wanted to discuss the demise of the designated hitter for next season, they have withdrawn that proposal.

INTERNATIONAL 3-15
 
Cuba Frustrates Hopes Of Church After Pope Visit
Roman Catholics in Cuba have grown increasingly frustrated and disappointed since the January visit by Pope John Paul II. Church officials say that while religious people generally feel a greater sense of freedom, the Castro Government has shown little new flexibility in things like admitting foreign priests and nuns or granting permits for religious processions. 1
 
Crucial Election in Bosnia
Bosnians vote in elections that are the most tension-free since the war, and in many ways the most important to Western peace efforts. All offices above the level of municipal council are at stake in the ballot, which pits still-powerful nationalist forces who led the country to disaster against more moderate politicians who want to end strife. 8 

Growing Threat to Amazon
Fires set by farmers and ranchers to clear land in Brazil have become a greater threat than ever to intact rain forest and to indigenous peoples, environmental groups say. The number of fires have more than doubled this year over last, according to Government figures, and many are burning out of control due in large part to the drying effect of El Nino. 4
 
Sifting Solutions in Russia
Russia's new Prime Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, began sorting through a pile of conflicting economic plans and emergency measures that arrived from all quarters. Moscow's Mayor proposed reversing the results of years of privatization efforts. And former Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev offered a blueprint centered on an international rescue plan to guarantee private savings deposits. 8
 
NATIONAL 22-46
 
Clinton Lawyers Push Hard To Counter Starr's Report
Mounting a blistering counterattack to defend President Clinton from impeachment, the White House rejected the independent counsel's charges of abuse of the Presidency as a "hit-and-run smear campaign" deliberately steeped in gratuitous "pornographic specificity," in a 42-page detailed rebuttal of the 445-page series of accusations and revelations -- officially known as a referral -- submitted to Congress on Friday by Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel. 1
 
Kenneth W. Starr, a deeply religious man, whose father, a fundamentalist minister, used to deliver sermons back home in Texas on the perils of women in Bermuda shorts, has sent an impeachment report to Congress chock full of explicit sexual details. 1
 
As chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, Henry J. Hyde has suddenly been thrust into the most visible and difficult role in his political life as he prepares to preside over any impeachment inquiry against Mr. Clinton. 1
 
Acknowledging that it had been an "exhausting and difficult week," President Clinton tried to turn the nation's attention toward his policy agenda, announcing new grants to fight drugs and calling on Congress to support his economic priorities. 37
 
Minnesota Sons in Primary
The candidates seeking the Democratic nomination for governor of Minnesota includes the sons of two former Vice Presidents, the son of a former Minnesota Governor and the son of a department store magnate. The front-runner in the primary on Tuesday is Hubert H. Humphrey 3d, the State Attorney General, whose father's memory still evokes reverence in the state. 22
 
NEW YORK/REGION 49-61
 
After Quick, Strong Start, Ferraro's Campaign Falters
With two days to go until the state primary, the nomination of Geraldine A. Ferraro as the Democratic candidate for United States Senate over two rivals, Mark Green and Charles E. Schumer, has come to be viewed as anything but assured. Many Democratic leaders, pointing to public and private polls, as well as anecdotal evidence, say they wonder if they are watching the final days in public life for the woman who made history 14 years ago by running for vice president. 49
 
One Minute in Harlem
Although not as violent as the 1988 Tompkins Square Park riot or other clashes between crowds and the police, the Sept. 5 youth rally in Harlem that ended in a brief but furious melee has disrupted the already tenuous relationship between the Giuliani administration and the city's black population. An analysis of videotapes, radio broadcasts and eyewitness accounts shows how four factors caused the event to explode in conflict just when it seemed to be nearing a peaceful end: the appearance of a police helicopter; the tossing of a chair at police officers; the closing words of the rally's organizer, Khallid Abdul Muhammad, and the phalanx of officers making for the generator just behind the stage -- all taking place within one minute. 49
 
Suspended Officer Apologizes
A New York City police officer who was suspended Friday for wearing blackface on a Labor Day float in Queens came forward yesterday morning, apologizing for his actions and asking to be forgiven for what he termed a "terrible mistake." The 30-year-old officer, Joseph Locurto, has been suspended without pay. 51

HEADLINE: THE NEW SEASON/THEATER;
THE ANNOTATED LISTINGS

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS

 BODY:
Here is a selective guide to coming theatrical events in New York City and beyond. Unless indicated otherwise, all dates listed are for openings, all addresses are in Manhattan, and all telephone numbers have a 212 area code. The addresses and phone numbers of frequently mentioned theaters are on page 19.
 
September
 
THE SECRET HISTORY OF THE LOWER EAST SIDE -- It sure doesn't get any more site-specific than this: three plays about the Lower East Side, performed on the roof of a high school on the Lower East Side. En Garde Arts, the wandering theatrical flock that makes its nests in the unlikeliest of places, unveils an evening of works by Carlos Murillo, Peter Ullian and Alice Tuan. Opens tonight. The roof of Seward Park High School, 350 Grand St. (279-4200) 
CULTURE OF DESIRE -- The idiosyncratic Anne Bogart tackled the visionary Robert Wilson last season in "Bob." Now she takes on that guru of pop art, Andy Warhol. In previews. Opens Wednesday. New York Theater Workshop.
A STREETCAR NAMED DESIRE -- Michael Wilson, the ambitious new artistic director at Hartford Stage, begins a marathon re-examination of Williams with this overwhelmingly lyrical New Orleans tragedy. In previews. Opens Wednesday. Hartford Stage, Hartford. (860-527-5151)
WIT -- Margaret Edson's smart and compassionate exegesis of a terminally ill professor, played by the excellent Kathleen Chalfant. A wrenching look at how a hospital treats a dying woman who happens to be a John Donne scholar. In previews. Opens Thursday. MCC Theater, 120 W. 28th St. (727-7765)
GYPSY -- It's Betty Buckley's turn. She's the mother of all stage mothers in one of the all-time great backstage musicals. The production, directed by Mark Waldrop ("When Pigs Fly"), features Deborah Gibson as Gypsy and Lenny Wolpe as Herbie. In previews. Opens next Sunday. Paper Mill Playhouse, Millburn, N.J. (973-376-4343)
THE MYSTERY OF IRMA VEP -- The incorrigibly campy spirit of the late Charles Ludlam again invigorates the theater district with this revival of the 1984 Gothic spoof that ran and ran and ran. Here's hoping things get completely out of hand. In previews. Opens Oct. 1. Westside Theater, 407 W. 43d St. (239-6200)
THE UNEASY CHAIR -- Evan Smith's comedy pits a spinster landlord against a confirmed bachelor who has a room in her boardinghouse. Dana Ivey and Roger Rees hope to drive each other crazy, onstage at any rate. In previews. Opens Oct. 4. Playwrights Horizons.
A NIGHT IN NOVEMBER -- Dan Gordon plays a spectrum of Northern Irish characters in the return of this acclaimed one-man show by Marie Jones about hostilities in Belfast on the day of a crucial soccer match. In previews. Opens Oct. 4. Douglas Fairbanks Theater, 432 W. 42d St. (239-6200)
ELABORATE LIVES: THE LEGEND OF AIDA --Walt Disney Theatrical Productions, fresh from the World Series-size triumph of "The Lion King," tries out Elton John and Tim Rice's version of the story of Aida in the precincts of the nonprofit theater world. Nineteen songs by Messrs. John and Rice, and a book by Linda Woolverton are being staged by Robert Jess Roth. Will Disney rise yet again? In previews. Opens Oct. 7. Alliance Theater Company, Atlanta. (404-733-4600)
MARCO POLO SINGS A SOLO -- The John Guare year commences for the Signature Theater Company, the group that gives you one living American playwright's oeuvre each year. Mel Shapiro, who directed the original production at the Public Theater in 1977, is reunited with Mr. Guare, guiding a cast that includes Polly Holliday and Chuck Cooper. Previews begin Tuesday. Opens Sept. 25. Signature Theater Company.
ELECTRA -- Zoe Wanamaker took London by storm in Sophocles' tale of homicide and parricide. Ms. Wanamaker and the director David Leveaux try to draw blood again in Frank McGuinness's visceral adaptation. Claire Bloom, Pat Carroll and Stephen Spinella are among those joining the cast. Previews begin Tuesday. Opens Friday. McCarter Theater, Princeton, N.J. (609-683-8000)
MEASURE FOR MEASURE -- The far-out Target Margin Theater, which had a particular success last season with "Mamba's Daughters," inaugurates another year of tweaking the classics with a new version of Shakespeare's problem play, directed by the estimable David Herskovits. Previews begin Wednesday. Opens Sept. 23. Connelly Theater, 220 E. Fourth St. (358-3657)
THE DYING GAUL -- Craig Lucas's angry, if uneven, satire returns with Cotter Smith, Linda Emond and Tim Hopper in Mark Brokaw's expertly staged production. Performances begin Friday. Vineyard Theater.
DEATH OF A SALESMAN -- The oldies often have the goodies, and the director Robert Falls hopes he has gathered a basketful in his cast: Brian Dennehy as a big, barrel-chested Willy Loman; Elizabeth Franz as Linda and Kevin Anderson as Biff. Previews begin Friday. Opens Sept. 28. Goodman Theater, Chicago. (312-443-3800)
HESH -- A tug-of-war across the generation gap, set in the Bronx and spanning 20 years in the struggle between a father and son. Frank Pugliese directs Matthew Weiss in Mr. Weiss's own script for Naked Angels. Previews begin Saturday. Opens Sept. 27. Intar Theater, 420 W. 42d St. (479-7304)
OEDIPUS -- Colleges have their Greek weeks; New York seems to be getting a whole season. Billy Crudup ("Arcadia") and Frances McDormand, an Oscar winner for "Fargo," are the big names in this Blue Light Theater Company adaptation by Dare Clubb that is being billed as "a new play." Uh huh. Previews begin next Sunday. Opens Oct. 11. Classic Stage Company. (279-4200)
'TIL THE RAPTURE COMES -- A drama with an Appalachian accent arrives in the young playwright Edward Napier's small-town study of unhappiness and addiction. Pamela Berlin ("Steel Magnolias") directs the dependable Pamela Payton-Wright. Previews begin Sept. 22. Opens Oct. 6. WPA Theater.
CORPUS CHRISTI --Terrence McNally and the Manhattan Theater Club have been playing it close to the vest about this modern Christian allegory concerning the spiritual quest of a gay man, presumably modeled on Jesus. When word got out last spring about the play's content, conservative religious groups called for a boycott, anonymous threats were reported to have been made and the theater canceled the production. An uproar among playwrights and others in the theater world led to a reinstatement of the play, and now the public gets to see what all the fuss is about. Previews begin Sept. 22. Opens Oct. 13. Manhattan Theater Club.
IMPOSSIBLE MARRIAGE -- Beth Henley, a Pulitzer Prize winner for the tear-stained comedy "Crimes of the Heart," looks into the union of a woman and her older, unattractive, unfaithful husband. The play is also a reunion for Ms. Henley and Holly Hunter, who is her star. Previews begin Sept. 23. Opens Oct. 15. Laura Pels Theater, Roundabout Theater Company.
MEDEA -- The National Theater of Greece, which brought a riveting production of "Electra" to City Center two seasons ago, pays a return visit with another bloody tragedy about a ferocious woman with the murder of her relatives on her rap sheet. Performed in modern Greek with English surtitles. Sept. 23-26. City Center, 130 W. 55th St. (581-1212)
REDHEAD -- The original 1959 production of this musical murder mystery was directed by Bob Fosse. Christopher Ashley directs the revival of an infrequently revived show. Sept. 23-Dec. 13. Goodspeed Opera House, East Haddam, Conn. (860-873-8668)
THE BERLIN CIRCLE -- Shades of Brecht: the Berlin Wall is coming down, the world is changing and a young woman tends to an abandoned child. The visually gifted Tina Landau ("Floyd Collins") directs Charles L. Mee's new spectacle. Previews begin Sept. 24. Opens Oct. 4. Steppenwolf Theater Company, Chicago. (312-335-1650)
DANTE'S INFERNO -- Now this is serious: five performers, including the violinist Gil Morgenstern, explore the first poem of Dante's trilogy "The Divine Comedy," as interpreted through the ages by other artists. From the translation by Robert Pinsky, the United States Poet Laureate, who also adapted it, and directed by Robert Scanlan for the Unterberg Poetry Center at the 92d Street Y. Sept. 26-Oct. 4. Playhouse 91, 316 E. 91st St. (996-1100)
DUET! -- The incisively funny, genre-bending Adobe Theater Company makes a big move, settling into the Actor's Playhouse for a season and starting off with the return of its eclectic, stiletto-sharp spoof of date movies, amusement parks, Catskills comics and third-rate Sinatra knockoffs. Previews begin Sept. 28. Opens Oct. 8. Actor's Playhouse, 100 Seventh Ave. South. (239-6200)
LITTLE ME -- Could this be the vehicle that finally sends Martin Short into the Broadway stratosphere? If all he got to do was his impression of Jerry Lewis singing for an adoring French audience -- "You'll jamais walk alone" -- Mr. Short would be home-free. Whether he does as well as Sid Caesar once did with this 36-year-old musical, based on the novel by Patrick Dennis, with book by Neil Simon, music by Cy Coleman and lyrics by Carolyn Leigh, will soon be apparent. All the signs are promising, though: Mr. Simon has updated the book, Rob Marshall ("Cabaret") is the director and choreographer, and Faith Prince is Mr. Short's co-star. Previews begin Sept. 30. Opens Oct. 29. Roundabout Theater Company.
 
October
 
MORE TO LOVE -- Broadway is the host of a bunch of new playwrights this season, and the first up is Rob Bartlett, sidekick to the cranky king of morning radio, Don Imus. Jack O'Brien directs Mr. Bartlett and Dana Reeve in a comedy about a man on the brink of 40 and success in television. Previews begin Oct. 1. Opens Oct. 15. Eugene O'Neill, 230 W. 49th St. (239-6200)

BAND IN BERLIN -- Wilkommen back to the final days of the Weimar Republic for this docu-musical based on the experiences of the Comedian Harmonists, five singers and a piano player who thrilled audiences in Germany and around the world, until the Nazis took power and deemed the group's three Jewish members unfit to perform for the German people. The story sounds fascinating, but who came up with the cutesy title? Begins Oct. 2. Opens Oct. 15. Theater to be announced. (307-4100)

The current craze for turning movie tuners into stage musicals continues with this teen-filled extravaganza, based on the 1984 movie that featured Mr. Bacon and John Lithgow, and one of three original musicals scheduled for Broadway this fall. Walter Bobbie, who brought a nasty 90's edge to "Chicago," will try to gloss over the sappier aspects of the story, adapted from Dean Pitchford's screenplay about an American town so repressed it doesn't allow its high school students to dance. The choreographer A. C. Ciulla sets a cast of 37, including Dee Hoty, Martin Vidnovic and Jeremy Kushnier, hopping. Previews begin Oct. 2. Opens Oct. 22. Richard Rodgers Theater, 226 W. 46th St. (307-4100)

Wager, tackles the emotionally complex issue of adoption. Performances begin Oct. 2. Arena Stage, Washington. (202-488-3300)

Opens Oct. 26. Triad Theater, 158 W. 72d St. (799-4599)
THE OLD SETTLER -- A charming, old-fashioned tear-jerker by John Henry Redwood. Leslie Uggams heads a cast directed by Harold Scott. Previews begin Oct. 7. Opens Oct. 28. Primary Stages.

Orensanz Center for the Arts, 172 Norfolk St. (307-4100)

PARADE -- The story of Leo Frank, a Jewish factory manager wrongly convicted of -- and later lynched for -- the murder of a young girl in Georgia in 1913, sure doesn't sound like the jumping-off point for a major new musical, but that didn't stop the book writer, Alfred Uhry, the composer, Jason Robert Brown, or the director, Harold Prince, the chief architects of "Parade." The musical represents a major-league debut for Mr. Brown. His fortunes changed -- he had been composing revues and incidental theater music -- after Mr. Prince took him under his wing. The cast is headed by Brent Carver (a Tony winner for "Kiss of the Spider Woman") and Carolee Carmello. It is one of the season's high-stakes entries. Previews begin Nov. 12. Opens Dec. 17. SECTION: Section 7; Page 43; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 664 words

HEADLINE: Manifest Destiny

BYLINE: By Adam Garfinkle; Adam Garfinkle is the executive editor of The National Interest.

 BODY:

WHAT AMERICA OWES THE WORLD
 The Struggle for the Soul
 of Foreign Policy.
 By H. W. Brands.
 326 pp. New York:
 Cambridge University Press. Cloth, $49.95. Paper, $17.95. 
 On a few occasions I have inflicted a course entitled "Wisdom of the Ages" on graduate students at the School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University. The course teaches the intellectual bloodlines of United States foreign policy by focusing on key thinkers and practitioners from Revolutionary times to the present. When compiling the syllabus, I wished for a book like H. W. Brands's "What America Owes the World" -- for Brands generally manages to trace those bloodlines concisely and with consummate skill.
A professor of history at Texas A&M University, Brands organizes his effort around a key dichotomy: exemplarism versus vindicationism. These somewhat clunky terms signify the difference between those Americans who have believed that the United States owes the world only its example, and those who have believed that it owes a more vigorous and direct sharing of its gifts. Both groups have presumed the existence of those gifts -- that's what American exceptionalism is about, after all -- a presumption made vivid in Brands's opening chapter, which deals with America's first century, or roughly half of American history. Such economy makes sense for, as Brands points out, the conflict between exemplarism and vindicationism could not mature until the United States had grown into a world power.
Once he arrives at the Spanish-American War, Brands weaves the major events of a period around a key thinker (or, occasionally, a pair of thinkers). His main men are Brooks Adams, Walter Lippmann, Lincoln Steffens, Charles Beard, George Kennan paired with Hans Morgenthau, Reinhold Niebuhr, Herman Kahn, William Appleman Williams and Norman Podhoretz. As he proceeds from one to the next, Brands adeptly draws connections between ideas, circumstances and authors (though he sometimes gets so involved in pocket biography that his theme seems to vanish for pages at a time). What he also achieves, without mentioning it, is an illumination of the direct and indirect power of political journalism, by showing how Harper's, The New Republic, Commentary and other magazines have influenced public policy over the years.
Brands concludes by suggesting that the battle between exemplarists and vindicators has not, cannot and should not end. As he puts it, "the outcome to aim for is what Morgenthau might have called a balance of intellectual and moral power, with each side keeping its arguments sharp, the better to keep the other honest."
His own narrative is true to this spirit of dialectical centrism. Brands does not side with exemplarists or vindicators but, rather, arrays them in context. "History has proven both parties to the debate right," he says, because both sides possess a part of the larger but more elusive truth.
Brands is not completely balanced, however. He does incline slightly leftward, particularly as the subject matter becomes more contemporary (he less picks than picks on Norman Podhoretz, for example). His choices of the obscure and obscurantist Adams, the erratic if colorful Steffens and the revisionist Williams also suggest a greater interest in, if not sympathy for, men of the left. And some fairly important figures go missing: Frederick Jackson Turner is never mentioned; Alfred Thayer Mahan is barely noted.
Nevertheless, it isn't easy to pack so much, and so well, into just over 300 pages. Brands's keen sense of intellectual evolution and knack for vivid summary often lead him close to wisdom, a virtue enhanced by a judicious use of quotations from his principals. The writing is unfailingly clear, often lyrical, occasionally witty. The book's imperfections notwithstanding, students of foreign policy should count themselves lucky to have "What America Owes the World" at hand. At least one instructor does.

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 906 words

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Intel's positive forecast leads many analysts to think that technology stocks' worst may be past.

BYLINE: By Lawrence M. Fisher 

 BODY:
INVESTORS seized on some unexpected good news Friday from Intel, Oracle and National Semiconductor to drive technology shares higher.
Upside surprises have been few and far between in recent months, so there is a strong incentive among prospective stock buyers to extrapolate a recovery in technology from these three data points. And indeed, some analysts said that so many companies had either warned beforehand of poor results or had come in below estimates in the quarters ending in March and June that a sizable number would now beat Wall Street's diminished expectations for September and December. Whether that kind of performance qualifies as a recovery is still open to discussion. 
 Look at Intel, which said Friday that its third-quarter sales would be 8 to 10 percent higher than the $5.9 billion reported in the second quarter, rather than flat, as it had suggested earlier. While 10 percent sequential revenue growth is enormous, it is only in comparison to the weak June quarter, which showed no revenue growth over the period a year earlier and a 29 percent drop in earnings.
Similarly, National Semiconductor said revenue would be up over earlier forecasts because of strong August orders, but it said orders were still down 30 percent, year over year.
For its part, Oracle announced per-share earnings on Thursday that were several cents above analysts' estimates, thanks primarily to stronger-than-expected license revenue from its traditional data base business. But in applications, where Oracle has placed its hopes for growth, revenue was flat, and the company still lags far behind rivals like Peoplesoft and SAP of Germany. Oracle remains the dominant data base company, but that market is widely regarded as mature.
Nevertheless, many analysts are ready to call a bottom. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange semiconductor index, which reached a peak late in April, nearly three months earlier than the broader technology sector as reflected by the Nasdaq composite index, may also turn out to be an early indicator of a market turnaround. The semiconductor index was up 8.70, to 211.52, on Friday and has now gained 11 percent from its 52-week low on Sept. 1 of 190.04.
"The PC inventory correction is over and PC demand is seasonally higher in the second half of the year," said Mark Edelstone, an analyst with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. He noted that the pickup in National Semiconductor's orders was primarily in the company's personal computer-based product lines, and that Intel, of course, was uniquely positioned to benefit from stronger PC sales.
"Intel is the first company to get healthy," he said. "The rest of the industry still lags."
Mr. Edelstone said he did not expect many positive surprises in the semiconductor business in the third quarter, but he does in the fourth. "We will see a contraction of the negative surprises," he said. "In the second quarter, more than 20 semiconductor companies preannounced negatives; 55 percent were below estimates. I think we can cut that number in half."
Michael Murphy, editor of the California Technology Stock Letter, takes an even more bullish view. "What's going to happen going forward is what we're seeing today," Mr. Murphy said on Friday. After scaling back earnings estimates in the first half of the year, "in the September and December quarters, technology companies are going to beat estimates pretty generally because we're in the right part of the product cycle," he said, adding, "At the same time, the Asian crisis is finally biting in the old economy."
Technology companies could flourish even as blue-chip companies head into recession because they are typically driven by product cycles rather than economic cycles. With the Microsoft Corporation's release of Windows 98 in May, and its anticipated release of Windows NT 5.0 next year, more corporations are likely to upgrade their PC's, and that will ripple through the industry, Mr. Murphy said, giving a lift to makers of semiconductors, disk drives and software.
John Rossi, a managing director with BancAmerica Robertson Stephens, said technology stocks were the first to fall as a result of the Asian crisis but might also be the first to recover.
"The blue-chip companies took longer to feel the effects of Asia, but next year a lot of these companies will do the bulk of their spending to fix year 2000 problems," Mr. Rossi said. "Maybe not a lot will happen in the first half, but the second half of the year should be very strong, thanks to Windows NT and 13th-hour spending on year 2000."
Roger McNamee, a principal in Integral Capital Partners, which specializes in technology stocks, agrees that technology companies could prosper, even in an economic downturn, but he takes a more cautious view. Personal computer technology, he said, "is the likely place people will do triage in terms of capital spending."
"Every company sees technology as their way out of this economy," Mr. McNamee added.
But technology producers will not all benefit equally, Mr. McNamee said. The current market is good for a company like Dell Computer, which is selling ever-greater percentages of higher-end servers, and challenging for Hewlett-Packard, selling more and more low-priced consumer PC's.
"What Intel is telling you is, 'Hey, the world didn't end,' " he said. "But as much as everyone would like to draw broad conclusions, I don't think it's appropriate."

HEADLINE: With Ford Out, Korean Car Makers Will Battle Over Kia

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 13

 BODY:
An auction of South Korea's ailing Kia Motors and its truck-making affiliate, Asia Motors, may turn into a pitched domestic battle now that the only foreign contender, the Ford Motor Company, has dropped out.
With Ford out of the bidding, the Hyundai Motor Company, the Daewoo Motor Corporation and Samsung Motors are the only companies left in the running. Bids must be submitted by next Monday, with the winner to be announced on Sept. 28. 
 Analysts said Ford's decision to drop out, announced Friday, would probably press Samsung Motors to make an all-out effort to win the bidding. Without Kia, Samsung may be forced out of business or absorbed by Daewoo Motor or Hyundai Motor as South Korea's major conglomerates seek to consolidate. The current round of bidding is the second after the first attempt failed last month, when bidders demanded a large write-off of Kia debt. Analysts said Samsung had the largest bid the first time.
Kia and Asia Motors are under court receivership, similar to bankruptcy reorganization in the United States, after defaulting on loans last year.
Samsung Motors, a unit of the Samsung Group, is the newest entrant in South Korea's automobile industry. It began producing passenger cars only six months ago.
Analysts said the Kia debt would be a heavy burden for a purchaser to assume during a recession. The Korea Development Bank, the main creditor bank, said on Thursday that the total debt of Kia and Asia Motors was 11.86 trillion won ($8.7 billion).
Creditors of Kia Motors said they would write off part of the debt, and the bank said that with the write-off, debt guarantees and debt rescheduling, the debt load would be cut to four trillion won. But the total cost would still be 7.06 trillion won ($5.2 billion) when paid back with interest, according to the creditors' schedule.
Ford cited the debt burden in withdrawing from the competition.
"Although we still believe that a Ford-Kia alliance was in the interest of both companies, as well as for the nation of Korea, we are unwilling to take control of a company that is saddled with an unreasonably high amount of debt," Ford's vice chairman, Wayne Booker, said in a statement.
"We believe the level of debt that the creditors have specified will make it very difficult, if not impossible, for Kia and Asia Motors to be successful internationally competitive companies," Mr. Booker said.

HEADLINE: For Tobacco Growers, a Changing Life

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: CAVE CITY, Ky., Sept. 10

 BODY:
Larry Walden doesn't look or sound very much like a villain.
This afternoon, he stood in his corrugated steel barn near here, just down the road from Mammoth Cave, and tried patiently to explain the economics, the emotions and the politics of growing tobacco, which he has done for a living for the last 30 years, since he was 12 years old. 
 Above his head, stalks of ocher-colored tobacco, drying in the late-summer breeze, hung from laths, sticks to those in the trade. The air inside was as opulently perfumed as a fine Havana cigar.
"We may be headed for nowhere," Mr. Walden said. "I think the price supports for tobacco may be finished in a year or two, and if that happens, these little towns around here will just dry up and blow away. I don't know what I'd do, but I know there's no other crop that would bring me as much income."
Mr. Walden is the biggest tobacco grower, he thinks, in Barren County, which produces more tobacco than any other county in the state. But he is no tycoon, and neither are many of the other Kentucky growers, most of whom produce flavor- and nicotine-rich burley tobacco. The state, second in annual production to North Carolina, has more tobacco-dependent counties than any other, with 60,000 farmers averaging an income from tobacco of about $12,000 a year.
A trim, bearded, laconic man in Cat hat and aviator glasses, Mr. Walden clutched a beer, encased in an insulating cylinder called a "hugger," as he talked to a visitor.
He conceded that he himself no longer smoked or chewed tobacco. His wife, he said, had told him, "If you stop, it might help your health." But that, he insisted, had nothing to do with his decision to give up.
"I made up my own mind to quit," Mr. Walden said rather defensively, like a man determined to defend his picture of himself as a rugged individualist.
For all the research projects and all the antismoking publicity in the last decade or so, he said he was still not convinced that smoking is harmful to health. His father, he said, smokes three or four packs of cigarettes a day. When his father had open heart surgery not long ago, in his 70's, the surgeon said that half his patients smoked and half did not, Mr. Walden reported.
Alice Baesler, the Kentucky Department of Agriculture's tobacco expert, said that most growers, like Mr. Walden, had grown up in the business. Families, she said, "have existed for this for generations, with tobacco at the center of their lives, so much so that in the fall, they are drawn to the fields at harvest time, whatever and wherever their everyday jobs may be."
It is undeniably a beautiful crop, with the broad leaves turning green-gold in the fields before the stalks are cut, mounted six to a stick and hung in old red barns, many of them covered with wild morning glories, with loose boards to let the air through.
It is undeniably a profitable crop. Mrs. Baesler, whose husband, Scotty, a Democrat, represents the Lexington area in the House of Representatives, said that an acre of tobacco produced a gross income of about $4,000 in good years, while corn or soybeans produced no more than $500. "Nothing else, except marijuana, brings in the kind of money that tobacco does in Tennessee, Kentucky and the Carolinas," Mr. Walden said. "Flat nothing."
Mr. Baesler is running for the Senate this fall against Representative Jim Bunning, the Hall of Fame pitcher nominated by the Republicans.
Over the years, everything from green peppers to wheat has been proposed as a supplemental or replacement crop for tobacco, without much success. In July, the University of Kentucky's Center for Business and Economic Research said that cultivating and processing hemp, a cousin of marijuana that can be used in paper products and textiles, could produce $17.6 million a year in worker income, less than tobacco but a lot more than most other products. But growing hemp remains illegal.
Both Mr. and Mrs. Baesler are loudly critical of President Clinton's tobacco policies, particularly his first-term proposal to finance health-care reform with a tobacco tax. Most Kentucky politicians feel that way. Representative Ron Lewis, a Republican whose district includes Larry Walden's farm, attended a 1994 smokers' rights rally where Hillary Rodham Clinton was burned in effigy. It was an "inappropriate" act, he said, a "desperate" bid to draw attention to a righteous cause.
Mr. Walden said he resented Mr. Clinton as well as former President Ronald Reagan, whom he blamed for driving Government-supported prices down so far that only now, 18 years later, were tobacco revenues returning to their former levels.
But his deepest scorn was reserved for the four big cigarette companies, whom he accused of profiteering and price manipulation. It is they, Mr. Walden said, "who give the farmer a real licking, year in and year out."
He will produce 175,000 pounds of tobacco this year, using Government quotas (the acreage the Government allows a farmer to use to grow tobacco and it can bought, sold or leased) for his own land as well as the quotas of other landowners who do not grow tobacco, which he leases. It is hard, manual work, from the time the seedlings are transplanted through the summer harvest and until the leaves are finally stripped from the stalks at a rotating table, after they have dried in the barns for eight weeks.
Sometimes, Mr. Walden is optimistic. He sees how much revenue tobacco produces for the Government in taxes, and how many sporting events it supports, and concludes that "they'll never put the growers out of business." Other times, he thinks the game is up and wonders about expanding his dairy herd.
"It never occurs to me," he said, "that I'm doing anything wrong. Nobody forces people to smoke cigarettes. It's their choice."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Larry Walden, on his farm near Cave City, Ky., said he expected price supports for tobacco to end. (Michael Morse for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Clinton to Try Putting the Focus on the Global Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
President Clinton on Monday will spell out on a six-pronged approach for a coordinated international response to the financial crisis spreading around the globe, in his first major effort to turn the country's attention back to policy since the publication of the Starr report on Friday.
Mr. Clinton's aides insisted today that his speech at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York was scheduled long before the White House knew that Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, was to deliver a report to Congress making a case for the President's impeachment. 
 In his speech, Mr. Clinton will endorse using the International Monetary Fund's "spare fuel tank" -- an emergency cache that is now down to $15 billion -- to choke off the crisis, probably beginning with loans to Latin America. He will also call for all leading economies to worry less about inflation and more about restarting stalled economies around the globe.
"The balance of risks has shifted," a draft of Mr. Clinton's speech says. "The industrial world's chief priority must be to spur growth." That message seems to be aimed at Japan in particular.
Taking a central public role now in fighting the financial crisis is a complex dance for Mr. Clinton. It is bound to raise questions about why the President, who by all accounts has been heavily involved in strategy sessions concerning Asia and Russia, is only now talking publicly about major initiatives, 14 months into the crisis and in the middle of the biggest threat his Presidency has faced.
Moreover, in recent days some of his own aides, along with global investors and senior officials among America's allies, have wondered aloud whether he still has the moral authority to organize a global response to a complex contagion.
Some say he should have taken a more public role in putting together support for Russia last month, in the days before it devalued its currency and announced a virtual default on its debts -- though it is unclear that even action by the President of the United States could have stopped the worldwide run on the Russian ruble.
"His speech tomorrow will be useful," said David Hale, the chief economist for the Zurich Group, a financial-services company, "but because of the diminishment of his own standing it would have been even better six months ago."
The concern is that in the coming months Mr. Clinton will be so distracted by the debate over possible impeachment that he will be powerless to push through an increase in Washington's contribution to the I.M.F., or to marshal initiatives by the Group of Seven, nations with the world's largest economies.
At the same time, Mr. Clinton's aides argue that the spread of the crisis to Brazil last week, along with the imminent threat to all of Latin America and, more distantly, the United States, gives Mr. Clinton an opportunity to cast himself as the world leader spearheading a battle against global recession, rather than a hobbled President looking for a way to survive in office.
The Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, urged Mr. Clinton to assume that role more directly in an emotional session he held with his cabinet on Thursday night. After agreeing that Mr. Clinton had made "a terrible mistake" in his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, Mr. Rubin, by his own account, urged the President to take a leading role in quelling the financial crisis, saying that "the most important thing now is the world economy."
"We are in a very, very scary time," said one leading foreign official, who has been deeply involved in the succession of bailouts in Asia and Russia and in the recent panic over Latin America. "Clearly, the prospect of a weak American leader only adds to the impetus around the world to sell."
In short, the United States has moved from a rock of stability in the global crisis -- the world's strongest economy and the muscle behind the International Monetary Fund -- to another potential source of uncertainty. That impression was fueled in markets around the world late last week when, just as the Starr report was being released, a House panel declined to approve $18 billion more for the fund. Other countries will not increase their contributions until Washington goes first.
The move by Republican leaders who have long been suspicious of the I.M.F., even before its remedies for international crisis became the subject of wide criticism, brought a harsh response from Stanley Fischer, the No. 2 official at the fund.
"There are decisions of enormous importance being made now about the role that the United States plans to take in the global economic system it created in 1945," Mr. Fischer said. "It's no small thing to decide to abandon that system."
Curiously, while Mr. Clinton has often called for Congress to support the I.M.F., he has made only a handful of telephone calls about the issue to members of Congress. That is a sharp contrast to his marathon effort last year, which ultimately proved unsuccessful, to press every member on trade legislation that would have given American negotiators more authority to strike deals that Congress would not reopen later.
The Administration says that the timing has not been right for the President to get personally involved in such lobbying. But it is difficult to see how he could ask members of Congress to cast a politically unpopular vote now, while he desperately needs their support either to quash an impeachment inquiry or to strike a deal that would submit him to only a censure.
The International Monetary Fund, meanwhile, declared on Friday that it was down to its last $5 billion to $9 billion in ordinary funds to fight the economic turmoil -- a signal to the markets that it is in no shape to be a lender of last resort for much longer. A bailout of Brazil, if one is needed, would probably require tens of billions of dollars.
So in his speech on Monday, Administration officials say, Mr. Clinton will endorse dipping into a backup fund, the General Agreement to Borrow. That fund has about $15 billion left after it was used, unsuccessfully, to aid Russia in July.
Russia was sent $4.8 billion at the time, but future payments have been halted during the political turmoil that has brought to power a new economic team that seems likely to shift away from the unpopular market reforms that are a condition of the loans.
In his speech, Mr. Clinton will also call for countries around the world, especially Japan, to act decisively to write off hundreds of billions of dollars of bad debts that are sinking their banking systems, and leading to a credit crunch around the world. But it is unclear if he will directly say that they should use taxpayer dollars to do so.
He will also call for a meeting of the finance ministers of the Group of Seven and emerging markets, probably next month in Washington, to take stock of broader efforts to improve the international finance system in the midst of its greatest threat in decades.

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE COMMITTEE;
Sharp Divisions on Judiciary Panel

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The name falls from their lips with uncharacteristic reverence, like ballplayers conjuring up Joe DiMaggio in Yankee Stadium.
"Rodino -- he did an extraordinary job," said Sheila Jackson-Lee, a Texas Democrat on the Judiciary Committee, mentioning the subdued, even-handed chairman of the committee during Watergate. "He will be my role model." 
 Then Ms. Jackson-Lee, who is known for lengthy attacks on Republicans and their policies, added, "I will not venture into the muddy waters of partisanship."
Conventional wisdom, and recent history, seem to indicate otherwise. Of all the House committees, the Judiciary Committee is known as the most polarized and ideologically split on Capitol Hill. Peter W. Rodino Jr. may have had a core of 10 moderates to depend on to steer his course, but the current chairman, Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, can count his on one hand.
The polarization is no coincidence.
As Representative Jerrold Nadler of New York, an Upper West Side liberal said, the committee's agenda attracts extremes.
"It's a very bifurcated committee," Mr. Nadler said. "You get people who are interested in abortion and civil rights and due process. They tend not to be the moderates."
The committee regularly grapples with an assortment of divisive issues, including affirmative action, tort overhaul, crime, terrorism and same-sex marriages. Though the debates are usually civil, party-line votes are the norm among the 21 Republicans and 16 Democrats; bipartisanship is the exception. What's more, the panel is stocked with both the President's harshest critics and his most unswerving supporters.
There is Representative Bob Barr, a Georgia Republican, who asserts that Mr. Clinton has so debased the the Presidency that last year, even before Monica S. Lewinsky became news, he filed a resolution to impeach him.
Mr. Barr also introduced a bill to prohibit the Federal Government from recognizing same-sex marriages. The Georgia Congressman, who has been divorced twice, said at the time, "The flames of hedonism, the flames of narcissism, the flames of self-centered morality are licking at the very foundation of our society: the family unit."
Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, the committee's senior Democrat and the only its only Watergate veteran, has been almost as severe a critic of Kenneth W. Starr as Mr. Barr is of Mr. Clinton.
Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts, the second-ranking Democrat on the committee, is a nimble debater who quick with a quip and prone to impatience for what he considers poor displays of intellect. Mr. Frank, who is expected to play a forceful role in the proceedings, is also the brother of Ann F. Lewis, the White House communications director.
Another much-talked-about figure on the committee is Representative Howard Berman, a California Democrat who is considered a formidable legal presence by his peers on the committee. Reserved and politically astute, Mr. Berman has forged a close relationship with Mr. Hyde, the committee chairman.
On the other side of the aisle, two bookish Florida Republicans loom as central players: Representative Bill McCollum, who has said perjury will constitute an impeachable offense, and Representative Charles T. Canady, a constitutional expert who heads the subcommittee that has proposed more Constitutional amendments than anyone since James Madison.
Republicans, eager to quell criticism about the panel's membership, recently appointed their first woman, Representative Mary Bono of California, who won the seat held by her late husband, Sonny. The Republican wing also includes several former judges and Federal prosecutors, who are likely to step back into those roles in any hearings.
Representative Asa Hutchinson, a Republican who expressed "shock" at the Starr report but urged his colleagues to be cautious about not prejudging the President, was once a United States Attorney in Arkansas. And Representative Ed Bryant, another Republican, was United States Attorney in Tennessee.
Despite the credentials on both sides -- only three members did not go to law school -- there is little question that the Democrats on the committee are considerably flashier and more experienced in the political arena than their Republican counterparts. The committee's Republicans, while no less zealous in their views, are largely a little less quick on their feet, a little more lawyerly in their demeanor.
Having so many lawyers in one room is both fortunate and unfortunate. "Lawyers tend to be more contentious and argumentative, and that can show up," said Mr. Canady, the Florida Republican. "But our legal background will be helpful in making a judgment."
Both sides have hired experienced chief counsels accustomed to gritty battlegrounds of a separate sort. David P. Schippers, the Republican counsel, is a lifelong Chicago Democrat who put the mobster Sam Giancana in prison. On the Democratic side is Abbe D. Lowell, a Washington insider who has defended a roster of scandal-tainted clients, including former Speaker Jim Wright.
Despite their ideological gulf, committee members bristle at the idea that they cannot set aside their differences and behave judiciously and thoughtfully, just as the committee did during Watergate.
"There aren't going to be any food fights," Mr. Frank said.
Indeed, the gravity of the situation appears to be sinking in.
"All members feel their constitutional obligation," said Mr. Hyde, who is considered fair-minded and gentlemanly and who is expected to set the tone of the proceedings along with Mr. Conyers, despite the Democrat's antipathy for Mr. Starr.
"This is not a matter we will relish doing," Mr. Hyde added.
Even such conservative firebrands as Representative Lindsey Graham, a South Carolina Republican who last year helped lead an effort to oust Newt Gingrich as Speaker for not being conservative enough, are dutifully composing themselves for the task.
"I'm going to speak out against any Republican who turns this into 'Let me tell you why I don't like Bill Clinton,' " Mr. Graham said. "I do that every day. But I'm playing a role here that is big-time serious. The worst thing that can happen is for an election to be overturned without a heck of a good reason."
The fact that most of the members on the panel are not facing tough re-election battles this November should help keep those partisan flare-ups in check.
"The American people are watching us closely" Mr. Canady of Florida said.
Democrats, too, say they want bipartisanship to rule. But a few have already complained of an inauspicious beginning. Some Democrats brimmed with outrage when the House voted on Friday to approve the public release of Mr. Starr's report without first giving the President a chance to inspect it, as Democrats wanted.
Representative Melvin Watt, a North Carolina Democrat on the committee, criticized the action as unfair and tinged with political motives.
"This one looks like it's going to get into a real war," Mr. Watt said, referring to a possible impeachment inquiry.
Mr. Hutchinson, the Arkansas Republican, acknowledges that there is not much of a precedent for bipartisanship on the committee. "But," he said, "hope springs eternal."

REPUBLICAN MEMBERS
 
Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, 74, chairman
One of the few Republicans newly elected in the post-Watergate election of 1974. In Congress he has played a starring role in promoting the causes of his party, defending the Reagan Administration during the Iran-contra affair and pushing the Contract with America, the 1994 campaign manifesto. But Mr. Hyde can be fiercely independent and has rankled Republican leadership by opposing term limits for Congress Until now, he may be best known for the 1978 amendment that prohibits Federal financing for abortions for poor women. HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE VIEW ABROAD;
World's Press Reflects Itself In Coverage of Clinton Affair

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
With a mixture of solemnity, worry and sometimes sheer glee at the crisis facing President Clinton, newspapers around the world continue to be dominated by news of how an official report about allegations of sex and lies has threatened to topple the most powerful man in the world.
Several news organizations posted the entire document on their Web sites and editorial writers from Munich to Hong Kong ruminated about its impact on the global economy. 
 The coverage worldwide revealed as much about each country's relationship with the United States as it did about its own press traditions and sexual mores.
In China, where Mr. Clinton is popular with the Government and the people, newspapers offered unadorned reportage, with none of the lurid narratives or fist-pounding editorials to be found elsewhere.
Yesterday The People's Daily, the principal Communist Party newspaper, published a short article on page two, with a headline that read, "U.S. Congress Publishes Starr's Report, White House Legal Advisers Rebut on Just Grounds."
The article reported the number of pages in the Starr report and listed the 11 allegedly impeachable offenses, but included no descriptions of sexual encounters. In fact, the paper offered more space to the White House rebuttal.
"President Clinton has admitted his mistake and apologized on many occasions in the past few days," the article concluded, "and in the meantime, he has instructed his lawyers to make an effort to defend him."
In Iran, where sex is not a matter of public discourse, the major newspapers did not editorialize about Mr. Clinton's alleged efforts to cover up an affair. Most reports politely referred to Mr. Clinton's "relationship with the White House intern," although one newspaper, Kayan, broke ranks with a story charging that "the report on Clinton's moral case shocked Americans."
In India, newspapers were not the least bit reluctant to print the sensational minutiae of the report by the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr -- "Clinton adrift in a sea of smut," screamed a headline in The Indian Express -- and some leading opinion makers there seemed eager to see him leave office. The Pioneer, a New Delhi-based paper that has vociferously defended India's explosion of nuclear devices, wrote in an editorial yesterday that few would shed tears over the departure of a President whose Administration had "acted like an outraged bully over the nuclear tests in Pokhran in May."
Indeed, most newspapers depicted the leader of the world's most powerful nation as a man reduced by his own hubris. "By his monumental effort to hide the truth and subvert evidence," declared The Hindu, in its lead editorial on Saturday, "Mr. Clinton lost the trust of his people, lost his own moral authority to rule."
In Mexico City, news of the Starr report led five of the most important papers in Saturday editions, with several describing an encounter between Mr. Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky on the night before his dinner meeting with Mexico's President, Ernesto Zedillo.
"Zedillo one of several world leaders present during the sexual adventures," read one headline in La Jornada, a leading leftist daily there.
If foreign media organizations lampooned Mr. Clinton's fate, they also poked fun at what they regarded as the prudishness of the American public. In Germany, for instance, ordinary people and professional pundits found themselves flummoxed by the prospect that the leader of the world's most powerful country might be forced out of office because of sexual improprieties.
"It is harder to say which is more grotesque," pondered the Stuttgarter Zeitung in an editorial. "Clinton's dumb attempts to free himself from his liaison and his lies, or the venomous investigation of Special Prosecutor Starr, a fevered hunt in the name of hypocritical morals."
All weekend long, the Starr report dominated the front page of every German newspaper and television talk show. Welt am Sonntag, a national publication, devoted two pages for a German translation of the report.
The Hong Kong editorial pages generally focused on whether the investigation by Mr. Starr would affect the fragile financial markets around the world, while in Cambodia and Indonesia, opinion makers lamented the fact that the White House scandal had overshadowed their own more pressing political crises.
In Israel, news of Mr. Clinton's troubles already overshadowed what would have been lead reports on the killing of two Hamas fugitives by Israeli troops this weekend. Newspapers published lengthy excerpts from the Starr report, and one Internet company provided a Hebrew translation of the entire report on line.

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE EXCERPTS;
A Sampling of Viewpoints From Nation's Newspapers

 BODY:

Charlotte Observer
Saturday, Sept. 12
The nation is not endangered by having Bill Clinton in the White House. Our economy is not collapsing, we're not under attack, there's no threat of a coup. Surely the worst that can be said of him has been said. He continues to exercise the powers of office, and did so rather well in Ireland and Russia. There is ample time for Congress to consider Mr. Starr's report and to receive a detailed reply from Mr. Clinton, then decide what course to pursue. 
 Removal of a President from office, by the impeachment process or by forced resignation, is a grave action. The notion that presidents should be removed or resign because of public outrage or unpopularity is foreign to our system.
 
Atlanta Journal-Constitution
Saturday, Sept. 12
A President more concerned with the national interest than his own self-preservation would realize that resignation is his only responsible option.
Sadly, Bill Clinton has shown himself incapable of such sacrifice. He is a complex man with many attractive qualities, but in the end his character has been defined by his crass selfishness. It is that trait -- perjury and adultery are merely its symptoms -- that has rendered him unfit to continue as President.
 
Boston Herald
Saturday, Sept. 12
During ordinary times, in an ordinary election year, Congress would recess in early October, and that has been the plan this year. But this is no ordinary time. This report cannot and must not be allowed to fester away at the conscience of a nation. It must be dealt with promptly and thoroughly until there is a resolution of the issues now before Congress.
 
Philadelphia Inquirer
Saturday, Sept. 12
Bill Clinton should resign. He should resign because his repeated, reckless deceits have dishonored his Presidency beyond repair. He should resign because the impeachment anguish that his lies have invited will paralyze his Administration at a time when an anxious world looks to the White House for sure-footed leadership.
He should resign because, if he does not, his once-glittering agenda of centrist change faces a devastating setback in November's Congressional elections. And those results will reflect not the view of the American majority of the issues -- they are with him there -- but only a weary, tragic turning away from a politics turned sordid.
 
Washington Post
Sunday, Sept. 13
The question that Congress now faces is whether the President's public conduct warrants impeachment and removal. It is not an easy question, and it goes to the heart of what does and does not constitute "high crimes and misdemeanors. On the one hand, the crimes alleged are serious ones and the evidence on some is quite strong; on the other hand, this misconduct took place in the context of a subsequently dismissed civil case and would probably not, in other circumstances, have been deemed worthy of investigation or prosecution. Mr. Clinton's behavior is at the margins of impeachability -- straddling the line that separates disqualifying crimes from conduct that merely mars indelibly the Presidential office and the man who holds it.
