HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT:;
10 Days in the White House: Public Acts, Private Moments

BYLINE: BY ROBERT D. MCFADDEN, JOHN KIFNER AND N. R. KLEINFIELD.; The following article was reported and written by Robert D. McFadden, John Kifner and N. R. Kleinfield.

 BODY:
For Bill Clinton, as for all Presidents, the White House has been a stage, the symbol of national power and executive authority, its stately rooms reflecting America's noblest aspirations. In the Oval Office, he has met foreign leaders like Boris Yeltsin and Yitzhak Rabin and pondered domestic issues like health care and welfare. He has also used the elegant setting for less lofty purposes, as a political platform and as a place to charm the rich and powerful for campaign contributions or votes. 
 But backstage, in rooms just off the Oval Office, his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky unfolded, in moments stolen between the bill signings, the state dinners and meetings with Government officials and foreign dignitaries.
On 10 days between Nov. 15, 1995, and March 29, 1997 -- 10 days reconstructed in this article -- he wove into his schedule a series of sexual rendezvous with Ms. Lewinsky, according to Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel.
While the Starr report did not tote up the precise amount of time the President and Ms. Lewinsky spent together, their encounters apparently occupied less than 10 hours over 16 months, although Ms. Lewinsky's life appears to have been dominated by her obsession with the President.
The encounters began, by Mr. Starr's account, in the course of the nation's business: eye contact at ceremonial functions, a flirtatious exchange or two, then a meeting one night when the White House staff was cut by a shutdown of the Federal Government in a budget impasse, and interns were brought in to help.
The first sexual encounter took place late in a day in which Mr. Clinton signed a "Family Week" proclamation and an appropriations bill, conferred with aides on negotiations to end the war in Bosnia and tried to cope with the Government shutdown. He saw Ms. Lewinsky working alone in an aide's office, invited her into the Oval Office and began with a kiss.
Later on, the encounters were less happenstance, increasingly orchestrated, the Starr report says. In an often blunt narrative intended as an argument for Congress to impeach the President, the report offers passages of seamy details and subterfuges that read like pulp fiction.
The cast of Secret Service agents, secretaries and assistants who protect and serve the President in his official role were clearly aware of the backstage activities, according to the Starr report, but in many cases chose to avert their eyes.
Several encounters were interrupted by phone calls, and once by the entrance of an aide, Harold Ickes, which sent Ms. Lewinsky into a panicky flight out a rear door, the report says. Toward the end of their relationship, it says, Ms. Lewinsky pleaded repeatedly to see Mr. Clinton, but was rebuffed. Finally they met again, but the report says the President had no time for sex: He had to rush off for a state dinner with President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico.
 
Nov. 15 1995
It was not a routine Wednesday for Mr. Clinton because a budget impasse with Congress had shut down the Federal Government, and 800,000 Federal workers were staying home for a second day, including over 80 percent of the White House staff.
The President had no public events scheduled, and he did not leave the White House. But he had meetings with aides, as well as with three Senators and a group of farmers. He had an appropriations bill and several proclamations to sign and an interview with a television network.
And there were major foreign problems on his mind. In Dayton, Ohio, negotiations to end the Bosnian war were at a critical stage. The President was grappling with another problem: whether to go through with a long-planned trip to Tokyo the coming weekend for a pan-Asian economic conference.
For days, his aides had debated the pros and cons of the trip, which was intended to ease rising tensions over economic issues. Foreign policy advisers argued he should go and not risk new tensions with Japan, or appear to be held hostage by Congressional Republicans over the budget. But domestic advisers had warned him of Congressional mischief in his absence.
Mr. Clinton early in the day decided to send Vice President Al Gore instead. His announcement would say he could not be away from Washington at such a delicate time. But sensitive to Japanese feelings, he delayed the public announcement until evening -- morning in Tokyo -- so he could first inform Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama personally in a telephone call.
Dealing with the budget, Mr. Clinton spoke to Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who averted a national default by borrowing $61 billion from two civil service retirement funds to cover interest payments on the national debt and other bills, including Social Security payments.
In an interview with the CBS anchor Dan Rather, Mr. Clinton struck a defiant note against the Republicans, saying he would not give in to their "huge cuts in Medicare, Medicaid, education, the environment."
Mr. Clinton signed three proclamations, for National Family Week, National Farm-City Week and National Great American Smokeout Day, which was the next day.
The Family Week proclamation cited a "shared commitment to the importance of family life," in which Americans "first learn important lessons about responsibility." He called for greater efforts to prevent substance abuse, domestic violence and teen-age pregnancy.
The White House was unusually quiet throughout the day because the Federal shutdown had furloughed all but essential employees. As a result, the White House staff of 430 had shrunk to 90. Moreover, some were White House interns, who could continue working because they were not paid. Many, including Ms. Lewinsky, who ordinarily worked in the Old Executive Office Building, near the White House, took on a wide range of added duties that brought them into the White House.
Ms. Lewinsky, who had begun her internship in July 1995, testified before the grand jury that, after about a month, she began making eye contact with the President at White House functions, and both began what she characterized as "intense flirting."
At departure ceremonies and other events, she recalled, she shook Mr. Clinton's hand and introduced herself. Later, when she ran into the President in the White House West Wing, she introduced herself again and, she testified, he responded that he already knew who she was.
While Ms. Lewinsky's regular job was to work on correspondence in the office of the Chief of Staff, Leon E. Panetta, in the Old Executive Office Building, she was assigned during the one-week Federal shutdown to answer phones and run errands in Mr. Panetta's office in the West Wing.
On this day, as on other days during the Federal shutdown, Mr. Clinton went frequently to Mr. Panetta's office, and sometimes talked with Ms. Lewinsky.
At 1:30 P.M., according to the White House logs, Ms. Lewinsky entered the White House. The logs do not show the time of her departure that afternoon, and the Starr report does not say whether Ms. Lewinsky and Mr. Clinton encountered each other in the early afternoon.
At about 3:15 P.M., Mr. Clinton met with the Senate minority leader, Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, and Senators Byron L. Dorgan and Kent Conrad, both Democrats of North Dakota, and six Dakota farmers. The President told them he would fight steep cuts in farm subsidies that were being advanced by Republicans.
At 5:07 P.M., according to logs cited by the Starr report, Ms. Lewinsky re-entered the White House and resumed work; her departure from the White House was logged at 12:18 A.M. During virtually the same time frame -- 5:01 P.M. to 12:35 A.M., Mr. Clinton was in the Oval Office or in Mr. Panetta's office, the report said.
That evening, the report said, the President and Ms. Lewinsky "made eye contact" when he went to Mr. Panetta's office, and again later at an informal birthday party for Jennifer Palmieri, a special assistant to Mr. Panetta. At one point, they were alone in the office and, according to the report, "in the course of flirting with him, she raised her jacket in the back and showed him the straps of her thong underwear."
Sometime before 8 P.M., when the White House spokesman announced that the President had canceled his trip to Japan, Mr. Clinton spent 20 minutes on the phone with Prime Minister Murayama in Tokyo.
At about 8 P.M., as Ms. Lewinsky walked to a restroom, she passed the office of a Presidential adviser, George Stephanopoulos, the Starr report said. "The President was inside alone, and he beckoned her to enter," it went on. "She told him that she had a crush on him. He laughed, then asked if she would like to see his private office."
He led her through a connecting door into the President's private dining room and toward his private study off the Oval Office. Ms. Lewinsky testified: "We talked briefly and sort of acknowledged that there had been a chemistry that was there before and that we were both attracted to each other, and then he asked me if he could kiss me."
In the windowless hallway adjacent to the study, they kissed, the report said, and before returning to her desk she gave the President her name and telephone number.
That evening, Mr. Clinton signed a $36.9 billion appropriations bill to provide money for the Department of Transportation and related agencies for the fiscal year that had begun on Oct. 1. The sum was only $1.4 billion less than the Clinton Administration had sought from Congress, and the White House expressed hearty satisfaction with the outcome of the bipartisan bill.
The Starr report quoted Ms. Lewinsky as saying she was alone in Mr. Panetta's office at about 10 P.M. when the President walked in. He invited her to rendezvous again in Mr. Stephanopoulos's office in a few minutes and she agreed, the report said.
They again returned to the private study and "this time the lights in the study were off," the report said. After a kiss, it said, a sexual encounter ensued. Because the study had uncovered windows, it took place, as did others later, in the windowless hallway adjacent to the study, the report said.
During the encounter, the telephone rang; the President answered it in the study, and while the sexual encounter continued there, he talked with a person Ms. Lewinsky took to be a member of Congress, the report said.
White House records show Mr. Clinton talked to Democratic Representatives Jim Chapman Jr. of Texas from 9:25 P.M. to 9:30 P.M., and John Tanner of Tennessee from 9:31 P.M. to 9:35 P.M., but no mention of a call after 10 P.M. was made. Before and after the sexual episode, the report said, Ms. Lewinsky and Mr. Clinton talked.
"At one point during the conversation," the report said, "the President tugged on the pink intern pass hanging from her neck and said that it might be a problem. Ms. Lewinsky thought that he was talking about access -- interns were not supposed to be in the West Wing without an escort -- and, in addition, that he might have discerned some 'impropriety' in a sexual relationship with a White House intern."
The duration of the conversation was unclear from the report, which noted only that Ms. Lewinsky left the White House after midnight, and the President was logged out of the Oval Office a short time later.
 
Nov. 17, 1995
The biggest Government shutdown in history was in its fourth day as the sharply diminished White House staff tried to cope with the heavy flow of Presidential pronouncements, correspondence, meetings, interviews and other activities.
Trying to get the Federal behemoth moving again, Mr. Clinton, as his first task of the morning, sent Congress a stopgap financing bill to get 800,000 Federal employees back to work, but he gave no ground in the budget impasse, warning that he would veto the Republicans' latest spending plan.
Mr. Panetta shuttled about Capitol Hill, seeking a deal, but the Republicans, led by House Speaker Newt Gingrich, refused to compromise on their plans for huge budget cuts, tax cuts and a balanced budget in seven years.
Gathering all the support he could muster, the President met at the White House with a delegation from the Leadership Council of Aging Organizations, representing 41 consumer, research and trade groups. They urged him to veto any bill that would cut money for older Americans.
Mr. Clinton also had a 15-minute Oval Office meeting with Alaska's Democratic Governor, Tony Knowles, who tried without success to persuade the President that oil drilling would have no long-term ill effects in an Arctic wildlife refuge in his state.
The President also acted on several foreign-affairs matters. He rebuked Congress over a Republican-sponsored bill to bar spending to deploy troops to Bosnia, saying it could torpedo the peace talks in Ohio. In a lengthy telephone call, he talked with President Nelson Mandela of South Africa about a multilateral response to Nigeria's hanging of nine human rights advocates, including Ken Saro-Wiwa, the writer.
And in an Oval Office interview with Japanese journalists, Mr. Clinton said he would reschedule his state visit to Japan but was vague about the timing. "I will come as soon as I can," he said. "This is very, very important to me. I hope the Japanese people will understand this is no expression of disrespect by me, either to the Government or the people of Japan."
He also said the United States' military commitment to Japan (47,000 troops) and the Asia-Pacific rim (100,000 troops) would not be diminished, despite calls for reductions in the wake of the rape of a Japanese girl in Okinawa, in which three American servicemen had been accused.
On this Friday night, two days after what Ms. Lewinsky said had been their first sexual encounter, both Mr. Clinton and Ms. Lewinsky worked late. White House logs show she checked out at 8:56 P.M. but returned at 9:38 P.M. for a little over an hour, according to Mr. Starr's report. She was still working in Mr. Panetta's West Wing office.
The report said that at 9:45 P.M., Mr. Clinton stepped into Mr. Panetta's office for one minute, then returned to the Oval Office. Because they were working late, Betty Currie, the President's personal secretary, and other staff members had sent out for pizza.
"I went down to let them know that the pizza was there, and it was at that point when I walked into Mrs. Currie's office that the President was standing there with some other people discussing something," Ms. Lewinsky testified. "And they all came back to the office, and Mr. -- I think it was Mr. Toiv -- somebody accidentally knocked pizza on my jacket, so I went to go use the restroom to wash it off, and as I was coming out of the restroom, the President was standing in Mrs. Currie's doorway and said, 'You can come out this way.' " Barry Toiv was Mr. Panetta's chief aide.
Ms. Lewinsky and the President went back to the private study off the Oval Office, and there they kissed, she testified. After a few minutes, she said, she told him she had to return to her desk, but Mr. Clinton suggested that she bring him some pizza.
A few minutes later, the report said, she returned with the pizza and told Mrs. Currie, who was now back in her office, that Mr. Clinton had asked for the pizza. Mrs. Currie opened the door for her and said, "Sir, the girl's here with the pizza."
"He told me to come in," Ms. Lewinsky testified. "Mrs. Currie went back to her office and then we went into the back study area again." A sexual encounter similar to the first ensued in the windowless hallway, Ms. Lewinsky related.
While it was taking place, Mrs. Currie approached the hallway door, which was ajar, and said the President had a phone call, the Starr report said. It quoted Ms. Lewinsky as saying the caller was a Congressman with a nickname. Records show that Mr. Clinton spoke to Representative Sonny Callahan, Republican of Alabama from 9:53 P.M. to 10:14 P.M. The sexual encounter continued while the President was on the phone, the Starr report said.
"During this visit," the report said, "according to Ms. Lewinsky, the President told her that he liked her smile and her energy. He also said: 'I'm usually around on weekends, no one else is around, and you can come and see me.' "
Ms. Lewinsky was logged out of the White House at 10:39 P.M. The President went back to the chief of staff's office until 10:34 P.M., then went by the Oval Office and the ground floor corridors into the President's private residence at 10:40 P.M.
In his deposition in the Paula Jones case last Jan. 17, the President said he could not recall most of his encounters with Ms. Lewinsky, but did remember her "back there with a pizza" during the Government shutdown. But he said he did not believe they were alone.
Testifying before the grand jury on Aug. 17, Mr. Clinton said his first "real conversation" with Ms. Lewinsky took place during the November 1995 furlough. "One night she brought me some pizza," he testified, according to the Starr report. "We had some remarks."
 
Dec. 31, 1995
Mr. Clinton had still not achieved a budget agreement with Congress, and 280,000 Federal workers were on furlough in a second shutdown. But polls showed Mr. Clinton's approval rating way up, from a woeful 1994 (as low as 40 percent) to a quite successful year-end 1995 (in the high 50's).
The reasons were not hard to find: a humming economy, Mr. Clinton's tough stand against unpopular Republican budget cuts, foreign policy advances in Bosnia, Northern Ireland and the Middle East. And his political confidant, Dick Morris, was at work masterminding the 1996 re-election, in which conservative themes like "family values" would play an important role.
It was a quiet Sunday. The President had no scheduled public appearances, aside from attending early church services. But before he could leave for a holiday weekend that afternoon with his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, and their daughter, Chelsea, then 15, he had one meeting on his agenda.
At 9:50 A.M., moments before budget talks in the Cabinet Room, Mr. Clinton and Congressional leaders spoke to reporters. There was a light holiday mood to the exchanges. The President said they were driving hard to settle the budget impasse and would keep at it. Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, said he and his colleagues would "try to pass something."
Somebody asked: "Are you closer?"
"Oh," the Kansas Senator said to a roar, "we're about six feet apart."
Senator Daschle, to more laughter, added, "We'll be a lot closer in a couple of hours."
"We're working at it steady," Mr. Clinton said, adding, "Happy New Year, everybody."
The talks ended at midday, amicably but inconclusively.
Mr. Clinton retreated to the Oval Office at 12:11 P.M., the logs show.
Ms. Lewinsky, by now a staff member in the White House Office of Legislative Affairs, testified that she was in the pantry of the President's private dining room, talking to a White House steward, Bayani Nelvis, sometime between noon and 1 P.M. She told Mr. Nelvis that she had recently smoked her first cigar, and he offered to give her one of the President's cigars, the Starr report said.
"Just then, the President came down the hallway from the Oval Office and saw Ms. Lewinsky," the report said. "The President dispatched Mr. Nelvis to deliver something to Mr. Panetta."
Ms. Lewinsky, the report said, told Mr. Clinton that Mr. Nelvis had promised her a cigar, and the President gave her one.
The report went on: "She told him her name -- she had the impression that he had forgotten it in the six weeks since their furlough encounters because, when passing her in the hallway, he had called her 'Kiddo.' The President replied that he knew her name; in fact, he added, having lost the phone number she had given him, he had tried to find her in the phone book."
By Ms. Lewinsky's account, they moved into the private study and a sexual encounter took place, their third. It followed the pattern of the first two: it was halted before climax by the President, the report quoted Ms. Lewinsky as saying. Apparently in explanation, it said she testified, "He didn't know me well enough, or he didn't trust me yet."
The logs show that Ms. Lewinsky left the White House at 1:16 P.M., and that Mr. Clinton went to the White House residence at 1:15 P.M.
Later, the President, Mrs. Clinton, and Chelsea flew to Hilton Head, S.C., for their traditional year-end family retreat called Renaissance Weekend. It was their 12th straight year at the gathering, at which the Clintons partied late on New Year's Eve with 1,000 of their closest friends, then attended a New Year's Day seminar on personal growth and family values.
 
Jan. 7, 1996
 The blizzard of 1996 had blanketed the East Coast over the weekend, paralyzing New York, Washington and everything in between. The President, wearing blue jeans and a red and black checked shirt, and Mrs. Clinton, in a purple fur-lined hat and a multicolored winter jacket, were among a few worshipers this Sunday morning at St. John's Episcopal Church, two blocks from the White House.
Ignoring their waiting motorcade, the Clintons trudged home through calf-high drifts and wind-whipped snowflakes. At one point, the President playfully scooped up a handful of snow as if to throw it and cheerfully told reporters that Congressional Democrats had canceled plans to visit him to discuss their continuing budget confrontation with the Republicans.
Mr. Clinton had ended a three-week shutdown of Federal programs on Saturday when he bowed to Republican demands and offered a new seven-year balanced-budget plan. That triggered Congressional action to finance all Government programs, but only through Jan. 26. Still, the Republicans were all over the Sunday morning talk shows, vowing to balance the budget by 2002 and denouncing the President.
"We're very concerned about whether or not there's two snow jobs going on in Washington," Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority whip, said on CBS's "Face the Nation." "Now, we feel like Charlie Brown, and Lucy has got the football, and every time you think you're going to get a real budget it gets jerked away from you."
On NBC's "Meet the Press," Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority whip, was threatening another shutdown, or at least a cutoff of Government services the Republicans did not support.
"We are going to fund only those programs we want to fund," Mr. DeLay said. "We're in charge. We don't have to negotiate with the Senate; we don't have to negotiate with the Democrats."
The Republicans were no less bellicose on the subject of Mrs. Clinton, accusing her of not telling the truth in the Whitewater investigation or about the dismissal of aides in the White House travel office.
Mrs. Clinton's answers are "not the truth," Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, said on ABC's "This Week With David Brinkley." "We've had this kind of thing over and over again from her people who have stonewalled us, who have feigned memory loss."
One poll showed Mr. Clinton trailing Mr. Dole, the Republican front runner for President, 46 percent to 49 percent.
Mr. Clinton told reporters he was going to spend the rest of the day holed up with Mr. Panetta and other aides, working on the budget.
But early that afternoon, he telephoned Ms. Lewinsky at her apartment in the Watergate complex, the first time he had called her at home, according to the Starr report. He said he was going to be in his office, she remembered, adding, "I said, oh, do you want some company? And he said, oh, that would be great."
By now, she testified, they had worked out signals for their encounters. "I got there kind of saying, 'Oh, gee, here are your letters,' wink, wink, wink, and him saying 'O.K., that's good,' " she said. She carried a folder as cover, but her job did not involve delivering letters.
On this day, Ms. Lewinsky said, they "made an arrangement that. . .he would have the door to his office open, and I would pass by the office with some papers and then. . .he would sort of stop me and invite me in. So, that was exactly what happened."
They went to the bathroom of the back study and had a sexual encounter, she said.
 
Jan. 21, 1996
Like the rest of the East Coast, Washington was fighting floods.
Samuel Jordan, the city's director of the Office of Emergency Preparedness, had been up all night, watching the rain-swollen Potomac rise nearly 14 feet, twice its usual height, and flooding part of Georgetown along K Street near the Tidal Basin and the waterfront fish market. Mr. Jordan worried that the river would rise another foot before it ebbed.
Swollen streams and rivers in eight states had ravaged homes and businesses. Some of the flooding was receding, but 10,000 residents were still being evacuated in West Virginia along the surging Ohio River. About 1,100 homes on Wheeling Island alone were under six feet of water, their 3,000 occupants refugees. Pennsylvania appeared hardest hit, with homes and businesses submerged or caked in mud, power and telephone lines down, and debris littering the streets. Mr. Clinton declared the state a Federal disaster area, making available temporary housing, home repair grants and emergency loans.
On the television talk shows, his opponents attacked him over the Whitewater investigation, while the House majority leader, Dick Armey of Texas, threatened to block the nation's ability to borrow money to pay its bills unless Mr. Clinton yielded to Republicans' budget-cutting to decrease "the size and intrusiveness of Government."
On the same show, NBC's "Meet the Press," Mr. Panetta protested the Republican emphasis on Whitewater, saying: "There is a fine line between what is a legitimate continuing inquiry into a situation and what becomes political harassment. I think they're getting dangerously close to harassment."
At one point the First Family had a private tour for more than an hour of the wildly popular Vermeer exhibition at the National Gallery of Art. Accompanied by several friends, including a former college roommate of Mrs. Clinton, they gazed at the luminous blues and yellows, the subtle reflected light and the pearly highlights of the 21 paintings, which represented much of Vermeer's known output.
The President logged into the Oval Office at 3:33 P.M. Ms. Lewinsky's name does not appear on the White House logs, but according to the Starr report, she ran into Mr. Clinton in a hallway near an elevator in the West Wing and he invited her into the Oval Office. They had had phone sex for the first time the week before, the report said, and she was "feeling a little bit insecure" about whether he had enjoyed it. Eventually, she testified, they had phone sex on 10 to 15 occasions.
At their meeting this Sunday, Ms. Lewinsky remembered questioning him about his interest in her, saying, "I asked him why he doesn't ask me any questions about myself, and. . .is this just about sex. . .or do you have some interest in trying to know me as a person?" The President laughed, she said, and replied that "he cherishes the time that he had with me." She thought the reply was "a little bit odd," because she "felt like he didn't really even know me yet."
As they moved to the hallway by the study, Ms. Lewinsky was in mid-sentence when Mr. Clinton suddenly kissed her and they had a sexual encounter.
"At one point during the encounter, someone entered the Oval Office," the report said, prompting Mr. Clinton to leave her in the hallway.
A short time later, the President was told his next appointment, a friend from Arkansas, had arrived, and he escorted Ms. Lewinsky out through a connecting office. She was signed out of the White House at 3:56 P.M.
 
Feb. 4, 1996
Mr. Clinton and his daughter ventured through snow to attend Sunday morning services at Foundry United Methodist Church, where the senior minister, J. Philip Wogaman, warned the dozens of Government officials among his congregation not to abuse the public trust by going on what he called "power trips."
A deep freeze gripped much of the South that day, after a week of snow, ice and record cold blamed for 55 deaths across the lower 48 states. Temperatures hovered around zero in parts of Mississippi, Georgia and Alabama, and Florida's $1.2 billion citrus industry was in peril.
It was frosty, too, at the annual meeting of the National Governors' Conference, which took up part of the President's official day. At a White House dinner, Republicans eyed the mansion like house hunters on a real estate tour. Fresh from the attack on that morning's "Meet the Press," Michigan's Republican Governor, John Engler, said he expected a different party to be in residence in 1997. "Next year, I'll arrive in a festive mood," he said at the dinner.
Even as the Administration put last-minute touches to a budget statement due the next day, Government officials unveiled data that showed that Medicare's Hospital Insurance Trust Fund had lost money in 1995 for the first time in 23 years, meaning the Medicare program was poorer than anybody thought. "Things turned out a little worse than we expected," said Richard S. Foster, chief actuary of the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, which runs Medicare for 37 million people who are elderly or disabled. In Israel, Prime Minister Shimon Peres leaked word he planned to call for new elections ahead of schedule. The elections would bring the hard-line Likud leader Benjamin Netanyahu to power, threatening the Oslo peace accords with the Palestinians that Mr. Clinton hoped would be his enduring foreign policy triumph.
On the bright side, Mrs. Clinton's book, "It Takes a Village" was on the best-seller lists, having soared to No. 1 within a week of publication.
In the White House, Ms. Lewinsky was in her office, and that afternoon, she received a phone call from Mr. Clinton. Her sexual encounters with him were usually on the weekend, she said, when there were fewer people about.
This time, at her suggestion, they bumped into each other in the hallway because, she said, "when it happened accidentally, that seemed to work really well." Mr. Clinton was in the Oval Office from 3:36 P.M. to 7:05 P.M., logs show; there is no record of Ms. Lewinsky. They walked together into the private study, where they had a sexual encounter.
Afterward, they sat and talked awhile, maybe 45 minutes, in the Oval Office, and Ms. Lewinsky testified that she thought their friendship was starting to blossom. He said he would call her again and, perhaps mindful of her previous unease, she remembered saying, "yeah, well, what's my phone number?" He recited both her home and office numbers and, the report said, he called her at her desk later that afternoon to tell her he had enjoyed their time together.
 
PUB-DATE: March 31, 1996
Mr. Clinton was looking forward on this Sunday to throwing the first ball for opening day of the baseball season on Monday at the Baltimore Orioles' stadium, Camden Yards. But rain delayed the all-American photo op.
In Russia, President Boris N. Yeltsin, also facing a tough re-election battle, said he could not win while the war was still going on in secessionist Chechnya and vowed to halt military operations against the rebels. In Bosnia, Defense Secretary William J. Perry visited American troops who were part of the NATO peacekeeping force. There was talk of capturing the Serb leaders indicted by an international tribunal as war criminals, Gen. Ratko Mladic and Radovan Karadzic, whose continued freedom was an embarrassment to the Administration. It never happened.
At home, Mr. Dole had clinched the Republican Presidential nomination earlier in the month and was assembling a team of economic advisers. Behind the scenes, the President's political consultant Dick Morris -- who would be brought down by his own sexual scandal -- sharpened the Clinton advertising campaign to focus on Mr. Dole. But the expensive advertisements, paid for with so-called soft money, later led to calls for an investigation into Democratic fund-raising.
Things had not been going well in recent weeks for Ms. Lewinsky.
More than a month earlier, on Feb. 19, Presidents Day, Mr. Clinton telephoned her at her Watergate apartment, Ms. Lewinsky testified, and she could tell from the tone of his voice that something was wrong. She asked to see him, but he said he did not know how long he would be at the office that day. Worried, she hurried to the White House, the only time she had come uninvited to the Oval Office, she said. There, the President told her he no longer felt right about their relationship and he had to put a stop to it. She could visit, he said, but only as a friend. He hugged her, according to the report, but would not kiss her.
Still, Ms. Lewinsky said, in the following days "there continued to be this sort of flirtation." Mr. Clinton called her apartment, the report said, expressing regret that she had left the White House early, which she thought "sort of implied to me that he was interested in starting up again."
On Friday, March 29, while Mrs. Clinton was in Greece, Ms. Lewinsky ran into the President wearing the first necktie she had given him. She asked him where he had gotten it. "Some girl with style gave it to me," she remembered he replied. He suggested she might want to casually join a group seeing a movie at the White House theater, but she said she did not want people to think she was hanging around the West Wing uninvited. She said she asked if they could arrange a rendezvous over the weekend, and that he said he would try.
They did meet that Sunday, March 31, while Mrs. Clinton was still away. "According to Ms. Lewinsky, the President telephoned her at her desk and suggested she come to the Oval Office on the pretext of delivering papers to him," the report said. "She went to the Oval Office and was admitted by a plainclothes Secret Service agent. In her folder was a gift for the President, a Hugo Boss necktie.
"In the hallway by the study, the President and Ms. Lewinsky kissed," the report went on, and had a sexual encounter. After they were finished, the report said, "Ms. Lewinsky left the Oval Office and walked through the Rose Garden."
Mrs. Clinton returned from her trip that evening.
 
PUB-DATE: April 7, 1996
It was a bone-chilling Easter Sunday, the exhausting conclusion of one of the most emotional weeks of the Clinton Presidency. Four days earlier, a military plane carrying Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and 34 others had slammed into a mountainside near Dubrovnik, Croatia, killing everyone on board.
And so it had been a week of personal mourning, a black stretch Mr. Clinton spoke of as "this interminable week." Mr. Brown had been a good friend of the President, and in the days following the tragedy, Mr. Clinton postponed or canceled almost all of his scheduled events to devote himself to propping up the emotions of a grieving White House and comforting the families and friends of the victims. On Friday, though, he did go ahead and visit another somber destination, traveling to Oklahoma City in advance of the one-year anniversary of the April 19 bombing of the Federal Building.
There were other world events to preoccupy the President. Fighting between rebels and Government soldiers was continuing in the capital of Liberia, and North Korean troops had entered a buffer zone with South Korea for the third day.
But the President found it hard to focus on much other than the deaths on the Croatian cliff. He had to blot tears from his eyes on Saturday, as he watched the coffins bearing the bodies arriving at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware. "We were all holding up pretty well until they started taking the coffins off the plane," he said.
But now it was Easter, and as was the Clinton family custom, the President, accompanied by his wife and Chelsea, attended the 11 A.M. service at the Foundry Methodist Church, brightly decorated with lilies, azaleas and balloons. The President wore a dark suit. Mrs. Clinton chose a white coat and black hat graced with a white band and pink flower. Chelsea was dressed in a navy skirt and blazer. Secret Service agents interrupted the Easter egg hunt on the church lawn so the First Family could enter.
Mr. Wogaman, the church's senior minister, praised Mr. Brown and the "practical goodness" of those who accompanied him on his trip. "Easter is God's reply to those in heartsick sorrow," he said.
Mr. Wogaman also singled out Adam Darling, a 29-year-old confidential assistant at the Commerce Department, who died in the crash and was a member of the church. During Mr. Clinton's Presidential campaign, Mr. Darling had endeared himself to Mr. Clinton by offering to ride a bicycle across the country in support of the candidate. Mr. Darling's parents attended the service, and they requested that his favorite hymn, "This Is My Song," be sung. It begins: "This is my song, O God of all the nations, a song of peace for lands afar and mine."
The sermon was about resurrection. During it, Mr. Wogaman complimented the President for having "ministered so well for our land."
As the congregation left the church, shafts of sun finally broke through the clouds. On the way back to the White House, the Clintons stopped and shared a quiet Sunday brunch at the Four Seasons Hotel in Georgetown.
Mr. Clinton spent the balance of the afternoon, from 2:21 to 7:48, in the Oval Office. At one point, the Starr report said, he called Ms. Lewinsky at her apartment. According to her grand jury testimony, they spoke of the death of Mr. Brown, and then she told him of a fresh personal trauma of her own. On the previous Friday, she had been advised by Timothy Keating, staff director for legislative affairs, that she was being transferred from her White House job and moved to the Pentagon because she was "too sexy" to be working in the East Wing. A number of White House aides had become increasingly uncomfortable about how much time she was spending in the vicinity of the Oval Office, particularly as the campaign heated up. Ms. Lewinsky said she later learned from the President that Evelyn Lieberman, the deputy chief of staff, thought Ms. Lewinsky was paying too much attention to him and "everyone needed to be careful before the election."
When she learned she was being transferred, Ms. Lewinsky said, she was crushed and felt it was because of her relationship with the President.
Mr. Clinton seemed disturbed by the news, the report said. Ms. Lewinsky was sobbing as she related the details to him. Then she asked if she could come see him. He agreed.
At 4:56 P.M., according to White House logs, Ms. Lewinsky arrived at the White House carrying a manila folder and, under the pretext of delivering documents to the President, was admitted to the Oval Office. She met with the President in his private study, where they spoke further about her expulsion from the White House staff.
"Why do they have to take you away from me?" she testified that he asked her. According to her testimony, he looked at her and said, "I promise you if I win in November I'll bring you back like that."
She said in her testimony that he told her he would find out why she was transferred, and he said that she could have whatever job she desired after the election.
Then, according to the Starr report, she began a sexual encounter with him in the hallway between the private study and the Oval Office.
Someone in the Oval Office called out that the President had a phone call, the report went on. A White House operator had put the call through to the Oval Office, the report said, but when no one picked it up, a Secret Service agent was dispatched to locate the President. According to the report, he knocked on the door to the Oval Office, got no answer and then entered. Seeing the door to the study ajar, the report said, he called out, "Mr. President." Getting no answer, he called out again louder. The agent heard someone say "Huh?" from the study and then, after the agent said that there was a call for the President, Mr. Clinton replied that he would take it. The report said Mr. Clinton picked up the call in the study, directing Ms. Lewinsky to continue her sexual actions with him while he spoke on the phone. According to White House records cited in the report, the call lasted nine minutes and was from Mr. Morris, the political consultant.
A few minutes after the President hung up, the report said, there was a second interruption. The report quoted Ms. Lewinsky as testifying: "Harold Ickes has a very distinct voice and. . .I heard him holler, 'Mr. President,' and the President looked at me and I looked at him and he jetted out into the Oval Office and I panicked." She retreated in the other direction, leaving through the dining room. It was nearly 5:30.
Two minutes after Ms. Lewinsky left, the report said, Mr. Clinton called Ms. Lieberman,, though it is unclear whether he reached her.
That evening, the report said, Mr. Clinton telephoned Ms. Lewinsky at home and asked her why she had fled so hastily. He seemed upset that she had left.
 
Feb. 28. 1996
There were big doings for Chelsea in the works. Yesterday, she had turned 17. To mark the moment, Mr. and Mrs. Clinton had given a dinner for her and 10 of her friends at the Bombay Club, just a block's walk from the White House. There was chocolate cheesecake and a rendition of "Happy Birthday" by the pianist, with the whole restaurant singing along. While the President and the First Lady took the Presidential limousine back, Chelsea insisted on riding in the van with her giggling friends. But that was just the prelude. The Clintons were leaving for New York tomorrow to take their daughter to see some Broadway plays, something she was very much looking forward to.
Before they could set out, though, the President spent a workaday Friday attending to drug policy and cigarette sales and Midwestern winter storms. His major announcement was to certify Mexico as a full ally in the war against illegal drugs, though only after the Mexican Government agreed to commitments demanded by American law enforcement agencies. For the second year, Mr. Clinton did not certify Colombia.
There was other international and domestic news for him to ponder. The Federal Bureau of Investigation was frustrated that the Saudis were not doing more to investigate a truck bombing that had killed 19 American airmen. The Democratic Party, in one more development in the protracted campaign finance drama, said it would be returning $1.5 million more in contributions that it now felt may have been illegal or improper.
Shortly before 11 A.M., President Clinton appeared in the Roosevelt Room and spoke about an initiative to toughen the rules on cigarette sales to children. Among the new rules was a requirement that anyone under 21 who bought a tobacco product was to show a photo ID so that store clerks no longer had to guess the age of customers.
On the legislative front, Mr. Clinton signed into law H. J. Res. 36, which released money for international population assistance programs. He gave out a statement celebrating the third anniversary of the "Brady Act," which provided for a waiting period before someone could buy a handgun, calling the law "one of the most effective public safety measures ever."
In the course of the day, the President announced plans for several appointments, including his nomination of Joel I. Klein as assistant attorney general in the antitrust division of the Department of Justice.
He declared a major disaster in South Dakota, which had been pummeled by a severe winter storm in November, and ordered Federal aid to supplement state and local recovery efforts.
He also freed $250 million for a program to teach Americans about the harmful psychological and physical effects of sex before marriage. The program was to stress that abstinence from extramarital sex was the expected standard of the country.
It had been almost 11 months since the President had had physical contact with Ms. Lewinsky. Her expulsion to the Pentagon had succeeded in separating them. The only times she encountered him were at group events. She had seen him at a reception for the Saxophone Club, a political organization, and went with her family to one of the tapings of the President's weekly radio addresses. She got into the President's 50th birthday party at Radio City Music Hall in Manhattan, as well as a cocktail party for major donors to the Democratic Party. She testified that she saw him at a fund-raiser for Senate Democrats. Noticing that he was wearing a necktie she had given him, she approached him at the event and told him, "Hey, Handsome, I like your tie." She testified that he called her later that night.
"I was insecure about the relationship at times and thought that he would come to forget me easily," the Starr report said Ms. Lewinsky testified. "Usually when I'd see him, it would kind of prompt him to call me. So I made an effort. I would go early and stand in the front so I could see him."
The report said the two continued to talk with some regularity by phone, especially in the months after she began her job at the Pentagon. During the fall '96 campaign, the report said, the President occasionally called while on the road without Mrs. Clinton. At least seven of those conversations, the report said, were sexually explicit. But Ms. Lewinsky complained that she had not seen him privately and, according to her testimony, he told her, "Every day can't be sunshine."
On Feb. 14, 1997, Ms. Lewinsky placed a Valentine's Day ad in The Washington Post intended as a love message to the President. It was addressed to "Handsome."
At 6:29 P.M. on this Friday, Mr. Clinton went to the Roosevelt Room and taped his weekly radio address to the nation. Among those who attended the taping was Ms. Lewinsky. According to her testimony, Mr. Clinton had extended an invitation to her through Mrs. Currie.
In the address, which was broadcast the next morning, Mr. Clinton spoke of the need to prevent drugs from ruining children's lives. "First, we must fight drugs before they reach our borders and keep them out of America," he said, and he explained his decision that day to enlist Mexico in the battle.
At the session, Ms. Lewinsky had her picture taken with the President. She was nervous, the report said she testified, for she had not been alone with him since her days working at the White House. She wore a navy blue dress that she had bought at the Gap.
According to the report, Mr. Clinton told her to see Mrs. Currie after the photo was taken, since he had something to give her. Mr. Clinton, Ms. Lewinsky and Mrs. Currie together went into the back office. Stephen Goodin, an aide to the President, had told Mr. Clinton and Mrs. Currie that he did not want him alone with Ms. Lewinsky, which was why Mrs. Currie chaperoned them, the report said.
Mrs. Currie, however, said, "I'll be right back," and went on to the back dining room where, she testified, she waited for 15 to 20 minutes while the President and Ms. Lewinsky were alone in the study. As belated Christmas presents, Mr. Clinton gave Ms. Lewinsky a hat pin and an edition of Walt Whitman's "Leaves of Grass." He told her he had seen her Valentine's Day message.
In the hallway near a bathroom, Ms. Lewinsky testified, she engaged in a sexual encounter with Mr. Clinton. He heard something and they retreated into the bathroom, but no one disturbed them. According to White House logs cited in the report, Ms. Lewinsky left the White House at 7:07 P.M.
The next time she got out her navy blue Gap dress, according to the report, she noticed stains near one hip and on the front of the dress. After seeing the President, she had gone out to dinner. She thought the stains might be spinach dip. F.B.I. tests, the report said, later revealed them to be the semen of Mr. Clinton.
 
PUB-DATE: March 29, 1997
It was a lethargic Saturday. The White House was quiet, and the President was in something of a funk. He had been forced into a state of unwanted inactivity. It had been only two weeks since Mr. Clinton had tripped on the stairs of the Florida home of the golf champion Greg Norman and injured his knee, negating the President's appearance in a member-guest tournament with Mr. Norman.
Although Mr. Clinton had gone ahead with a Helsinki summit meeting with President Boris Yeltsin of Russia a week earlier, at which he had to be lowered from a catering truck in a wheelchair, his public schedule had otherwise been sharply curtailed. At most, he attended one or two brief events a day. Today he had none.
Yet Easter was at hand, and tomorrow the President would be presiding over the annual Easter Egg Roll on the South Lawn of the White House. There was a need to prepare for an Oval Office meeting on Tuesday with King Hussein of Jordan. A whole year had passed since the death of Ron Brown, and there would be a memorial service on Thursday that the President would attend.
On sleepy days like this, Mr. Clinton usually changed into his jogging shorts and took to the roadways or, better yet, tuned up a golf game grown rusty over the winter. Instead, because he was on crutches, he was reduced to tasting spring by opening the door of his study or relaxing on the Truman balcony overlooking the Rose Garden.
For the moment, he was home alone. Mrs. Clinton and Chelsea were on the last leg of a six-nation trip to Africa. On this final day, they were to tour a women's skills center in Asmara, take in a tree-planting ceremony and pay a courtesy visit to Isayas Afewerki, the President of Eritrea. Mrs. Clinton put on a white, gauzy cotton dress known as a tilfi and danced merrily with the leader of Africa's newest democracy. She was scheduled to return to Washington at 7 the next morning, in plenty of time to attend the Easter Egg Roll with her husband.
Even the Vice President was away, on a diplomatic mission in Asia. And so Mr. Clinton was reading, watching basketball and growing restless.
In his Easter radio address, broadcast at 10:06 in the morning, Mr. Clinton concentrated on the promise of spring, though there was still too much of a winter snap in the Washington air. "Spring is a season of renewal, not just of the world around us but of the ideals inside us, those that bind us together as people," Mr. Clinton said in the address. "Millions of families will come together to celebrate Easter this weekend and Passover in the coming weeks, to reaffirm their faith in God and their commitment to our sacred values."
He went on to speak of the need to overcome "the divide of race." He spoke of a 13-year-old Chicago boy who the previous week had been riding his bike home from a basketball game and was attacked and nearly beaten to death. The boy was black and his accused attackers were white. He finished by saying: "The holidays of this season teach us that hope can spring forth from the darkest of times. Those of us who are Christians celebrate a risen God who died a painful, very human death to redeem the souls of all humanity without regard to race or station."
Early in the afternoon, Mr. Clinton repaired to the Oval Office. At one point, the Starr report said, he called Monica Lewinsky and invited her over. He said he had something important to tell her.
A little past 2, Ms. Lewinsky showed up. Mrs. Currie greeted her and took her to the President's study to await Mr. Clinton. He hobbled in.
The President talked at length to Ms. Lewinsky about his concerns that others might learn of their rendezvous, the Starr report said. Without specifically identifying it, he told her that he feared that a foreign embassy was tapping his telephones. According to the report, he recommended cover stories if they were found out, suggesting that she insist that they were only friends. Should anyone have tapes of intimate phone conversations, well, then she should say they knew that someone was eavesdropping on the calls and thus they simply feigned the exchanges, the report said.
Then he kissed her and they had a sexual encounter, she said, although Mr. Clinton later implicitly denied "inappropriate" contact with her that day.
She left at 3:16 P.M. A few minutes later, Mr. Clinton left his office as well. This was, the Starr report says, Monica Lewinsky's 10th and final sexual act with President Clinton.
 
Epilogue
In the nine months after the last of the White House sexual trysts, the Starr report says, the relationship between President Clinton and Ms. Lewinsky crumbled inexorably under the President's fear of exposure and Ms. Lewinsky's growing frustrations at being shut out of his life.
They met several more times, and had numerous telephone conversations. They also exchanged small gifts and expressions of endearment. But the Starr report details a post-sexual deterioration that spills from argument and recrimination to growing suspicions and finally mutual distrust and even threats by Ms. Lewinsky.
Amid the alternating periods of anger and appeasement, there were hopeless musings about a possible future together. Letters and notes were exchanged, then destroyed in an effort to get rid of evidence of their affair. Most of their gifts were retrieved.
None of the President's promises to find Ms. Lewinsky a job got her anywhere, and she harangued him about these failures and her exclusion from his life. In an Oval Office meeting on July 4, 1997, the report said, Mr. Clinton reprimanded her for a letter in which she had obliquely threatened to disclose their relationship. "It's illegal to threaten the President of the United States," he told her.
The President showed increasing fear as the arm's-length relationship dragged on, and it expressed itself in his harsher tones to her. In a face-to-face argument on Dec. 6., Ms. Lewinsky recalled, he told her he had "never been treated as poorly by anyone else as I had treated him."
When the story of their relationship finally broke on Jan. 21, the President, in meetings with aides, denied he had ever been alone with Ms. Lewinsky. He told Sidney Blumenthal, a White House communications adviser, that she "came on to me and made a sexual demand on me," and that when he rebuffed her, she had threatened to say they had had an affair.
Mr. Blumenthal later testified that the President had spoken like a trapped man.
"I feel like a character in a novel," he quoted Mr. Clinton as saying. "I feel like somebody who is surrounded by an oppressive force that is creating a lie about me and I can't get the truth out. I feel like the character in the novel 'Darkness at Noon.' "
The protagonist in Arthur Koestler's 1941 novel was a man caught up in the Moscow purges and political trials of the 1930's.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Sosa Matches McGwire With Homers 61 and 62

BYLINE: By BILL DEDMAN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Roger Maris's children were not in the stands today at Wrigley Field. The commissioner couldn't make it. The official National League baseballs bore no infrared markings. And the only nation with a live broadcast was the Dominican Republic.
Someone forgot to tell Sammy Sosa that the home run race was over. 
 With his 61st and 62d home runs on the same afternoon, the Dominican slugger for the Chicago Cubs moved even with Mark McGwire of St. Louis, who left tonight's game in Houston with minor back spasms after grounding out twice. McGwire has only one single in 14 at-bats since hitting his 62d home run last Tuesday. For the moment, the tortoise had caught the hare.
So Maris's 37-year-old record for most home runs in a single season, set at 61, has been passed twice in less than a week. The name next to the new mark in baseball's record book will be decided over the next two weeks by the friendly competitors, McGwire and Sosa. One, a son of a dentist from California, has had all the attention. The other, whose first baseball glove was made from a milk carton in San Pedro de Macoris, now has all the momentum.
After Sosa's record-tying blast, it took three curtain calls to sate the overflow crowd of 40,846, the largest this year at Wrigley. The crowd roared for five minutes until the game continued and buzzed for an hour after with chants of "Sammy! Sammy!"
After the game, the 29-year-old Sosa conducted interviews in two languages and received congratulatory telephone calls from Randy Maris, one of Roger's sons, and from Bud Selig, baseball's commissioner. Selig also issued a statement congratulating Sosa on his record-tying home run.
"It's unbelievable," Sosa said in words that echoed what McGwire had said after hitting his 62d home run with Sosa watching in St. Louis. Sosa, who had never hit more than 40 home runs in a season, gave the credit to others. "I have to say what I did is for the people of Chicago, for America, for my mother, for my wife, my kids and the people I have around me," he said. He went on to name even the manager of the opposing team, the Milwaukee Brewers.
Sosa would have had another chance for a home run today if the veteran Mark Grace had not hit a home run to beat the Brewers, 11-10, in the 10th inning. Sosa, who would have batted next, was so happy with Grace's game-winning blow that he hugged the umpire. "I'm sorry that I hit that home run so Sammy couldn't come up to the plate," Grace said.
For Chicago fans, the other significant event of the day was when the Cubs raised the "W" flag above the scoreboard to show they had won. Chicago stayed ahead of the Mets by one game in the competition for the last spot in the National League playoffs. The Mets won, 1-0, in Montreal. The Cubs have not played a post-season game since 1989.
When asked how he felt about the home runs, Sosa said, "I have a good feeling we're going to make it to the playoffs."
After McGwire broke the record on Tuesday, Sosa might have begun trying too hard to hit home runs. He went five days without coming close. By then, McGwire was the toast of the nation with 62, and Sosa remained four back at 58, the race conceded even by Sosa, who continued to declare, "Mark is the man."
The foul pole oracles at Wrigley Field disagreed on whether Sosa was anxious.
Billy Williams, the Hall of Famer and Cubs coach, whose No. 26 hangs from the right-field pole at Wrigley Field, said: "You could see it a few times in Pittsburgh and St. Louis; overswinging a bit. All the hoopla about the home runs has to get in your way."
Ernie Banks, the Hall of Famer whose No. 14 hangs from the left-field pole, gently disagreed: "He's not pressing. He's handled it extremely well."
Sosa showed grace by muting his celebration on the home run that equaled Babe Ruth at 60 on Saturday and again today on the home runs that tied Maris and McGwire. After he hit No. 60 on Saturday, he did not even smile. Sosa just waved his cap to the crowd and took his seat. But when Orlando Merced hit the game-winning home run in the ninth, Sosa was the first one to greet him at home plate. Today after each home run, he made his trademark leap of exultation and clenched his fists, but ran the bases as if they were routine home runs. When he reached the dugout, Sosa acknowledged the crowd's cheers and was hugged by his teammates. After the game, he helped carry Grace off the field.
Both of Sosa's home runs today sailed over the ivy-covered wall in left field, over the fence and over Waveland Avenue beyond. No member of the Brewers offered a pat on the back or applauded, as the Cubs had done for McGwire when he broke the record.
Both of Sosa's home runs were estimated at 480 feet. The first, a two-run blast at the expense of a rookie pitcher, Bronswell Patrick, put the Cubs ahead, 8-3, in the fifth inning. The second, against the veteran Eric Plunk in the ninth, started a rally in which the Cubs tied the game.
The first ball was misplayed by a mob outside the stadium that knocked over a man in a wheelchair, then was fielded on the rebound by John W. Witt, an unemployed man who quit his job last year as clubhouse manager for the Rockford Cubbies, the Cubs' Class A team. Witt was sitting in a van under a Dominican flag at the corner of Waveland and Kenmore Avenues when fortune came his way. A divorced 29-year-old from Dixon, Ill., he said he faced a hard choice: give the ball to Sosa or sell it. The profit might help him take care of his two young children. Friends hustled him and the ball back into a van for safe-keeping as fans scrambled for his autograph.
"I'll talk to Sammy about it," Witt said.
The second home run bounced down an alley. The police said a man caught it on a bounce and was tackled by two men, one of whom bit his hand and knocked the ball away. A fourth fan picked up the ball and ran into the arms of police officers, who took him to the nearest station and then home. It was unclear how he would authenticate his fortune. Major League Baseball had not marked these game balls, as was done when McGwire reached 60.
Could Sosa, who is the leading candidate for most valuable player in the league, end up with more home runs than McGwire? Sosa has 12 games left, McGwire 14. Both will face the weak-pitching Brewers and the powerful Houston Astros.
Sosa also draws the first-place San Diego Padres and the lowly Cincinnati Reds, while McGwire, who left tonight's game as a precaution, plays two poor teams, the Pittsburgh Pirates and Montreal Expos.
If Sosa passes McGwire in the next four games, he will do it in the relative obscurity of night games on the West Coast.
The Cubs left town today for San Diego for four games with the Padres. The first three are night games, putting Sosa far from the attention of East Coast television viewers and newspaper readers.
"Who'd have ever thought that two people would do it in the same year?" Grace said. "I hope Sammy gets the attention that he deserves."

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE EDITORIALS;
At Least 30 Papers Call for Resignation

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
Scattershot anger and disgust at President Clinton, combined with pervasive anxiety about the potential use and misuse of constitutional impeachment powers, left many editorial pages groping to find analytic prescriptions to ease the dilemmas facing Congress and the President.
At least 30 newspapers have called for the President's resignation, including 7 that circulate 250,000 or more papers on Sundays: The New Orleans Times-Picayune, The Seattle Times, The Des Moines Sunday Register, The Philadelphia Inquirer, The San Jose Mercury-News, The Tampa Tribune and The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. The Albuquerque Journal on Sunday called Mr. Clinton "morally unfit to continue in office," while The Seattle Times said, "Without moral authority, the President cannot lead." 
 Focusing on the damage the President's affair with Monica S. Lewinsky has done to the dignity and effectiveness of the Presidency, The Journal-Constitution declared on Sunday that "only one person can spare us that nightmare" of a drawn-out discussion "of a particularly seamy Presidential scandal." The President's "only responsible option" -- resignation -- would entail a sacrifice that the newspaper said Mr. Clinton "has shown himself incapable" of making.
At least two newspapers, The Charlotte Observer and The Detroit Free Press, argued against resignation. The Observer declared: "The nation is not endangered by having Bill Clinton in the White House. Our economy is not collapsing, we're not under attack, there's no threat of a coup. Surely the worst that can be said of him has been said."
The Detroit Free Press, in the home town of John Conyers Jr., the ranking Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, acknowledged, "We cannot say we would be devastated" by a resignation, but continued, "For him to resign before this process is completed would be to cave in to the relentless Starr, and that could set a precedent that would make future Presidents sitting ducks for their political enemies."
Over all, the ideas and analyses that emerged from the editorial pages reflected ambivalence and a sense of being overwhelmed by the issues involved.
Should they focus on what was and was not contained in the report of the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr? Should they address the President, the Congress, the voters, or all three? Should they zero in on sexual encounters and misleading statements? What about the practical issues of a weakened President's governance? The legal questions of what constitutes an impeachable offense? The moral issues of leadership?
The most common warning was crystallized by The Sacramento Bee, which wrote Saturday, "The Constitution is the sacred text of American life, overarching Presidents as they come and go beneath it." It added, "The accelerating hysteria that accompanied release of the prosecutor's report Friday is the enemy of constitutional self-government."
The St. Louis Post-Dispatch solved the problem of which questions to answer by running three separate unsigned editorials. Sunday's lead opinion piece argued that the Starr report "is like a tower of blocks wobbling on top of the shaky foundation of a sexual relationship between two consenting adults -- albeit an immoral, adulterous, pitifully adolescent relationship." A second editorial was titled "The Peep-Show Presidency" and said, "We hate ourselves for staring, but we can't turn away." A third editorial was headlined 'The Contrition Gambit."
The New York Times ran two editorials over the weekend. On Saturday it said that "until it was measured by Kenneth Starr, no citizen -- indeed, perhaps no member of his own family -- could have grasped the completeness of President Clinton's mendacity or the magnitude of his recklessness." It added, "A President without public respect or Congressional support cannot last." Sunday, it argued that scrupulously careful and fair procedures should govern any impeachment inquiry in the House of Representatives.
The Washington Post took Mr. Starr to task for being arrogant in his "aggressive advocacy for impeachment," contrasting the Starr report unfavorably with "the restraint showed by the special prosecutor during Watergate," the scandal that led to the resignation of President Nixon in 1974."
In a clear expression of ambivalence, The Post concluded, "Mr. Clinton's behavior is at the margins of impeachability -- straddling the line that separates disqualifying crimes from conduct that merely mars indelibly the Presidential office and the man who holds it."

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
A Fleet Gore Is Far From the Madding Washington Crowd

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Sept. 13

 BODY:
This is the quintessential road trip for Vice President Al Gore.
In two days of travel through the Pacific Northwest, Saturday and today, he talked to enthusiastic crowds about light rails, planned growth, economic revitalization, Social Security, health care, education, coastal salmon and affirmative action. 
 Along the way, he shared the podium with Democratic candidates and elected officials and starred at eight fund-raising events, where aides said he had helped local party officials in Oregon and Washington generate more than $350,000 for Congressional and statehouse candidates.
In the course of all this activity, he made about as much news as the sun rising. His only mention of the report by the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, was a hurried and predictable statement on Saturday -- no questions, please -- that he did not think the case outlined against President Clinton in the Monica Lewinsky matter justified impeachment proceedings.
"Our story," a close aide to the Vice President said as Mr. Gore made a speech in Vancouver, Wash., "is that there is no story. Maybe after the election, we'll step out. But not now. The country is stable. Why make things unstable?"
This is the protective bubble surrounding the nation's second-in-command, a haven of rarefied air that fairly floats above the political craziness along Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington, unconnected to any aspect of the boss's relationship with a young White House intern.
Inside the bubble, Mr. Gore carries himself like a politician without a worry, other than standard anxieties over close Congressional races in a year of midterm elections.
Scandal? What scandal? Mr. Gore never mentions it in speeches and is fiercely insulated by his staff from reporters. Two months from the midterms and two years from the Presidential balloting of 2000, he is but two things above all else, a Clinton loyalist and Presidential candidate. As his aides say, what is the upside for him to elaborate now?
And so, they say, Mr. Gore's campaign season will proceed in the same manner as the trip at hand, stuffed with frenzied days like today, in which he followed a five-kilometer race to raise money for breast-cancer research with five events before an overnight flight to New York, where he is to join Mr. Clinton at a state party dinner on Monday night.
Later in the week, he is off to Boston for an event with Mr. Clinton, then his third trip this year to New Hampshire, an early battleground for the 2000 Presidential campaign.
For Mr. Gore, the bubble is the ideal campaign vehicle. By assiduously avoiding sensitive subjects, he has cleared a path to discuss only his favorite issues, Administration initiatives that many Democrats claim have bolstered the economy and reflect voter satisfaction with Mr. Clinton's stewardship of the country.
As a strategy, it satisfies his main agenda, supporting Mr. Clinton and reinforcing policies that would be extended into a Gore Administration.
At the same time, Mr. Gore's message and crazy-quilt of a schedule are letting him fine-tune his presentations before partisan audiences. Listeners are beginning to see a politician unlike the 1992 and 1996 version of Mr. Gore, a self-parodied "stiff guy" lacking the touchy-feely qualities that make Mr. Clinton a hit along the rope line and elsewhere.
Mr. Gore has become more emotive in speeches, more animated and funnier. One of his best laugh lines generally follows a comparison of the Administration's proposal for a patient's "Bill of Rights" and the Republicans' version, which he calls a "Bill of Goods."
"You know, the Republicans are in such discord and disarray," Mr. Gore says with a straight face, "that the right hand doesn't know what the far right hand is doing."
For the most part, the reconstituted Mr. Gore plays well to the crowd, especially in places like here, which are geographically, and to some degree psychologically, far removed from events in the nation's capital.
"I've been doorbelling a lot, and I'll bet I haven't gotten more than two comments about the President," said Maureen Gallegos, a businesswoman who is running for a seat in the Republican-controlled Washington Statehouse. "Clinton's sex life is his business. This district has experienced 20 years of growth in five years, and that is presenting us with a lot of problems to talk about."
For some partisan Democrats, Mr. Gore -- at least for now -- may be the premier headliner to address them as he stumps for candidates, makes a case for Democratic ideals and raises money.
Paige Richardson, campaign manager for Brian Baird, who is running for the open seat in Washington's Third Congressional District -- Linda Smith, a two-term Republican, is running for the Senate -- appeared ecstatic that Mr. Gore helped draw 400 people to a rally in Vancouver, Wash., on Saturday. The event raised $30,000 for Mr. Baird, whose Republican opponent in what is expected to be a close race will be decided on Tuesday.
When Ms. Richardson was asked whether the crowd would have been as exuberant had Mr. Clinton been the speaker, she hesitated, a clear sign she was happy to have Mr. Gore.
"I didn't hear that question," she said, smiling because she did. "I don't have an answer for that."
